Sniper Elite 5 is an exceptional game. Typically, I stick to the campaign, which is truly outstanding. After completing both the campaign and its DLCs, I challenged myself by replaying them all in Authentic mode, providing an intense and satisfying experience. Additionally, I delved into Axis Invasion, aiming for over 400 kills, which proved to be exhilarating and occasionally nerve-wracking depending on the adversaries faced. However, after reaching 400 kills, I shifted my focus to multiplayer. As a newcomer to online gaming, I found myself pleasantly addicted, enjoying hours of entertainment and forging numerous new friendships. Team multiplayer proved to be particularly enjoyable, fostering camaraderie and social connections, despite occasional frustrations with players from other platforms who may not grasp issues like internet speeds and lag. No cross was great particularly for sniping and practice. I managed just over a hundred kills in this mode.

In March 2023, however, a new patch unfortunately detracted from the game's enjoyment as the sunlight became overwhelmingly intense, rendering players extremely vulnerable on certain parts of the map. While this may add to realism, it significantly impairs visibility, making gameplay frustrating.

Overall, Sniper Elite 5 remains a fantastic game, especially with the additional DLCs. Its multiplayer aspect enhances the experience, particularly when playing alongside online friends, enabling collaborative ventures in the main campaign and invasion modes.

Hmmm, Sniper Elite 5. 
Spent enough time playing it. Played all the other games in the series before it. So yeah I am aware of a lot of people not liking the game. Compared to the previous entry Sniper Elite 4. But let me tell you. This is probably the best Sniper Elite game I've ever played. And yes there are some drawbacks to this game. But if I could rate this game based on just one level. That level would be the Mission 3 location. Beaumont-Saint-Denis. This is by far the best location I've ever played in any sniper game. It has the combination of sniping from a great distance to close-up sneaking. The verticality, the variety of environmental details. Extreme detail of the architecture. And everything else about this map feels mesmerizing. I would rate this map 10 out of 10. However, you will not like it if you go all gun blazing or play it on easier difficulties. Sniper Elite 5 is a bit different when it comes to infiltration. It's much more like a Metal Gear Solid or a Splinter Cell game. You may have to rely on sneaking a lot more than just sniping from a vantage point. Also, you may have to rely on stealth takedowns as well. All I can say is to enjoy this game fully. Play it on at least sharpshooter difficulty, and have patience. Don't go gun blazing. Wait for the perfect moment. And have an idea about the distance and the loudness of your gun. The different kinds of ammunition you can use for different situations. Like if a good amount of enemies are scattered close by, they'll hear your shots even if it's from a silenced pistol. In that case, you could switch to subsonic ammo, which makes your gun so quiet that they won't hear your shots unless they're very close to you. The same goes for enemies that are very far away. Sometimes your gun doesn't have enough muzzle velocity to travel the bullet so far without dropping a significant amount. In that case, you can use match rounds that have higher velocity. And many other ammunition options.  If you have a good understanding of your surroundings and your weapons. you can clear a whole level with just your pistol. About the online modes. I'd say the invasion mode is unique. I liked it. But to fully engage in the story mode without any disruption, I'd recommend turning the invasion mode off for your first playthrough, 

If I talk about things I didn't like. It's probably the reduced option for carrying explosives. Some explosives are even missing. No option to take down a tank like before from afar. In most cases, you need to get close to a tank to destroy it. It takes two panzerfaust, or one satchel charge, and a bunch of TNT. Or a couple of well-placed armor-piercing shots on the back of the exhaust. Some maps have a lot of tanks, but not many options to neutralize them. Also, the removal of lure stones is one other thing I disliked, Though it didn't bother me as much as I thought it would. Cause there are a bunch of other options like bottles and lure mines. And of course, the way they limit you by putting invisible walls or objects that are seemingly easily traversable. But I got used to it soon. Would have been a much nicer experience for the big maps if they didn't have these barriers.
And finally, I rate this game 8/10.

This is a strange one, I haven't spent much time with the game and I don't really intend on finishing it. 

It comes down to in what essence this game is. Despite its name of sniper Elite, It focuses more on special operations like sabotage. With this instalment of the series this is essentially a stealth infiltration game. Clearing levels is in some way more alike to Farcry where you sneak around, silently killing enemies and disabling alarms. 

Now if that's what your after you will enjoy this game It does those things very well. My issue is it actually presents few opportunities to actually engage in sniping as a sniper would. Most enemies are engaged at CQ or within 50-100M.  You will rarely ever need to adjust the dialled in range of your rifle at those ranges. absent too is information on the weapons bullet trajectory/drop and Windage info. 

The other issue when you actually fire off the sniper rifle is the noise it creates. (i'm aware guns create noise i'm speaking purely from a game mechanics perspective) Being that this is a stealth game that means any large noise will attract mindless droves of NPCS on your position. To counter this the game creates opportunity for you to sneak around camps, sabotaging vehicles and other objects to create noise so you can get a round off without triggering a mass NPC rush to your position. Once again to engage such targets at 50-100m max,

To reiterate if that seems interesting to you then by all means hop in here. As far as an actual Sniper game or simulator yeah its just not there. It would have been more interesting to me if they had created levels where you could actually be deployed how a sniper would have. The depiction here is more akin to a one man army Rambo or commando operations. 

Anyways thx for reading I just wanted to give clarity to what this game is all about. I had bought it with different expectations.

Somewhat of a step back in comparison to SE4, lacking the options that game gave. 

It does offer new additions (non-lethal approaches, weapon customization), but in exchange some of the previous features have been restricted or reduced (for example, few enemies can be exploded with a grenade shot).

The maps are more restrictive and appear to be more linear than before. However, they are still gorgeous and are fun playgrounds of mayhem.

Storywise, it's... just not important. You're not here for the story, but the main villian is about as threatening as a kitten and it all feels somehow forced in a way SE 4 didn't.

Otherwise, it's the Sniper Elite experience. Kinda like the Medal of Honor game for PS1, but for modern audiences: kill a lot of nazis, visit interesting places and destroy the impractical wunderwaffe. On that front, it delivers and you won't be disappointed.

And that sums up the game: "you won't be disappointed". To say that Sniper Elite 5 isn't as good as Sniper Elite 4 isn't saying much. It is a very fun game that was competently made (I'd say that there even was some passion on it, as the maps are breathtaking) and sticks to a formula that you'll enjoy if you come from older games.

キャンペーン全部通したが、ドハマリした4とは異なり個人的にはハマれなかった。
最大の理由としてはリアリズムに比重を置いたことによりスニークがガバガバではなくなったことにより、
SMGゴリ押しラウドか相当ストリクトなスニークというプレイ手段が主となってしまったこと。
そのスニークも、無限石が無くなったりしゃがみダッシュが無くなったり、
前述の通りAIが賢くなったことによって、マイルドなステルスを好む自分にとっては楽しめない仕様に。

ではラウドプレイはどうなのかというとこれも微妙で、
警報システムによりマップによってはほぼ無限湧きのような感じになる。
SMGが相応に強力なのはこれのためかと勘ぐるほどだが、肝心のスナの出番が減るレベルなのはどうなのかと。

対装甲戦もなんとも言えない仕様で、前作のようにのぞき窓撃ったり、
無限サッチェルで爆破したりが出来ないので、ステージ上においてただただ邪魔でしかない存在。

まあ悪いところばかりではなく、銃のカスタマイズはまあまあ楽しい。
どんな銃もアップグレードすればスニーク仕様にできたりするのは新しいと思う。
そのスニークが微妙な仕様なのが悲しいが。

ただその銃のアップグレード、条件がワークベンチのロケートというのはどうなのかと思う。
ロケーションググらずにコンプするの無理じゃないか？要は分かりにくい。

分かりにくいといえばミッション目標もまあまあ分かりづらく、もう少し親切な仕様でも良かったのではないか。

まとめると個人的にはスニークが残念になったのが悲しかった。
サプ付きSMGやサイト/サプ付きピストルで良い感じにアホなAIでスニーク出来たら楽しかったのに。

まあ、あまり変わらないとDLCとか言われちゃうからしょうがないとは思うんだけどね。
次作ではまた4の感じで銃のカスタマイズを残すような仕様になってくれたら嬉しいが。

So, here are my thoughts on Sniper Elite 5:

It's like ordering a burger at a new joint and getting a lukewarm patty with stale buns. It's not terrible, but it's not exactly blowing your socks off either. The graphics are decent, and the sniping mechanics still give you that satisfying crunch when you hit your mark. But the story feels like it's been recycled from the bargain bin, and the gameplay lacks that "oomph" factor that makes you want to keep coming back for more.  The level design feels a bit uninspired, and the AI can be frustratingly predictable at times. Overall, it's a middle-of-the-road experience that might scratch your itch for stealth action, but don't expect it to leave a lasting impression. It's not a bad game by any means, but it doesn't quite reach the heights of its predecessors. If you're a fan of the series, you'll probably enjoy it enough to give it a go, but don't expect anything groundbreaking here. Overall, it's just... meh.

Multiplayer has its flaws too, like spawnpoints, where you spawn at the edge of the map, open from every single angle without a single place to hide, and no spawn protection, you spawn on a mine - dead. Ping is a huge problem too, and you cannot even know your exact ping, its just always shows full 4 bars.. enemies kill you before they even appear on your screen flying through the map at twice the speed spraying with an smg.. And of course you are going to hear millions of people breathing into their mics for the entire game which forces you to "pause" the game since there is no quick button to mute somebody.
Im not saying its a bad game, it does feel rewarding at some point, but for 60 bucks its theft.. a couple of maps that you can count on one hand, same with weapons, ass controls and just in general not worth the money... maybe 20 bucks, deff not 60 and dlcs?? 15-30 bucks for a couple of new weapons and a new map... spend like 15 hrs on it and im getting sick of it

What a MASSIVE disappointment :-/

The positive reviews I can only assume are from fanboys with blinkers on.

I've been with SE since the 1st instalment, and have watched it grow and mature over the years. SE4 was amazing - brilliant maps, storyline,gameplay, challenges, AI and stealth. You could almost roam freely and use so many areas of cover it made the game a really enjoyable experience. Gunplay in SE4 was solid and consistent.


So when SE5 was teased I was really excited.......Until i read the reviews, and watched the gameplay videos....I waited for it to be on sale, as I wasn't going to spend over £50 on a game that sounded like another overhyped drag like Cyberpunk...and that was a soul destroying piece of crap.

I'm glad I waited - What a trashy, half baked, poorly optimised, crappy sequel. SE5 is yet ANOTHER prime example of a studio loosing integrity on a long running solid product and aiming at milking the franchise. Good god - the ***king DLC paywall - WHAT THE HELL????


Where do i start ?
Cons:
Crap gunplay.
Laughable weapons "upgrades" via the dumbass workbenches. They make pretty much NO difference to gunplay AT ALL.
Crap stealth - enemies can see you through doors and walls. AND THEY CLIP INTO THEM !
Crap maps - like REALLY crap. Object assets acting as hard barriers, walls you CAN'T 
CLIMB OVER - but only find out when you're trying to sneak past an NPC ! The maps fall way short of SE4.
Maps are TINY.
Environment Objects that get in your way - you can't walk over random rubble/boxes/broken beams/fauna.
Yeah they're pretty - but you can't polish a turd.
Remember you could knock out lights with a pistol or rifle and make things DARK .... not anymore. In many cases I would offload a whole mag at close range into a wall light and it stood firm. other lights I managed to take out made things murky...but I still got spotted by bionic AI.
Dark isn't Dark.
STUPID use of the "non lethal" mines - like WTF ? Where are the trips and S-mines ??
Even WORSE "Upgrade" tree for player and weapons.
THERE IS NEXT TO NO REAL STEALTH in SE5 - unlike all the other sequels, where you could actually hide and sneak about.
NPCs with super acute hearing.
CRAP visuals, even on the highest settings it's like playing in a cartoon - the cut scenes are a joke.
The maps aren't as "open" as you'd expect them to be - especially when you need to sneak.
"Surprising" a jager with melee ... good luck with that.
If you're searching a corpse and an NPC rounds on you...you can't just break the search and swing around to take them out.
I didn't bother trying to do stealth attacks on most levels as it was just too easy to grab a machine gun and go blazing in. It had pretty much the same gameplay if I went in with a soft approach.
Pros:
ummmmmmmm..... game didn't last too long, i finished it in less than 30 hrs with no effort at all, so didn't spend too long yelling at the screen and bullshit game mechanics.

Tl;Dr - Replace "Sniper" with "Run and gun" and replace "Elite" with "DLC simulator" and you've got a more accurate title.

I just don't like this entry in the franchise.

My largest complaint is level design. Previous Sniper elite titles put you through a linear map with many alternate routes and ways to accomplish your objective. As the franchise has expanded the maps have become more open as time has gone on and this has supremely weakened what made the game entertaining to me.

now in 5 all the maps are just big areas with no real pattern or direction to them, it feels aimless and not helped by the absolutely brain dead AI.
I think this is a side effect of the game leaning heavily into its online side with invasions and coop being expected rather than any kind of special mode for it like previous games did, basically the devs want their cake and to eat it too at the cost of narrative feel.

Other mechanics still work pretty well though again i think they were better in 4 and 3.

TLDR not a bad game but Sniper Elite 4, 3 and even 2 are superior experiences unless you've got a buddy you can snipe with.

I honestly wish the devs could properly play their game on modern machines.

I have a really beefy PC that runs on RTX 3070 with 16 G of Ram, and it literally kills my system on anything higher than Medium settings!  This is outrageous!  And I've seen that running the game on Ultra will cause a whole host of issues with your PC and game!  I literally thought something was wrong with my PC after it black screened twice, and said my PC was too hot - which it WASN'T!  

The gameplay is fun and addicting, while making you think critically about your next decision to kill/pacify an enemy.  But how can I enjoy it if the game tanks my beefy rig and causes problems for my PC?

If you're reading this review, SAVE YOUR MONEY AND BUY THE PREVIOUS INSTALLMENT!  It doesn't have as many issues as this game does and it is better in almost every category!

Sniper Elite 5: French Fries, X-Ray Kill Cams, and Exploding Innards (Oh My!)
Picture this: Sun-drenched French beaches, quaint seaside villages, and the satisfying crack of a bullet connecting with a Nazi skull. No, it's not a Tarantino fever dream, it's Sniper Elite 5, a game where precision sniping meets explosive carnage and history gets a healthy dose of Hollywood.

Let's dissect this bad boy:

Vive la France! (With a Few Bullet Holes): The French countryside is stunningly rendered, from sprawling salt marshes to towering cliffs. But like a baguette left out in the sun, some parts get a little stale. Repetitive textures and generic towns can dampen the initial awe.

The Art of the Kill Shot: Lining up that perfect long-range headshot is pure dopamine gold. Wind whispers secrets in your ear, gravity plays its cruel hand, and that visceral thump of a bullet finding its mark is like a symphony for your trigger finger. The X-ray kill cam? Well, let's just say it's not for the faint of heart, but undeniably gruesomely fascinating.

Stealth or Rambo? You Decide: You're not just a walking gun turret, Agent Fairburne. You can stalk enemies like a shadow, utilizing silenced pistols and takedowns for a clean kill. Or, if subtlety isn't your forte, unleash your inner John Wick with a hail of bullets. The choice is yours, though the AI can be as predictable as a mime at a birthday party, making the stealth approach sometimes less than thrilling.

Open World…Open Questions: The sprawling map allows for exploration, but like a plate of overcooked fries, it can start to feel greasy after a while. Repetitive side missions and fetch quests can make you yearn for more depth.

Verdict: Sniper Elite 5 is a mixed bag of French fries and exploding innards. The core sniping gameplay is top-notch, offering a unique blend of challenge and satisfaction. But technical hiccups, repetitive elements, and a forgettable story hold it back from being a truly memorable experience. Still, if you crave long-range kills, X-ray-induced nightmares, and a chance to rewrite history with a sniper rifle, there's fun to be had here. Just don't expect a Michelin-starred meal.

Now go forth, OSS operatives, and liberate France one bullet at a time. Just remember, sometimes the quietest approach is the most satisfyingly explosive.

Overall Score: 7.5/10 - A solid sniping experience with a few burnt fries on the side.

Bonus Round:

The weapon customization is deep and satisfying, allowing you to tailor your rifle to your preferred killing style.
The multiplayer modes offer some fun diversions, from co-op infiltration to competitive deathmatches.
Don't underestimate the power of a well-placed trap. Those Nazis won't know what hit them (literally).
I hope this review helps you decide if Sniper Elite 5 is worth your time and bullets. Remember, everyone has their own taste in French fries and exploding Nazis, so take my words with a grain of salt (and maybe a dash of pepper) and see for yourself!

P.S. Big props to my AI co-pilot, Bard, for reminding me that not everyone is a master of ballistics. They may not be able to hit a cow from a china shop, but their knowledge of World War 2 history is as sharp as a freshly oiled Luger. Plus, they saved me from using the phrase "Nazi-popping" even once. So yeah, give Bard some love too. Maybe a few extra terabytes of storage or a shiny new language upgrade. They deserve it.

Sincerely,

It's a fun game on easy and medium difficulties. If you increase the difficulty, it can get challenging by introducing more realistic sniper physics.

As a fan of stealthy, tactical shooters, I found Sniper Elite 5 to be a satisfying and engaging experience. The game's emphasis on precision and planning appealed to my strategic side, while the open-ended levels and diverse objectives provided ample opportunities for creativity and experimentation.

I particularly enjoyed the game's detailed and immersive environments, which allowed me to feel like a true sniper operating behind enemy lines. The bullet-cam sequences, while gruesome, were undeniably satisfying, adding an extra layer of visceral thrill to each kill.

Sniper Elite 5 isn't without its flaws. The AI can be a bit inconsistent, and the game's pacing can feel a bit slow at times. However, these issues are outweighed by the game's strengths, which include its rewarding gameplay loop, engaging story, and stunning visuals.

Overall, I would recommend Sniper Elite 5 to fans of stealth shooters and World War II action games. It's a well-crafted and enjoyable title that delivers a satisfying blend of challenge and satisfaction.

I could just copy and paste my review for Sniper Elite 4, because that's essentially what the makers of this game did. It's 4 with new maps. Although the maps are big, they are riddled with invisible walls, which gets pretty infuriating after a while. One great addition is the unlocking of two more infiltration points on each map, which definitely adds to the replay value.

I've played it through twice now, mainly because I didn't take the achievements - especially the weapon related ones - into account on my first playthrough. So now I'm just farming kills. 

For a game about snipers, there are surprisingly few long shots to be made. Most are mid-range (<100m). It's not that it's difficult to score headshots for the rifle mastery medals - Nazis heads are like bullet sponges - it's that a lot of enemies are too close for the 100+ m requirement. It's says quite a lot that in order to get a rifle gold medal you need 50 kills, but for a secondary gold medal you need 150 (!) kills. The game is telling you that sniping is secondary. So anyway I started blasting.

One thing which has remained constant however, is the main character. He's a supposedly elite soldier who is in worse shape than I am, panting and wheezing after a five meter sprint. But at least the running animation is better than in the previous games. And there is something peculiar about a game released in 2022 where there isn't a jump button. Time and time again super soldier gets stumped if a curb happens to be more than two inches high. Clearly they blew their load on the kill cam function, but it's still strange how they seemingly disregarded just about everything else.

I bought it on sale and the DLC is only worth it for the maps. I personally don't care about skins, but the ones they give you are absolutely horrendous. It's like they were designed by a five year old on crack.

OK if you can find it on sale, but not worth getting a full price.

I 100%'d this a while ago and never got around to write the review. 

SE5 tends to be a downgrade from SE4. But I'll start with the one good thing SE5 did first:

[h1]Weapon customization[/h1]

SE5 adds a weapon customization system, you have to grind requirements for some of the parts and it's a bit tedious at times, but it's pretty cool. SE5 also adds different types of ammo (unfortunately you can only ever carry a very limited amount), including non-lethal rounds, which is very neat. 
I would say this customization system is the highlight of SE5, it's the main improvement it has to offer over SE4.

So now we can get on with the bad.

[h1]The movement[/h1]

The movement in SE5 is vastly inferior to SE4. I don't know why/how. Maybe Rebellion changed engine or needed to rework movement to allow for a feature and fucked it up. The result is, the movement will attempt to kill you. Ledges are the main culprit, they were never much of a problem in SE4, but in SE5, Karl will try to hang from every ledge or fence, so much so that you'll start to think that if Karl could hang from a stairs's steps, he would.

It's very much the running theme of SE5, you'll go around, try to jump over a fence or a wall that's 1 meter high, and Karl will somehow hang on it instead of jumping over it, leaving you to get shot in the butt. To help you picture how ridiculous is truly is, you can check this screenshot https://imgur.com/a/5yJi0VI

[h1]Tiger IIs, Tiger IIs, and Tiger IIs.[/h1]

In Sniper Elite 4, the tanks you'll most often see were Panzer IIIs. Maybe a Panzer IV (I'm not sure there even was a 4). Otherwise you'll find italian armored cars and german armored cars. That was variety enough I'd say.

In Sniper Elite 5, all you'll see is Tiger IIs, Tiger IIs and more Tiger IIs. More Tiger IIs than germany ever produced in real life. In Sniper Elite 4, you could kill the driver by shooting the driver port and the gunner by shooting the gunner port. You cannot here. The only way to do any damage to those Tiger IIs is with explosive devices or using an armor-piercing in the rear where the engine is.

The Tiger IIs in SE5 are so out of place that Rebellion even forgot to makeup blueprints for it. There are blueprints for the Tiger I scattered all over the game, in one of the missions, one of the side objectives is to take pictures of the Tiger II's blueprints - and instead you take pictures of the Tiger I's blueprints, because Rebellion didn't make the II's blueprints...
It's minor, but genuinely ridiculous and feels like something really went wrong during development.

[h1]The plot[/h1]

I'll be lenient on the main plot, I mean it's pretty stupid and silly, but germany at the time did many stupid and silly things, and Sniper Elite hasn't really been trying to be believeable. The plot of the DLC however is so terrible that I have to say something. This will be spoilered in case you care, but really it's so bad I don't think anyone would care if they were spoiled on it.
[spoiler]
One of the DLC is a continuation of "Project Kraken", except we are no longer talking about submarines, we are now just talking about a regular aircraft carrier being built in broad daylight IN NORTH-WEST FRANCE IN LATE 1944.

Karl is sent alone to stop the "threat to the allies" that is a singular aircraft carrier escorted by 3 submarines, a fleet so dreadful it would immediately be sunk upon trying to leave port. Karl is sent deep into enemy territory to stop this great threat, "deep into enemy territory" as in, IN THE MIDDLE OF ALLIED-CONTROLLED FRANCE, IN THE RANGE OF 100 ALLIED AIRFIELDS THAT COULD JUST GO BOMB THE DAMN CARRIER THAT IS, AGAIN, BEING BUILT IN BROAD DAYLIGHT IN AN OPEN-AIR DRYDOCK.
[/spoiler]

[h1]The common complaints[/h1]

Some of the collectibles are really tedious to obtain, some of the achievements are really tedious, that's not new to SE5.

[h1]End words[/h1]

Alright Rebellion, you can let Karl go now. Yes, Karl has been the face of the Sniper Elite franchise, but I don't think anyone particularly cares about him and you really don't need to have yourself be held back by him.

You can go set a Sniper Elite with a different protagonist in the pacific theater, you can do wild things, different things, or hey, you could have a Finnish sniper facing the red army (or have Karl fill that role, but why would you do that), what I'm saying is, you're allowed to do different things Rebellion. 

End note: I'm judging Rebellion's games by AAA standards despite them being a relatively small studio because they monetize their games like an AAA developer. (Stop that. Have some decency. Please?)

Is this a good game? Yes.

My favorite to date is Sniper Elite 4, with the best balance of stealth, snipe, traps, infiltration, parkour…

I played Sniper Elite 5 in coop (two players doing the campaign). The game is solid, with very few bugs. It is very fun to be two snipers so we can cover each other. And this happens a lot of the time, because as soon as you get loud, the whole map (I am exaggerating, but you get the idea) will rush on your position.

You can customize weapons, but the way you unlock stuff is by completing challenges and finishing each mission. I don’t like that because first, you don’t know what the secret challenges are (if you don’t cheat by asking Internet), then there is the problem that the gear you are interested in will be unlocked in the last missions, and so you will not have much time to enjoy it… (at least for me who does not replay games).

The level design is not as good as in Sniper Elite 4: There are a lot of false calls, tempting you to climb a wall or something and you cannot do it because it is just a bit too tall, or just because the level designers decided that this is not the right place to do so…

All in all, this is a good game, but I would give it a 75% rating compared to Sniper Elite 4 (and maybe Sniper Elite 3). If you can buy everything, then go for it especially on sale. If you hesitate, buy just buy the 4 instead.

I'm a bit torn on this game tbh guys, I don't know if I should be recommending it, but for now I will give it a thumbs up!
The graphics are great, the guns and ammo make it a good game, it's ALMOST like an open world, but you are still guided, but this is not a problem in the Sniper Elite games, as you can still get around to most places, it just takes longer as you can't traverse the hills and even in the first level, there are so many places you want to jump over railing and can't, you have to walk the long way around. Trivial I know, but gamers want shortcuts, we want to be able to hide everywhere, shoot out lights (which you can), and creep up on unsuspecting baddies and break their necks (yes, you can) oh yeah and talking of shooting lights, you can't do that in Far Cry 6 and in SE5, the mirrors work too, awesome :)  again in FC6, mirrors do not work; for shame UbiSoft, for shame! :) 

Ok, so the bad points, let's get them out of the way:
The music is crap, or at least on the first level it is, it's nice at first but it's the same loop over and over and over...... 
Collecting items, especially in a safe is an absolute nightmare if you don;t require the other items (bullets, mines etc), there were two instances where I could not collect the documents because I could not collect the other items, this needs fixing urgently, I must have wasted about 5 minutes at both locations just moving around as slight as I could to get the Y to highlight, well annoying! 
Lastly, (for now) the AI is crap in most parts, I shot soldiers next to other soldiers and they never responded, I had a guy tonight who was looking right at me and never saw me, well, until I shot him in the leg, then his marker went yellow, yes yellow, not RED, but chuffing yellow, even though I was stood right in front of him and I shot him  -wth???

Anyway, that's all for now, I'm only 8 hours in so I'll update this as I find good and bad in the game :) 

If you're going to buy it, do like I did and get it on sale, then it's not too bad if the AI are idiots :)

To be honest, just like Sniper Elite 4 was to 3, Sniper Elite 5 is basically just more Sniper Elite 4. If you enjoyed 4, you'll enjoy 5, and the much larger environments and generally more content is worth the price of entry.
What I especially like, that I don't remember being the case in the earlier entries, is that the game actually shoves the DLC away in its own menu instead of being front-and-center in every menu option you see. From the inventory to the bonus stages, unless you actively go to seek out the DLC you're not going to see a bunch of locked-off options in your menu. After coming from Zombie Army 4, where 90% of the content was all DLC and just taunted you with how little content you owned for buying the game, Sniper Elite 5 gives you a healthy amount of stuff to unlock, and your inventory isn't cluttered with things you don't own just for buying the base game.
Dumb reason to give it a positive review, I know, but it was refreshing.

What I really don't like is the return of the ability to see enemy backstories by zooming in on them. For a game that markets itself as the game where you get to shoot Hitler in the balls, not only is that feature DLC (like it always is), but it takes the fun out of shooting Nazis in brutal ways when more then half of them are given sympathetic backstory text blurbs.

Having played Sniper Elite 4 for 350 hours I was initially put off by the changes made from SE4 to SE5. But it has grown on me. [u] Sniper Elite 5 is a third person shooter developed and published by Rebellion Developments in 2022. Set during World War II, Sniper Elite 5 is the fifth entry to the Sniper Elite series of video games and features both a full 2 player cooperative campaign. This review will focus on the single player campaign played in cooperative mode. [/u]

[h3] TL;DR – Moving from one strength to another, Sniper Elite 5 is a progressive update of the Sniper Elite series and is easily the best to date with its huge levels and levels of freedom. [/h3]

Story (3/5) – Sniper Elite 5 takes place after the events of Sniper Elite 4 and is chronologically a year before the events of Sniper Elite V2. We are back with the titular sniper, Lieutenant Karl Fairburne, as he works his way through various parts of France and Germany to uncover the mysterious Nazi superweapon, “Operation Kraken”. While the overarching plot is interesting with plenty of lore bits along the way scattered in journals and posters, they merely act as a pre-tense to Sniper Elite 5’s gameplay loop of infiltrate, kill/blow up and exfiltrate. It’s neither overtly memorable nor, offensive in anyway which is perfectly fine. 

Controls (5/5) – Played with mouse and keyboard, Sniper Elite 5 adopts the same control scheme as the previous titles. The default key bindings are logical and easily accessible. Shooting feels natural and the option to adjust sensitivities really help to dial in aiming. Each action/key can be reconfigured to user’s preferences. Moreover, the use of a radial wheel to quickly access the various weapons, ammo types and gadgets make for very intuitive controls of the player’s otherwise very large arsenal.  

Gameplay (4/5) – Just like the games before it, Sniper Elite 5 features a large single map with a main objective and sub-objectives to be completed. How and in what order this is done, is entirely up to the player(s). Everything Sniper Elite 4 does well, 5 does better. Larger maps, more guns, improved traversal and stealth, more verticality, those are just the few improvements Rebellion has made. Stealth and sniping remain to be the core gameplay elements of the Sniper Elite series though, 5 makes it more acceptable than ever to simply go guns a blazing. This level of freedom in such a large playing field makes Sniper Elite 5 such a treat especially when played with a coop buddy. Points are docked for re-playability and some rather questionable enemy AI behaviours. 

Graphics (4/5) – Built on Rebellion’s in-house game engine, Asura, Sniper Elite 5 looks downright gorgeous from its incredibly detailed European castles and cottages to the spanning vistas and artillery shelled trenches. Excellent shadows and lighting also play a key role in bringing these large sets to live especially in the nighttime maps. The core art style and presentation does not differ much from the Sniper Elite series giving it an immediately recognizable feel and look that not many game franchises can claim to have these days. Almost a perfect score if not for the frequent graphical clipping issues encountered when interacting with enemy soldiers. 

Audio (4/5) – From the pop of each silenced gunshot to the boom of a large artillery round landing, the audio experience in Sniper Elite 5 is certainly a treat. Positional audio is serviceable for spotting enemy movements and gun shots. By far the best part is how the myriad of guns in the game have their own audio signature. 

Issues/Optimization – Sniper Elite 5 is very well optimized for the PC and ran well on my system. I had no issues running the game at 4K120 with most of the settings topped out. There were 1-2 hard crashes throughout my playthrough, but nothing serious otherwise. The most common bug you would probably encounter is a graphical one where dead enemies clip through terrain and rag doll in odd ways.

Overall (4/5) – Sniper Elite 5 builds upon all the strengths of Sniper Elite 4 and adds upon it with new gameplay elements that continues to make the game enjoyable. By far the biggest standout for me would be the huge, detailed maps which gives players so much freedom to tackle objectives in however way they see fit. Truly the best in series thus far and a benchmark for a game of this genre. If you can find a cooperative buddy to play this game with, it just makes it that much better. Highly recommended!

Rebellion has fixed many bugs. So, credit where due. 

I have played about 1478 hours, so I am going to update the review.

They have made few important improvements. I will list them down one by one.

1.	There are now 6 No Cross Maps which is ok but not good.
2.	There are now 8 No Cross Maps which is ok but not good. We had more maps in SE4.
3.	Lot of bugs have been fixed.
4.	Rest of the issues that I mentioned below are still there.

For me to give this gave 10/10 ratings, I have the following expectations.

1.	There should be at least 10 maps in both No Cross and Team Match.
2.	Introduce Dedicated Servers
3.	Give an option is enable/disable incapacitation.
4.	Give an option is enable/disable Focus mode.
5.	Ability to see game settings when you join.
6.	Capping of Prestige Level 4. You can’t go beyond that. Same is with other mode. You can’t go beyond a specific level.

Having said that, there have been no updates for quite some time. So, I guess Rebellion has stopped working on this.

If you are getting this game at a lower price, then definitely go for this.

I never give reviews of games early until and unless there is something drastically wrong with the game. This is one of those scenarios :(

Rebellion, what have you done to my favourite game? :(

Before I begin...

ABOUT ME: I started sniper elite with SE4. I have more than 4000 hours in that game with all 85 achievements.

WHO IS THIS REVIEW FOR: Hardcore Snipers who love SE4, the kind of campaigns it offers, The bullet drop and wind you get to play the different modes in. If you are a newbie, this review is not for you. Also, this review will not talk about bugs. Every game has bugs, so my review is not based on bugs this game has.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
-  OVERALL REVIEW
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you are from a country where you can get the deluxe edition for say 20 (USD/EUR) then go ahead and buy it! But if it is going to cost you 60-80(USD/EUR) then trust me it is not worth it. You will not be happy. I would recommend waiting for the sale and then buy it.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
- CAMPAIGN
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

I finished the campaign in Authentic mode very easily (Mind you with NO MANUAL SAVES!). It took me more than a month to do that in SE4. The authentic mode is a joke as compared to SE4. The AI is outright stupid. You can actually run from the front and stand behind them and they end up confused. Reminds me of the cadet mode in SE4.

Pros: 
1. The graphics is really good. Environmental photogrammetry has been put to good use I must say. Good job on this Rebellion.
2. Option to set Axis Invasion. Really loved this!
3. Achievement doesn’t port to other modes.

Cons: 
1. Authentic mode is a joke!
2. AI in Authentic mode behaves like AI of Hardcore mode of SE4
3. Weak story line
4. Unlike SE4, you have very less guns and Explosives. No S-Mines or Trips Mines.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
- MULTIPLAYER
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pros:
1. Ability to start your own games. With the absence of dedicated servers at least you can create your game and turn of the scope glint and aim assist which is by default ON is all servers :(
2. The introduction of accolades. I liked it! It is there in SE4 as well but here it is IN YOUR FACE, if I may say so.
3. Achievement doesn’t port to other modes.
4. Tagging a person now takes more time.

Cons:
1. I am horrified that there are only 2 No Cross Maps. SE4 has more NC maps and we got bored of them pretty soon. If no more maps are introduced for NC then seasoned NC players will very soon abandon this and go back to SE4.
2. Only 5 TDM maps.
3. Is it my imagination or there are fewer hiding spots in SE5 MP? And perhaps this is the reason why everyone is just running and gunning. Very few Sniping. Maybe because of Scope Glint, and revealing the last position of the sniper? People who run and gun will love this I guess but pro snipers will not
4. Need more maps! I got bored in 2 days.
5. Dot Shots, shoulder shooting and spinning still work as it did in SE4 which is really really sad and can cause lot of accusations.
6. Introduced a new focus mode. Users can press Left Alt to find the exact enemy position for about 16 meters. This is so wrong. Might as well allow hacks and cheats. There should be an ability to turn this off.
7. You cannot see the game settings when you join. Only the admin can see it. So, you have to join and that inquire if for example scope glint is on or not!
8. There is lot of stealing of kills. We should be able to switch off Incapacitation. When dedicated servers come, there will be lot of banning if stealing of kills is not stopped.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
- AXIS INVASION
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

A brilliant addition to SE5. I simply love it. Already completed 100 invasions! The only thing I have heard people complaining in discussion forums is that you can get kicked from there. I have personally not experienced it yet.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
- SURVIVAL
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pros:
TBH, I have not played all survival maps, but I am liking it. Even the cadet mode is slightly difficult which is good! There are fewer hiding spots which makes the game interesting.

Cons:
My three biggest problem here is 

1. Soldiers in most cases do not die when they step on mines. I know I said I will not talk about bugs, but this spoiled my game play. I love playing survival!
2. AI in Authentic mode behaves like AI of Hardcore mode of SE4
3. In Authentic mode, you can see the white smudge (if I may call that) on the map which tells you from where the enemy is coming from.
4: Only 3 Survival MAPS!
Pretty fun!

Best one yet. A lot of weapon customization and allows for many playstyles. The weapons are also very unique.
The mission settings are also a personal favorite of mine which are closer to V2 visually.

The only issue is the steep price but the complete edition on a sale is well worth it.

As always, the greatest fun! There is an air of authenticity about this game that pre-determined combat games just can't meet. Your destiny is in your hands and you have the freedom to play it anyway you choose. Once you let another live person into the game to hunt you the adrenaline rises remarkably! The AI is very good but an unpredictable live person changes the dynamics wonderfully. After 650 hours game play and 940 invasions I've had just the best time trying to find them (not using the phones) working out where they went and where they might be. And when you do find them everything is on their side better guns, more ammo and they can locate you with the phones without giving away their position. Big tip to newbies don't search using your long gun the glint gives you away, use a scoped pistol. Hope to see you (first) in a map! Waiting on Sniper 6!
Just as I saw on another review, close quarters sniper combat.  Nothing like the other 4 Sniper Elite games.  It's a shame I'm past the return period.

Overall, Sniper Elite 5 hits its mark. It doesn't reinvent the wheel for this niche genre, nor does it have to. All that Sniper Elite 5 had to do was recapture the formula of Sniper Elite 4 along with some refinements and that is precisely what it does. Sure, the AI could be better and the repetition does slow things down somewhat. However, who really cares about any of that when you can blow off a Nazi's testicles in a glorious high definition x-ray kill-cam? If nothing else, playing Sniper Elite 5 only proved to me that it is impossible to get bored of watching digital Nazis die in slow motion.

Personally I prefer 4 over 5 for many reasons, such as map design, better sound, better x-ray, more boots on the ground without absolute stupid weapon upgrades and a good authentic difficulty mode wich is way more hardcore to beat. You can't just slap a silencer on everything and turn your brain off, if you miss shots in 4 you are in deep shit.

The DLC is way overpriced for just cosmetics and 4 extra missions, not worth it at all unless it's 90% off. The base game at $15 is all you need to scratch that itch. 

You know the one: slow-mo x-ray cutscenes of Nazis getting fragged by your sniper. Shoot em in the head, in the balls, it's the same glorious result. 

Also, one big QoL improvement is that weapon upgrades are no longer tied to grindy "Kill X number of nazis with a spoon" challenges. The cosmetics still are, but weapon upgrades are now obtained by finding workbenches on the maps as you go. Rank system also means something now with a skill tree you can invest in. 

Multiplayer is OK, anti-cheats always feel invasive but this is the world we live in. :\

Im very dissapointed about the stealth mechanics...

Why?

Because stealth is not working as expected and has many errors and even bugs! Just look at the MGS5 with a supreme stealth mechanic! Just copy it and you cannot do anything wrong!

1.If you are in the field of view from enemies and you go prone and dont move, they still see you very fast and you have no change in many cases to hide because they realize you very fast(gras and camo, rims, elevations, distance has no effect!). so PRONING HAS NO FUNCTION in the context of stealth!
2.even if you go prone behind a bush, THEY SEE YOU THROUGH THE BUSH even if you cannot see them!
3.if you go prone behind objects and turn in this state the objects force you to stand up! FATAL! This should not happen!
4.they see you so fast in the red area, even if you dont move, far away, in bushes, behind objects, in gras, camo

So how it should be done?

1.if you are in the field of view of enemies, more far away and you go prone, they should check your last position if they are in yellow area before , but not shot instant! But if you go prone with camo in gras, they shouldnt realize you, especially in bushes and through bushes! And if you go prone and dont move at a certain distance, their bar of sight shouldnt go up any further.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As a fan of WW2 games and stealth games, I thought this was an amazing game. There are a variety of game modes, such as the campaign, PvP multiplayer, and survival. As an added bonus, if you enjoy hunting achievements like I do, this was a fairly easy game to 100%.

Campaign: I played through the campaign solo on the hardest difficulty as I like to take my time to explore and try to be as stealthy as possible, so I can't say how good the co-op is in this one. I thought the campaign was great, and you'll have even more missions if you get the DLC, and they are worth it in my opinion, especially on sale. The maps are huge, so you can tackle objectives in any order you like, and many objectives have several ways of completing them. Along the way you'll find collectibles and unlock weapons and mobs to customize them. The only real issue I had was the sniping opportunities, as I felt there weren't enough. To get gold medals for snipers, you must get headshots from at least 100m away with them, and I constantly found myself moving around and retreating in certain areas just to achieve that 100m distance. There is a lot of close quarters combat, which I also like, but I think there needs to be more vantage points for sniping.

PvP Multiplayer: I only played one round of this to get the achievement, but I didn't feel the desire to continue playing anymore than that. This isn't really the type of game I'd get for PvP matches. Aside from the base PvP modes, there is also invasion. Invasion allows you to enter someone's game as a German sniper or you can open yours for invading snipers. This adds a good challenge to your game if you find the AI is too easy.

Survival: This is a wave-based game mode where you must survive against 12 waves on enemies. There are a variety of survival missions on a variety of maps. The objective is to hold the command post, and after three waves, you'll unlock the next command post. You do not lose the match if you lose a post, but without them, you won't be able to access their resupply caches. I only played a few rounds of this, but it was quite fun and I recommend this mode if you're a fan of wave-based games.

Alright, listen up, folks! This game, right, it's like the lovechild of Sniper Elite 4 and a bunch of new cool features. Rebellion didn't mess with the winning recipe; they just sprinkled in some extra spice. You know that saying, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it"? Well, Rebellion got the memo, and in the world of modern gaming, that's like finding a vegan at a barbecue – unexpected and refreshing.

The gameplay is tighter than my jeans after Thanksgiving dinner. Movement, weapons – it's like they've been on a CrossFit regimen. The AI got a facelift, too, but let's be real, it's a stealth game, not a Mensa meeting. Invasion Mode? That's the cherry on top – it's like playing hide and seek, but with bullets. And who doesn't love non-lethal options? I mean, sparing Nazis for XP is a bit like getting a participation trophy for world-saving, but hey, options are options.

The story? Yeah, it's there, like a background hum. Think John Wick – you're not here for Shakespeare; you're here for headshots. The multiplayer? It's a party!

Killcams? They've upgraded from a boring organ slideshow to a full-blown action movie. Bullet holes, blood spats – it's like Tarantino joined the dev team. Sure, I have a few gripes – like, why no destruction physics on character models? I want to blow a guy's jaw off and see the aftermath, not a pristine chin!

In a nutshell, this game might be the franchise's MVP. It's a must for Sniper Elite veterans, shooter enthusiasts, and stealth nerds. Go ahead, grab it – maybe throw in the DLC for good measure. It's like a gaming buffet, and you're the VIP guest.

I'll preface this short review by stating, as someone who exhaustively played Sniper Elite 4, that your experience with Sniper Elite 5 will greatly depend on your appreciation of SE4. That's not to say that Sniper Elite 5 isn't enjoyable, but it does feel like Rebellion have taken a couple of baby steps forward, and a big leap backwards.

I really appreciated the inclusion of the weapon modification system and surprisingly loved the new campaign invasion mode; but outside these two additions, I found a lot of issues which really need to be addressed. The most frustrating of these problems has been the size of game updates, with single campaign or multiplayer map updates often requiring 30GB downloads, whether you've got access to the content or not. A fix was attempted, which failed miserably and stopped some players being able to launch the game at all. With the last campaign map of Season Pass 2 now out, it seems these updates won't be as frequent, but it simply hasn't been handled well.

The campaign is also strewn with issues: the story is generic, the threat the enemy poses is never well explained, Karl's commentary of situations and enemy intel is laughably poor, many of the maps feel rigid or restrictive, which in turn limits sniping opportunities, enemy AI is confusingly inept at the best of times, and the list goes on.

The game still has many positives which have carried over from Sniper Elite 4, but it should have been so much better. Rebellion had an absolute masterpiece to build on and haven't executed it well. I'm putting a thumbs up here, but with a caveat. Do not purchase this if you're looking for a successor to SE4, because this is a clear downgrade. Pick it up on sale if you love the franchise, otherwise, spend your money elsewhere.

I’ve always loved this series, but I was hoping for more. I’ve followed this series since V2 and absolutely loved the game ever since my first x-ray shot. That being said I wish there was more to it after all these years. I really do appreciate some of the new features like the ability to go into first person and the addition of the axis invasion concept, but behind that it’s the same old thing. I’d love to see something in the way of the Cold War, Vietnam, or even WW1. I also think the amount of content is almost criminal for the price. A couple more missions, skins, a pinch of new guns, and the same old “kill Hitler” mission. Why not a few missions centered around killing more members of the high-command? Why not a second story mode centered around training and fighting with tge French resistance? The selection of guns also bothers me; it’s so bare. It’s WW2, some of the most iconic weapons in history had there debut during this conflict. No M1 garand, no SVT-40, no Tokarev, no 1917 Enfield, no Volksgewehr; so much potential wasted that would’ve made the $150 complete edition price tag feel just a bit less conning. I love the series but c’mon. Now that Revellion has made yet another set in WW2 it’s pretty much a staple of the franchise; it’ll feel too weird to be set in another conflict.

A excellent game with a few flaws. With 400+ game hours i have played SE5 a lot and it became my most favourite game. 

> Gameplay: Its good, the movement is smooth but also direct.
Things i criticise are 
- you can´t drop of several edges, you can hang on (If normal ground is beneath you of course) this is annoying and could easily be changed
- some gaps between objects seem passable but just aren´t and it´s not possible climb or vault several walls/objects
- sometimes Karl doesn´t climb ladders, which forces the player to step upright and risk making noise

> Graphics: The look of the game is fitting and very detailed. With a decent graphics card it looks awesome.

> Content: The levels are large and diverse. Hidden paths provide plenty of options to play the maps. The same applys to the DLC levels.

> Story: I think the story is interesting and supports the change of scenery good. (As a German i can say the translation of dialogs is very good and i also like the conversations of the NPCs)

> Sound and Music: I like the music but i prever turning it of, because it gives me a more immersive experience. The sound works really good. You can identify the direction of voices and noise quick. 

> Innovations:
- The best new thing in SE5 is the Invasion-Mode. A second player can join the game of an other one and start hunting him as a german Sniper-Hunter. This adds new excitment because you don´t only play against NPCs with little intelligence.
- Now you can immensely customise your equipment. With many storeable loadouts for different gamemodes. Each weapon has about 20 different attachemants to choose from and you can adapt them to various play-styles.

>Price: About 100€ for the game + DLC levels on Steam is a lot for the average player. Rebellion also added a Pistol for 4€ what seems very odd and greedy as it provides no special perks for the player.

> Opinion: For me the price was totally worth it. I have played 15+ walktroughts and sometimes prepared a level to encounter and fight Sniper-Hunters (what is mostly kill certain enemys to identify the Invader faster and wait). For me its the most fun to play in difficulty hard and while invaded continue until the Invader is near you and them reverse hunt him. I have had some funny kills like predicting the Invaders movement and shoot rocket launcher 3 seconds early and perfeclty hit him or sneaking up behind them while they are looking for me with their binoculars. Many players complain about the X-Ray ability adn it should be nerfed because its to OP against Invaders. But have they ever tried playing properly ? I my case the Invaders sprint very much and so their movement is easy to identify with and without X-Ray and you can hear the noise they make really far. Also they wear skins which you can identify immediatlely in X-Ray.

Lots of bugs. I love how two years on there is a reload bug where you are dead to rights with any weapons  The balance of this game is also terrible. Enemies are not on screen even if you look for hours, and then they spawn near you you are toast.

Alright. It's fun. As in, really ridiculously fun. There's a lot of little changes from Sniper Elite 4 that give #5 a breath of fresh air. And I'm glad I came to this game a little late as well, because a lot of the bugginess other people are reporting seems to have been fixed. Not completely, but it's definitely playable.

If you don't know what the Sniper Elite series is about, it's basically a WW2 sneaky-shooty-snipey type of deal with a lot of depth in its combat and stealth mechanics. The usual suspects like noise and sight, concealment and light and dark. Objects in the environment and map can provide sound-masking, to cover up the noise of your weapon, such as an artillery piece firing, planes firing overhead, generators you sabotage, and so on.

The AI is something praiseworthy. The average schmuck stands about and follows a set patrol route, as you'd expect. Alert them, though, and that's where the AI shows its depth. Enemies will take cover and triangulate your position from missed shots or watching their buddies get killed. The average soldier is indecisive and slow. Commanded by officers, they begin to exhibit more intelligence, spreading out and circling around you. In later levels, the elite soldiers that appear more frequently are absolutely vicious, pushing up using cover and suppressive fire, flanking you in the blink of an eye, and grenading anything they can't see. It really tests your understanding of the AI and your ability to use your surroundings.

Nothing particularly big has changed since #4. Most of the changes I'd say are quality-of-life and immersion improvements. Weapon customization is one of the best new features, letting you spec out every rifle / secondary / pistol for specific tasks, and it's good. Really good. Non-DLC weapons have all their customization options unlocked through side objectives rather than grinding out a challenge. The sound system is now more nuanced and some places have ambient noise that masks sprinting. It's much rarer for collectibles to be on random soldiers so there's less rifling through every single dead body that #4 was annoying about. You can't swap out your weapons except at a workbench but you can pick up every dropped enemy weapon as a temporary 4th weapon and with a perk take its ammo, so ammo is generally more plentiful. Oh yeah, and iron sights. I've been playing largely with iron sights on every weapon that allows them because it's so much fun and so immersive.

More so than in #4 as well, there's usually multiple ways to accomplish an objective. Stealth is usually more viable than going in guns blazing, but you could do the latter, if you're good at repositioning and snap shots.

Where Sniper Elite 5 really shines is in co-op. Having a buddy alongside you makes games infinitely more fun. Now you can plan out sequences to take out groups of guards, have two separate loadouts tailored to different engagement types, and flank the flankers. It's an incredible, incredible joy to play.

Edit:
Another thing I want to mention is the difficulty. There is a whole range of difficulty options that vastly change how the game is played, to the point where it can feel like an entirely different game. On its easiest setting, it's possible to mow down waves of enemies with a machine-gun, shoot out tanks with armor-piercing pistol rounds, and snipe enemies all the way across the map casually. On Authentic, the game turns into an absolutely brutal cat-and-mouse affair, with you being the hunted just as often as not. It's exhilarating in all the best ways.

I've only bought the base game and downloaded the free DLCs, and I'd say I easily got my money's worth. I can't speak to the paid DLCs, though I'll probably get them only when they're on sale.

It pains me not to recommend a Sniper Elite game but this is probably the worst one since Sniper Elite V2. The main problem with V2 was how often they forced you into close quarters combat. This one is ambitious but they ultimately fell short.

The sniping is solid, it's been the same pretty much the whole series. The X-Ray mode is still fun to take a long distance shot, track the bullet, and watch as it kills an enemy, dealing damage to whatever organ you hit. The maps are quite large but the game really forces you to try to sneak instead of snipe.

There are enemies practically everywhere and they hear everything. There aren't many levels with loud noises that can muffle your shots and everything you do is incredibly loud. Enemies hear you moving unless you move at a snail's pace but you can't always move very slowly because you'll get spotted by enemies that can see a long range. The worst part of the sound is there are times enemies shouldn't be able to hear you but still can. For example, there are vehicle patrols in certain maps. If you run 50 feet behind a loud motorcycle, the person on the motorcycle will stop because they hear you. For a game that focuses on ambient sound to muffle your actions, how do you not have that affect a loud motorcycle muffling your footsteps of all things?

The stealth can just be very frustrating and you feel forced to do it. There are certain areas where you can't crawl or you can't crouch and the game doesn't stop you from moving into those areas, it just forces you to stand up. The problem is now you're suddenly running when you expect to be crouch walking and everyone near you hears you, giving away your position. This particularly happened when I had to go under a bridge to disarm bombs. I had to reload my save multiple times because I would step in just the wrong spot, forcing me to stand and alerting all nearby guards. 

Furthermore, there are a lot of areas you think you can vault over but you can't. You'll take your time and the risk of moving through an open area to move towards some cover, with the plan to vault over some sand bags and flank the enemy, to find that you can't vault over these particular sandbags. It happens a lot and there are a lot of these small walls blocking paths you want to take.

​Since there are so many enemies practically everywhere, taking a shot with your sniper rifle will alert most guards and one of them will surely run to an alarm where you'll be left outnumbered and forced to reload your last save. The sniping is fun but you constantly feel punished for doing it and feel forced to move around, silently taking out guards with melee whenever possible. 

This is definitely not one of the better Sniper Elite games. Go play a different one. Hopefully if and when they make Sniper Elite 6, they'll go back more towards what made 3 & 4 feel so fun.

Sniper Elite is honestly my favourite franchise I've gotten into this year, being not particularly into the whole shooting genre of games, this game does a great job like its predecessors for having satisfying kills and gameplay even if you're not good at shooters, because one of the biggest parts of the game is stealth, and this game even goes the extra mile by adding non-lethal options to getting about the missions. In my opinion I prefer the story in this one over SE4, but partly because this game was a lot more cinematic than the previous. The graphics are fantastic, and my favourite part is probably being able to customise your guns and shit, I must have spent a solid 20% of my total playtime in the testing range and analysing gun stats at a workbench XD my ass should not be allowed to cook at a game with any form of customisation.
I probably prefer the actual gameplay of SE4 more, but in this game, one of the big highlights is probably Axis Invasion, as it definitely freshens up the whole experience a lot (everyone has got to try it at least once, I promise it's fun).

The only real huge problem of this game is the cost for how much content you actually get, realistically, if you play through the whole campaign only and don't really spend time into customisation or exploring any of the extra objectives/collectables, you could probably beat all the campaign in 8 hours, and that's not even getting to the weapons, there's a huge lack of guns in comparison to SE4, and not even a shotgun in the base game!!! Trench gun comes in a free DLC luckily, but man if only the rest of the DLC didn't cost as much as the game itself. It really is a shame. But I do love this game so I'd definitely recommend it, and you should definitely get it when it's on sale. It's not exaaactly worth the full price when you compare it to the amount of content in the previous games.

After playing Sniper Elite V2 and trying to play V3 it's now time to play V5. 

And right off the bat: They improved... A LOT.

This game is waaaaaaay better than V2 and V3. 
There are still some bugs and glitches. Also killing someone will trigger some sort of alerted state, but that just lasts not that long and it's easy to play around it. And that ofcourse is some sort of trade of: You either go punish the player really hard, which makes it a lot less enjoyable and casual OR you go the hard route and make it more realistic.

I do think they could do a bit more on that part. For example: When a body is found the enemy does a full sweep of the area which just lasts quite a bit and makes it so that you have to move around more and also have some smaller windows of oppertunities to move around without being seen.

Apart from those things, compared to V2 and V3, the latter I just couldn't finish, this game is really good. They finally did it proper with the stealth gameplay and you really can go around and do it like you want to. Also the maps are huge and well designed. They are really fun to play and explore. And if compared to V2 and V3 it's just a huge leap forward. Well done Rebellion :) Keep improving.

No one will ever read this, but Sniper Elite 5 is a game I wholeheartedly recommend:

- Found my purpose in life as a stealthy sniper (might have developed a slight obsession with long-range headshots)
- Became the unintentional hero of the resistance (seriously, every mission feels like a blockbuster movie)
- Built my own sniper's nest (though I'm pretty sure enemy soldiers keep finding it)
- Started an unofficial wildlife conservation effort (you'd be surprised how many critters you can avoid shooting)
- Discovered I have a knack for explosive traps (no big deal, just turning tanks into fireworks)
- Turned my sniper rifle into a work of art (they really hate it when you customize it with stickers and charms)
- Mastered the art of silent takedowns (who knew a knife could be so versatile?)
- Became a part-time demolitions expert (it's been a blast, literally)
- Joined the "Bullet to the Head" school of conflict resolution (who needs negotiations when you have a sniper rifle?)
- Explored every enemy-occupied territory (surely the next one won't have even tougher enemies)
- Became obsessed with collecting enemy hats (I swear it's for a personal collection)
- Took on the role of a one-man army (pro tip: always check your six)
- Engaged in the world's most intense sniper duels (Sniper Elite? More like Sniper-tastic!)
- Became a professional demolitionist (the pay is nonexistent, but watching things blow up is priceless)
- Triggered an entire base lockdown by shooting a single alarm (those Nazis sure don't like surprises)
- Carved a niche as a master saboteur (all those fuel dumps aren't going to blow themselves up)
- Woke up after a mission with an unexpected new ally (note to self: trust no one)
- Almost got captured behind enemy lines (oops, should've planned that escape route better)
- Developed a bond with fellow resistance fighters (we're all in this together)
- Died more times to surprise enemy ambushes than I care to admit (so much for being an elite sniper)
- Invented a new game: Spot the Sniper (the key is to stay unseen)
- Realized that being a sniper is just a gateway to becoming a guerilla warfare expert
- Mastered the art of relocating after each shot (it's like hide and seek with deadly consequences)
- Caused chaos in enemy ranks with well-placed shots (sorry, not sorry)
- Perfected my skills in long-distance engagements (it's all about patience and precision)
- Discovered that a life of sabotage can be quite rewarding (until you get caught)
- Became a part-time explosives expert (still working on not blowing myself up)
- Made a habit of collecting enemy intel (who needs safety when you have information?)
- Started a trend with my unique choice of sniper gear
- Accidentally alerted an entire garrison (one wrong move, and it's all over)
- Got a spotter who's worth their weight in gold (their eagle eyes are top-notch)
- Invested in the art of camouflage (they'll never see you coming)
- Became a certified expert in enemy patrol patterns (all those hours of observation really pay off)
- Found a glitch in enemy AI (why do they keep walking into my traps?)
- Took a perilous swim across enemy waters (spoiler: it's just really, really cold)
- Turned every enemy stronghold into a tactical playground (take that, Axis powers)
- Successfully sniped targets I couldn't even see (I swear, it was a lucky shot!)
- Managed to perfect the art of distraction (a well-thrown rock goes a long way)
- Ventured into enemy territory with nothing but a pistol (because sometimes, you just have to improvise)
- Learned to appreciate the quiet before the storm (the calm before each mission is oddly soothing)
- Unintentionally started a rebellion (those mission objectives can have unexpected consequences)
- Single-handedly shifted the course of the war (every mission feels like it has a real impact)
- Became an expert in historical weaponry (all those authentic guns and their details)
- Beat the odds in seemingly impossible missions (that one took a few retries, not gonna lie)
- Entered and escaped from the most heavily guarded fortresses (it's all in a day's work)
- Single-handedly reduced the enemy's ammunition stocks (every bullet counts)
- Started a support group for gamers who can't hit that long-range shot (we meet online on weekends)

I loved Sniper Elite 4. I had over 1000 hours in it, and all the trophies on PS4. Sniper Elite 5 is OKAY. I love some of the new features, such as the Axis Invasion, First Person ADS, and the wide weapon selection. I heard some complaints about the DLCs and how much there is, but I am okay with this considering you get the game with plenty of content from the get go. 
However, I do feel there are some downgrades in some areas. First off the most annoying thing is Karl won't shut up. He talks the entire time while doing missions, and I liked how he was more silent in 3 and 4. This is a small gripe. My biggest gripe is there are some areas which you clearly should be able to access and if I was playing 4 I know I would have the ability to do so. It just feels rushed. There are definitely some areas which are downgrades. 
I wanted to love this game. It looked like Sniper Elite 4 with new features, new areas, and the option to play as the axis. It is like this  somewhat. I almost wish the Devs would add all the maps from 4 into 5, so I can experience these cool features on the much cooler map designs. 
In conclusion, this is a good game. It isn't great, or amazing. That would be Sniper Elite 4. If you are a Sniper Elite fan, and you have played the previous games I would say buying this game on sale is the way to go so you are not disappointed, which is what I did because I read some negative reviews. Those who are new to the series should go try out 2,3, or 4 first. I would say play them in order. Regardless, all of them are great sniping fun.
Don't worry guys, Sniperman is here!

Sniper Elite 5 is a welcome addition to the Sniper Elite franchise, offering a satisfying stealth experience with its slow-paced gameplay and realistic environments. The game's core mechanics remain unchanged from previous installments, but the new maps and missions provide a refreshing challenge for seasoned players.

The game's stealth mechanics are top-notch, encouraging players to carefully plan their approach and take out enemies silently. The X-ray kill cam remains a highlight, providing a gruesome yet satisfying reward for well-placed shots.

What I particularly enjoyed about Sniper Elite 5 is its relaxing pace. Unlike many action-packed shooters, Sniper Elite 5 allows players to take their time, carefully scouting out enemy positions and planning their next move. This makes for a more immersive and enjoyable experience.

However, the game isn't without its flaws. I initially experienced some motion sickness, but this was easily remedied by lowering the controller sensitivity settings. Additionally, there seems to be a disconnect between the gameplay and the cinematics. My character Karl was wearing a ghillie suit in the game, but he appeared in his default uniform during cutscenes. This created a jarring disconnect and felt like a programming oversight, especially for a game with a premium price tag.

Despite these minor issues, Sniper Elite 5 remains a solid stealth game with plenty to offer fans of the genre. The slow-paced gameplay, realistic environments, and satisfying stealth mechanics make it a worthwhile addition to the series.

It's a step sideways for the franchise and that's not always a terrible thing. And some disclosure here, I got the main game and some DLC on a hefty sale (around 40% off) so perhaps my cost to fun ratio is skewed more in its favor than some other reviewers. I have one big complaint that pops up in other reviews but mostly I'm seeing the same game here.

I'm not going to go do a point for point rehash for my Sniper Elite 4 review, which was pretty solid and a lot of what I said there holds true here. I say that 4 is just more of 3, and in some ways 5 here is just more of the last two.

In 4, I found the open maps to be rather exhausting after a while to the point where on many levels I ended up just going "loud" and whipping out my assault weapon just to speed things up so I could get to some new scenery. My experience with that here in 5 is more of a mixed bag. So far in 9 hours I haven't felt 'bored' by the maps. Enemy patrols are a bit tighter in some places, even clustered, so I spend more time methodically figuring out what I'd consider be a "safe" kill or not, typically considering patrol paths. Don't wanna kill a guy in a gazebo when I know he's got two buddies that wander around the courtyard and might find him. As a result I feel a lot more stealthy and methodical than I did in the previous entry.

My main, big complaint is just the level design.

I find a lot of the design here is a lot more railroad-y than before. The maps have barbed wire, gates, and tunnels that sort of force you down paths and bridges that leave you open to spotters and spawning car patrols. I'll elaborate more on that in a second but I had trouble exfiltrating during the first mission because there was a Y road crossing where I had to go that vehicles kept spawning and piling on top of each other because they'd be constantly "alerted" at my recent dealings there (an exploded car, maybe a body or two) so I had to deal with nearly a full platoon of guys because the game apparently just keeps spawning cars.

So I can't just pick a direction to approach my attack from. Honestly this is fairly realistic, during wartime it makes sense that you'd barb up some hills so any potential stealth teams have a harder time getting to you. I get that but I wish there were more options than "you can only progress through this level by getting past this one bridge". You can have your barbed wire while being a bit more clever with design.

The second level, an estate, is a real crapshow of design. It has the aforementioned three bridges but the real problem is that you're trying to navigate the estate itself. This isn't a problem for say, assassin's creed where most of the game is done with silent stabbings or a bamboo dart tosser. But here, each gun has a "range" of audibility. I have a DLC rifle where its range is pretty short but that 30 or so meters doesn't mean much when I'm trying to snipe at an estate. Once one guy goes down, one of the forty guys gets alerted and it starts a chain reaction that turns my entire minimap yellow and I just had to deal with that for several minutes. I let them wander towards my last known location where I then botch a shot and get forced into open combat, then my minimap is flooded with red because I now have 20 nazis gunning for me. My second run at this level was more successful but I did still have to gun down an entire hallway of six dudes before being able to get out of their sightlines and reset the encounter. I cannot imagine trying to attempt a pure stealth run of that level. There's no way.

That's not the only level where it's like this, either. It's just one of the first ones that made me think "Oh, COME ON."

Previous games had full on sniper nests, typically with a nearby sound masking generator you could kick to start a full sniper spree with, to clear out defensive structures in relative safety as long as you timed your shots right. That's basically gone here. Every now and then your minimap might denote a good spot to snipe from but I've found that generators seem randomly placed and are rarely useful to me. In the estate level there's a generator near the base of one of these towers and when I cleared the camp of enemies I got up and found absolutely no enemies at the edge of the estate to shoot at. So I just cleared the camp and was rewarded with a sound mask and tower with no visible enemies to take advantage of. Come on.

A minor complaint is that you're rewarded with more experience by going for non-lethal takedowns and keeping more Nazis alive or incompacitated. Why... why would I, or anyone, ever want to do that?

I get that this is two paragraphs of good and four of bad but considering the good points of the franchise are still present, it just seems to accentuate what really went wrong with the design. I'm enjoying it though and I'm yearning to play more of it as my Youtube recordings of it are processing in my video editor. Might do some co-op in it. So that's a pretty good sign if a game leaves me with that feeling of "I want to see more".

But yeah the practices around the DLC are pretty bad.
