Far from perfect at launch, but fun enough. Some glitches, fell through the ground once and was left "hanging" on the edge, but couldn't get up - happened to have saved just a few seconds earlier so not too bad.

Haven't yet figured out exactly how to customize the difficulty to my liking, and a few other such small things, but after playing the first 2 missions I can say I had fun.

Worst part so far is that dead bodies, vehicles, etc. just randomly disappear, even undamaged vehicles can randomly despawn when you're standing within 20 meters of them and just looking the other direction. Probably second worst part is that the AI cheats. Bushes etc. regularly obscure your visibility, but some enemy is busy shooting you through 7 trees and 15 large bushes as if they were not there.

There's other things that are less than perfect, rocks have been replaced with glass bottles, but nobody seems to ever hear them, even at pretty short distances. The only time I had someone react to one was when it accidentally hit their head.

The weapon customization seems nice, but I can't seem to be able to actually switch weapons .. I can pick up a panzerfaust, but if I want to put it on my back, it's just dropped on the ground instead (and the one time I tried that it fell through the ground into the void).

Maps seem reasonably large, but random areas are blocked off for no good reason, and the slightest incline on the side of a ditch is blocking you from climbing up and instead you can only slide down.

This game is so good in many ways, but also so terribly buggy and clearly rushed.. I kill literally everyone in the map, but it counts people I tagged with the binoculars anyway as "spared". Similarly I can tag the same person over and over again and get "ribbons" for "tagging 20 enemies". Probably because tags don't actually do anything on the difficulty I'm using.

There's the xray kill camera, which now has some speed controls .. they seem to do nothing.

There's regularly cases where I sneak behind an enemy that is crouching digging through trashes or something, and so I can't stealth kill them, the action option just isn't given to me, and then when I bump into them, they get up, stand in front of me, point a gun at me, and I just gotta wait keep tapping E hoping that at some point the stupid buggy thing will let me kill them before they can shoot me .. this goes on for multiple seconds.

The item highlighting is also incredibly flawed, it used to work great in SE4, but it's constantly refusing to highlight items for me to act on, or is constantly selecting the wrong thing. Particularly bad in a box that has like 5 items in it, trying to select the one thing you can pick up and want to is sometimes near impossible.

If you accidentally step too close to some hole, the character may decide to start hanging off the ledge, and then refuses to climb back up. There's hidden back entrances where e.g. you open a grate to go through, but due to bugs you can't always actually fit all the way through and so can't use them.

Doors require an action to open, which takes control away from you, and you can't close them.

Actions regularly animate poorly, and sometimes due to the animation glitching you just can't perform them - searching bodies in certain positions is impossible, throwing TNT doesn't always show the arc, and when you release the button he just tosses it in his feet, etc.

Still fun, but in its current state very flawed. Don't buy until the devs clean up their act and fix it - considering the amount of bugs I keep running into, it's months away from being really enjoyable.

One REALLY big minus - it attempts to force an unwanted multiplayer invasion system on you, and for that system, it attempts to force one of those rootkit DRM piece of trash cancerware things on you. It seems you can avoid this by checking the settings BEFORE launching the game, but it's far from obvious.

UPDATE: 1.5 years later, the game still has most of the same issues, there's a few less issues with clipping through the world or being blocked from a few areas you should be able to crawl through, that's it. All the other bugs and issues mentioned above are still valid. I keep regularly bumping into new bugs that have been reported long ago that the devs have completely ignored. Very disappointing behavior from the devs.

Not a big fan of this game. The series peaked with SE4. This game is basically Hitman: WWII. Which is fine, but I find some the missions far too restrictive with pathways and routes you can take. There are a lot of fences and sandbags you should be able to vault over, there are so many fences that you can't vault over just to be a path blocker. The worst offenders are the little sheet metal piles on the train tracks on War Factory. Why are those there? Why can I not traverse them? Why does it seem like the devs made lanes and avenues and staircases with roof access on many buildings just to block it with a copy/paste debris? Vantage points are very few and far between imo. The game feels linear when each mission is touted as a sandbox.

I have always enjoyed the survival modes ever since SE2. In each installment it is easily the best part of the game. This game's survival mode is bland. The maps stink, there are very few vantage points. If there is a vantage point you can bet it has no sight lines to objective. That means if you're solo you have to sit on OBJ with your secondary or if you are in a group someone has to babysit OBJ while the others have fun sniping.

The weapons. I'm fine with the creative liberty Rebellion took in regard to weapon customization. It's not for me, I find it a little immersion breaking but for others I can understand if someone likes it. The ballistics seem to be overhauled which I like, no more shooting at an enemy who is at 100 meters and I'm zeroed for 50 meters and I'm shooting at his toes. Or being zeroed at 50 meters and my target is 30 meters and I'm shooting the sky behind him. Well done, it is a *little more realistic.* What I do not like about the weapons is lack of variety in base game. This has always been a Sniper Elite problem but Rebellion has shown they do not necessarily care for equipment being outside it's theater of war. Why not add in legacy weapons  from previous games locked behind challenges? 

The axis invasions and multiplayer are okay. I like the invasion system, gives the campaign a neat dynamic. 

This is nit picky but I cannot stand the sound track. SE4 had a pretty epic soundtrack, and the previous games had fine soundtrack. I had to turn the music off in this game. I have never turned off game music before in any other game. 

Overall the worst offense SE5 makes is monetization. The DLC packs. I think its pretty lame that there is like $250 of content you can buy. I feel really bad for those that bought deluxe with season pass thinking they would get all content. Especially considering how little meat is on the bones of the base game.

[u][b]TL;DR[/b][/u]
I can't recommend a game that claims to be Sniper Elite but feels more like Hitman in WWII,and fails to execute either properly. This experience taught me the value of not preordering.

First of all, it's not a bad game and looks very good. However, I've played all the earlier Sniper Elite games and most of the Hitman franchise (which is more relevant than it might seem), and I find this one to be the least enjoyable among modern games.

[u]What I like:[/u]
In this installment, compared to the previous ones, I particularly like the [b]weapon customization[/b]. It allows you to dramatically alter how a weapon performs in some cases, and enables specialization of weapons for certain tasks or playstyles. Additionally, I also like the [b]graphics.[/b] While not necessarily better, the grittier atmosphere it creates suits the game quite well in my opinion.

[u]What I don't like:[/u]
Let's address the big issue first: [b]map design and the Hitman-like feel[/b]. The maps are expansive but, unlike Hitman, all paths feel constrained (sometimes oddly so). For three-quarters of the game, you're so close to the enemy that an SMG or a knife is more useful than a scoped rifle. The game introduces new options for killing like poisoning, and to top it off, it features the same hitman-o-vision from the Hitman series. The only difference is that it feels even more out of place here. All of this contributes to the game feeling more like a poorly executed Hitman set in WW2 rather than a proper Sniper Elite game.

[b]Grinding[/b]: If you want everything, be prepared to do a lot of grinding. If you want to do it in multiplayer, you'll have to do it all over again against other players who most likely already have the upgrades.

Speaking of [b]multiplayer[/b], the old-style multiplayer has been replaced with gameplay similar to CoD and Battlefield, but with everyone equipped with sniper rifles. I find that this style challenges less thinking and sniping, and leans more toward reflexes and bunny hopping.

[b]Multiple DLC seasons[/b]. call me old fashioned but i think this is bullshit, certainly at €30 for 2 maps, 2 guns, and some skins.

P.S. The best anti-tank weapon is an SMG with AP bullets.

First time playing sniper elite, i have to say there isn't as much "sniping" as I would have imagined. It is very fun in the first say 3-4 missions, but gets quite repetitive afterwards. There are so many aspects of this game that makes me wonder how is this game already the 5th in this series. Here are why

With everything pre-calculated for you in sniping, you just need to lock the red diamond box onto enemies' head. The bots are moving very rigidly according to the designed routes, where enemies would keep pacing around even if you triggered the alarm. The controls for climbing ladders are awfully designed, making it almost impossible to move immediately after climbing down a ladder. If you non-lethally subdue an enemy on a slope / stairs, they will fall into the ground and be deemed "killed". Great game. This one has to be the best in the series. Graphics are better than they've ever plus way many more kill actions added. The missions themselves granted if you play like a real sniper would they could take few hours to complete witch i liked but the amount of levels is short in main game I would of liked to see few more that i didn't have to pay for with DLC. I only played he single-player campaign and below are my 50 cents about it:

The game brings a few innovations to the fanchise however it falls short of it's predecessors especially regarding the quality of the maps and AI.
The maps could be better made, there are areas that seem accesible but are not and many bugs.
The AI is quite poor comparing to previous iterations of the game. Most notable is the fact that once the soldiers become cautios (yellow) they seem to be running around forever, including snipers. Also they sometimes remain in combat mode even after the character left the area by a significant distance (e.g., other side of the map)
The camera and angles around the main character are also very poor. While switching to binoculars and scoped weapons, most of the time you are no longer looking at the same angle as in the third person view. Also while aiming or looging through the binoculars over a parapet the character no longer raises his head, forcing you to stand up to see over.

The scenario could also be improved. For a sniping game there are too few opportunities to take long shots with the rifle. Instead, it is far more easy to complete the game using take-downs and fighting with your side arm and muffled SMG. This is due to the fact that the game requires you to actuate various valves and levers placed in vaious crowded places. This gets old very fast , and combined with the above-mentioned AI fault it is far more appealing to the player to try to sneak in and take down all opponents in hand to hand combat than to use the sniping option.

I wish the next iteration of the game would take the maps quality from SE3 and $E4, the AI and scenario from SE4 and the new featurs from SE5 (Pacify option, Loot boxes, Workbenches) and create a truly captivating game.

To conclude, I was very hyped by this game and waited to buy it on a Black Friday deal and still feel I paid too much for it.

Had fun with this and have played all Sniper Elite games (except maybe #1).

Stealth is very important in this game. I probably used my silenced pistol more than my sniper rifle, but that's OK as it made sense based on the situation. You can go in guns blazing in certain situations. The enemy spawns are not unlimited.

You can snipe more if you use sound sources and distance as your cover (different weapons are heard at different ranges - also quieter bullets are a nice option). Lots of difficulty options to suit your play style.

A few glitches using cover and picking up items, but nothing major. I do miss the trip wire trap as enemies can sneak up on you when you are focussed on frontal combat. 

I liked the various ammo/gun options (and of course bandages and med kits) but did not use most of the misc items in my play through (e.g. decoy, various mines, TNT). The glass bottles and whistle were useful though. Satchel charges are required but you pick them up as you go. 

Took me 31 hours to finish (no DLCs) with a lot of sneaking required (and hiding sometimes when enemy was searching).

The DLC pricing is absolutely outrageous tho (currently 2 guns and 1 skin in a bundle on sale for 7.49€ , normal price 11€), they are really bad value-for-money and are much more aggressively priced than SE4 (half the content for twice the price in comparison) and so far the DLC content has not seen a sale that would go down to a price that i would be willing to pay for said DLCs (3-5€). sniper go pew pew

It's hardly improved in anyway since the last 4 of these games, and the real reason I'm not recommending this is because the DLC is not DLC at all. The whole game's story, from mission one, surrounds a thing called the Kraken. What's Kraken? DLC, what would be the obvious last or second to last mission is DLC. That tells me some scumbag is leeching off the game, and considering how much junk dlc there is, maybe many. It's really designed to make you buy dlc too. The one automatic pistol, dlc. There's no try before you buy or examination of what modifications you can use on these dlc weapons, so, they can sell you junk and you won't know it until you pay. It's just greasy crap like that that really bothers me when the lack of improvements to the series feels frustrating. 

Default controller sensitivity is fucked, and seems to be always fucked. The character is the clunkiest, stuck on every little thing. I got stuck on a ladder for 5 minutes, trapped between a wall and a hole that it wouldn't let me drop down, wouldn't side climb over to me grab a ladder (even tho my guy is touching it.) It's just sad. With all that said, it's basically just the same game as the last few with some added features... but I swear nothing was improved. It's all reuse, which is fine, if you reuse and improve. 

Another thing I have a problem with is the level design. Outta the 14 or so maps, 5 of which are DLC, I think I enjoyed 2 or 3, and that's because most of them are just cluster fucks, and again it's almost allllll reuse from the past 4+ games. You go into a lot of the buildings and it's like 100 doors you can't interact with, shooting off in hallways that run 5 directions, with sparsely open doors here and there, basically doom enemy closets. So, every door you come out, there's enemies to your left right front and back, but you can never determine which door or what direction they are... it's just unintuitive. It's a sniper game, and you end up running around in trench mazes and cluster bunkers, or big ships most of the time. Like I said, there's good maps too, but there's a lot bogged down with just, flat places with no good lines of sight on anything, with bushes acting as boundaries everywhere in the middle blocking line of sight and logical pathing to objectives, and the arbitrary obvious post you're supposed to use. Hey, that old empty windmill just beyond the perimeter of our top secret base, maybe we should hit it with a rocket real quick just incase ya know. "No, it looks pretty."

 Another thing I don't like, and I think it's cause of the price of this game, limiting who plays it to either A; people who get it on discount and are casual as hell, and B; the most hardcore of fans. This is a pretty bad combo. You wanna jump in, you jump into someone who has been camping for a half hour because they have an invade, you spawn in, instant death cause they have the difficulty jacked up. Or, you open your game up, and you get people who are just thirsty to kill the first person they can, they do it, alert everyone everywhere, then try to speed run, or they just leave after they set off all the alarms and get killed. Then there is the tacked on multiplayer modes, survival is standard and generally fun, but they have this whole upgrade leveling system for modes separate from survival and coop, unlocks tied to bs nonsense busy work, etc, and again, this game is filled with sweat... so sweat and forced multiplayer progression always makes a good combo. 

I've been wishing since like number 3 that this would just be a coop metal gear v, and they just keep making the same game. The clunkiness of the player tho is whats really frustrating, he's magnetized to a lot of stuff, and incredibly slow in some cases. Really slow crouch walk, realllly reallly slow walk while aiming, no matter what the weapon. Very slow crawl. These problems combined with the bad business, few inspired maps, and the fact that these games quickly loose player counts. I can't tell you how many times people love to shoot a guy you are currently melee killing. So, instead of the silent kill, where you get all the items, they alert the place to your position... just because they are salivating for a dopamine response. This happens a lot while sniping too, but it's more forgivable. Plus, it's one of those games keyboard and mouse players "shift w" the whole game, while at the same time controller x and y is all fucked up. These are all things that really should have been reworked like 3 games ago. 

I'd say get it on sale only, as cheap as possible, 10 or 15 bucks, and there's really maybe only 1 dlc worth a shit. Again think of this, if 99 percent of the content from this game was made from or just straight reuse from the other 4 or 5 games, why did you only gives us about 3 skins for the main character? Because you are almost purely relying on reuse to make the game, you may not actually even have any original artwork for this game? We are literally paying for things that were made idk a decade ago for a different game. Reuse is fine, literally every major company does it, but this dlc really feels pulled straight outta the actual game. How can you have a STEALTH game with a mad militant leader who is making a super weapon... and you end it before dealing with the superweapon. I can't get over how dumb that is. 

I actually checked the reviews on this, and a lot of people seem to acknowledge this problem, but I think a lot of people who are positive... first of all, they just don't know what they're talking about, probably prefer their cereal stale, and it's the first of this franchise that they've played. IDK, pretty insulting experience all around. Oh and my 26 hours... I've pretty much done everything I wanted to do twice already. I haven't grinded levels in multiplayer and I haven't searched for every collectible, and I won't do those things ever, because they are not really fun things to do. Oh yeah, when surrounded by nazis and all their junk I'm gunna make sure to keep an eye out for statues of eagles... That's like saying, here's a forest, it's your job to collect green leaves, and when you're done, go ahead and get the brown ones too. I don't know why this is still a thing.

[h1]Loved it, but haven't been able to play it in months now[/h1]

I loved this game for a while. Axis Invasion was a hoot. Then I had to take a break of several months for medical issues. I was ready to get back into it and Season Pass 2 came out. Perfect, I'll pick it up and jump back into the game and ...

... never got the chance to play it. Unfortunately, the game (at least for me) is now completely broken. It will load, but only until it gets to the copyright screen. It hangs there and I have to kill the process via task manager.

I'm not new to PCs. I've used every version of Windows since 3.11. I've tried every single troubleshooting technique I've learned in that time on this game. Drivers? Up to date. Anti-virus? Off. Firewall? Off. Change every setting in the launcher? Done. Run as administrator? Doesn't work. Verify the files via Steam? Done that. DXDiag? Clean. 

Hardware - i9 12900, RTX3070, 64GB Ram. Not hurting on the system specs. Every other game I play works flawlessly and runs smoothly. Star Citizen, DCS, Cyberpunk, Hell Let Loose, etc. all run at high FPS with no problems.

I've submitted trouble tickets. The 1st one was in August. I understand they are a small company, so the long response times were not that big of deal. However, the support I've received has been nothing more than "update your drivers and try other options in the launcher". And because I gave Rebellion the benefit of the doubt  and waited for a support response, I exceeded the Steam refund timeline. I regret that now.

If you take a gamble, purchase this, and it works, you'll have a good time. But I'm now so frustrated that I doubt I'll ever buy another Sniper Elite title again.

"Let me start by saying that Karl Fairburne is one of the coolest characters in video games. He doesn't use cringe-worthy or awkward dialogue that makes me cringe and drop the game. He's pretty cool, and I also like his attire. So, the main character gets a solid 9/10 from me.

I appreciate that there isn't a lengthy and complicated tutorial in the game. Instead, you have a short and straightforward tutorial before diving into the game. I give this aspect an 8/10 because overly complex and long tutorials can make a first-person shooter boring. However, I had a slight issue with not knowing how to heal initially. It might have been my mistake for missing it, but it would be helpful if the game explained which button to press for healing.

The variety of guns in the game is fantastic, and I like that the game explains their historical usage in a simple and concise manner. It's impressive, and I've learned about guns I never knew were used. The fact that guns can make different noises depending on their loudness adds depth to gameplay. So, this aspect gets a perfect 10/10.

I admire that Sniper Elite 5 includes elements that many other AAA games wouldn't dare to touch, unlike titles like Call of Duty. The game provides an authentic World War II experience, and even using terms like 'Nazi' and featuring the Nazi flag was surprising to me, as many games have avoided them since 2005. I appreciate that the game uses accurate terms like 'Fritz,' 'Heinies,' or 'Kraut.' It feels more genuine than generic labels like 'bad guys' or 'evil people.' This aspect deserves a 10/10 for its boldness and respect for historical accuracy.

Thank you for giving German voice actors a chance. It makes the characters feel genuinely German, unlike Ubisoft, who didn't use Swedish actors for Assassin's Creed Valhalla. This approach often results in incorrect pronunciations and disconnects from the culture. Kudos to Sniper Elite 5 for giving voice actors from the respective countries a chance, and I appreciate that effort. It makes me happy to see this attention to detail.

I also love how the soldiers' dialogue feels like it's meant for them, making the game feel more real and immersive. It's a subtle but important touch that adds to the overall experience.

Moreover, when you press 'B' to use your binoculars for scouting, and you can see their names and some personal information, it adds a layer of complexity to the game. Sometimes, it can make you feel conflicted about taking a shot, depending on what you've learned about them. It adds an emotional dimension to the gameplay that can be both engaging and thought-provoking.

Regarding bugs or lag, I purchased the game a bit late, so I can't comment on its early state. However, I didn't encounter any major bugs, just some minor issues like soldiers occasionally bunny hopping or having creepy, open mouths. So, I'd rate it 8/10 for the relatively smooth experience.

I like the game's map and how it creates an immersive environment that isn't empty. It's great that you can find items scattered around. However, I did notice that some areas are inexplicably blocked, which was a bit confusing. So, I'd give this aspect a 7/10.

The menu design is good; gray and blue colors work well, and it's simple and visually appealing. While it's not a big deal, it could be interesting to see different menu designs for various locations in the game. So, the menu gets an 8/10.

Overall, Sniper Elite 5 offers a solid gaming experience with a few minor quirks, making it an enjoyable addition to the series. Its historical accuracy, including the use of the Nazi flag, adds an extra layer of authenticity to the game. The immersive dialogue of the soldiers adds to the realism, making the game truly engaging. The personal details you discover about enemies while using binoculars adds an emotional dimension that deepens the gameplay experience."

[H1]Apparently the running while crouching was too much of an extravagance...[/h1]

The game boasts less content than its predecessor, Sniper Elite 4. Apparently, "running while crouching" was just too much of an extravagance for Sniper Elite 5. Who needs innovation and improved mechanics when you can have the authentic "crouch-and-slow-walk" experience that keeps you begging for more? The absence of running while crouching is a bold choice that says, "We believe in tradition and refuse to be swayed by the allure of modern gaming."

Also, who needs vast, open spaces when you can have endless twisty hallways, right?

In summary, Sniper Elite 5 takes all the conventions of open-world gaming and shatters them with the force of a thousand clunky controllers. It's a masterclass in not fixing what isn't broken and embracing the glorious world of narrow hallways. If you're tired of progress and innovation, look no further – Sniper Elite 5 is your ticket to the past.

I was kind of on the fence with this one. On one hand, I did enjoy it. On the other hand, some of the criticism in the other reviews are fair: it is a downgrade from SE4, and that's not what you would expect from a sequel. The un-reloadable, un-holsterable picked up weapons are arbitrary and annoying, and while the levels are still large, intricate and picturesque, *some* of them seem less open/more linear than they used to be, with less opportunities for actual sniping. I also feel like there's just overall less enemies in the game, or at least they are more sparsely placed around the maps - it's rare to find more than two germans within sight of each other, which makes clearing an entire level without firing a single shot almost trivial.
With all this being said, it still feels and plays like Sniper Elite, so if you liked the previous games and craving for more, you should probably check this one out too. May wanna wait for a sale though.

I should preface this review by saying I've only played through Authentic mode (and Authentic mode on SE4 as well). This is basically just the SE4 engine with extra maps and some dumbed down mechanics. AI seems less intelligent than SE4; it's a lot easier to methodically work your way through a map in authentic mode without getting full aggro than in SE4. Other unfavorable changes from SE4: no more rocks to throw, no running while crouched, no authentic hardcore mode. The storyline is just okay.
However, it's fresh Sniper Elite content and the game is still fun to play on its own.

Bottom line: if you can buy this game at 50% off or more, then give it a go. Otherwise, it's just not worth it (particularly the DLC prices!).

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round as we dive headfirst into the mesmerizing black hole of pointlessness that is Sniper Elite 5. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a game that defies every expectation, where boredom is the main attraction, then congratulations, you've stumbled upon gaming's magnum opus of nihilistic irony.

Sniper Elite 5's brilliance lies in its ability to take everything you've come to expect from a game and turn it on its head. The game opens with all the enthusiasm of a sloth in a sedative-induced coma, introducing you to Karl Fairburne, the protagonist who probably questions the meaning of life more than you do. His mission? Well, it doesn't really matter, because nothing in this game does.

The gameplay is a masterpiece of absurdity. It revolves around the concept of hiding behind cover, waiting for enemies who seem just as clueless about their existence as you are about yours, and then engaging in a slow-motion ballet of monotony as you line up your shots. Each kill is punctuated by an X-ray kill cam, which serves as a stark reminder of the sheer absurdity of it all. It's as if the game is saying, "Look at this! Isn't it ridiculous?"

The AI, or lack thereof, is a work of art in itself. Enemies saunter around like they're on a leisurely stroll through a warzone, and they hardly react when their comrades mysteriously drop dead around them. It's almost as if they've given up on life, just like you while playing this game.

As for the story, it's a narrative rollercoaster that somehow manages to go in a straight line. Characters deliver their lines with all the enthusiasm of someone reading the phone book. You'll find yourself chuckling at the sheer absurdity of trying to care about a plot that seems more interested in mocking you than engaging you.

Graphically, Sniper Elite 5 pushes the boundaries of mediocrity. The environments are as exciting as watching paint dry, which, ironically, might actually be more engaging. Character models look like they were rendered by a bored intern, and the animations are so stiff that you'll wonder if everyone in this game is secretly made of cardboard.

Sound design is another exercise in ironic indifference. The soundtrack seems to be on a never-ending loop of monotony, while the voice acting delivers lines with all the emotion of a malfunctioning robot. It's as if the game is laughing at you for even bothering to listen.

In conclusion, Sniper Elite 5 is a nihilistic and ironic masterpiece of tedium. It revels in its own absurdity, inviting you to join in on the joke. If you're in the mood for a game that not only embraces boredom but turns it into an art form, then Sniper Elite 5 is your ticket to a hilariously pointless gaming experience. Just remember, in the grand scheme of things, nothing really matters, and neither does this game. Enjoy! Or don't. It doesn't matter, anyway.

Sniper Elite 5 doesn't just raise the bar; it sets a new standard for tactical shooters. Rebellion Developments has crafted a masterpiece that combines precision gameplay with a riveting narrative, delivering an immersive experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

From the first bullet fired, Sniper Elite 5 demonstrates a level of realism that's both awe-inspiring and challenging. The attention to detail in the game mechanics is nothing short of exceptional. Every shot feels deliberate, and every decision matters. Whether you're choosing the perfect vantage point or managing your resources, the game rewards strategic thinking and patience.

The level design is a testament to the developer's dedication to creating a dynamic, living world. Each environment feels meticulously crafted, offering a range of strategic options for players. Whether you're perched atop a crumbling building, navigating a dense forest, or infiltrating an enemy stronghold, the game invites you to explore and adapt.

The addition of new tools and gadgets adds depth to the gameplay, providing players with creative ways to approach each mission. From suppressed weapons for stealthy takedowns to environmental traps that turn the tide in your favor, Sniper Elite 5 empowers players with an arsenal that complements the methodical nature of sniping.

The narrative is both engaging and emotionally resonant, weaving a story of espionage and intrigue against the backdrop of World War II. The characters are well-developed, and their interactions add a human touch to the high-stakes missions. The campaign's pacing keeps you invested, with each mission offering a fresh set of challenges and objectives.

The game's signature slow-motion kill cam returns, and it's as satisfying as ever. Watching a perfectly executed shot in glorious detail never gets old. It not only serves as a testament to your skill but also adds a cinematic flair to the overall experience.

Multiplayer modes, including cooperative play and competitive matches, enhance the replayability of Sniper Elite 5. The thrill of outsmarting opponents or coordinating with teammates adds another layer to an already compelling package.

In conclusion, Sniper Elite 5 stands tall as a triumph in the genre. It's a game that demands precision, rewards strategy, and captivates with its immersive world. Whether you're a fan of stealth, tactical shooters, or gripping narratives, Sniper Elite 5 hits the bullseye and then some. It's not just a game; it's a testament to the art of sniping. Lock and load, sharpshooters – this one's a must-play.

Campaign mode is really polished and well-made, but my review here, will focus mainly focus on the multiplayer. 

The multiplayer modes are affected mostly because there are no dedicated servers. Meaning that, if the host of a team-match (8v8 multiplayer mode) leaves the lobby, during the game or right before the match-ending screen, all the progress is lost. More than that, is it's happening during the match, you will get a "migration lobby" screen which will stop your session. 

For a game like SE5, multiplayer should have dedicated servers, especially when it was advertised as focusing on the multiplayer as well. 

Overall score 5/10.

I've been a fan of the Sniper Elite titles since I first played V2. Owning all of them, including the Nazi Zombie Army titles & going so far as to buy this game even when my PC wasn't capable of running it.

The campaign is good, definitely entertaining, but I feel previous titles like SE3 (Africa) & SE4 (Italy) had done a better job with the story-telling. Co-op was a fun experience and I look forward to trying out the Invasion mode (If people even bother playing it). The game has Cross-Play which is great if you have friends that you want to play with on Co-op, but have decided to be lame and go for consoles. Although cross-play probably isn't so great for multiplayer (Aim assist and all that).

I haven't really found any bugs in the game, with the only noticeable recurring bug that I've found is when you take-down an enemy, some of these NPC's decide to clip through the floor / walls and disappear.
Another issue is the auto-saving. You will have to save regularly, (With F5 / Pause Menu) as the auto-saving isn't good at all.

The scenery is great and the graphical detail is decent, but there is some things that need fine tuning, like NPC's often being stuck with a ridiculous face whilst unconscious or dead.
Even though (In my opinion) there's a handful of disappointing things with this particular title, I'm definitely enjoying the story of the game and love the idea of non-lethal ammo & mines.

This is a game that should essentially be bought on at least a 30% discount because really, it's only a 7/10 at best.

5/5. The gameplay is not as refined or as smooth as Sniper Elite 4 or 3, but the core mechanics are exactly what you can expect. The stealth is great. The new weapon customization options definitely increases game time and complexity and allows you to customize your weapon to be either more lethal or stealthy depending on your preferred play style. However, all these features are good but they don't deserve a full score, what is really the cherry on top, in my opinion; is the Axis invasion gamemode. Playing stealthily or loudly can get dull, eventually you master it. However every 15 minutes or so an enemy sniper joins you singleplayer game with their own play style and skill level. forcing you to change your play style and outwit the other player. This adds a whole new depth to the game and truly captures that "Enemy at The Gates" feel.

The Ai can be either smart with flanking and shooting you in the back, or astoundingly stupid - so you end up over-preparing... assuming you can put up with an uninspiring and agonizingly slow tech and skill progression.  AI mainly relies on swamping you with so many Germans to shoot you run out of ammo and are simply swarmed.  As for the additions of the caricature angry American Ranger won over by your hero American protagonist (with the fake British identity and name), the sullen anorexic teenage French resistance leader, and the totally out of place black Scottish female resistance contact (which makes this virtue signalling BS beyond painful) with her bulging eye thyroid problem and blue truck which seems invisible to the Germans, this makes the Afrika edition look better than it was.

There is ~20-30 hours of content if you play on standard. The map design is very good, probably the best so far, it looks good, runs well in mission and has the classic feel we all love with some good updates to AI, UI and a lot of other things. Its fun, but its no Hitman 3 that's for sure!! Whats here is great, but there could be so much more. it almost needs to learn from hitman 3 and have the in-game achievements with fairly token unlocks to incentivise replaying missions to rethink and redo your kills for amusements sake. Also if you don't realise the kill missions require very specific methods of murder youll spend the entire game with 2-3 guns unlocked (if the game bugs like mine and doesn't unlock guns that require missions competition) 

BUT, a lot of the previous content from earlier games is pay-walled behind expensive DLC which doesn't add much. The DLC feels super lazy and money grabby. You get a few guns that were mostly free in previous versions of the game, a new map (despite maps being fairly easy to make as a lot of assets are easily recycled and skins galore, which makes no sense as in a single player game no one else sees the skins and in pvp no ones going to stop to admire you skin from 400m away....

The invasion aspect is mostly annoying and feels imbalanced. Either hide and wait out invaders or expect to randomly get shot/bush wookied while you try do objectives as players generally know how to easily camp and have all the advantages. Its an interesting feature, but needs work. It would almost be better if it was a multiplayer mode where lots of people spawn say 5v5 or 10v10, and Theres some kind of AI battle with objectives to force both sides to be more involved and have to choose between camping in a bush or winning the match. IDK just an idea

Sometimes knockdowns send corpses underground. I had such a case when I knocked down an enemy in a non-lethal method, and his body dropped down through the textures and drowned in seconds, lol.
Same with multi-level structures, like a bunker, if it has a few floors you may knock down an enemy, and his body will be dropped on a lower floor.

All in all, it's pretty clear - not a bad game in the end. Stealth, as it seemed, not particularly polished. Level of Splinter Cell from 2005. The game just does not push on thoughtful passing quietly at least because of the size of the maps (otherwise you'll just spend 3 days on one map) and because of the crowds of nazis that'll come for you if they detect you, you just get tired of fighting them off. So it's easier to take out all of them at once while you go through the map.
And so there are all sorts of things to pump your guns and additional missions as you explore the map.
Optimization is lame only in terms of video memory - the game needs more than 16 gb in 4K on ultra. I catch lags sometimes in the same place - when you squat or stand up.

В общем, яснопонятно. В целом, неплохая игра. Стелс, как показалось, не особо проработан. Уровень splinter cell 2005 года. Игра просто не подталкивает на вдумчивое прохождение втихую как минимум из-за размеров карт (иначе ты просто дня 3 будешь одну карту проходить) и из-за того, что когда все же палишься и на тебя сбегается тьма немчуры, то просто надоедает от них отбиваться. Уж очень зрячие. Поэтому проще сходу всех убирать сразу.
А так есть всякие штуки для прокачки пушек, доп.миссии по мере изучения карты.
Оптимизация хромает только в плане видеопамяти - игре надо больше 16 гб в 4K на ультре. Ловлю лаги порой на ровном месте - когда приседаешь или встаешь.
Эдакий Flashpoint/Arma на минималках, где не надо по часу лежать в кустах и выжидать, чтобы пройти мимо пары солдат.
Нужно отдать должное Rebellion за то, что не сдались и все еще тащат свой движок Asura и не перескакивают на паршивый Unreal Engine.

+ Great way to scratch a WW2 shooter itch.
+ A good looking game that's well optimised. Consistently runs at high FPS and doesn't seem to jerk or stutter at all.
+ Accommodates different play styles. Sniper only, run-and-gun, stealth/non-lethal.
+ Huge maps with different routes and several objectives. If you're planning a non-lethal/stealth run, prepare to spend several hours per map.
+ Granular difficulty controls, can easily fine tune to your specific tastes.
+ Unique multiplayer modes. Axis Invasions are the highlight; another player can enter your PvE mission and try to hunt you down, or you can do the same to someone else. Short queue times if you're invading. There's also a dedicated sniper mode called "No Cross"; essentially, two teams snipe at each other across the map.
- The story... exists. You're John Elite, you're running around France sabotaging Nazi plans. That's it.
- Cheeky to suggest there are nine maps when number nine is essentially a thirty second epilogue. In reality, there are eight (plus DLC) full fat campaign maps.
- AI a bit weird at times. Even with the increased aggressiveness setting, they sometimes don't seem too concerned about investigating dead bodies or trying to co-ordinate flanks. Other times, if spotted, you'll be shot at with laser accuracy across large distances by pistols and SMGs. Tanks like to camp and stare at you incessantly.
- Enemy footsteps don't seem to exist in this universe.
- Maps aren't completely open. There are some routes and paths that are deliberately blocked.
- Axis Invasions seem to happen at the worst possible time (at least for me), when a mistake has been made or there's already pressure from the AI. When I've invaded other games, it tends to be on earlier maps in the campaign, possibly with other players still figuring out the game.
- The several other multiplayer modes are dead. There were about seven or eight custom games at the time of writing, five of which were Rebellion servers with zero players. I didn't go in expecting a vibrant multiplayer community, but it's something to keep in mind.

I had fun with SE5 overall. Definitely do not pay full sticker price. Recommended on sale (£13.49/$14.99). Maybe look at SE4 first if you're unsure about the gameplay, it goes on sale more often at an even cheaper price.

Sniper Elite 5 - First Impression Review

I'm writing this as a Sniper Elite 4 vet, and you should read this if you have already played SE4. If you haven't, feel free to read it also.

The question is, "Should I spend my time on Sniper Elite 5?". The answer is Yes, if you're familiar with the Sniper Elite franchise.

Graphically wise, it's improved from the last game(which is Sniper Elite 4, by the way). The color is much more defined, although it didn't overshadow the last game. Texture wise, things such as rocks and foliages and buildings, are not much different from SE4, unless you're counting pixels. Water looks better, although not significantly. Ballistic looks more enjoyable. Kill cam is more intimate and more casual. Body movements have been improved: Karl now ascending/ descending stairs with careful steps rather than running/ stampeding through as seen in SE4. Sniper Rifle's Scopes has more natural sway to it. Soldiers can be spotted wearing watches, added more realism to it.
Conclusion, it's improved, the same way GOW Ragnarok compared to GOW. 

Gameplay is more or less the same. I would say that this game adopted several key mechanisms from The Last of Us. Infinite stones for distraction are now replaced with limited bottles. Infinite Satchel Charges from SE4 are now replaced with Satchel Charges picked up from battlefields(you can still carry an inhuman amount of them, however). SE5 now introduced work benches(again, The Last of Us), with significantly more weapon adjustments compared to SE3(rudimentary) or SE4(non-existent). 
You might have seen some reviews online saying that SE5 is not as big as SE4, which is debatable. I would say that the maps are more compact but still big. It still can stump an SE4 vet like me from time to time. 
Picking up weapons from battlefields is no longer something you can do freely as in SE4, but I like it as it's significantly realistic. You can't just pick up a Sniper Rifle from the field and fire it, it doesn't work like that. However, you're allowed to use it as Temporary, which is acceptable. There are many more varieties to pick up from the field as well: weapons with attachments that give you advantages. 
Weapon Wheel is the same.
God vision, or something called Enemy Position has also been replaced with zones of interest(a colored circle that signifies the whereabouts of an enemy). Why, hello there, Ghost Recon Wildlands, I have missed you. This makes it more important to tag enemies, as you're no longer given the Detective Vision back in SE4.
Iron Sight is now officially in the game. Love it.
You can now take out enemies with non-lethal melee technique as well. Guess that they're slowing down after all the gruesome close-combat takedowns back in SE4. 
There are also fewer enemies in SE5, compared to SE4. In SE4, thanks to God vision, you can take out an entire base of enemies, like 20 or 30 of them Nazis, but here in SE5, even 3 to 4 of them is already some struggle. I personally think it's more intimate.

Music is not a thing. The warrior of Rome motif in SE4 is no longer here. I don't miss it particularly, but this is also a different game anyway. I would say that the Alarm sounds remind me of Wolfenstein a lot. It's okay, i don't think people are too hung up on the music department for this game.

The game ran well on my dated machine! It heated up the machine even less than SE4, what a relief!. Kudos to you, Rebellion.

As of now, the complete edition is quite expensive, but i'm happy with my Deluxe Edition. Will be purchasing the full Edition in the future.

The game is good, i will greenlit it if you ask me. That's all I have to say for now.

If you loved Sniper Elite 4, you'll love this. Ignore all those negative reviews..
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Cons (that people say):
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To be honest, I am kinda torn. I love this game, even though it's really uneven - it does some things better than its predecessor (weapon customization for instance is a tad better than challenges-upgrades from 4th installment), while some it does worse (optimalization is rather below average). 

Worst offender is a price - I bought it on a sale, but still, managed to buy only one season pass with the vanilla game and it still cost me around 25$, pretty steep I daresay. I don't care for storyline, cause it was always mediocre at best in the series. GFX-wise, it's just a SE4 with some tweaks here and there - and by "tweaks" I can also mean "some textures don't load properly at times", though it's nothing gamebraking. What IS gamebraking, are bugs - sometimes enemies dissapear after a takedown, sometimes you can't take a proper aim at something with your scope, at times game can CTD or get laggy for a few seconds out of the blue. Also, to nitpick a bit - skill tree is even worse than SE4. Could be gone completely and nobody would even notice. Animations are a tad better, but still on the bad side. AI is more stupid than my boss. 

So yeah, to keep it simple and sum it up - game should have at least a half year more development time, but can still give you lots of fun. If you like killing nazis, it's for you. 

tl;dr - expensive and with bugs, but still worth it on sale and if you like killing nazis

If you are seen by one guy, all the others instantly react as if they all have telepathy.
This is the fifth in the franchise and this stuff is still 'a thing'.
Your character getting caught on small objects on the floor, which would not obstruct a human being's waking pace.

I'm enjoying it, but there's a lot of time where your enjoyment is completely thrown off, if not obstructed/overshadowed by the pain in the A** BS coded into it, which completely dismantles any semblance of immersive or enjoyable stealth.

It's great, until it's not.

I've only played on max difficulty/authentic. 

Perhaps lower difficulties permit gameplay features/aids which help to balance out the scale by mitigating the broken immersion, but if you're going to have an 'authentic' difficulty, you should probably strive as developers, to ensure your game is up to that standard.

You know, immersively authentic.

Not 'bugged out and tacky'.

I liked this game so much on PS5 (Fully platinumed it) that after complete came out and it is now shows as playable for Steam Deck that I'm looking forward to doing the same on PC. Game sucked most of 2022 away from me! Highly recommend turning off music, putting on good headphones, and playing on Authentic difficulty.

Things I love:
#1 By far over previous entries is Sound ranges and Suppressors. Some of these attachments are unrealistic for the time but greatly speed up play. No more hoping for a sound dampener or dealing with half the map knowing exactly where you are. This also applies to most Secondaries and Pistols.

#2 Aim Down Sights on all guns! Was very annoying in the older games that you couldn't do this!

#3 Souls-like Yager Invasions! You can invade or be invaded by another player. Fear not that it'll ruin your game... it auto saves when they first load in and you can choose to reset to before they loaded in if you die or from the last checkpoint (they do occur during invasions if it's safe enough). Also, take note that unless you are on authentic difficulty, you can see them through walls with focus and if they are far away the compass will point you to their direction. They don't get this advantage. Also, you have 0 ping so host has massive advantage. Also, both Karl and Jager should know that the Jager always spawns pretty close to Karl. I think the furthest I've ever seen was like 150 meters away.

#4 Despite what the individual reviews of the DLC says, most of the DLC maps are better for advanced play than the vanilla ones. Also... IMHO the Lee Enfield is the best stealth rifle in the game and that's only available as DLC... get complete or Season passes and it won't feel like a ripoff.

Could be better:
#1 If you are ANY model of Karl, his monologuing can give you away to an invader. Wish you could turn it off so you can enjoy the Karl Gillie.

#2 I wish you could see your single player Invader kill count.

#3 Wish you could rate your match and send some GG's to Invader or Karl. You can request rematches but that seems to be it.

#4 Wish there was some kind of time limited reward or something for Invasions. Once earned all the cosmetics for Karl or the Jager, no real incentive to keep doing it other than for fun.

Anyway, I have no major issues with game... definitely my pick from 2022. I have a youtube playlist of mostly short videos if you want to see some of this in action.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLOhQZU0YF0L7AUWTZ4nzPq4-E7Dl2UOzp

The game is ok. Can be entertaining for a few hours.  

Multiplayer is a bit frustrating, sometimes maybe good, sometimes maybe shit. Hacking can be frequent. And obvious. And the balance is non-existent. Peer 2 Peer Hosting is the worst idea ever, with the match just ending if a hosts leave mid-match. Happens so frequently... that you just get used to it. Luckily XP earned is instant, only xp loss would be a possible match win bonus.  

Single player campaign is quite lengthy. The maps are a mixed batch. Some are good, some are not.  
I would say more good than bad maps. But only a few that encourage Sniping. Then again, I don't see this as a sniping game, as much as a Stealth game.  
Difficulty customization are very detailed, and allow for great personal customization. Only miss is a Authentic Plus Mode, seen in Sniper Elite 4.   

Survival, it's not as hard as previous games, but still quite fun overal. Higher difficulties can become a challenge, as are playing anything but solo. 

Invasion mode is a nice welcome, albeit the huge nerf to the invader since release. It adds a little challenge. However once you're quite skilled at invasions. Matches can be completely crap, frustrating and boring. Or Amazing. Not really anything in between. 
Due to the fact, you'll get matched against players playing for their first time. And players who've spend the past 8 hours on a single map, gathering every single explosive they could find to make it a guaranteed deathtrap. And they'll just be camping in some cuboard, waiting for you to step on a mine.  But once a match is good, youll be guaranteed to rematch multiple times.  

Weapon customization. 
Ok, so the most unrealistic part if you ask me. But then again, Not an unwelcome part. 
Unlocking of new weapons, or weapon modifications are done through challenges ingame, encouraging replaying levels. And compared to the 4 challenges per weapon that would "upgrade" it in previous games. This allows for more persoinalized equipment. Very noticable when picking up someone else their rifle or SMG in multi-player modes. Often, you'll just not like the feel of a weapon.  
And allows for a more wide style of gameplay, from full assault to stealth purist.  

But honestly, The game is not bad. Could be better, but have seen worse.

With some reservations, though. I find SE5 is less than SE4, which is a disappointment. 
Some issues I have with SE5 are:
- Awkward character movement and difficulty with terrain, often resulting in moonwalking against invisible obstacles, only being able to vault over low walls in certain places, things like that (Mission 8 is a nightmare in this sense). 
- Weapons and upgrades: right in the first 3 or 4 missions you can already get the best weapon set-up for the whole game and anything after that is basically useless. Most upgrades and weapon unlocks (some of which require Kill Challenges) really represent no improvement and often send you back down a notch or two, making them  more a frustration than a reward.
- Characters..... ok, woke and all that crap, but a black Scottish special ops woman in WW2? Stretch things much? The Scots had the Black Guard but there were no women there and anyway, they were fighting in Africa. If you're going to throw historical accuracy entirely out the window (I mean, more than you already are with all the ridiculous secret weapons and Möller character), you might as well make the game about aliens on a different planet.
- There's more, but I don't want to drag on
I recommend playing the game but don't expect too much (especially from the final mission.....)

To be completely honest, I enjoyed Sniper Elite 4 more. This feels like a step backwards, if not just recycled material with a premium price tag. Graphics, gameplay, features, everything is identical to SE4 or worse - For example, there are now invisible walls GALORE in this game compared to its predecessor. Including most bushes and shrubbery. Yup, that's right. And they axed being able to run while crouched. Get ready to spend hours on missions because you have to crouch everywhere. The X-ray cams seem so generic too. It felt in SE4 there was more variety to what you saw in terms of organ damage. 
My biggest gripe though, is that the Developers gave us NOTHING new - improved NOTHING - and charged us full price. Too add insult to injury, get ready to pay big time for DLC missions and weapons - which there is very little variety in the game. 
Overall disappointing. The devs may have lost me with this iteration of the franchise. It seems to me they knew they could be lazy, so they were.

影响游戏乐趣的几大通点问题：
（1）升级系统不好：多数玩家任务过40级就无法升级了，通过纯粹多人游戏（生存模式不算，生存模式无助于升级）升级非常虐心，游戏延迟、噪音大，脑残多，几乎就是比显卡、比网速，且游戏模式一成不变，同质化严重，吸引力会逐渐下降；
（2）平衡性不够好：入侵模式下，入侵一方无法拾取武器，无法开启屏息辅助，而防守一方却都是可以的，相当于开挂，这样很不好；我敢说，这游戏一旦把入侵模式做好，做得更具有挑战性后，游戏将非常有意思。比如，我提供一个思路：现在不是打战役只能提升到40级吗？可以改变为：如准许入侵的前提下，在有人真的入侵和打胜了的情况下，通关后可以继续升级到41级及以上；同样地，入侵一方如果赢得了比自己级别更高的对手，积累到一定赢盘数也可以升级到41级及以上——那这样一定会大幅度吸引老玩家来反复重温已通关战役，这样在线人数多了，也会吸引新玩家参与入侵模式——  《狙击精英》系列的亮点不正应是结合大地图的【对抗性】+【策略性】互动吗？多人游戏那种不叫对抗性，那是一堆人投机取巧+轮盘赌，一露头就被干死，没有什么战术性和策略性可言，我敢说《狙击精英》非要指望走《CS》系列那种模式，是在错误的道路上越走越远，注定会被淘汰。
（3）武器系统不好：各类武器可供升级核心功能的选择不多，升级或改装后功能差别不大，开发团队热心于制作一堆枪械皮肤，其实真正的铁杆FPS玩家不太看中皮肤这类东西，何况你皮肤设计得也不好看，关键不同皮肤真的仅仅是皮肤，对在游戏中的功能提升或转型毫无贡献，纯粹就是走少女外形控路线，没有实际意义，升级经常生了个寂寞。早起玩家为了解锁部分枪械功能，还会努力打拼，一旦解锁完毕，就没有动力玩下去了。
（4）能力升级系统：与武器系统类似，早起玩家为了获得升级点以提升能力，还会努力打拼，一旦解锁完毕，就没有动力玩下去了。当所有玩家都是40级+，打多人游戏又非常痛苦，觉得毫无区分度，玩着玩着也就没什么吸引了；
（5）武器更新太慢：我能理解开发团队想通过每次升级一两款枪械的这类“添油战术”，来多次吸引玩家买武器包或季度包，这么干本无可厚非，但你们给出的武器系统问题在于，要是武器种类有限，那咱就把每种武器的配件和升级系统做得更丰富，更自由，更耐玩，以使武器系统更有生命力一些；要么就开发更丰富的武器，现在即使是完整版内的武器也太少了，连加兰德A1、1888式这类都没有，有点太不思进取了；
总之，《狙击精英》系列这款游戏的开发团队及其股东，应该扪心自问，想想清楚热爱狙击类的玩家群体到底想要什么游戏，你们能够给这么多新老玩家带来什么体验，是不能自已地一味跟风丧失狙击游戏的魅力，还是坚持底线努力为玩家们献上一款更为符合狙击战对抗性和策略性特色的游戏。
最后，我还是给出【推荐】，批评不是为了扼杀和劝人止步，而是为了市场真的能识别出什么好的狙击类游戏。
既然事拿来售卖的商品，就请不要总辜负玩家对游戏的热爱！！！！

[h1]A Masterpiece Unveiled - Sniper Elite 5 Review[/h1]

[b]As an ardent fan of the Sniper Elite series, I've been captivated by its immersive gameplay and meticulous attention to historical detail from the very beginning. With the release of Sniper Elite 5, my admiration for this franchise has reached new heights. Set against the backdrop of war-torn France in 1944, this latest installment continues to follow the journey of the iconic Karl Fairburne as he battles the enigmatic "Project Kraken."

From the moment I stepped into the virtual world of Sniper Elite 5, I was greeted by breathtaking vistas and meticulously crafted environments. The landscapes are a testament to the developer's commitment to recreating the atmosphere of wartime France. Each mission is a marvel in itself, with sprawling maps that invite exploration and a level of detail that leaves no corner unexplored.

One of the most striking features of Sniper Elite 5 is the painstakingly recreated architecture of the era. Every street, building, and structure feels authentic, transporting players back in time to the tumultuous 1940s. The commitment to historical accuracy enhances the immersion and makes every encounter within the game world feel incredibly genuine.

What truly sets Sniper Elite 5 apart is the sheer diversity and scale of each mission. Every mission is a work of art, intricately designed to be visually stunning, unique, and endlessly engaging. The addition of new gameplay mechanics, such as the ability to hide in high grass, scale walls and pipes, and conceal fallen enemies, has completely transformed the strategic landscape. These innovations demand players to adapt and strategize like never before, leading to an entirely fresh experience.

The introduction of "starting positions" is a brilliant stroke that empowers players to unlock new vantage points as they progress through missions. This not only enriches replayability but also allows for a dynamic evolution of playstyle and strategy. These starting positions have become an invaluable tool for mastering missions, ultimately enhancing the overall enjoyment of the game.

The arsenal of weaponry and accessories at players' disposal is truly remarkable. The inclusion of different types of ammunition adds an extra layer of tactical depth, influencing decision-making and encouraging players to explore new strategies. The hallmark feature of the series, the X-ray kill cam, has been refined to perfection in Sniper Elite 5. The bone-crushing realism of every shot, whether from a rifle, pistol, or machine gun, is astonishing. The level of detail in the depiction of bodily organs during these sequences is both shocking and awe-inspiring.

Visually, Sniper Elite 5 is a marvel, with stunning locations and landscapes that push the boundaries of what modern gaming can achieve. The game's graphics are a testament to the developer's dedication to creating a visually immersive experience that does justice to the era it portrays.

Furthermore, the extensive range of post-launch DLC missions is a testament to the developer's commitment to keeping players engaged and entertained long after the game's initial release. This consistent support has added considerable value to the game and ensured that fans like me remain enthralled.

The multiplayer experience in Sniper Elite 5 is a well-crafted affair, with a robust anti-cheat system that has virtually eliminated the scourge of cheaters. This has rejuvenated the multiplayer community and breathed new life into the competitive aspect of the game.

In closing, it's clear that words alone can't encompass the entirety of Sniper Elite 5's brilliance. This game is a testament to Rebellion's dedication to excellence, and as a devoted fan, I am immensely grateful for the opportunity to traverse the battlefields of wartime France with Karl Fairburne once again. Sniper Elite 5 is not just a game; it's an experience that has left an indelible mark on my gaming journey. Kudos to Rebellion for crafting a masterpiece that has brought immeasurable joy to fans like me.[/b]

All the sniper elite games are good never a bad one. This one changes a lot of things from 4 such as a basic skill tree, player invasion, and workbeneches. I have only played this game in single player mode so far.

I got SE5 and the season one pass on sale, having completed all of the content of SE4 multiple times (but not managing to get all achievements - especially the time limited ones).  The game doesn't disappoint.  Lots of varied weaponry and lots of different approaches.  Heavy weaponry is much more satisfying than the limited options available in SE4.

It's not completely open word, there are some things I'd like to climb on that I can't.  There are parts of the environment that I'd like to interact with that I can't (like turning over a cart to provide cover).  The audio dialog repeats when you replay missions.

What I have found though is that there is enough in it to keep me coming back ... can I master this weapon, can I try completing the mission with different equipment, or melee killing all the snipers (not an achievement though).

The game lets you save as well as periodically saving when you're not in combat.  You can have a relaxing session picking of enemies at range, or running in front of them and letting rip with your SMG (or the MG42 you have 'liberated'), or sneaking in close and using a silenced (or not so silenced) sidearm.  Then you can save your mission and come back to it, or just abandon it and restart another time.  And you can choose your difficulty level so the game becomes rewarding and challenging in different ways.

Above all I have had great fun, and it continues to be fun.  Isn't that what games should be?

I did enjoy the new customization options but I felt they were a little too ridged. If you're special forces in WWII, why can't you put an American 16X scope on a Kar98k? I understand mounting systems were different back then and not universal like the Picatinny rail systems on rifles today, but someone could've forged a custom bracket to mount your scope for you I'm sure. Do you need a 16X zoom scope on the majority of missions? Absolutely not, but the option to use one would've been nice.

Well, to start with, I am fan of the series. After wonderful SE4 I was looking forward for set up in France, as that country is way closer to my mind when it comes to WW2.

Well, to be honest... the game is just mediocre at best. It has no epic "feeling" of war, as back in previous versions of Sniper Elite franchise. Technically the game looks as good as SE4, but only if textures load correctly. Yes, there are loading textures issues a year after release, even though, the game literally looks the same as SE4 from 2017. Music is also worse compared to Karl's adventures in Italy. Hell, the series were never known for good story lines, but this one blew my mind as one of the worst ones I have ever seen in any game. Karl Fairbourne after this iteration should get retired.

Rebellion has already proven that they can make a great games, but this one seems like it was rushed and released way too fast, and never really finished the game. The maps are great (at least in base game), especially map in mission number 3. However you can also feel that the entire great design of maps wasn't correctly used.

And the last part is pricing. Hell, I bought it at somewhere around 60% discount, yet imho it is still overpriced. I have deluxe edition, so missing season 2, but s1 is already bad enough that it doesn't encourage to buy another one, unless it will cost somewhere around 1-2$. But again, having two season passes in this game, that feels unpolished, with two crappy-dlc maps feels like rip off done by Rebellion.

While I had moments I loved in this game, and spent over 42 hours playing it, I suggest you to wait until price drops to 10$ for this to buy. And that is, including both season passes.

This is not a bad game... if you've never played SE4 (coming from a person who has 100% completed Sniper Elite 4). This game has a lot of minor irritations that make me question if the devs knew what the hell they were doing.

Here are a [i]few[/i] things (rambling incoming):
[list]
[*]-No crouch running
[*]-Finite bottles instead of infinite rocks
[*]-Want to switch a weapon in your loadout? If you're not at a workbench, then fuck you. Oh sure you can grab a weapon from a body, but after that one mag you discard it. So say you have a welrod, but you've screwed up and now you're in a firefight. Too bad kid, you're stuck with the welrod unless you find one of max 3 workbenches around the map (trust me, you won't be anywhere near them when you need one)
[*]-Speaking of weapons, I really don't like how suppressors work. Why would I want to use subsonic ammo with a weapon that has no suppressor? I don't. In SE5 you have to commit with what playstyle you want to go with. You can't do it like SE4 and use subsonic ammo when in a pinch and when you just need to take down 1 guy. Nope, now either you customize the weapon to have a low noise range, or you don't. Trying to balance it doesn't work and you just end up with an inferior weapon. And yes, while you CAN change this mid-mission at a workbench, have fun going to one of 3 fixed locations to change it.
[*]-The worst autosaves I've ever experienced in a game. EVER (game doesn't autosave so if you fuck up have fun redoing the last 10 minutes!). SE4 got this right, so why doesn't this game?!
[*]-Explain to me how an armored car can survive 2 teller mines and a block of TNT
[*]-My MP40 couldn't fire through some thin wood. Hey I guess they have to justify all the ammo types.
[*]-Static alarms are just worse in every way compared to the radio operators in SE4.
[*]-Why the absolute fuck doesn't your character default to the same stance you had before? If I crouch and pick up a body, then why does my character stand up after dropping the body. This can be the very reason you would get spotted if you drop a body say in a patch of tall grass and Karl thinks it's a good idea to stand up.
[*]-Let me disable the ugly white outline when I'm in foliage
[*]-Why do I have to interact with every item manually to pick it up? Just make me auto pick it up when I'm near it. Why wouldn't I want more items/ammo?
[*]-Why can enemies block a takedown? Karl is canonically an absolute unit that has destroyed entire operations single handedly. How can he not melee a random guy?
[*]-Terrible feedback and control. A lot of the times when I miss my pistol or sniper shot and want to switch to my SMG, it just doesn't. Same with aiming after reloading or looting a body. This game feels very clunky and shooting enemies with your smg/pistol doesn't feel good (unless getting a well placed headshot).
[*]-AI is arguably worse than in SE4
[*]-Some enemies never moving and standing in one of only a handful of ways to progress (you're forced to either kill him ranged or find a different route for stealth)
[*]-Don't bother with third person shooting. Since they now have first person shooting, trying to headshot a guy in third person is almost impossible. Weapons are peashooters and have terrible accuracy. Also the first and third person crosshairs don't line up sometimes.
[*]-You can't shoot in third person with snipers anymore, but seeing as that doesn't work anyways why bother I guess.
[*]-Bad maps. Maps in SE4 were big and were pretty complex. Here a lot of the maps are just basic flatlands with some buildings. The second mission is a joke with how small and empty it is (and don't get me started on the 'final' mission). There are a lot of 'zones', and rarely are the maps truly open. You usually get funneled to 2 or 3 chokepoints.
[*]-Poor weapon roster. I can already see the 3 season passes this game will get, with a 'weapon pack' consisting of only a single weapon (seems that atm they are just re-releasing the exact same DLC weapons as in SE4. These should have been in the base game).
[*]-Weapon attachments look awful
[*]-Karl won't shut the fuck up. I don't have to hear that 'I have to move' every time I'm in combat or that 'this foliage will keep me hidden' every goddamn mission. Or when picking up a weapon I don't have to hear Karl loudly comment on him picking up said weapon.
[*]-I often pick up enemy weapons on accident when trying to loot corpses. Ffs just make it either a hold or change the default bind so that they're different. Actually this is also the case with either using the key to open the door or placing a satchel charge. SE4 again got this right.
[*]-Rip tripwires and S-mines. Now you only have a non-lethal option.
[*]-No leveling past level 40
[*]-Enemies often instantly begin firing at you when they spot you. In SE4 if you were close they would first do a shocked animation, giving you enough time to quickly kill them before they would alert anyone else. Enemies will also sometimes keep firing while in the takedown animation.
[*]-Why is non-lethal an option? It's Sniper Elite. You kill nazis. You're not forced to do this so it isn't THAT big of a deal.
[*]-Bugs. This game has some minor but frequent bugs. It's still hard to properly go for a corner takedown and I once couldn't melee a dude who was leaning out of a window fsr, and then EVERYONE was alerted :)
[/list]

It really feels like the devs had to make you weaker in order to 'balance' the gameplay. In a lot of ways this game is a downgrade. It also kinda feels like the devs changed random things just because.

SE4 with all DLC is only around 9 bucks during sales, which is an infinitely better deal than buying this. If you (for some reason) do want to try SE5, then [b]DO NOT BUY [u]ANY[/u] DLC[/b].

Things I do like:
[list]
[*]-Enemies can't hear you through multiple floors anymore, so no worries about alerting an enemy that's a floor above/below you
[*]-Option to set satchel charge fuse time
[*]-Symbols aren't censored
[*]-You can sabotage vehicles for soundmasking
[*]-Reload mechanic is alright
[*]-Seeing character bios even when dead. I always enjoy reading random info about soldiers I encounter (before I brutally murder them without mercy)
[/list]

This is the first Sniper Elite game that you should get for the multiplayer, not the campaign. The servers are still somewhat active and it's genuinely fun to fight people, as is the co-op PvE mode. Invasion is also very fun on both sides, so give it a shot and enable it on your campaign runs (don't be afraid to turn it off though if it gets frustrating)

The actual campaign is disappointing though, and unlocks don't carry over between campaign and multiplayer so there is no real advantage to playing it for that reason. Levels are often too big for their own good and full of invisible walls and closed off buildings, level 3 especially is a maze.

The main benefit to SE5 over SE4 is the weapon customisation, which is absolutely brilliant despite being sectioned off between PvP and PvE. The detail of options is excellent, and it makes it fairly easy to take any weapon and make it fit most roles - at last the Welrod is not the only stealth pistol option.

If you want to shoot virtual nazis, play SE4. If you want to shoot your fellow gamers, play SE5.

The game is excellent. There are pros and some awful cons that need addressed, but if you're a fan of Sniper Elite you will love the game. Multiplayer campaign is so much fun

Pros:
1. Full multiplayer campaign, and several fun other multiplayer modes. Woo, friends!
2. Unique music for each level with varying levels of intensity based on combat
3. Sniping feels good, kill shots return in their typical glory
4. Unlocked perks in single player are useful and welcome
5. Weapon customization is fun - lots of detailed specs to drool over and really create your own play style
6. Plenty to do in each massive map. 
7. Plenty of unlockables, hidden locations and items, lore - great stuff
8. Beautiful environments/graphics
9. Very good replay value - higher difficulties that introduce fun mechanics (no indicator of your location on map, reloading a magazine throws out the bullets you left in the dropped mag, etc), different starting locations to unlock on each level
10. Steam deck plays awesome - i lock at 40 fps with medium settings and looks fantastic

------------------------
CON - THIS NEEDS FIXED YESTERDAY AND UNBELIEVABLE IT STILL ISN'T, ESPECIALLY WITH THE AMOUNT OF COMPLAINTS ALL OVER FORUMS:

HUGE ISSUE - if you are going to play on a controller, prepare to rip your hair out. The joystick deadzones ARE MASSIVE - and you cannot alter them in any way. I'm talking, i can move both joysticks in full 360s without my aimer or character even moving. It is MISERABLE. Fine tuned aiming is not possible at all. You move the joystick - get nothing, move it slightly more - still nothing - move it EVEN more, then suddenly you've way overpassed your target. I cannot emphasize how frustrating this is.

If you're on Steam Deck, you can at least use the track pad as a mouse, adjust the sensitivity to suit your aiming, and when you zoom in just use that for precise aiming. It works, but doesn't feel particularly great. But on any standard controller - you're going to get very frustrated, very quickly.
-----------------------

Other Cons:
1. No more crouched jogging - you move very slow crouched and can only jog standing up......what though??? Why?? Please bring this back
2. Unable to swap weapons for keeps in missions - you can pick up enemy weapons, steal its ammo, or use the one mag, but then you drop it
3. Steam Deck doesn't have anti-cheat so no multiplayer modes or Axis Invasion is playable...bummer
4. AI can be derpy - for example they're looking for you then take cover at a bail of hay next to a wall and poke their head to aim while just staring at the wall directly in front of them

Sniper elite 5 is very meh but still decent enough to get a recommendation, it's the AA franchise that's never really deviates from it's established gameplay for better or worse. 

This game has no surprises and if anything might be a little worse than 4. There is basically very little change, you still play as Karl who's bland as fuck, you still sneak around nazis whilst mortal kombat xray-ing them in the nuts with your sniper and you still continue the trend of picking a country and making that the theme of the game. 

And it's perfectly fine. Just that though, fine. It's the sorta game my dad would enjoy, it gives just enough challenge and diversity to be engaging but doesn't overwhelm you with options, plus it has harder difficulties for those who find medium a little too easy. 

The issue I have is that you can cleary see this game has some jank. It's got decent environments but character models are weak, music is decent but voice acting is not and the character animations are better than ever but still a bit janky. 

The issue I have is this game feels like it really limits your ability to be a sniper and feels more like it's trying to be hitman with it's open environments and options for killing targets, it is a weird mix up of hitman and metal gear solid 5 whilst struggling to be as good as either and also trying to remember the game is about sniper kills. 

Look it's very decent fun on sale and I can certainly see the appeal but this is the game that has given me sniper elite fatigue, think I'll just stick with zombie army for now.
