This is a good game. Pretty fun, but also sometimes pretty fking annoying. 

Sniper Elite? More like Silenced Pistol Elite. Like bruh. Anytime you fire a rifle, or even anything other than the silenced 1911 enemies will swarm you, and not just a few, legitimately about 50 all at once. 

Another thing to note - Why are SMG's completely useless outside of 2.3 centimeters away? the recoil / accuracy is completely out of control. You cannot hit a thing unless you shoot one tap at a time. Also why can you hit an enemy straight through the heart 3 times and they just flinch and move on like it was nothing? This has been a problem in the last 2 sniper elite games as well but it definietyl still happens here too. 

Next gripe - the maps are so big that it's completely overwhelming in my opinion. I enjoy branching paths, and different options for stealth, but the maps are so large it almost feels like a chore. Think of a hit man level but 3x as big. Of course this is my opinion, but I preferred the map design on sniper elite 4 much better.

Another thing - Enemies will legit spawn near you after you clear an area, and the WILL kill you. 

So basically - not enough "sniping" sidearms are almost completely useless outside of headshots or pointblank, gigantic overwhelming maps. and in a lot of ways this is a re hash of the same game we've played since sniper elite 3 and 4. 

 Even with my complaints, I do think this is a great game. and I had a fun time with it. I finished in about 9 hours. While it was frustrating at times, the exploration is vast and you might need to play a few times through to see everything in a certain level -
This is more of a splinter cell meets ww2 type of game, and less of a sniper game. If that's what you are looking for though, I think you will love this. Oh, also the graphics are quite good.  

Might replay in a year or two.

Cheers

This is the SE I always wanted after SE1 ;-)

This is the sequel I've always expected in modern times and now I finally got it with a FOV slider. The FOV in SE2/3/4 made these games almost unplayable for me, there was no mod and Rebellion refused to address this issue for so long. But now we finally have it, an SE that really gives you all the freedom you've ever wanted and it's just a great game. 

I especially love these extremely large and detailed maps, made with so much attention to detail and hidden things. Depending on your playstyle, you can waste hours on a single mission. I personally prefer to play stealth with a bit of action here and there. Well, let's face it, the action happens when I do a stupid thing and all hell breaks loose, and that's where this game shines in my opinion. If that happens, it doesn't mess up the whole mission. It's always like having a small battlefield, on the larger battlefield. It's not realistic, but it's still fun. Nobody wants to lose their mission because of a mistake or reload afterwards. At least I personally like to live with my mistakes in this game and the game is perfectly designed for that. 

I have to mention it again, the maps are insanely cool, there is so much to discover, even beyond the side objectives. I can't imagine how much work it was to finish all these maps and make them work with everything on them. I haven't beaten the game yet, but now, after about 15 hours, I'm already giving it a 4/5 considering I had it on sale for only $17

(Please no more SE without FOV slider)

AMAZING GAME.

I have played every Sniper Elite game since the start, but never really took to them. I think this was due to Sniper Elite's poor graphics compared to other games on the market at the time of their release(s) as well as very generic/bland story lines.

However, Sniper Elite 5 has approved upon all of the above, MASSIVELY. Playing on my 2560x1440 display, with all ultra settings, along with NVIDIA filters to make the game really pop, SE5 really does look fantastic.

The animations of movement, shooting and everything in between has gotten so much better. The audio has improved massively, I love the sounds the guns make when reloading/bolting. The graphical fidelity, the audio, everything is just so much more crisp and clear compared to SE4. The story line involving operation Kraken is deep, believable and had me hooked to the very end.

The only not so positive things I have to say about this game is that there are only 9 missions which, given how good you are at the game, can be completed really quite quickly, as I completed the entire game in just half a day (with plenty of breaks included in that time).

Also, the online connection on co-op campaign leaves much to be desired. I play on PC and my girlfriend plays on PS5. Whenever we played co-op, we could see each others' players lagging across our screens, when we were not lagging ourselves. Also, there were any cases where one of us would pick up and move a body to hide it, but on the other persons' screen the body is still there, causing confusion when a guard finds a body that you thought you hid. It is worth noting that we both have fibre internet with very strong connections.

Overall, I would rate this game an 8.5/10. I deducted 1 point for the lack of missions, as well as 0.5 points for the online connection (it seems an easy fix, taking away 1 whole point seemed a bit harsh).

I've been very fortunate to understand that this game changes in most every mission.  I started each game with different weapons, most of all locations, and what I found it required changing a tactic.  I agree with one member that if you go into guns blazing, you may find getting killed quickly.  I feel that the understanding of weapon capabilities is also important because secondary weapons is required many times in close quarters.  Is the game perfect?  No, especially at the beginning when there was bugs, which is not new.  I was always treated by the staff with their desire to fix the problems I encountered.  The graphics are excellent and the additional DLC missions truly fun, some more challenging then others.  The final mission just arrived and it has been fun, especially changing locations created new tactics, one especially places the player in almost instant combat.  I'm hoping that the staff will continue with season add on, perhaps implementing new weapons, most of all continue being the professional and courteous people they have demonstrated towards me and even a criticism or two from me that never changed their focus to improve the game. I like the game, but, significant caveats and/or warnings:

#1 - This isn't about sniping much of the time. Thus far, most kills are probably under 100m, and a large number are even under 50m. Scoped rifles almost seem like a liability in some missions... the first mission, rounding corners constantly and going through narrow bunkers, I used a Thompson and a MG-42 most of the mission. Soooo.... more like SMG-Elite 5, especially compared to the previous game, SE 4, where a number of missions did have larger open areas to snipe from.

#2 - I read reviews about invisible walls, but that's not really it. The problem is the clipping is wildly chaotic. Sometimes, I can walk right up to a hedge... other times, I'm colliding with it despite the graphics showing another 6-8 feet of space before I should be touching it at all. This makes sniping over hedges and low walls a pain. Not so much an issue of navigation (mini-map tells you basically what can be moved across), but more an issue of sloppy clipping design around some areas of terrain.

#3 - Invasions aren't my thing. Played with them off the whole time so far, so one of the major changes of the game I am not even really experiencing. I don't want to play MP, so, that's a change that is lost on me I guess.

#4 - Movement feels worse than SE 4. I'm either running too fast, walking to slow, or crouch-walking about right. Karl will just freak out at full speed trying to find the angle to open a door sometimes, so hitting the Z key to walk or Ctrl to crouch is how I slow down when I need to, but it's too slow for advancing forward all that far. Speed of movement is a little off.


Overall, though, it's a fun game if you approach it as a combo of Wolfenstein and Hitman. It feels a lot like another universe where Wolfenstein is less dark and Hitman is less stealthy. I really enjoy blasting away with the SMGs and throwing grenades and using traps... but I'm not sure that's what players were expecting, especially since SE 4 had much more open maps. SE 5 still has those sniping mechanics, but after a fun little practice with the 1,000 meter target in the training area, I've since been making most shots, often with SMGs, at a distance under 100m, which is a bit odd. But that's how the map design pushes the player to play. Even the DLC maps sometimes feel not that open, with buildings and corners to clear more often than large open horizons.

Again, really fun, but not that much sniping despite the name.

I get off work around midnight, I might do a few beers after work, I may come right home. Either way, I get immersed in the game. Before I know it, it's 4:00 am. The graphics are nice, the sound as well. It's enjoyable. I've purchased all the missions as far as I know. I just finished the Kraken awakes. By far that has been my favorite. 

A critical review? I'll say not being able to climb over a lot things is ridiculous. There are things you can do in some places but not others. I know there are limits the programmers have to include but it would be nice if you could climb over a lot of things. A box in front of front of a stairway after I just climbed up a vine trellis or scaled some crates? I should be able to get over the box. 

The enemy AI, yeah, not consistent. I know they wanted unique experiences and give you weapons options, but I do not agree with all the damage the weapons provide. Regardless, the game is pretty, the world is large, the tidbits about enemy soldiers you watch with binoculars is a treat.

This game was fun until I was flooded by an ocean of game breaking bugs. We are talking about stuff like not being able to fire your gun, persisting through save games!! How can stuff like this not be discovered during testing? Even worse, I found a youtube video complaining about the very same issue from May. It is now almost August and it is still in the game. The bug triggered twice in the same map even. That is just not good enough. :(

This isn't the game you think it is. It's not bad, but it's not a game about being a sniper.
There are precious few sniping spots in the missions, and very few objectives that demand usage of your sniper skills. The levels are quite constrained compared to the previous game, and there's a LOT of space that isn't traversable or usable.
Player movement is worse than previous games - the environment is much more visually 'noisy' now, and mantle/jump is less consistent. There are often knee-high obstacles you can't step over, but can't mantle either. There are also lots and lots of places where you can't jump/hang, but it seems like you should be able to. The cover system is improved, but still prone to nasty bouts of stickiness at the worst possible times.
I can't speak to the invasion system - maybe it's the secret sauce that makes this a 9/10 - but I can't see how it improves the base gameplay. There's already very little sniping, having another player trying to hunt you down is only going to make it more tedious to peel the onion on these levels.
The upgrade system, previously only tied to objectives, is now ALSO tied to finding hidden objects in levels, which makes it even more likely that you'll go through most of the game without seeing a lot of the content than previous games.
The 'special target' system is good - giving specific kill requirements adds the thimbleful of extra thought to their deaths that makes it more than just another speedbump in the missions.
The 'targets of opportunity' that show up as optional objectives are nice, but I found only one mission where it wasn't guaranteed that you'd be given those objectives through normal play.
Adding multiple spawn points to each mission is a wierd extra system to spend time on - there's basically no variation in how the missions play out, I'm not sure why Rebellion thought anyone would want to play them more than once. If you've gotten all the objectives, you've seen everything the mission has to offer.

In conclusion - This feels like Rebellion wanted to make a Hitman game with asymmetric multiplayer. It's not that, it's about 30-40% of that, and in the process they lost most of what made Sniper Elite 4 a good game. I'd have gladly paid 60$ for "Sniper Elite 4: 10 more missions edition," but this isn't even close.

It's... fine for 10$, but it clearly cost way too much to make to sell it for 10$.

I've really enjoyed the Sniper Elite Saga since its early beginnings, playing coop since Berlin over Africa, Italy and now France. However I just couldn't catch the sniper fever in the 5th game. I played the first four maps and the setting, the targets, everything became worse after the very first mission. The first mission let's you play in Normandy, it's a coastal area, small hills, a tiny village, a big radar station, some orchards. I explored every tiny corner of that map, I adored it. 

Then came the second mission. You start in a foresty area and have multiple ways to reach the castle/manor. So far, so good. The target and every other mission objective is inside the manor. Not in the perimeter of it, inside a multi-floor manor. You have two options, either sneak for an hour or accidentally triggering the alarm, going in full rambo with your sub machine gun. To finish the mission you have to get into a specific room, very unsnipery attitude if you ask me.

I thought to myself alright, maybe this one mission is the exception, let's try the next one. Your target? Get into a highly secured cathedral. Walled of. With tight street corners, a lot of corners, barely any free sight. Tiny bridges. Oh and you have to go all in, inside the temple on the very top floor. Snipers on choke points. But, what, why? You have a lot of silenced weapons, even some non-lethal ones, but what's the point if you have to kill specific guards, get discovered and the whole map escalates to a warzone. The coop and the new pvp campaign mode are fun, so is the customization, but the DLC mania is really over the top. I've stopped playing it.

I got nearly 20 hours into the game but haven't even finished the first level yet.

The axis invader mode is pure crack cocaine. I can hardly describe how much fun it is - I have already maxed out all the rewards you can get (100 kills) and still want to play it even more.

For me the 17 bucks was already worth it purely for the invasion mode, but now I still have an entire single player campaign to look forward to!

75/100: Sniper Elite is now a familiar ride and somehow the signature slow-mo bullet kill-cam never gets old. This iteration is quite versatile. Snipe from afar, run and gun up close, stealth around and go stab mode for a bit. The levels are quite nicely done in general, large with some great sniping lines, multiple objectives, and plenty of nooks and crannies to explore for secrets.

The AI is pretty dumb. Classic shooting gallery stuff, running back and forth aimlessly and popping their heads out of cover to give you a target. But I suppose that's what makes it fun in the end. There are some customisable difficulty settings allowing you to choose how much the game assists you and some other handicaps for those who enjoy the punishment. 

It's good for a couple of runs with a buddy but doesn't hold much replayability as a single-player game unless you want to chase achievement medals for the sake of it. The PvP invasion mechanic is an interesting concept though and can provide an extra layer of excitement. The other multiplayer modes seemed to be dead / laggy servers so I didn't bother much. 

Story line is serviceable but forgettable. Graphics are good, no complaints.

Overall, worth it on a 50% special. The season passes look like a big ripoff though; £55 base price for 5 new maps (1 is very small) and a bunch of worthless weapons and skins. This is worse value than the base game and a rather insulting price. I would only grab them on a deep discount if I felt like one more spin through the new maps with a buddy.

You don't have to play with Invasion Turned on. Yeah, there's an XP loss, but I doubt you'd notice it. It's really not a big deal. Like, at all.

Other Cons: 
The invisible borders can be annoying, especially for a stealth game, let me hide in the bushes! Controls can be a bit wonky at time. Sometimes it's difficult to grab items, but just use the 'arrow' on the screen, hover it over the item you want, and it will let you select it most of the time. Can't think of much else I didn't like about the game.

Pros: 
You can adjust the difficulty a lot more than you can in the other ones. For example I like turning off the mini map, making the enemy search long and hard for me, and making them a good shot. But, I also left detection on, and kept loot turned on high so I could find a lot of mines because I love booby traps.

All-in-all it's a great game and it had a lot of the same magic the older ones. I loved the attention to detail with all of scenery.

Before all else; this game has committed an unforgivable sin. It took my Nagant from me. My fucking [b]Mosin-Nagant.[/b] My baby. My beloved. My GOAT. My This Machine Kills Fascists. My "You spent so much time and are so good with this gun you now get it in gold with a little leather corset-strap around the stock because we both know it's that damn sexy." To get it back I would need to pay at least 20 dollars for DLC, and on the sale I got this game in that's more than the base game. Fucking disgusting. I killed entire regiments of Nazi scum with my Nagant and to rip her from my arms is an unforgivable sin. 


In terms of gameplay and scummy overpriced DLC practices aside, this is a direct upgrade to SE 4. Stealth is better. Ballistics are better. Weapon Customization is now intricate part-by-part and represented visually in the gun's model, scopes are even interchangeable. Levels are a bit hit and miss, the first level especially feels very flat and open which does help with easy long-range shots to get comfortable with one's weapon but makes good stealth play much harder, I personally think ideal SE levels are a more fine mix between the two. cheaper stealth tactics seem a little less powerful too, it may just be my lack of practice since putting down SE 4 but I've found that Welrod sniping isn't nearly as powerful as it once was. (My other SE 4 golden gun, but still useful enough to be part of my arsenal here in 5)	


I do have to say with some sadness that it seems scope sights are now tied to each scope as a customization item, and cannot be swapped out for your favorite design. This is probably more realistic, but as someone who became very used to a modern rangefinder for assist-less bullet trajectory estimation, it does hurt a little. I can't personally mention the multiplayer as I'm most interested in the series' single-player content, but what I have seen in menus looks massively expanded upon from previous games. There's also the inclusion of a new optional "invaders" mode in which other players can join your single-player missions as enemy snipers and hunt you down, which is an awesome concept even if I'm yet to try it. With all this understood the game is a pretty direct follow-up in gameplay and design to the fourth entry, and is more of a good thing.


[h1]IF YOU ARE LOOKING AT THIS GAME WITHOUT EXPERIENCE WITH THE SERIES:[/h1]


[i]Sniper Elite[/i] is best described as an open-level stealth series, but that's simplifying it a bit. You're dropped into an extremely large open level as a WW2 allied powers commando, with a set of gear you've decided on before the mission consisting of a rifle, a secondary weapon (Usually an SMG or shotgun), and a sidearm. This, plus some usable items, will be your backbone as you work your way through a set of pre-defined objectives all across each level's map. The backbone of your arsenal is your rifle, SE puts massive emphasis on an accurate sniping experience with simulated bullet drop, range adjusting, wind offset, bullet penetration, ricochet, etc. Your difficulty selection will decide how many of these interfering factors are enabled, and how many assist tools are provided to deal with them. All difficulties below the extreme range allow the "steady your aim" function to also gradually reveal exactly where your bullet will land, letting players still getting used to the mechanics score consistent shots at the cost of needing to invest more time to land a sure hit. 


This emphasis on your rifle also ties into stealth. The level's ambient noise as well as nearby loud props can help mask the sound of your fire, and since enemies will be hunting you over long distances their AI is designed to try and narrow down your location and flank around it, boxing you in and basing their strategy off of where they last were alerted to your presence. This unique formula of stealth over often incredibly large distances also means that going loud is perfectly viable since even unsuppressed shots can only be heard so far and the WW2 setting means separate groups of pursuing soldiers can struggle to communicate with each other. It's helpful to think of Sniper Elite as a sort of Commando Simulator, rather than pure stealth as optimal gameplay as in Metal Gear or Splinter Cell. To further this levels are scattered with items and weapons for you to stock up or swap your loadout with, and secondary objectives such as documents or optional side-quests to fulfill for higher completion. 


Because of the open-ended level design and nature of stealth games campaign missions are generally meant to be replayed to perfection, and progress is tracked with an XP system that rewards passive upgrades to your character and gear. Sniping itself is a skill you'll become more comfortable with too as you play, with time I found I was learning to predict shots well enough even without the assist features, and this massively opens up how you can interact with levels. I'd easily call SE beginner-friendly with its "no wrong answers" design philosophy but would warn against the series for anyone who isn't as interested in slower methodical gameplay.

Awesome game

The game looks awesome and when it runs right,  it is a blast to play!

however, that is ultimately why I can't recommend this game because of performance problems while playing the campaign(I don't play multiplayer).  I got this game soon after it launched and didn't have any of the perf problems that many others reported.  I played about an hour or so each week as I had time and eventually made it to halfway through mission 7 which was back in Nov 2022 and stopped then when I got caught up in playing some other games. Fast forward to May 2023 I started back where I left off and started  having weird perf issues, the game will launch just fine and run well until about 30 minutes of playing and suddenly start having severe hitching and stuttering performance, lots of lagginess.
I was using a 1080ti and a 3900x and at end of May I switched to a 4070 wiht fresh install of windows 11, fresh install of latest drivers and still same perf weirdness.  No other game or app I have has ever done this, only this game. 
Your mileage may vary with how this game will run for you, but be very aware that it's not just me, many others have reported the same thing.   I doubt I'll ever do any of side missions or any dlc,  just can't see playing this game for 20 ~ 30 min only to have to save and use task manager to kill the game and Steam because the game is such a hot stuttering/hitching mess that it locks up Steam and it won't allow the game to be relaunched, stuck at "stopping" but never gets past that, I even let it sit there for 30 min just to see how long it would do that.
Anyway, enough ranting, the TL;DR of it is this - the game has issues and most likely will perform badly for you, even if you have newer and/or higher end hardware so I advise you to not buy this game.

EDIT 7/26/2023:  After taking a break from trying to play this game and then doing some digging, it turns out this game has at least 2 issues going on at the same time:
1.  has trouble running in DX12, you most likely will start getting "device lost" errors and the game will start freezing up at random times, even causing game to lock up to point where you'll have to use task manager to stop game, so run the game in VULKAN api
2.  all ULTRA settings are borked, they cause VRAM leakage which eventually cause game to freeze/laggy/hitching due to running out of VRAM.  does't matter if you have highest end card with 24GB of vram, seen some reviews of those with 3090TI having this problem.  I have a 4070 running game at 1440p, looks awesome at ultra, but then the above happens after a little while. turn down settings to high and problem is immediately gone!

I honestly don't see much, if any difference in ULTRA to HIGH, it sucks this game has issues and I still don't recommend getting it.  but if you do go ahead and buy it anyway, keep in mind the above and  it should help

An extremely well made and competent stealth shooter, and a great addition to the franchise. I picked this up on the summer sale and have just gotten through the story. The actual story-line is most likely the weakest part of the game, and the final mission is rather disappointing imo, but the level design, freedom and overall polish that is represented by the gameplay is peak stealth shooter. The levels are huge, and if you want to perfect stealth them, expect to be in them for at least 2 or 3 hours. The Xray bullet cam is as good as ever as well, now I'm onto getting my 100 kills in invasion for that sweet sweet ghillie suit. 

TL,DR: A great stealth shooter with top notch level design, the story is the weakest point, but you can totally ignore it if you want, highly recommended.

I love this serie, so despite the critique I have for the 5th game in the serie, I still give it a thumbs up, because I want to get SE6 in the future. That said...
- IMO SE5 should be better then SE4 since it builds upon it. Sadly SE4 is the superior game. In SE5 there are no radio officers, the mortar strikes are virtually gone from the single player and the flare gun became a rare exotic weapon you can only use once. 
-The amount of weird AI glitches pile up when you start going loud. It's like the enemies got infected by Agent Smith and duplicate itself, to then glitch into each other and itself. 
- The weapons customization looks fun initially, but I'm not a big fan of it. I fear this took a lot of development time, Time that could have been spend into other more important things. What I do love it the fact you could choose your scope. That's the only customization I truly love, appreciate & want to see in SE6. 
- The wind mechanics in SE4 were better then in SE5. 
- The personal skills you unlock for Karl in the single player, there are some skills in there that you didn't have before in earlier games. These skills make the game way easier & I don't really understand why you receive these skills.  
- You can revive now, while it's new, I wonder if it fits into this game. You are a sniper, not RAMBO. Yeah sure you can play RAMBO style on easy, but where's the fun in that? Especially in a game called SNIPER elite? 
- Mission 9 ain't a mission, what a personal let down. I expected more. The guy should have been present somewhere in mission 8 at the end, after the final bunker. Every mission took me like 3 hours to complete, but this 'mission' 9 took me 3 seconds -_-' 
- Mission 8, oh boi I suffered, that one was a though cookie to crack. This 1 might be the only one that strongly recommends you to be stealthy and remain stealthy. 
- All other missions were top knotch, exactly what you would expect. Multiple entry points, multiple ways to get somewhere, secret passages, alarm posts you could deactivate, explosion barrels here and there. 
- The implementation of finding satchels, crowbar and bolt cutters is a good move. It really drives you to look around for stuff like intel & ammo, not just enemies. 
- The cutscenes you get are not wanted, not necessary, the developers shouldn't have wasted their precious & expensive development time on creating strong women just because it's a F hot woke topic these days. Stick to your core gameplay and just offer us a good mission intel before and after the mission. Strong women are so saturated these days that I personally nearly gag each time it gets shoved into my visual cortex. That US ranger that was present in earlier games, could have been the only buddy with boots on the ground you need. Since you have been in this war together for a rather 'long' time, but no he was just another a$$hol€ He had zero added value, you could have cutted him out aswell at this point. No camaderie, no brother in arms, no band of brothers, nothing, just another prick whining about rules. & Karl... apparently prefers to listen to a random wahmen, instead of actually listening & talking to this US ranger that has been assisting Karl the whole campaign in previous installments with solid mission intel. 
- Jager Snipers are annoying once they spot you & I love it. Sad thing is their position gets revealed like crazy. No more sublte glint in the scope, no no it's a mini rotating white dwarf star ready to go supernova. 
- The weapon customization needs parts which you need to unlokc at workbenches during missions. Despite all that, you only get 6 weapons in total. 6 Snipers, 6 SMG's & 6 pistols. 6 Snipers in a sniper game... *sighs* No Carcano, no Lee-Enfield, I found this a bit lacking. Sure you can expand your armory by buying rather expensive DLC, it just stings/stinks. 

I only played the single player, I have not played multiplayer. I plan to play co op.

In the end I'd recommend the game, but I considered not recommending it for a while.

The gameplay itself is great, it has interesting stealth mechanics and even allows you to use stealth in combat if you fail the stealth part. However, the game is also incredibly unstable. It takes about 10 minutes to load the game, and it will crash about 3-5 times per mission, after which you have to sit through that loading screen again. This gets quite annoying, but in the end the gameplay balances it out again.

         From someone who put over 2000 hours into SE4 I simply cannot see myself putting anything near that in this abject failure of a game. I tried to rack my brain for something that is actually an improvement and I could only come up with 2. The more realistic ballistics and the upgrade system, aside from that the rest of the game is worthless. Where should i start with the cons(just what infuriates me)
   1) Untold number of glitches, from day 1 we have been given an unpolished game. We basically beta tested the game and told them all of the bugs we ran into and not even half of them have been fixed. 
   2) Playing the game on authentic is nowhere as challenging as SE4, yes the AI cheat but the fact you can still stealth missions on that level of difficulty is laughable
   3) Non-lethal. why oh why is this even a thing. why do you get extra XP for sparing people. I can understand if you needed someone to be knocked out for extraction, but there is none of that in this game. I cannot for the life of me remember needing to knock someone out and extract with them, correct me if I'm wrong. 
   4) Map traversal is a joke, plenty of spots i should be able to get across the map or snipe from but invisible barriers and just flat out half of the map blocked off. If your maps need invisible walls all over the place let me tell you a little secret, your maps are shit. Its just a series of funnels with only 2 or 3 ways in even though I can clearly see many more ways that are blocked arbitrarily. Can't pass through gaps in bushes, cant mantle small walls, can't jump over certain walls, its a joke. This game isn't even about sniping anymore, aside from a few enemy snipers you can run the map with a pistol. The maps have very few areas that you can sit there, spot and take out a lot of the guys in the area, draw more in and slaughter them like you could in SE4. CQB is most of what you do in this game now. 
   5) Survival mode is another joke in this game, Being forced to move with the CP is annoying to say the least. Having any semblance of teamwork seems to have gone out the window with now needing to use med packs for revivals. The maps are just crap and this goes back to it seems sniping with just a tertiary thought for this game. Run and gun seems to win the day.
   6) This is more of a side rant but you can really tell that who ever worked on this game has ever seen a gun for making a model of it, because they just gave them almost arbitrary values. I can hear people now "oh that's just for balancing the game" but there is still the fact the guns just look good and that's about it from a historical view.
   7) Ready for another rant? Invasion mode. What is the point to a game mode where you have a enemy sniper come into the game with NO disadvantages. There is no downside to being a Jager. You have no choice when an Jager invades the game but to try to camp, and if you camp for too long your position is revealed. You cant proceed with the mission because hes just going to come up from behind you.All the Jager has to do is camp an objective and he has pretty much won. The fact that they pretty much spawn on top of you also, if you are engaged in a gunfight with the AI when they come in they can be on you in 15 seconds and thats it game over, Its a joke. If you are playing on anything but authentic difficulty its even easier for the Jager, with the hud and map on. If the AI spot you you have a marker over your head along side of the fact that every sniper rifle comes with a air raid search light attached to each and every scope in the game. This game mode adds nothing but ball ache.  
   The longer i play the more broken sh!t I find to complain about. This game is just not fun to play, its just infuriating. The sniper elite franchise was one of few on my list that i would just buy on release because they were all enjoyable up until now.

If you like the other games in the Sniper Elite series, then you'll like this one as well.

Pros:

Hey, it's a Sniper Elite game.  Frankly, it is about the same as the last game, but more of it.

Cons:

My only (slight) knock on the game is that the graphics and mobility aren't up there with the top AAA games. Because of the lack of mobility, it limits the opportunities for reaching what I would consider optimal sniping locations.

Another very small con is that when you walk up to SOME interaction points (e.g. where you can unlock a door or use a satchel charge) one is easy to select, while you have to move the character around a lot to get that option (e.g. satchel charge is easy, but unlocking the door isn't).

Summary:

Regardless, this is an enjoyable game in this genre!  Recommended!

So the levels are great and big and really fun...but...too easy for alarms to go off and then they never turn off. And recently, game keeps crashing all over the place. I had it crash after a mission even. Not sure what they did, but it is no longer stable, hence the thumbs down. Otherwise I love it.

The good:
The game has some pretty solid play through, with a variety of ways to approach objectives, kill or incapacitate bad guys, decent weapons customizing abilities, and insanely accurate bullet ballistics (for those who play more challenging difficulties). Hell, they even accounted for the range your guns can be heard from, and bullet travel time in your shots.

The bad:
The game mechanics are somewhat of a downgrade from SE4. A lot of your character movements just don't feel as natural as they did in SE4, you can't use a proper toggle aim (tap the button and your character stays aimed until you tap it again), vehicles are more difficult to kill than ever (except for trucks), and the maps, although nearly excessively large, are partitioned off into sections in a way that's reminiscent of SE2 and SE3.

(July 2023) Movement mechanics have been much enhanced, as has ability to properly corner/kill vehicles. However, while a toggle aim function has been added, it is more accurate to call it a toggle scope function. It still doesn't match the versatility of the toggle aim function a player will utilize in SEs 3 and 4.

The ugly:
Lot of little bugs. You might fall on a fence and be stuck there. You might get stuck on, or even in, a wall, rock, or tree root. NPCs often glitch out in any number of ways. Your game will crash, freeze, or even lock up hard enough you have to reboot your PC. Sometimes part of the gameplay mechanics stop working (i.e. losing the throw arc display for aiming grenades and bottles, or having explosions stop dealing damage to npcs, or even from happening at all). This game needs some serious debugging and updating over the next year.

(July 2023) Many of the most annoying and most major bugs have been worked out. However, updates to the system requirements show that this game requires about 30% more robust specifications than was originally advertised. Additionally, some bugs still emerge, such as one which will randomly pause your game and force you to a desktop view (thankfully without crashing or quitting your game session). Often, these require unique tweaks to your individual system's settings to sort out, or to at least prevent from becoming major issues which prevent game-play altogether.

The truly annoying:
Customizing your weapons is pretty limited. Figure, by the time you've unlocked everything, you'll be choosing to use the Kar98k rigged for high damage, or the m1908 springfield rigged for extreme distance and bullet velocity. Only 3 rifles aside from these, and they're really meant for mid-range use.
Long shots are annoying for those playing Authentic difficulty for a few reasons. First, you have to hit very specific targets for them. Second, you may find a target at a greater distance than the Long Shot target, and shoot it----It will NOT register. I shot a boat at 800m on the first level, and because it wasn't a specific infantry whom you can only shoot at 730m from one spot only, it wouldn't register my shot. On another level, I shot a guy in a crane at 540m, and again, it would not register the shot because the guy is part of a cutscene destroying a train, and I had to shoot another guy at 460m to get my long shot instead. This happens all the time.
What you unlock in campaign play is NOT available in multiplayer, nor invasion. You have to play those independently to unlock abilities and weapons for use. Why? because everything has been sandboxed off from everything else for the sheer hell of it. I had a wonderful time getting use to my weapons in single player, went to play multiplayer, and discovered I had to start with basic beginners equipment, rather than being able to use the gear and abilities I'd already customized my campaign character for. VERY FRUSTRATING...

(July 2023) The addition of numerous weapons, and even the addition of upgradable components to specific weapons has been a major boon to SE 5. While this does allow more personalized game-play, sadly, some of the better weapons have been nerfed a bit due to complaints out of MP session players. This still leaves you often choosing to use just one of three rifles, even if you have the DLC rifles.
Many Long Shot issues have been resolved. However, Long Shots on cut-scene characters and vehicles, even if they are just as difficult, or more difficult, still don't count.
All game mode arsenals and character skins are still sandboxed. Strangely, this is not a total sandboxing of skins, only weapons and upgrade componenets. If you want certain cosmetic affects on your SP weapons loadouts, you still have to complete Invasion. Vice-versa. Yet completing SP campaign, or Invasion mode ranks, does not affect weapon and component usage in other modes, so you'll have to unlock it again. STILL A STUPID WAY OF DOING THIS!!!!

Overall:
As a sniper game in general, this gets about a 7/10. For a Sniper Elite series game it rates a bit lower...maybe a 6/10 for the series. A few months of tweaks, a few new weapons and customization utility packs, and maybe some merging of weapons/abilities across single and multiplayer and this game would get an easy 9/10. For now, though, I'd say it's a bit lacking.

(July 2023) Would rate this a solid 8/10 for Sniper type games now, and maybe a 7.5/10 for the series. The main issue now faced by SE 5 is not any of the above mentioned....It is the hackers and cheaters (view discussion boards for specific references). Unfortunately, this means if you try MP mode, you find yourself playing among many players who openly admit to using, or having used at some point, cheats. Rebellion either doesn't, or is unable to, properly deal with this issue.
The only other big issue facing this game is the very, Very, VERY, ABSOLUTELY IDIOTIC notion of sandboxing weapons and character skin loadouts between game types. It's obviously done as a means to keep you playing as long as possible, like pay-to-play games. However, Rebellion is unlikely to ever admit this. As such, get ready to slog through each mode to unlock your loadouts time and again.

THIS IS AN UPDATE TO MY OLDER REVIEW IN WHICH I RECOMMENDED SE5, BUT HERE'S A NEW ONE ADDRESSING THE CURRENT STATE OF THINGS:

Sniper Elite 5 Falls Short: A Beautiful Shell with Disappointing Updates and Lackluster Content

Sniper Elite 5 had the potential to be a standout game in the series, but unfortunately, it missed the mark on several important aspects. Here's a breakdown of my experience, taking into account the game's positive and negative aspects:

Visually Stunning, but Superficial:
One cannot deny that Sniper Elite 5 is a visually stunning game. The graphics are top-notch, with attention to detail that immerses players in the game world. However, it quickly became apparent that the game's visual appeal was merely a façade, masking deeper issues that detracted from the overall experience.

Intriguing Invasion Mode Lost in Updates:
The Invasion mode initially piqued my interest, offering a unique twist on the gameplay. It had the potential to provide hours of entertainment. However, any enthusiasm quickly evaporated when I discovered that every update for new content required a whopping 60GB download. This excessive requirement not only proved to be a hassle but also strained my patience and ultimately diminished my enjoyment of the game.

Multiplayer: A Haven for Cheaters:
The multiplayer aspect of Sniper Elite 5 proved to be a letdown. Both console (Yes we know cheating on consoles is a thing) and PC players faced an onslaught of cheaters, ruining the competitive integrity of the game. The lack of adequate anti-cheat measures made the multiplayer experience an exercise in frustration and disappointment. It's disheartening to see the developer's failure to address this glaring issue, leaving legitimate players to contend with an unfair playing field.

Insulting "New Content":
One of the most infuriating aspects of Sniper Elite 5 was the so-called "new content" updates. Instead of delivering substantial additions to enhance gameplay, the updates merely consisted of three new items, such as skins and some weapons. To make matters worse, these additions were not even available for all characters (if rebellion wants to add skins at least please do it for all characters). This lackluster approach to expanding the game content feels like an insult to the loyal customers who were promised meaningful updates and improvements.

In Conclusion:
While Sniper Elite 5 initially impressed with its beautiful graphics and intriguing Invasion mode, it ultimately falls short due to its problematic updates, rampant cheating in multiplayer, and insulting "new content" additions. The game's superficiality and failure to deliver on promised improvements leave players feeling unsatisfied and betrayed. I hope that the developers take these criticisms seriously and make the necessary changes to provide a more fulfilling experience for their loyal customer base.

I just finished playing through Sniper Elite 5, and let me tell you, it's an absolute blast! Now, I know there were some reviews floating around claiming that this version wasn't true to its sniping roots, but trust me, they couldn't be more wrong. This game is all about sniping, stealth, and it's seriously awesome. If you've been playing it like a run-and-gun shooter, then you've been missing out on the real deal. So, buckle up and let me break it down for you.

First things first, Sniper Elite 5 nails the sniper experience. The developers have gone all out to make it feel authentic and intense. The visuals are stunning, and the attention to detail is insane. Whether you're stalking through a heavily guarded enemy base or perched on a crumbling building overlooking a war-torn city, you'll be blown away by the realistic environments and the sheer scope of the maps. Trust me, it's like stepping into a World War II movie.

But let's talk about the gameplay, because that's where Sniper Elite 5 truly shines. It's all about being patient and methodical. You have to study the enemy's movements, factor in wind and bullet drop, and time your shots perfectly. And let me tell you, when you line up that perfect shot and see the slow-motion X-ray kill cams, it's like nothing else. You'll witness bone-crushing impacts and organs getting shredded by your bullets. It's so satisfying, and it adds a whole new level of realism to the game.

Now, sniping is the main focus, but that doesn't mean you can't get your stealth on. Sniper Elite 5 has a solid stealth system that lets you silently take down high-value targets and infiltrate enemy territory undetected. You'll have access to cool gadgets like silenced pistols and throwable distractions, giving you plenty of options to play it your way. The level design is fantastic too, encouraging exploration and rewarding strategic planning.

Now, let's talk replayability. Sniper Elite 5 has got you covered. Each mission offers multiple paths and optional objectives, so you can go back and try different approaches. And if you're up for some co-op action, the game has multiplayer modes where you can team up with a buddy and tackle missions together.

But, I'll be real with you. Sniper Elite 5 isn't without a few minor flaws. The enemy AI can be a bit wonky at times, doing some weird stuff that breaks the immersion. And there might be the occasional performance hiccup or graphical glitch, but nothing major that ruins the overall experience.

So, if you're into sniping, intense action, and methodical gameplay, Sniper Elite 5 is a game you don't want to miss. Don't let those misleading reviews steer you wrong. Grab your sniper rifle, dive into this immersive World War II adventure, and prepare for some heart-pounding moments. This game is the real deal, and I highly recommend it. Happy sniping, everyone!

Best Sniper Elite game to date IMHO. If others get a remake or a remaster then my opinion about them might change but to date this one has the best game and gunplay, together with the soft enemy body targets it isn't tedious to deal with the enemies by proverbially missing the required eye shot (or organ shots to be more precise) that was always present in older games before this one where enemies could literally take dozens of bullets to drop if you just kept missing which is the main reason why I can't really play them and finish them even though in the past having finished Sniper Elite 3 when I play 5 now and go to revisit 3, I wonder how I dealt with that at the time.

I think at the core of these games the idea of sniping is really an appealing one and again the core of the games: the shooting is good at least theoretically but having to deal with the enemy health and sometimes AI behavior that made playing the games frustrating I always felt older games could have been better in practice. I feel that Sniper Elite 5 has made these adjustments.

This game might be easier than the older ones which I don't necessarily feel is the case at least not for the wrong reasons but again it feels more organic and the gameplay isn't as frustrating as it used to be, so I think this game is a step in the right direction, basically it is just very fun to play and still requires skill, just the enemies feel better to shoot (lol) and the movement of the player character is a bit swifter than say previously in Sniper Elite 4 was the case. Like I can't understand why older games, which also had a lot to do in them and by not doing it; by not playing those games felt really like a pity and I can't fully understand why older games weren't this way as 5 is now. I guess it has to do with the image of the game that makes it very skill based but a game that requires too much skill can be very unrealistic I think especially if overall it feels authentic or is going for that authenticity.

Some other reasoning:

I saw this game had iron sights and it was from there on a direct buy for me, because I really like these Sniper Elite games but always felt that this aspect was missing.

Now the older ones will never feel the same.

Beyond that the game is good, simple as that. If you like sniping then this one is definitely for you. Subsonic ammo and suppressors included for more weapons than just the sniper rifles at least De Lisle sniper rifle. Submachine guns and handguns now have suppressors too and that's good as an addition IMHO.

The game has beautiful maps, like really nice and I also kept replaying the first mission here because it is just so much fun and something which in older games I think never was the case because of the feeling of just wanting to get over playing them because again due to the enemies feeling really hard to kill before that took the fun out of the gameplay. Here, again, things have changed considerably and I think for the better.

If you look at a video like this one:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iv6C5GjUPt8
And you hear how hard the bullets hit the targets at the range from even a carbine like De Leisle, this then might explain a bit better what I mean by older games not feeling good shooting wise.

I am a fan of this series and I have played parts of SE2 and 3, all of SE4.

Now SE5 is a big let down.

The developers always have some weird tastes when it comes to a sniper game. In SE3, they wanted us to sniper tanks...countless tanks. In SE5, they want us to do CQB.

Just look at the screenshots on the store page. Half of them are CQB or non-sniping fights. Why do I need to do those? This is Sniper Elite, not just some WW2 Agent game.

SE4 was nearly perfect. Everything was better than SE5.

Things that SE4 had done right but failed in SE5:
1. Level design. SE4 was a sniper game. SE5 is a game where you play a guy who kills an entire city of Nazis without having to be quiet.
2. Again level design. SE4 was way less linear.
3. Customization. SE5 DOES NOT allow stealth play until you are late into the campaign to unlock muzzles. SE4 had stealth rifles (with severely reduced damage, which tested the player's skills) from the start.
4. SE4's Karl's movement was way less clunky.
5. SE5 is INSANELY big. It seems that it downloads all the DLCs even if you don't buy them. It took 100G on my disk.

TL;DR
Hard pass. Massive step down from previous games. Don't bother with this one.

-Imagine a game titled ''Sniper Elite'' but you use melee, pistol and smg 90% of the time. Yeah. Most encounters are close range, you rarely get to use your sniper. This was the biggest let down about the game.

-DLCs. My god. Curse whoever invented this ''DLC'' nonsense. If you buy the standard version of this game you only get access to like a quarter of the actual existing content. Most of the missions are behind a MASSIVE paywall. DLCs are like x3 times the price of the base game when combined. They took it way too far with this game.

-Broken AI. It seems to me the germans share a telepathic connection because soon as you make the slightest disturbance you will be swarmed from all sides. Oh and they will aimbot you with a pistol from a hundred meters away. They never seem to miss. On any difficulty. 

-Unclear missions. On three seperate occasions I had to look up on youtube where to go because some missions are really obscure. No indicators or anything just wasting my time running around not finding it.

-Mission 9 is a joke. It takes literally 10 seconds to complete. You just shoot one high profile target from afar and it's over. They should've just included that in the end of mission 8 after a cutscene. Are they trying to boost up the number of missions by doing this? 10 SECONDS for the whole mission. How is this justified? I'm amazed.

-Shallow characters and weak story ruins the immersion. I personally cared nothing for those 2 girls I don't even know remember their names. They add absolutely nothing to the game and just kinda hang around. They were just your typical strong female character I guess. Yeah, a black woman in year 1944 is an elite, well trained, high rank spy working for allies in WW2. Well done. That's what I'm looking for in a sniper elite game dude. Hell yeah.

-Invasion. They apparently added this multiplayer system like in dark souls where you invade other players worlds and try to kill them. No thank you. I turned it off after my first encounter. Game is already hard enough for you to get invaded by some sweat with hundreds of hours to hop in and grief your game. I'm good. Plus you can't save/load or even pause the game while he's in your world for obvious reasons. Just an inconvenience I'd rather avoid and instead play my own little solo dolo stealth action game.

Conclusion:
Extremely overpriced. Not a bad game per se but completely forgettable and average passtime. Nothing more. You won't be missing much if you skip this one. Just not worth your time nor your money. Disappointed.

It isnt necessarily a bad game. However, just by playing the first mission and the Berghof, I can already see that the game is centered around close combat gameplay, which completely defeats the purpose and objective of the SE series. In my opinion, Sniper Elite 4 is the better game.

[h1] Review #32 [/h1]
[b] Brief: [/b] Buy this game whenever it's on sale is my best recommendation. I do not feel the game lasts long enough to deserve it's original price, but to each their own I suppose. Now this is my first ever Sniper Elite game I've played, gonna try the fourth one next so keep in mind I don't know if this game is an improvement or not from the previous one but I will say it was a lot of fun to still play. The sniping felt good and the x-ray slow motion effects were awesome. Story was okay, nothing too boring but nothing too exciting, however it's pretty easy to complete the whole story in just a few days sitting. Also I dont care for Invasion so I have no idea about that mode.

[u] Positives [/u]
[list]
    [*] Great map designs, really open space to move around
    [*] Sniping feels good, not terrible
    [*] Trying to do stealth can be satisfying if it doesnt randomly screw up on you
    [*] You can get most of the achievements
    [*] You can shoot men in the groin
[/list]
[u] Negatives [/u]
[list]
    [*] Base game story feels a little short
    [*] Overpriced DLC for a couple more missions and weapon skins...
    [*] Can't get all the achievements without buying the Season Pass DLCs
[/list]
[i] "I'm not gonna tell you if you should buy it though, that's up to you to decide, I just provide my positive and negative experiences" - wamcrash [/i]

Feature with Space when you in zoom totaly low skill option and how you will use it on Hard/Hardcore levels when enemy sniper shoot you less thenone second. Mission tipicals and same. I am a fan of the series and sniper / stealth games in general. However the last one was a little bit on the clunky side. SE5 however is absolutely fantastic. I encountered almost no bugs - campaign game me a decent length of play time and really nice flexibility for how you go about your objectives in terms of quiet, loud, lethal, non lethal. Super forgiving with the various assistance levels (I played through on authentic) and customisation for difficulty - as well as the save almost anywhere ability. This means you can really get what YOU want out of the game in terms of technical play style vs loud and unrealistic. 

HIGHLY recommend this for the average FPS player when on sale, and still recommend for fans of the series or genre at full price if you aren't a steam sale tight fist like me.

First, I don't think it is a bad game - for me it is a 3/5, kind of fun for a while. Despite this I wouldn't recommend it - SE4 is way superior.

It feels to me that the devs want to make Sniper Elite into Hitman - especially notable in the Hitler mission. Different ways to kill him and all that. Unfortunately it is instantly obvious that SE doesn't have the gameplay features, the intricate maps nor the narrative elements which make Hitman great. So you're left with an ok stealth shooter where you'll have on some maps trouble to find any sniper shots above 100m.

There are also other elements that don't make sense - for example I haven't found a use for decoys yet. You can also sabotage parked vehicles, but outside of a few scripted events the NPC don't use them at all, so why even have it in the game? It also features the 'modern' DLC policy of "two weapons and a skin for 10€".

It also has a lot of solid features, like the gun gameplay, lots of customization, the way in which it handles exploration, how you can tailor the difficulty exactly to your liking, but compared to its predecessor it is unfortunately a big step back.

Sniper Elite 5 is the best game in the series imo. It runs incredible well, and the gunplay is better than ever. The main campaign consists of 8 missions in various locations, with main objectives and optional objectives. The maps are not 100 % open world, as you have to follow certain paths in some of them, but you are free to play it however you want. You could go non lethal, stealthy or go in loud. On top of a really good campaign, you also get the following modes:

Coop - Play story missions with other players
Invasions - Invade another player and try to take them out, or the other way around
Survival - Defend command posts with other players against waves of enemies
PVP multiplayer - Various modes of standard multiplayer with levels and stuff to unlock

I barely touched the PVP as it's not really my cup of tea, but i played a lot of hours of survival and coop missions. Only had good experiences, and people were friendly and helpful. It was easy to find games to join, but there are no servers, so keep that in mind. If the host leaves, the game will end.

But i do have one negative about the game, and that's the season passes and DLC's. As of writing this review they are way too overpriced for what you get. You only get 5 extra missions, and only 2 or 3 of them are decent. Included in the season passes is also skins and new weapons. If i were you i would purchase the main game first. If you liked it and want more, and maybe get all the achievements, then get the season passes on a really good sale (Like 50 % off or something) Or buy the mission dlc's individually.

The DLC missions i liked the most were Wolf Mountain and Rough Landing
Awesome and fantastic game. A must.

Well now the entire story is out i can say definitively that SE5 is worse is almost every way than 4. 
Fewer weapons, Worse customisations. Waaaaay too many challenge or gimmick guns. The kill challenges borrowed from hitman are more annoying and harder to get than the ones in 4 and sometimes essential parts are locked behind them. For a game set in France there are only 2, maybe 3 French guns. They even tortuously contrive a reason for Japanese weapons and troops to be in France and do nothing with it. A handful of officers to kill and two guns (three with dlc) from Japan and what did they pick? The Type 100 submachine gun that can't be fitted with a suppressor and the Nambu (the worst production gun of ww2). The DLC adds the Terra rifle some weird low power paratrooper rifle that can only be fitted with  a handful of shitty scopes. Woo! I guess the Japanese forgot to bring the Arisaka rifles, the actually decent rifle with real sniper variants. And i guess the germans forgot all their P38s so every officer has a Luger and every soldier has an obscure french pistol. 
Sorry got on a tear there. 
Can't swap your gun for enemy guns in the field anymore, no more S-mines or trip-mines. 
Enemy AI seems somehow smarter and dumber. Better at tactics under fire but brain-dead pathfinding. Every tank in the game is now a King Tiger but don't worry armour-piecing rounds will kill one in three hits from the back. Oh but the driver is now invincible. 
Look this game is perfectly fine, hell i played it for 89 damn hours. But having played 4 i can't help but see how in basically every way this instalment is inferior. And as far as i can see they stripped out a whole bunch of stuff for no reason, put in a heap of BS that would only appeal to streamers and even with the overpriced dlc still haven't restored the missing content. 
If you want a Sniper Elite game get 4, its cheaper, longer and better than this. So very disappointing.

Pistol Elite 5 (A Fun Bad Game)
Once again, voice acting is terrible, pistol is more accurate than the sniper rifles, and running and gunning was more interesting than playing the overly complicated sniper gameplay. That being said, they added iron sights to the sniper rifles!! Now you can use the rifles without worrying about windage and all that jazz. If you can get it cheap and play with a friend, there is fun to be had.

It's just good enough to pass. But barely. Still good enough to keep me playing, slowly, for dozens of hours, so it's doing something right...

- The story is bland (solo agent singlehandedly penetrates Nazi strongholds and disables a WMD).
But... It holds things together.

- The freedom is annoyingly restricted - maps are just patches of gameplay in a LARGE map, but connected by narrow paths that artificially confine player movement. It's annoying that a small hedge holds you back, and you can't climb in/out trenches, and you cannot jump... Not at all. So many things look entirely traversable but aren't.
But... You get used to it, and at least you can *shoot* all across the map. Which you sometimes need to do, and albeit artificial, it keeps you from too much running & gunning (at least on higher levels because you die easily).

- They say the sniping is "authentic"... But you just press "space" and a useful diamond comes up that assists in headshot after headshot even at extremely long distances. And there is x-ray vision for enemies you saw once, which makes it incredibly easy to plan a route and stay undetected, just as long as you have patience.
But... Yeah, shooting is fun.

- The enemy AI is one of the most braindead AI's ever in a game like this. They see five of their buddies getting headshotted in a building doorway, and they think "hey, maybe if I walk through the door as well, I catch the sniper, hey you know what? let me LOUDLY yell ahead that I'm coming through as well". It's ridiculous. They are alone, and they loudly yell to their imaginary friend or to me, the sniper, just to let me know they're there, so I can take them down with great ease. They don't listen, they don't look around, they don't work together, they don't take cover, they don't change weapons, they don't take strategic positions, they don't create funnels, they don't draw me out of a hiding place (except from the odd grenade), they don't cover each other, they don't care at all about their wounded buddies, they glitch and look/shoot through doors and walls...
But... No, there's no but for this one. The insanely terrible AI is, for me, by far the hardest hit on the immersion, and made me ragequit often.

But the maps are gorgeous and large, and the environments (especially the indoors) are detailed, chaotic and very well done. Even if traversing chokepoints is often extremely artificial and limiting. It's fun mowing down countless numbers of bad guys in a combination of slowly scouting from the edges of the map, and then barging in and having hectic firefights in maze-like indoors quarters, churches, science stations, armories etc..

I'm not military, so I have no idea if this is is anything like sniping at all, but "authentic sniping"? Nah, absolutely, definitely not even close.

Current Review just for Sniper Elite 5 base campaign, single player, Invasion turned off, no DLC/pre-order/Season Pass stuff.

Pros:
-For the most part, huge, intricate and at times gorgeous maps
-minimap features for detection/investigation/combat/hearing range slightly improved
-didn't have a single crash to desktop like on SE3 and 4, though I suspect that's more DX11's fault on the older games.  YMMV.
-25h campaign if you're chewing the scenery, at least that's what I got playing on default (medium) difficulty.
-Killing Nazis never gets boring. Replayability is subjective, but there's multiple starting locations you can find on each map, collectibles, workbenches, etc.
-Flanking AI seems slightly improved, though it's a mixed bag when the AI is already somewhat dumb.
-Like most games, it's undoubtedly a completely different experience with any form of multiplayer (co-op, invasion, etc.)
-some modes and options completely new to SE5.

Cons:
-AI is still Snipe Elite AI.  Its iterations improve in some aspects and remain dumb as a box of navel lint in others.
-Mission 9.  Yes, it qualifies as a mission, with a designated, clear objective, but really, this should be an epilogue not listed in the individual mission list considering it takes 30 seconds to complete.  Feels like a massive tease and a slight disappointment at the end of very satisfactory iteration of SE considering how much time I was able to enjoy in the other missions.

Mixed/Subjective:
-You don't get all the weapons and attachments up front.  You earn some by completing missions, earn others by finding workbenches and earn still more by completing certain challenges within missions, like kill person X with this method, etc.  You still have everything you need to get by.
-If you like SE, you'll like another iteration in the franchise.  If you demand an authentic sniping experience, like every other time, this is more arcade/shooting gallery-like, with stealth elements, and at times gets closer to a third-person version of popular FPS multiplayer franchises...but you have the ability to play how you like, which is good, and there's no immediate fails for being detected, which I've always thought of as a red flag for any game.
-I'm not a fan personally of any type of Pass model (Season, Fast, Pass/Fail). Rarely is the supposed discount vs. the individual DLCs worth it.  Value in this is entirely subjective however.

These are my guilty pleasure games and this one continues the trend of just getting better and better. They take the same formula that the previous games have had and layer on a few more components to keep it fresh. The missions themselves are very well designed and thick with things to do. You could just focus on the core objective, but it encourages you to engage with the secondary objectives and they add a fun challenge. The core sniping is as good as it has always been and that is the main thing you are here for. You get some interesting new options with the added bullet types so you can tune in your strategy for each mission a little bit more. Would for sure recommend this to fans of the previous games as it is a worthy follow up to what they laid down.

Playing SE5 is an immersive experience and engages the player. The high quality graphics and sound effects help to do that. Campaigns can be played in a variety of ways as determined by the player which alleviates boredom when playing them repeatedly. Skin packs add variety and interest. Weapon choices are limited and needs expanding. Photo mode is great - it allows a screenshot to be manipulated with photographic tools such as depth of field, aperture, and camera height and angle. Survivor mode is challenging and really tests your skills. I have not played invasion mode or multi-player yet - long overdue! There are much less bugs since first release. There are still some bugs but they're minimal and don't ruin the game. DLC campaigns are much too small and need considerable expansion (compared to SE4).  I play SE5 on a dedicated PC that exceeds recommended spec, without other game software or commercial software running on it - as a result I've had no technical or functional issues.

This is a fun game with some negatives; I played the crap out of it when I had Xbox PC Game Pass then bought it on sale on Steam. It's Crossplay so you can play with your friends on consoles or different platforms, so that's cool. This is the first Sniper Elite game realistic-feeling ballistics in it, it's not dead-on or anything, but the bullet flight time, the lead, and drop are pretty legitimate to where you won't question it, though the wind is a bit extreme.

1. The game has false chokepoints like what Hell Let Loose suffers from (the map seems bigger and more open than it is). 
2. You can adjust your zero, but the increments are shoddy beyond 300m with big gaps between the different ranges on most scopes, making it basically nearly useless to engage beyond 300m regardless of how much magnification you have (that's fine, but it could've been better).
3. If you equip a suppressor, the already-dumb AI is broken unless they see their friend get hit or get killed, or they get hit themselves; the game basically plays itself. So I don't use suppressors.
4. As already mentioned, the AI is dumb and will go out of alert after a certain time rather than continue to track and search for you, regardless of difficulty.

I bought this for Axis Invasion and multiplayer and basically, on Axis Invasion, the Allied sniper/s get wall hacks (Focus mode) on any difficulty lower than Authentic, and Allied sniper/s can get AP ammo that can penetrate 4-6 feet of concrete with a standard rifle (so there is no such thing as cover for the Axis Invader), while the Axis invader can reveal location every few mintues, after the first 5 minutes or so have passed. I played a game a few moments ago where my location was revealed 6 times in just a few minutes before I could reveal his location even once with the invasion phone. Also, most people in Axis Invasion try to get kills with secondaries, handguns, or throwables/traps, so you're rarely going to get that Enemy At The Gates experience. One last thing about Axis Invasion, you cannot filter for players of the same or similar difficulty, which would be nice. Also, photo mode wrecks this Axis Invasion when people won't play honorably and they still haven't addressed it.

A good game of Axis Invasion requires these things:
1. people who don't use Photo Mode to find each other
2. an axis invader who goes seemlessly between stealthy and blending with the AI troops
3. an allied player who doesn't use Focus mode (Authentic difficulty)

I'd give it a 5 or 6 out of 10, MAYBE a 7 out of 10. The game feels rushed and they keep focusing on DLCs instead of addressing bigger issues or Quality of Life things and it will always be limited by being a third-person shooter. If you want a real sniper game, they still haven't really made one to my knowledge.

So far my max distance shot was around 250m but most less then 100m and 90% close quarters kills. 

Again the developers impede your progress (try to slow it down) by limiting you with weapon choices until you progress the missions/story and unlock ditto suppressors and other accessories. Some poor design choices here IMO.

I had never tried this game because I thought it was only about sniping. It turns out it's very similar to the Splinter Cell games that I used to enjoy. Stealth gameplay is great, sniping is top notch, maps are enormous and detailed with dozens of clever or straight-forward ways to accomplish the objectives. The selection of weapons and customization was excellent. The details around the sound and loadouts of each weapon are fantastic. 

One BIG tip to anyone playing for the first time... make sure you "use" the workbenches you find in missions even if you don't need them. I didn't realize that you had to "use" them not just "find them" in order to unlock the rewards. Can't wait for part 6 and now I'll have to see if part 4 is not too old and worth playing.

Overall, well worth the money and one of the better single-player action games I've played this year. I did not try multiplayer or survival yet but I'm excited to try them next.

Love this game

First of all, no it's not just sniper elite 4 but more, they improved A LOT.

It can be a bit short with it's to few missions, but the ones we get are still very fun and varied, with interesting paths to take and positions to snipe from, so just for campaign this game would be worth to buy on sale.

Where it truly shines tough is the invasion mechanic. It gives you tools and is balanced in such a fun, asymetrical way, that actual irl sniper tactics really work and are worth using in PVP, like never staying in the same place to make it harder for the enemy to stop you, predicting enemy movement and laying traps, etc. 

And unlike most online games, there is no real meta here, this is primarily a battle of wits between two players, and smarter one will usually win regardless of gear. Good invader can track down and hunt the invaded and hunt them like an animal, but the good invaded can turn the whole round into a horror game for the invader. I love this game, you won't find anything quite like it anywhere else.

Also if you're just interested in it for the PVE or coop experience, the survival mode is also very entertaining, and let's you not only blindly shoot at enemies, but also set traps, find good defensive position and manage your resources, so even if pvp hunts are not your thing, you will still find enough content for yourself.

Regular symmetric pvp is pure garbage tough, if you just want pure non-invasion PVP play something else

I didn't buy this at release for a few reasons. The whole "invasion" thing turned me off and the "anti-cheat" software sounded intrusive.

But I ended up playing the game on "another platform" and really enjoyed the experience. Once my subscription ended and I lost access, I picked it up here on Steam. Played through on Authentic and felt the core gameplay was still the excellent style one expects from the Sniper Elite series. The changes were overall good (except I turn "invasion" off because it's really a bad idea) and the maps were really inventive and interesting. Even playing through this game twice now I still find it enjoyable and discover new things all the time.

One minor thing to note: Getting the Authentic achievement is not so prestigious anymore because you can save scum through it. Older Sniper Elite games made you lose your character if you died. Having said that, I did a full Authentic run without dying so it's definitely doable even with the changes.

There seem to be many times when your assigned a mission goal & the map shows where you need to be; only to get to that spot and find nothing.  The searching a dead soldier is way to tricky; you must be in an EXACT position to do so, & that position is usually not with touching distance of the dead body.  The slo-mo on kills is drawn out way too long; it seems to be twice as long as that on SE-4.  The destruction of tanks and armored vehicles has become overly difficult due to the position you need to be at in order to make the multiple shots at exacting points of each vehicle using only armor piercing ammo.  The lack of ammo / explosives to be found or gleamed from dead bodies can often necessitate undertaking a search for 15-30 minutes or longer to find what is needed: armor piercing ammo, explosive to open a safe or door, and just adequate ammo to continue toward your goal.  Overall the missions are fine.  The low ratings received on most all of the DLCs have kept me from adding any missions to the game.

By comparison with the last offering (SE4), this game is a disappointment.  If you can start the game at all (lots of reports that people can't), and if you play without crashing (lots of people complaining about crashes), and if you can put up with bugs that are being "looked into" for months, and if you can run the game long enough for memory leaks not to send you crashing, then you can play.

Survival mode is a disappointment, lacks the luster SE4 had for replayability, and has coding issues where sometimes poor spawns or out-of-bounds vehicles end your game.  Also too few maps.

The maps are beautiful in most cases, but there is repetition (designer laziness) in some of them and you are not as free as you'd like to be.

Wind effects do not compare with SE4 unfortunately, and also there is no authentic plus mode, both of which make the game less challenging than most would welcome.

Weapon modifications are too complex and silly, too overdone.  And some weapons that should appear do not.

The game is geared towards console warriors, and the game is cross-platform.  PC Steam users do not get the attention of the developers in the forums.  The most you will get is some lame acknowledgement (sometimes, not the majority of time either) that they read the issue, then you get told to contact support, who does nothing in most cases.

Updates are still 40 GB and up, all the time.  "We are working on it"

Most maps are not sniper-generous.

I enjoyed the single player campaign, but replayability is not as good as SE4.  It is replayable, but not as good.  If you play multiplayer, be prepared for a host of cheaters and disappointments there, IMO mostly because of all the console action that is now in the game.
I play singleplayer only and I like it.

I have played all of the Sniper Elite games, from the beginning.  I will admit, I am not that good at these sort of games, and it takes me forever to finish them. SE4 is still unfinished, because I am not that good, but I enjoy the games.  So why don't I recommend SE%?

Well for a start off, I've just finished it in under 30 hours on medium difficulty. Let that sink in, I am useless at this sort of game, and I finished it fairly quickly (for me, anyway).  There wasn't much challenge, if I was noticed by the enemy, I could just get into a massive gunfight, taking out 11 or 12 guys who knew where I was and were gunning for me. It was not an oh damn I'm dead moment, it was just "Switch to SMG and blow them all away" time.  My recommendation, go play SE4 instead, it's more fun, and more challenging.
