The game play is good, Karl doing Karl stuff, sneaks, stabs, long range sniper shots. It gives a good amount of sniper locations, and the kill cam footage is always fun. 

The story is weak, though. the bad bitch resistance leaders were pointless virtue signaling and diversity hires. i got bored with it about half way through *skip* and just focused on the game play. 

I played it through half-way by myself and then started over with a friend. i enjoy the co-op play a lot more. It's nice that it is cross-platform, he's on a PS5, i'm on PC. 

Some of the fun traps from 4 are missing, like the trip mines, and the schu charges? knockouts that hardly do anything to Jagers, stagger them a bit. There is a heavy XP reward for not killing your enemies, but this is an elite sniper game, so blowing peoples heads off is kind of the point. 

There seemed to be a lot more character customization in 4, too. maybe there is more with more DLC, but i bought the deluxe version, and nickle & diming me to death for a skin seems greedy. 

I completed the whole game with the gewar [sic] rifle, and that was a good choice. I liked the weapon customization work tables. nice addition. 

The last mission... maybe this was to "Tie up loose ends," but it felt weak. It would have been better to have some plan, or some obstacles to overcome. 

Still, the maps are well thought out, there is a good amount of objectives to accomplish, and I enjoyed it, especially co-op.

Sniper elite is the best sniper game series (or probably because I don't play many fps games). The install size is huge 93gb for deluxe version, but I think a lot of it goes to assets, mainly for graphics because the game world looks really good and there are many objects and buildings and they look different even though of course they're also reused in other places.

The most important thing is improvement from previous series, it can be a good and a bad thing because that way the latest will ofc be the best and there is no urge to get the previous installments. It's like they're competing with their own existing games and replace it with the latest. 

The one improvement I like the most is Enemy AI. In SE4 if I snipe someone, enemies will be alerted and the second shot will always reveal my position. So it kinda beats the main feature of the game as a sniper, the game has melee, pistol, submachine gun and rifle so I can use any of those to defend myself while the enemies are alerted . In SE5 enemies have better status (I think SE4 also has it but simpler). In SE5 the statuses are Clear, Investigating, Searching, Combat. If it ever reaches combat status but I manage to kill the enemies engaged fast enough, it will go back to clear status. That is the biggest improvement because then I can snipe again. Esp if I use rifle with the lowest noise range. So far I managed to stay in stealth all the time in all missions that I have played (1 and 2), while still be able to kill any enemy as I please. I still have to wait a bit to cool down depending on situation, but not too long.

The whole experience is very atmospheric, the music, the sound effect, the chatter, the graphics, this is the only game/genre that I'm comfortable walking slowly in stealth most of the time without needing to rush to go somewhere (unless I know I already clear the area). The game world is big but not too overwhelmingly big. It's the right size for each mission.

There are also rpg elements (I forgot whether it's already there since the previous series but I think it's new or already in se4), for skills. Not too important though but it helps.

As with other sniper elite series, bullet time showing slow motion kill when the bullet penetrates enemy body part never gets old. Especially when it's a difficult shot from great distance (enemy has helmet and micro movements). And loading a save file is really fast like in seconds. There is also quick save and quick load buttons, it feels like savestate in emulator games, can just load when messed up and back in action in just seconds.

Price is a bit steep as others also mentioned. So wait for a discount. It's still too expensive to buy all even at discount though, but the deluxe version should be enough for a while, and buy the rest at later discount event.

It never gets old. I've been playing Sniper Elite since its first installment back on the PS2 and I love the franchise. Is Rebellion becoming more and more a money-grubbing shameless company? Totally! Just got the game on sale and I'm pretty happy with it and with the DLCs I bought, based on reviews. I laughed a lot when I saw a DLC that adds a silenced .22 pistol and it just showed what's wrong with companies these days: they do have a good product and can make millions with it, but they need to milk that cow to near exhaustion before getting their creative team back in the room and work on something new and original and focus on COOP instead of the ridiculous multiplayer. Again, great game with a solid fan base, but most people want to enjoy it solo or with a friend. Last but not least: if you're selling one weapon with a couple of customizable parts and some ridiculous camouflage, it doesn't make it a weapon pack, it makes it a money grubbing scheme. Bottom line, the game is great, [spoiler] Rebellion isn't [/spoiler]

To select a bandage/tnt/mine can take multiple attempts...again causing interruptions to the flow.
If i had bought this at full price then I'd be very unhappy, but fortunately it was on sale!!
If the character motion was the same as SE4 then I'd be happy......but it isn't....not at all!!!

Pros:
- The game can be passed without killing anyone (except those who must be killed as objectives - would be nice if that was tackled as well).
- Very beautiful. Lots of attention to details.
- Sniper rifles have a new distance based aiming mechanic. Still it's a far cry from what Sniper Contracts offers.

Cons:
- Plastic faces. I've never seen so bad faces in a AAA title. Crysis from 2007 looked better.
- Horrible terrible stupid AI. I'm playing on authentic and it's just not there. AI won't see you when you're right in front of it. AI will however spot you when you're crouching 50 meters away.
- Not a lot of new stuff if any in comparison to previous installments.
- IRL something that's guarded is guarded at all times. Without ifs. That means it's ridiculous that you can sneak in almost everywhere without being spotted.
- I can pick up a fourth gun which is the same as mine but with better modifications or the one which is not yet available, why? I can use it. If I switch to my own primary three guns, this fourth gun is dropped. What the hell? Found modifications are not unlocked by picking better guns.
- Enemies popping out of thin air. This happens e.g. when you destroy objects and you have enemies "sleeping".
- Not enough traversal freedom. Too many areas of the game are blocked seemingly for no reasons.

Buy only when it's on sale.

The graphics have been beefed up a bit over the 4th installment but the invisible walls still remain. If you'd like an idea of a game with life and activity in it, go play Ghost Recon Wild-lands then come back to this and you'll see what I mean. This game is depressing in comparison. Overall I feel the developers still managed to make a good 'sniper' game. It's not a AAA title but I give it a pass despite my gripes.

I've had no performance issues, but can't seem to find an option to reduce frame rate. Admittedly graphics seem slightly behind the times, but still they've made a good job of creating suitable and fun environments to explore. There's a good mix of sniping and close combat. Would like to see this series evolve though. Run, gun, hide, snipe and collect gameplay does feel a tad repetitive after a while. Or how about moving things to Japan, or Vietnam or another conflict? Or why can't be a Nazi killing Bolsheviks? Something a bit different next time would be great.

SE5 is a good game with some flaws. I was a huge fan of SE4, so naturally I'm going to be comparing the two games.

The Good:

-Options for days for configuring your guns and loadouts
-Interesting new take on survival mode, once you beat one there are different base options
-Longer and more involved single player missions than the base SE4 missions, feels more like some of the dlc missions from SE4
-Elite snipers no longer have heat seeking laser point accuracy like in SE4
-I really like that if you pick up an enemy weapon, you get what's left in the clip and then discard it.
-Tanks can no longer be shot and destroyed with a simple sniper round.

The expected:

-Allied characters are wooden cutouts with no personality just like in SE4. This time they just amped up the diversity. At least you can skip the cutscenes.
-AI can be janky: enemies can magnetic snap to cover 10ft away sometimes. Enemy soldiers stupidly exit their sidecar despite having a mounted machinegun they are leaving behind.

The Bad:

-While the gun options are cool, the progression system is completely tied to the single player missions, for a game with 3 distinct game modes, why always force players into one mode to progress?
-Despite these choices, it almost feels like there is always one correct upgrade path for each weapon.
-Base game guns are quite limited, I think there are only 5 non-dlc weapons
-Elite enemy types running with MG42s seems a bit over the top and cartoonish. Why not go back to the FG42?
-The speed at which wounded enemies instantly pull out their pistols is cartoonish as well
-When finishing up the third wave at a base, the instant spawn mechanic is kind of lame, really should've just let you run to the new base like in SE4
-DLC prices are insane. Seriously, twice the base game cost for both season passes?

I think that's everything. Overall a good game but not as good as the fourth game!

The game is fun and the maps/campaigns are interesting.  I've always like the FPS games that don't just seem like a repeat.   You have to think about how you are going to assault each area, and some take a bit, which I like.

Fun game and on par with other Sniper Elite's (4 still my favorite). Story wasn't too bad and combat as usual was fun. I don't think there was much "new" in this game from previous #4, but still a fun play through. Certainly worth the play if on sale.

I enjoyed the previous two games. I wanted a better quality game with a new story but a game that was basically "more of the same". I think this is exactly that.

The idea of some rando coming into my single player game and forcing me to change my preferred slow and methodical gameplay style seemed like a terrible idea. The cool thing about the invasion mechanic is you can set it to friends only, or turn it off entirely. That's what I did for my first playthrough of the campaign. I had a blast. The invasion mechanic is actually really cool if you want to play through the game again. I'm in the process of getting all the achievements and medals currently. It's fun to have others turn up in my game and give me some fun PvP interactions. It's also to load into someone else's game and try and slowly hunt them down. The 4 person survival modes are a ton of fun. They really bring out the fun in using some of the secondaries provided. My campaign playthrough was mostly rifle for distance, pistol for close quarters. Survival was the SMG's and shotguns time to shine. I don't really have an opinion on multiplayer matches, I've not really played much of any of the game modes. I'm currently playing through the campaign again with a friend in co-op and it's a lot of fun. Something I really appreciate is the ability to switch to first person view on all guns. That's my preferred way to play.

Not much of a groundbreaking review to be fair. I liked the previous games, I liked this one with invasions turned off. I liked playing again with invasions turned on. I liked doing the invasions myself. I recommend it.

Its why the two latest DLC's, "Saboteur weapon and skin pack" and "Death from above weapon and skin pack" has 30% and 16% positive reviews. Rebellion needs to work on more content, not just more stuff that should have been included anyway. And for this very reason, I do not recommend it. Don't get me wrong, the game is cool and you are most likely going to like it, but if you buy all the DLC and the cheapest version of the game, you will pay 1,5 times  any ultimate version of any game from Ubisoft and that says it all IMO.

A year ago I would've recommended this game to almost anybody. But I can't anymore, not in good conscience. 

The problem has been the postlaunch support; two season passes worth of content and a succession of major technical updates have brought myriad problems as well as destroying the core balance of the game. It's reached a point where I don't enjoy playing it solo anymore, and where the enjoyment I get out of it comes from being with people I love. And you can get that from any game.

It's a bizarre situation, the game has been downgraded quite comprehensively from launch. I don't get a smooth framerate anymore (6900xt/5900x/32gb@1:1) with major frame drops and stutters in certain areas. I didn't have any issues with bugs at launch, but now the game routinely crashes on me. The general idea is to patch your game to fix issues, not to create them...

I would particularly warn anyone on a metered connection. Not only is the install size for the game immense, it gets immense (40 to 150 gigabyte) updates regularly as well.

Sniper Elite 5 offers a thrilling and immersive sniper experience that fans of the series will appreciate. With its impressive visuals and immersive environments, the game sets a solid foundation for intense and strategic gameplay. The sniping mechanics remain precise and satisfying, rewarding skilled marksmanship. The addition of new gadgets and weapons brings fresh options for creative approaches to missions. While Sniper Elite 5 builds upon its predecessor, [u]Sniper Elite 4 [/u], with minor improvements, there is still room for further innovation in future titles. [b]Multiplayer mode is not recommended for players in Asia.[/b]
Sniper Elite 5 maintains the series' strong gameplay elements and realistic details, ensuring a solid and enjoyable experience for fans of the franchise.

With Sniper Elite 5 completed, I have now all SE Games (except Part #1 - it is just too old/clunky) completed and am now able to say the last one is the best of them. The levels are great designed and there are always a lot of ways to solve the instructions. 
A few optional tasks are added to each mission, as well as a new kind of task: Kill a named guy within the area using as specific way. This can be via an explicit gun type or to e.g. throw somebody in wet concrete. 

I have completed each mission with all side missions, which took me 21 hrs - whereby this includes the sneaky gameplay. If SE is played like a shooter it will be most likely way shorter.

Graphics are, as well as the Music/FX, good and the story is also better as in the previous parts - even though most of the parts are not historical correct.

SE5 is also the first part in the series which came 100% uncut to Germany, which increased the immersion a bit, too.

I would recommend this SE part to everyone who is interested in this kind of games and to everybody who had fun with the previous parts!

Honestly I just assumed this game would be kind of uninteresting and more or less just Sniper Elite 4 all over again, but I'm pleasantly surprised.

The most defining feature of Sniper Elite 5 is just how insanely big the maps are. Some of them are not only massive, but also incredibly detailed and impressive. I spent an entire 3 and a half hours on the first level alone. It's honestly surprising just how jam-packed full of content this game is.

The weapons are interesting. They chose a really weird selection of rifles, with 1 of the 6 not even being a rifle, one being an SOE prototype and one being a somewhat obscure French rifle. There´s an attachments system too that is actually fairly useful for optimizing different aspects of your guns. I made an M1 Carbine for myself, stripped it of all of its powerful features and slapped a suppressor on it to bring its audible range to about 30 meters. I´m sure it can probably go even lower if you play around with the attachments more.

It feels like the sniping is more realistic than before. In Sniper Elite 4, at about 100 meters you'd have to scope almost a full head length above somebody's head to hit them, but the large aim adjustments you're used to are much more subtle in Sniper Elite 5. You'll have to adjust for bullet drop and wind over long ranges, but to nowhere near as great an extent as in Sniper Elite 4. Overall, it feels more realistic and less arcadey.

For some reason the devs felt compelled to add a skill tree? I really don´t know why, as none of the skills are important and you´ll unlock them all in a few hours anyway. Were we meant to think hard about how we spend our skill points? Since you unlock everything so quickly, what´s the point of even thinking about it? Why does it matter if I unlock slightly higher lung capacity now or later? Why bother adding these faux RPG mechanics? My whole interaction with the skill tree was: "Oh, I forgot this existed. Whatever, let me just unlock this shit I guess." Why bother adding it? Or XP? Or a levelling system at all?

The story is once again just "evil Nazi general is making a device that will end the war yesterday, it's up to you to stop him!". I particularly loved how every single level had an objective where there's some kind of device that you can overload by pressing two buttons, then said device explodes and Karl goes "There, that'll slow down those Nazi bastards". And when I say every single level, that's surprisingly not even as hyperbolic as it sounds.

Lastly, the invasion gamemode is really interesting. You either invade someone who´s bleeding to death in a field surrounded by Germans on all sides and just blow his head off with ease or you invade someone who´s been dead quiet all game and have to wander the map looking for any sign of him, hoping that you find him before he finds you. It´s one of the most fun multiplayer stealth games I´ve played in a while.

For some reason though, there´s an anti-camping mechanic? In a game about sniping? If you sit in one spot for a few minutes, the game will mark you so the other player can find you. It makes sense in that it prevents the player from just hiding in a bush somewhere and being nigh impossible to find, but I hate that I take up a position overlooking somewhere I know the other player is going to go through, only for the game to fuck me over and mark me for him to see. Surely I should be rewarded for having the patience and the basic deduction to recognize that if the player just completed an objective to my north and now needs to complete an objective to my south, they´ll have to pass through a certain place and that I can see said place from my position. But no, fuck you, you´re camping, suck my cock.

One last thing: Karl suffers from severe unable-to-shut-the-fuck-up syndrome. I get it, people in real life think about things, they have an internal monologue, so it´s realistic for them to have an internal monologue in game too. Unfortunately, I don´t give a fuck if long grass is good to hide in, or if the scopeless rifle I just picked up does not indeed have a scope. Karl loves to make useless observations and there´s really no need for it. You pick up an SMG and he´s like ¨Hmm, this SMG could do some damage...¨ Like, what? Grizzled war veteran picks up a gun and his first thought is ¨Hmm yes this gun can hurt people¨. After 100 hours in game I don´t need the main character to mumble that long grass is good to hide in or that a scopeless rifle is still useful.

All in all, there's nothing really wrong with it. The level design feels like a huge step up, the gameplay is more or less Sniper Elite 4's and the story is, again, less memorable than a conversation about washing machines.

[h1] Great Game, Not For Me [/h1]

Third Person Stealth games, or stealth games in general have always been some of my favourite genres in video games and by all intents and purposes, I should've really enjoyed Sniper Elite 5 but for some reason I never had that itch to keep playing it.

Sniper Elite 5 is a game where you assume the role of Karl Fairburne, an American-German Sniper on the side of the allies who helps turn the tide of the war in France 1944 through the games own inner plot set around the events of the historical D-Day.

The gameplay is what you'd expect, sneak around, line up your shots, hide bodies and collect intel. You are truly a commando in every sense of the word.

One of the best aspects of the game are the level design and missions. The maps are not massive but they're not small either, they are packed with things to do and each level feels meticulously crafted by the developers to an astonishing level. Although you have your main objective every mission there are an abundance of side missions as well as a few different difficulties, I imagine the replayability of this game is great and you could definitely get your moneys worth. 
There are 9 missions in total and each can take between 60 and 150 minutes to complete. Definitely bang for your buck.

There are multiple ways you can complete each mission, sometimes its just blowing something up, sometimes its breaking a production line, there are several ways to do things as well as multiple enemy types and loadouts that can suit your playstyle. 

If I'm being honest with myself, I genuinely don't know why I didn't enjoy this game. I was the same with SE2 and SE4. For me something just feels off and I would like to make a disclaimer that it is just the way I [i] personally [/i] feel about the game. I just never clicked with it. I felt no urge to hit launch and when I was playing it I wasn't getting any enjoyment out of it. It felt like a chore just so I could get a review out and be done with it.

I got halfway through mission 6 before I said to myself. "I'm just not enjoying this and I don't know why." I genuinely don't. The game ticks every single last box but I guess I can just say that I'm not in the mood for this game right now, that's the only thing I can think of.

I will not be giving this game a rating as I feel that it is unfair but I will be bold enough to say that I do recommend this game to people who enjoy the stealth-shooter genre.

I will come back to this game when I'm in the mood for it and see if I can complete it.

OK, right off the bat I feel like mentioning that I'm only covering the base game in this review, because most of the DLC's deserve their own review entirely, so please keep that in mind.

Sniper Elite 5 has it's flaws and drawbacks, don't get me wrong. Yes, the map design is on average subpar to that in Sniper Elite 4, with some of the levels being particularly frustrating to get through (*Cough* Level 6 *Cough*). Yes, it was odd for Rebellion to remove the trip mine and S-mine from the main game, and yet keep them inside Multiplayer. And yes, this game doesn't give you as much of an opportunity to snipe as much as the previous games, which is a little weird. But with that said, it's still a pretty good game in my mind.

1. Story
First things first, this game has much better characters, and a better story compared to anything that came before. Karl is a little bit more interesting than he was in Sniper Elite 4, and actually has pretty decent chemistry with all the main characters. Speaking of them, Charlie is a decent enough buddy for Karl, but be warned because she might have the single most aggressive Scottish accent in any character from anything ever.

Other than them, Marie is a pretty good character who ties them to the resistance and sometimes helps provide transport, although not being super interesting. And Moller is a good villain who bears a likeness to the douche bags in charge of the Nazi Regime.

For the story, Operation Kraken might just seem like another evil Nazi super weapon, and it is. But what really sets it apart from what has come before is just how insane the actual plan is. I wont spoil anything, but the whole game is worth playing through just to find out the awesome conclusion of exactly what it is.

2. Gameplay

Sniper Elite 5 might not have as good levels as Sniper Elite 4, but it does make up for it in the new things it added. For one thing, this game added Invasion mode, which is a wonderful way to play through the game if you don't feel challenged enough. The game adds plenty of new weapons like the SREM-1, Welgun, and RSC 1918. I for one think that it's an interesting idea to add non-lethal kill methods, since it's a really good way to get XP. Some of the levels are pretty well designed, such as levels #2 and #7. \

There are several different ammo types, all of which are useful for different situations. And of course, weapon customization might not be realistic to the period but it is a really cool factor. 

3. Conclusion

So, in the end Sniper Elite 5 might not be an amazing game, but I do believe that it has many strong parts. I would recommend to get it on sale, since I'm not sure that it's worth the $50 (but to be fair, I'm not sure that Sniper Elite 4 is worth $60).

8.2/10

I hope that if they make Sniper Elite 6 it will take all the good stuff from this game, and the good stuff from the last few games, and put it all together to make the perfect game.

Until then, stay safe, drink water, hug your loved ones, play this game, and have a nice day. :)

I purchased the game somewhat reluctantly as I previously played the games in the franchise. 
 I am also awaiting other titles to be released.  I read some reviews and thought....okay, it would fill the void.  However, now that I am comfortably in the game I realize that this franchise is past its due date and needs an overhaul.

The game suffers from multiple limitations as well as being a bit buggy: Enemies showing up, looking away for a second, then looking back but they are not there?  Walking up to pillage a body, but if you stand too close, or at the wrong angle, you lose some menu options.  Very limited in movement as you have to follow very distinct paths, and cannot open many doors or leap barriers right in front of you.  The menu wheel is buggy as you have to almost double check your selection before you continue as it sometimes selects wrong.  Movement is terrible, unless you are perfectly aligned to a track you get stuck behind poles, etc....really fun when you are trying escape......not!  Upside?....GREAT graphics as I am using a 2080 RTX Ti, and the map is "nice".  Would really prefer it to be more open....but again the limited pathways.

All in all this game lacks...well...a lot!  If purchased discounted...very maybe.  I won't be buying the next in the series....that's all I know.

Sniper Elite 5 is absolutely the best entry in the series and pinnacle of the design that made this game stand out. The game can be enjoyed in many modes but absolute stand out is INVASION. You basically play the story and allow anyone to invade your game as an enemy sniper. There is nothing like the feeling of actually being hunted by someone while you're trying to do your objectives. I have some of the best memories from that mode and for that alone the full price of this game is absolutely worth it.

It is a great sniping game. It has some elements of stealth and sneaking which I appreciate and the maps are absolutely gorgeous. If you like any of the things I have just written please do yourself a favour and buy this game.

I'm currently playing and trying to enjoy this game as much as I did SE4. I'm not a massive fan of the franchise, but 4 was pretty good fun on medium difficulty and it felt like you could sneak around until you cleared the map and the world was a happy place. SE4 made it clear what you could do with the environment and you could plan around it. SE5 on the other hand, is very ambiguous.

There was one section where I thought I would walk upstream to the waypoint. Upsteam had an invisible wall in it so a pretty glaring break from immersion as my character moonwalks in the water against a glass case of emotion. The game also doesn't really reward you for playing clever. It just descends into run and gun like a third person shooter where you're flailing around murdering waves of Ze Germans who teleport out of the woodwork screeching Achtung! All the cool trip mines and ambush stuff is pretty much missing. It is a little confusing because I'm not really understanding how the game should be played. Maybe it doesn't know either. AI also is pretty woeful. I was standing in a stairway while Jerry is moonwalking against my character model, until I mercifully kill him in melee and put him out of his digitised misery.

Oh and if you're into playing games for the story, please be aware that WW2 is very progressive now. "The Message" features heavily.

This game is terrific. Don't be fooled by the title. While it does include various rifles and plenty of open areas for shooting, this isn't really just a sniper game. Karl is a commando, through and through. You'll be sneaking around hostile territory conducting guerrilla warfare against the Germans, sabotaging enemy equipment (coastal gun batteries, AA guns, comm equipment, etc), gathering intelligence and assassinating officers. There are a bunch of different ways to complete each mission, including both ends of the spectrum. It is a lot like Splinter Cell in that way. You can sneak around without touching anyone, you can just knock them out (why not kill those nazis?) or you can ventilate them with your blade. Naturally, you can also engage at all ranges with various firearms. If sniping isn't your thing, there are submachine guns and pistols that are perfectly viable in combat, especially now that you can aim down the sights. CQB with a Thompson is definitely a treat. 

A lot of care was put into making Karl shoot and scoot in a realistic and period accurate way, including his usage of the fighting knife melee kills and the way he reloads his weapons. 

It's a cool game, and definitely nails that espionage vibe. The Axis Invasion mode is a lot of fun, too. Definitely give this game a shot. If not here on steam, then try Gamepass. 

Also, set your AA to medium and increase the render scale instead of just maxing out the graphics. You'll thank me later.

I bought this late, but I've played through the campaign twice, once on medium and once on hard. It's pretty simple really:

- In a vacuum, sniper elite 5 is a "decent" game.
- Compared to Sniper Elite 4, it's a bad game.

Why?

- Map's are prettier but not open world. Way too many invisible walls or things you cant't jump over, each map really only offers two or maybe 3 direct paths to follow. This makes the best part of the game (Sniping from long distance) naturally harder because you can't get on that hill over there that you want to, no you have to climb this specific building they put right here. SE 4 gave you WAY more freedom and options for long distance sniping.

- Weapon upgrades are a cool idea, but don't make a big enough difference really, I always end up just going for muzzle velocity, and as quiet as possible. Even then most of the rifles are just too loud. Now this would be fine if the maps were like SE4 because you can almost always go over 100-200m away from the enemies but in SE5 you are semi guided on a path, there is FAR less room for long distance sniping. This felt more like Splinter Cell where the majority of kills were either stealth take downs or pistol shots. Why not call it Pistol Elite 1 instead.

Main Point : Sniper Elite 4 was awesome because you could CHOOSE to be a up close pistol man, or that guy that finds the furthest possible point and then sits there and takes out 1/4th of the map, then moves to another great natural spot. SE5 does not give you that same freedom. It has a tiny bit of it, but it's just way more forced and ultimately that's the complete wrong direction they should have gone in. 

I still enjoyed the game, I like the B movie campaigns they are silly. I didn't personally find this game woke, I think adding non lethal options is good. Choice is good. Unfortunately overall SE4 had more choice than SE5, and ultimately that's why you should buy that one and play that one instead.

I really hope SE6 goes back to the more open world design. It's the difference between a just okay game and a great one.

How to describe this then?

We have waited a long time for this, the 5th in the SE series. 
Numbers 1 and 2 were very clunky, 3 started to get a lot smoother, 4 remains one of the most played games in my library.

But SE5? 
I'm 5.6 hours in at the time of writing, finished the first mission, started the second and I haven't tried multiplayer yet.

But the graphics! They seem to have taken a backwards step.
Perhaps I should crowdfund for several brand new graphics cards?

Gameplay has suffered in my opinion. Little things like placing a satchel charge. You have to be in exactly the right place or no dice. Similarly picking items up, if there are two close together you find yourself swapping your gun for something you really didn't want or need. 

I paid up front for the game pass and can't see any of the additional missions or weapons promised. Am I missing something there?

All in all a swing and a miss so far. I'll keep playing it through and I will make it into multiplayer once I've finished the campaign.

But I'd love to see those weapons and missions.

EDIT: 255 hours in.

So the missions are all finished, the last 5 of the awards are yet to be collected, many guns and tweaks have been unlocked.

However.....

It still feels very clunky. 
Multiplayer (not co-op) is very linear. Scope glint is always on, hacking seems rife.
I'm looking at profiles with level 40(max) solo play and level 50(max) multiplayer play and the player has 40 hours in-game?

Whatever happened to the Easy Anti-Cheat that auto-loads with the game?

Summary is still this: For the cash I paid for it, the sheer acreage of area that has been made available to play in is fantastic. The graphics and gameplay is still clunky, the multiplayer maps are limited and fellow players are deserting it in droves to revert back to SE4 to play there until many more of the bugs are fixed.

EDIT: 478 hours played.

[h3]Update: They are currently throwing all that credit for good value for money away.  by now the first season pass is through. It was ok. The missions included were few but big and well made. BUT now Season pass 2 is  sold for 25€, half the games price again. It promises only TWO missions, the first is out and is apparently very underwhelming in size I absolutely don't care or see as value weapons and skin packs.   So what i said about not milking as much money out of the game does NOT extend to their current DLC policy. Season Pass 1 ok, 2 way too expensive. Wait for 50% sales. Update end[/h3]

 Also SE5 doesn't have SGWC2's 20+launch Weapon and Skin DLC.  So instantly a better look and less exploitative feel.  But of course SE5 was just begging for a (completely avoidable) shitstorm by gating the usual kill-Hitler DLC behind pre-ordering. Will they ever learn?

[h3]Edit after finishing: SE5 (40hrs) is a MUCH bigger game. Levels are not just more and bigger, but also more interesting and complex. 
There is the odd glitch on top of a ladder when you can't get off, and  2 or 3 jumping "puzzles" the movement system is REALLY not build for, but all in all no technical issues.

SE5 is basically more of the same as  SE4, Which is perfectly fine with me and what i hoped for. For the many good things,a bit less for the few issues. Apart from those, gameplay, ui, graphics are all as good as ever. [/h3]
Issues like the still very limited movement and object interaction systems. Like(no)  jumping or moving gas canisters (aka bombs) to strategic locations. Or using doors...  Instead still concrete canisters and some impenetrable obstacles that don't feel like they should be. 

A clear and completely unnecessary change for the worse is the new, very limited weapon pickup system. I absolutely don't understand why they did that and what was wrong wth just swapping your weapons.  That makes no sense.
You can still pick them up as 4th, temporary weapon but they are just dropped when switching to your loadout ones that you can only change at workbenches to very few unlocked other ones Those are at least nicely customisable.

I don't care much for the new online "Axis invasion" feature. I guess it's a nice option to have if it works and doesn't get annoying. Can't judge, have it off. Only annyoing that some items are locked behind that feature.
 On that topic a big bonus point for just having a simple checkbox option to disable the the Easy Anti Cheat spyware*. Instead of needing launch parameters, file renames or no way at all. Forcing EAC down your throat (unnecessarily!) has become a absolute pest in recent (mostly) single player games

*Only the privileges people give willingly to EAC in their windows are a wet dream for any spyware.

This is one of the better games made in the past 10 years. The story is simple thoughnot particularly engaging. The gameplay is a great deal of fun. The maps/missions display the labour of love the developers have put in, with some incredible and arguably unnecessary level of detail. Invasions, above all else, have made this game a favourite of mine. It's exciting to be on either side of it.

This game is truly a step above the rest in the franchise. The default FOV is better, and the ability to adjust it is welcome. The way the character moves, the controls and default keys for interacting are much better than previous titles. It's so much better I struggle to enjoy SE4. I sincerely hope this game serves as the framework for all future titles. I do hope there is another Zombie Army title, and that it has invasions.

I'm a long-time player of stealth games. The 'Hitman' franchise was a favourite, until it lost it's dark edge.
Then along came SE4. What I noticed straight away was how much of an improvement SE4 was over the Hitman games.
The stealth system, and all the associated mechanics were much more satisfying.
Having played SE4 to death, I was looking forward to SE5.
Then the Steam reviews came out for SE5 and it appeared to be universally slammed as having taken a backward step.
These reviews put me off purchasing, as it's easy to believe that a developer has lost their way, and haven't made the necessary progressive improvements to the game.
Typically, therefore, I waited for a Steam sale, and bought SE5 then.
Within minutes of playing, I knew it was a faithful improvement on SE4.
The automatic snap-to-cover when in crouch position was exactly what I wanted from a stealth game.
The weapon customisation, the dialogue, the graphical realisation of 1944 France are all of the highest order.
Wait for a Steam sale by all means, but don't be put off by negative reviews.
In short, Sniper Elite 5 was everything I had hoped it would be, plus a little bit more.
Buy with confidence.

My choice for a new game would have been, in a perfect world, "please can we have MORE Sniper Elite 4 for the single-player campaign?"

Rebellion delivered!  

It's more SE4 but even more gorgeous (except that distracting AA shimmer) and with lots of small enhancements, like 'focus' where, when especially close to enemies, you can press focus to gain a faint outline of where the enemy is on the other side of a wall or barrier.  It's a bit of a cheat and you don't have to use it, but I liken it to assessing where someone is by their footsteps - so yeah, I'm using this!  Other new things include weapons now carrying an indication of hearing range.  If a rifle has a hearing distance of 130m, you need to be at least that far away from the nearest enemy for your gunshots not to not be heard.  Even the trusty Welrod suppressed pistol can be heard within 14m by default, so it's not quite so much of an easy way out in this game!  The game now offers workbenches in the locations where you can upgrade and swap weapons mid-mission (love this).  You can now sabotage vehicles as well as generators to mask sound, though nuisance soldiers will insist on poking at the noise and trying to fix it as in previous games...  There is the polarising addition of non-lethal weaponry and attacks - polarising because why wouldn't you kill off someone wearing a Swastika?  But it adds a new gameplay option, and you get more points for non-lethal combat.  Polarising yes, but you have total freedom to play how you want - and who doesn't want extra choice in a game?!  Finally, you can now also upgrade Karl as well as your weapons - by earning skill points, providing enhancements such as the ability to carry more ammo, or to automatically mark an enemy that takes a shot at you.

The maps are again HUGE with plenty to do and to find (each, when played properly as a stealth operator, taking several hours to complete - easily 7 to 10 hours for me per map).  I'd estimate the title divides game-play into around 60% sniping and 40% close-quarters stealth (or combat - choice is yours).  A lot of reviews are panning it for not enough sniping and there probably is less in this one, but it's also a lot to do with how you play.  Like the previous games, you CAN run-and-gun, but the way you're supposed to play is to scout out some suitable vantage point (if lucky, with sound masking) and pick off enemies at distance.  Unfortunately, the story, map and objectives unwittingly steer players straight into direct routes leading to close quarters combat and that's probably why there are so many complaints about lack of sniping.  Ignore where you're supposed to go next.  Take your time, pick high points, mark enemies through your binoculars, and pick them off at a distance.  

Along with the good is a little bit of bad too.  Karl's impediment for climbing over small walls is back (he really suffered this in SE3 too).  This time, the 'wall' might only be an ankle-high pile of pebbles around a tree and the gap looks easy to traverse, but nope, Karl cannot go there.  He cannot climb low rocks, squeeze through what look like decent gaps in hedges etc.  It's a tad frustrating.  I get why it's been done but I think, in SE4, it was better disguised by blocking off no-access routes visibly with barbed wire, fencing or other obvious barrier.  Another issue is trying to interact with things like opening doors or picking up ammo.  There seems to be some issue where you keep having to spin round and find a perfect position to trigger the interacting prompt and, if you're in a hurry, this is beyond maddening and ideally needs to be fixed.  One thing I DON'T like: if you opt out of playing "Invasion" (yes, players can land right in your game and kill you), you earn less points.  In my opinion, a game mode should be able to entice people to play without gating game rewards behind the feature.  But that said, even without invasion points, you will ultimately find enough points to unlock all upgrades before completing the game.

The AI is a bit hit-and-miss.  Sometimes, creeping up on a foe unseen launches the red COMBAT! alert without you making a sound, and other times, the AI can seem a bit confused and bewildered before shrugging their shoulders at the dead body in front of them and assuming it was nothing.  It's not ALL the time, but it does happen here and there. 

The NPCs are a little bit wooden, but they always are in SE games.  There's a nice mix though.  You'll see complaints about some, like the black woman you first encounter because "unrealistic".  I have NO time for people who whinge about this sort of thing.  It's a fictional game with fictional characters and a whole fictional resistance.  If it was realistic, then Karl would be kicked out from the off given his lack of fitness, huffing and puffing after 10 yards of running and not even able to hop over a short stone wall, so...  I like what Rebellion has done. 
 Why can't Rebellion fictionalise it as much as they want?  I 100% support their decision and welcome it.  I can count the number of games with a black female primary on the fingers of one hand from 40 years of gaming which is shameful, so it's about bloody time!

People are commenting that bullet physics are a bit off.  I only play medium difficulty so wind direction isn't a biggie for me, but it's worth bearing in mind what others are saying.

Final criticism others make is a greatly pared-back selection of weapons.  That's true, but honestly?  All the hundreds of weapons in the previous game were just clutter and most were not used.  The weapons in this game might be fewer, but they vary in a meaningful and interesting way.  I almost feel like I've had MORE choice because the differences are greater (whereas in past games I just shrugged them off and played mostly with the default load-outs).

So, should you buy it?  If you enjoyed SE3 and/or SE4, then an absolute yes.  It is more of the same but with enhancements.  If however you found the earlier games repetitive, you'll be no better off here either.  It IS more of the same and, for that, I'm very, very glad!

Good game, bad community. 
If you are into stealth games and planning to play the campaigns mostly, this could be the best game out there for you. 
If you play too good in the game, you could be rejected by the community, and here's why:

The SE community is a small one and mostly consists of fairly old people. The matches in this game are slow in action and therefore it attracts a lot people with slow reaction time. And If you play way better than them(which is very common and easy), you will get a lot of hate and eventfully receive accusations. I've been playing there since 2020 from SE4 and along the way made a lot of friends and had a lot of fun but eventually ended up with drama as many other people.

In short, if you are old or bad at other genres like FPS, this game is built for you and it's community welcomes you. Otherwise leave the old men alone.

I'll start with the pros: Weapon customization is good even though some are a bit ridiculous. Invasion is the best part of SE5 its great fun with friends. Probably the second best improvement in SE5 is the story line, its more in depth and creative. The maps are aesthetically more pleasing (i wish there was some terrain variety) the maps are more expansive. The multiplayer maps are better and in my opinion more difficult. I like the weapons, i feel like they're pretty well balanced i havent noticed any of them that are OP. 

Now for the cons: The sniping is worse in most ways it doesnt feel as much of a sniper game compared to SE4. I think it feels more like other WW2 games which to me is a bad thing, if you like to run n' gun its definitely better than SE4 at that but thats not what Sniper Elite players want. They want something that they can push their skills and methodically take out nazi scum from 400m away. Another down grade was the traps, theres a lot less variety now you have to collect bottles instead of throwing rocks. A land mine rarely kills people in invasion and multiplayer. One of the most annoying thing is all of the invisible borders, it limits a lot of stealth. I wish they made a few different variants of builldings such as the churches.

I could keep adding to pros and cons but thats just of it, a lot are disappointing in the sniping which is obviously important. Its a good game but was a disappointment at the same time its taken away from the niche it had as a mostly sniper/stealth game.

***Another update*** 

I wont be buying the new season pass. Most of the issues bellow haven't changed. Rebellion have killed the SE franchise for me. 

This is now a dip in game for me at best. 

***

After playing several hundred hours on this game, as wells after several  40-50gb updates, I stand by my original overall opinion. This is one of the worse coded games I've ever played, and they had the cheek to declare it GOLD before release. 

It has lots of potential, however as it stands now i would only just pass as a beta version.

- Invisible walls all over the map. and Ironically, places where you can shoot through walls and tanks etc. 

- Inconsistant landscapes ie: you can jump over railings in certain maps and not in others, even tho they appear to be the same type/height etc. Same with shooting through wood. 

- Glitches galore including Mines don't go off or go off without making a sound. Or they go off when you are no where near them.  Enemy snipers and tanks track you through walls. 

- Grenades don't throw properly. They will randomly end up anywhere but where you throw them. 

- Wind and Bullet drop are a joke. 

- Melee system is retarded. You cant melee from the front unless you have a bayonet, and you can melee people before they are even anywhere near you. 

- Survival is far too easy even on Authentic. Abundance of supplies, gormless enemies, highlighting enemies when you get 5 left. white boxes and exclamation marks appearing over their head so you know where they are. 

- Ridiculous features such as Focus - basically a built in wall hack. At least give us the option to turn it off in multiplayer. 

- No dedicated servers leading to toxic noobs who will kick you for shooting them.
- Annonymous votes so people will just keep spamming the vote button with no accountability. 

Lots of potential. There are some good ideas in the game but Overall a let down over the previous SE series and has clearly been dumbed down for the next generation of gamers.

 Ive paid for it now so i will keep playing it but don't buy it unless it is on sale. 

***
A massive let down. SE4 is basically all I play so I was looking forward to SE5. 

I don't mind bugs in this stage of release. It is to be expected (however how thoroughly was it tested given that bugs appear in the first few minutes)

Graphically it is excellent. I like the weapon customisation feature. Shoulder aim has been eliminated and there are different aim options. But that's where the good ends. 

As well as small but very annoying features being removed, this is basically a watered down, overly simplified SE game clearly aimed at the younger generation. The Sniper Elite veterans have been forgotten.

- Movement and interaction feels clunky and not smooth and fast like SE4. Almost like everything is microscopically slowed down. 

- Authentic mode is a joke. Enemies are highlighted (on survival), You get red exclamation marks over enemies in campaign so you can then see them.  No wind until later missions in campaign (why?! just why?!)   If i wanted an easy game I would choose an easier mode. Bring back the standard of Authentic plus in SE4!!!

- They have removed unlimited stones (which in reality would be readily available) and replaced it with limited supply of glass bottles! How bizzare and random is that! Why would a sniper carry bulky bottles that clunk around rather than using stones? An idiotically bizzare feature. 
 

- Multiplayer movement and game play looks and feels like fortnight, its lost the speed and atmosphere of SE4. 

- Also they removed the option to see the game rules, ie: when you enter a server to see what they have turned on or off. Useful feature that is no longer there. 


Overall, despite the excellent graphics, this game is just feeling dull and lifeless compared to the others.I don't mind the fact that many people say its a copy of SE4. That would have been excellent. In fact I would have welcomed new SE4 maps rather than this SE5. 

And its not nostalgia, I was ready for a whole new challenge. This has been a major let down. Especially for the cost. 

I hope further updates change some of these features.

Quite simply, this isn't a sniping game.  There's more elements of a fetch-quest RPG, a CQB game, and a survival game than actual sniping.  

The main character is annoying.  He tells you everything you're supposed to do.  Even when he's supposed to be quiet.  Sometimes you're in the wrong spot when his voice triggers so the advice falls flat.

The quests are annoying.  Everything in the game is either 0 or 10 in difficulty, there really isn't any in-between.  Either you need to blow up a bunker and there's a satchel charge right outside it, or you need a crowbar and you spend twenty minutes searching before you find it.

The minimap gets cluttered easily and there are bugs in how the map and minimap work.  For example, it will tell you to hit return to track something, but actually you need to click on it.

The controls themselves are very weird and difficult to get used to.  The first mission does an absolutely terrible job of introducing new players to how to use them.  Apparently there's different types of ammo.  It's not made clear what they do, because there's no description to go with their name.  You just pick up different types of ammo.  It's not easy to track how much you have.  

The sniping, when you do actually get to do it, is fun.  But this isn't a sniping game.  It utterly fails at being a sniping game.  And since that's the name of this game, the game is just bad.

Short version NO BS the game is quite good aside from the HORRIBLE monetization practices!!!! KNOCK IT OFF with the BS there. So while on a deep sale I feel like the price I paid for the base game was worth it I would not suggest others purchase the extra content or even purchase this game until either they fix the amount of content in this game or you see it on cheap sale and its well under 50% off. Maybe then they would push out a complete game with more than 8 missions and enough guns to go with it. If there was a neutral button on steam even more so with a wait for sale check box I would in a heart beat pick those. However on steam there is only YES/NO for recommending the game. I would have to say no I do not unless it is on a extreme sale. The day they start putting in the content and then doing proper paid expansions if they really want that particular profit model... is the day I will give them a good review. If you want paid expansions then the expansions have to bring as much of the base game as the price they are. If you sell 30 hours of content for 60 and then charge 10 bucks for a DLC then it better bring every single min. of 5 hours of solid content. If the base game is 8 missions for 60 and the DLC is  15 bucks for some missions then I better see 2 full missions out of it being 1/4th the price of the base game then I want truly 1/4th the content. Not a mission that says it is a mission for the sake of it.  (No I mean FULL FLIPPING THING) If paid expansions and DLC have to be a thing take a note out of the witcher that is the only game I have seen to get that right. 

((edit) after playing the game) I will have to say there is a lot of good about being able to customize the guns so much. However there is a relative lack of them less than in sniper elite 4 more than sniper elite 3. (least compared to how much I have played of 3) they kinda force you into buying several season passes and buying guns one pack at a time. I do like a few free guns and skins they gave out but i feel like It was because they had to not because they wanted to.  Another thing I would like to add is the last mission number 9 is not a full mission I do not want to spoil it for people who have not played the game yet but it is not even close to a full mission. In fact you can complete it in about 30 seconds. To call that a mission is insulting. So what you get with the base game is this. 
1. series of 8 missions - the 9th is not a mission objectively speaking. 
2. highly adjustable but severe lack of variation and number of guns in the base game
3. Some of the maps are much much bigger and have much more replay value than others to a degree that is kinda hard to describe. 

What I think stands true for this game and I think for sniper elite 4 as well but not to this degree is as follows. 
They made a fun game they even improved a lot on the prior however someone pinching pennies says well take this , that, this, and that out of the game and we will sell 1/15ths of the game for 1/4th or more of the retail price of the base game. OH BUT WAIT THERE IS MORE ... why don't you buy more than one season pass to get a deal on all the content we stripped out....It is in your face cash grab. look at the reviews of the additional missions (DLC) you can purchase they are not worth the price unless on a very deep sale. This feels like penny pinching turned worse where up till now they have gotten away with it. However they are not taking your lunch money too and it long past has gotten old. Long story short here is that I think a lot of people would be willing to pay a bit more for the game or would even expect slightly less from each new title in the series if the games were actually new / had all their content/ a full game worth of content. Some of these missions are new. Some levels are amazing and truly massive while others (about half) are not quite so much like that. With how many guns are in the base game and with the size , scope , and replay factor of the missions there it feels like they took too much out of the game and gave a few things back to appease the customer base with the "free" DLC -- why is it even DLC if it is free than it should of been in the base game. Some of the skins probably came later so sure just push a update and everyone has it. Point being is I have no issue with them have extra paid content as well as in general making a profit. I have a issue when it gets so in your face and as well as down right insulting. It is kinda like if you went to the movies and you bought a ticket, then you paid 10x to much for popcorn but the popcorn toppings are a paid DLC. Then you pay to get way too much salt in turn making you thirsty so you go buy a overpriced drink. After all that when you go to sit down and you feel 10 lbs lighter cause your wallet is empty you go and try to recline in the new recliners and there is a coin slot asking for another hand out for you to do so again. That it sniper elite 4 and 5 in a nutshell just 5 is even more in your face and bad about it. With 4 it felt in your face but with 5 it feels like they are in your face about it and then they even go as far to reach in your pocket for your wallet for you as a service. That is what I am displeased about. 

The missions are similar to sniper elite 4 but in some ways better. One annoying thing is looking at the map it is pretty easy to cover objectives and stuff you want to look at with popup boxes on other aspects of the map screen. Combat is pretty good and there is more vehicles on roads and stuff and makes for a heck of a time setting traps and you are much more likely to encounter scouts and patrols. Overall the additional patrols and scouts really make the levels feel more alive and unique. I like that aspect very much although it is not the only aspect I like. The thing I like most is customization to guns and the fact you can find special weapons in the levels and you can even pickup and shoot MG42s as well as there is the added anti material rife and the standard panzerfaust. There may be even more special weapons but I have only done 2 missions so far. I have yet to encounter any vehicles other than trucks, motorcycles and a few variants of cars but hopefully more will come in later missions. Generally I think this game is a improvement while at the same time not a overall improvement to sniper elite 4 as some stuff really did not change. There is tons of good improvements as well as the weapon customization's are amazing. Gives levels much more replay-ability when you can customize your weapons so much.  

The bad: They added yet more season DLCs and there is like 2 season passes it daft way worse than prior games and my stance is still the same the DLC should be in the base game.

Finished my first playthrough (Normal) and wanted to share my first impressions. 

I enjoyed the game and would recommend it if you enjoyed previous Sniper Elite and Zombie Army games. Dropped down to Normal on my first playthrough because for some reason I couldn't shoot straight at first. Only played the campaign, haven't played any Season Pass content yet. 

The main campaign was shorter than I expected but the missions and side objectives were what you'd expect from a Sniper Elite game. AA guns, lots of them. Nazis too.

Sniper Elite 5 reintroduces armour piercing ammo which makes dealing with armoured vehicles a lot quicker. There's also non-lethal, subsonic and match grade ammo. Can't say much about the new ammo types as I haven't really used them enough. Takedowns now offer a lethal or non-lethal option. 

Each map has 3 different starting locations, the default locations and two other locations that you have to find and unlock. A nice feature that allows you to mix things up a bit.

Rocks are replaced with empty bottles. No longer an infinite supply but you can find empty bottles all over the map. Throwing a bottle at an enemy's head will knock them unconscious which is handy and neat.

Truck engines can now also be used for sound cover, just like generators. Alarms are also new-ish. Once the alarm is triggered, sirens will call for reinforcements. Alarms can be disabled and booby trapped as well, so that's fun.

Zip lines to travel across larger distances relatively fast. I suppose they're handy but I'm not sure if they really add anything. 

A crowbar and bolt cutters are new tools. They can be used to open doors and supply crates, some can be opened by picking the lock or brute force, others only by brute force. You can also use them to cut holes in fences or sabotage mission objectives. 

The Kill List is a nice addition. Every mission has an optional objective to kill the target in a specific way. Some are easy, others are a bit trickier but they were fun to do and I'm sure I'll have fun with them in the next few playthroughs. 

I do have some issues with the game, though. Nothing that made me regret buying this game but I still want to mention them.

First of all, it is set in France. Not one French person to be shot, though. Not even civilians. In Italy we got to shoot Italians on both sides but in France the best we get are NPCs slipping in and out of their stupid French accents. Very disappointing.

The graphics are really nice, the fabric of Karl's sweater looks pretty realistic but at the same time the player models look a bit more plasticky. The facial animations are more detailed but look off, especially in the cut scenes. Corpses often have wide open, contorted mouths [strike] and for some reason a lot of them also end up sticking their asses in the air as if to say "Fick mich hart, Karl, du heißer Scharfschütze" [/strike] which is more comical than anything else.

I always found the Zombie Army games to a bit a jankier than the Sniper Elite games when it comes to the controls in general. Weapon handling was the most noticeable difference to me and  Sniper Elite 5 feels more in line with Zombie Army 4 than Sniper Elite 4.

Gun handling feels different, more Zombie Army than Sniper Elite but I can't quite explain what that means. The balancing of weapons and other decisions don't make sense to me. They added the Drilling shotgun but it doesn't have a rifle barrel, which is the defining feature of the Drilling. Also, Mosin, poor thing. 

Maps are big just like in SE4 but feel emptier, first few maps have a lot of open fields and hedges. Villages and military structures are smaller. Feels a bit more open world compared to SE4, if that makes sense. Maybe it's the difference in design, I think SE4 had better level design with elevation differences and pathing. Traversing the terrain in 5 is a lot jankier. Lots of invisible walls, hills you can't climb, obstacles you can't mount or vault.

Getting interaction prompts to appear can be a pain. Especially picking up items from safes was quite iffy. I point directly at the documents but no prompt, have to do a little dance to get the prompt and then I still have to pick up the TNT or ammo or whatever before the documents even register. Don't know why that is but it is annoying. 

Enemies are spread thin,  I first thought that was due to Normal difficulty but apparently it's no different on higher difficulties. Will find out for myself soon enough.

Not a big fan of locating work benches to unlock weapon upgrades. I suppose it's nice to change or upgrade your rifle on the go but adding three, one for pistol, SMG and rifle each is a bit much. I very much would have prefered individual weapon challenges like in SE4 to upgrade instead of unlocking them across the board.

And last, but not least, there sadly is no Overwatch mode. I'm sure Invasion can be fun but Overwatch was really good in SE4. A huge improvement on SE3 and I would've loved some DLC missions for Overwatch. 
I prefer co-op, don't really touch multiplayer so the removal of co-op Overwatch means a game with less content.

I've just finished my first play through of Campaign. When you choose to replay a mission you keep your rank, skills, weapons + customisation and items. You find or unlock items, weapons and ammo types with each mission, and can change or customise your load out at the start of each mission or at workbenches during game play. An item wheel allows for a quick change of ammo type, weapon or item -choose the most effective gear on the fly. Difficulty level ranges from very easy to masochistic, so pick your poison! Replay has the same mission objectives each time but as the environment isn't linear, you can find different approaches and also change your weapons and play style: stealth / assault / non-lethal. 
   Unlike some similar games, you can F5 quicksave and F9 quickload as well as create save games which I really like. The environment is cinematic, voice acting perfect, weapon handling realistic. Detonations are particularly satisfying. Just aim armour piercing ammo at conveniently highlighted weak / flammable spots and kerboooom. Get yourself a Panzerfaust and watch those tanks explode. Or sneak through long grass whilst the infantry yak in German either about their personal lives or even better about what the bosses are up to. Maps are well drawn with objectives clearly marked. Tutorial hints are really useful when you're learning the mechanics and you can turn them off in options when you've got the hang of them.
   All in all, a very satisfying experience.

This is fine, I'm not looking to play liveleak the game, but its bizarre how buttoned up and completely sterile the game is. Fuel doesn't burn enemies.The interaction as a whole is lacking, which is not what some people care about, but its been a decade. OK, after SE4 I expected an improved version of the game.Positive: great large maps in single player, a lot of love and sweat went into this game. The story line game play is a winner.Negative:1 Still can't get over threshold on your belly.2 Move on your belly against anything and you stand up automatically, thus having no control over staying down and in cover (this, I think, should have been taken care of by now)3 Multiplayer: maps are nice, but a bit small in most cases.4 Multiplayer: level up system sucks: instead of getting better yourself, playing more hours increases your skill exponentially (your digital self is getting better), thus creating games where one or two snipers can have a lot of fun at the expense of all others.5 Multiplayer: opponents can still spin around and/or hop up and down, spotting the opponent, but having very little chance of being hit = unreal game play in a sniper sim. Yup, this should have been made impossible.6 Anti cheat works for a lot perhaps, but not for play station 5 - opponents literally are at any location at once and always know where you are.7 There are too many bugs, including being kicked out by the server, changing to a riffle after placing a mine and not getting your riffle, gun of machine gun back (takes some effort and does not always succeed at expense of being defenceless).8 Using a knife is still too dominant: shooting in defence of a knife attack does absolutely nothing to the opponent, even if you stand at a ready and the opponent is still meters away (this should have been addressed even in SE4 already).9 Clearance while shooting is so marginal that you can't see the enemy at all, but you still will get shot - only a growing circle symbol gives the enemy away.10 Assigned mouse key suddenly does not work, needs a restart to work again.11 When the host of a mulitplayer game stops mid game, your points will be lost.12 Lying still on a slope makes lying still a joke. Most of the time, you will slowly slip out of cover. And an opponent out of view.13 After checking the scene with binoculars, grabbing the rifle often results into looking pretty far up. In reality, one would bring the riftle to the line of sights. Very annoying at best.14 Be ware of carpets, chains and threshholds: they will pose a major obstacle which will force you to get out of cover if you want to cross them.15 Lost connectivity again for the 4th time today... I was "signed out", error 11202.16 After having placed mines, I can't get to my gun. Unless I still have something to grab in my invenory. Gonna have to use that item then, before I can grab my rifle again. Still not solved.17 Wall huging is unvolunteraly and makes aiming near a wall difficult. Cost me a few nice shots.18 Multiplayer: for 20 players, the maps are somewhat cramped. One is almost forced to spawnkill players.19 Playing sniper in stead of Counter Strike or Day of Defeat is NOT rewarded really.Online (multiplayer) game play is nice if teams are balanced. However, Rebellion has programmed a system where you can gain levels up to 50. Once reached, you can start again, gaining better level up attributes - this you can do 4 more tier levels up. Keeps you busy, but screws up game play between tier level 0 and say tier level 2, 3 or 4 players. It takes away the fun in this game. Find yourself in one of these games, better to leave and find a better balanced set of teams.Rebellion still puts a lot of effort in nice and large maps.But Rebellion MISSES OUT on several very important aspects in game play, stuff that should and could have been sorted out by now. A real shame...

Fantastic addition to the Sniper Elite series!

(The only real thing bad with this edition is the crazy price of the expansions, so will get them someday on heavy sale. I also find it comical they added a "pacify" instead of kill option to the gameplay, but F that!  nazi-SCUM deserve to DIE no matter what, bonus xp be damned. haha)

Soooo, Sniper Elite 5.

Steam says I have played 30 hours. But it does not count first two or three missions, because I started playing them while in Microsoft Game Pass, that is add about 10 hours more. And that'll be time required to play the base game from start through the end (9 missions, actually 9th is very short), while in general one mission took me 4-5 hours o complete. Yes, I know, it is long time, but I like to explore everything and find what is there to find.
So what's new since Sniper Elite 4?

Workbenches in every map (3 per map), where you can unlock/modify your weapons while in mission.

Various weapons (usually slightly better in first missions) lying around to pick up and use while they has ammo. That is modified general weapons you can unlock by progressing thtough the game - silenced versions, stronger versions or with larger magazines etc. Plus there are weapons falling from every dead enemy, you can pick these weapons and use while they has ammo, or simply take ammo from them (need to unlock certain skill for that).

"Parkour". Yes, some climbing elements from Tomb Raider - ledges, ladders, vines, sliding down the slopes, ziplines. Interesting, useful.

I'm not sure if it is new since 4th game, but there are crowbars and bolt cutters in every map as well as locked doors, crates, walled with planks holes that needs these tools to open new paths.

Also the game still has safes with secret materials or secondary objectives. Safes can be opened with found keys or explosives.

As 4th game it has beautiful graphics and sound, retain hiding in tall grass, sound mask options where player can create them by himself where applicable or use those in the world (fight sounds, plane sounds etc)

One little personal disappointment I have to notice. Even with most difficult custom setting set to lowest amount of ammo found/dropped, there are still plenty of ammo to use. One minor bug I found where killed vehicles retained working engine sounds. And that is it from negative things.

In summary, if you liked 4th game, you'll also like the 5th one. Plus there are additional DLC missions, weapons and skins to unlock.

Oh, and now you can slow down or fast forward the flying bullet scene, I think it is also new feature.

So yeah, thanks for reading.

TLDR: This game doesn't play as well as its predecessors and really needs polishing in order for it to feel better. A strange downgrade with this installment compared to the rest of the franchise. But definitely try out Sniper Elite 4 if you're looking to play a smoother, less janky and well paced version of this game.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Compared to Sniper Elite 4, this game doesn't play well at all. I don't know what happened, but this feels like a downgrade to the franchise. It's hard to explain, but there were a lot of little things about the game that killed my experience playing it. Player movement was janky at times, and often wouldn't allow you to perform the action you wanted. Stealth could be ruined because of a glitched texture or object you thought you were safely hidden behind. And sometimes the enemies would just.. break ...and not move anymore, especially when you raised suspicion. 

These sorts of things were very smooth and well executed in SE4 but for some reason it's terrible in this game and it really killed my enjoyment of it. Things felt less intuitive and more forced and there were times where I thought I could get creative in my approach, but the game basically said I couldn't for no real reason. 

On top of that there were new mechanics implemented that felt unnecessary. Gun customizations instead of simple upgrades, non-lethal options for bullets and explosives that do nothing for overall gameplay or story, and character upgrades that didn't really change much in how you performed, and were too easy to level up.

The story was also all over the place. Without giving away too much, the game starts with you stuck behind enemy lines for the longest time, all by yourself aside from a few french revolutionists. And all of a sudden, after 3 or 4 of the levels going like that, you're then back with the allies invading Normandy?? There was no real flow to it after that because it felt like we skipped 3 or 4 chapters in a book. In the past, Sniper Elite games have had stories but it never really focused on them aside from providing backstory to the mission you were doing  and setting up the big bosses and their evil scheme that was supposed to turn the tide of war for Germany. It never needed to go further than that, but for some reason it's starting to and it's almost to Sniper Elite's detriment.

Overall while I really wanted to like this game, it just has too many issues for it to be worthwhile. It really felt like I was forcing myself to finish the game towards the end because I was fed up with it. If you've read this far, GO PLAY SNIPER ELITE 4!! I promise you that game is much more polished and very satisfying to play. I hope that future installments of Sniper Elite really try and smooth over these issues. Very disappointed to say "no" in my recommendation of this game.

[b]Positive[/b]
[list]
[*]Beautiful environments, lots of building details, overall nice graphical presentation.
[*]Fun and easy gameplay, new player friendly.[/list]
[b]Neutral[/b]
[list]
[*]Game is less of a sniper game and more of a stealth shooter game (like Hitman or Splinter Cell, they also have long shots).
[*]Good size maps, not too large, not too small.[/list]
[*]The story is ok. Nothing new, but not a big factor in my books.[/list]
[b]Bad[/b]
[list]
[*]40 years of computer games and yet, the first thing that highly trained soldiers do when they hear shots, they come running not to miss being shot themselves.
[*]Too much hand holding ("If I turn this wheel..."). Karl reminds himself EVERY TIME that the grass could be used to hide in. This all I would love to turn off and figure things out myself.
[*]Completely useless leveling system, all maxed rather fast, but not really granting useful benefits unless you run and gun.
[/list]

Initial review:

There are issues with movement, some invisible walls. Sometimes you can't get on a rock. Sometimes your scope range settings resets but it stills shows previous distance... some enemies are stupid as hell, sometimes investigation mode pops out just out of nothing even though there's just no reason for it...
But it's awesome game. Maps are good. I really enjoy stealth & snipe action.
Level design however was great, but .... first mission I felt like I should/could go everywhere and look for clues. Open field map with several buildings and you could guess that every building might have "intel" or "workbench" or some other collectible. It was easy to find them all. Next levels are flooded with buildings, many of them being empty. Finding all collectibles when playing pure stealth - is just impossible because you would have to check every building and corner. Some workbenches are in same building as you can enter, but cannot get to them the normal way and you need to search for every climbing area outside of building just to explore and get to them. I find it hilarious and it broke some of my fun. Had to use web guides just not to waste 4 hours stealth crawling through the map to collect everything important. Other  than that the gameplay is awesome.

Generally I don't like writing reviews, but i think this must stand on the lack of understanding that Gaming consumers DO NOT LIKE to have to spend more money for mediocre content, skins, accessories, loot boxes etc. This game has given me hours and hours of fun and great times in co-op. The graphics are good, the story is OK, i think the customization of load-outs and weapons is a great choice for the direction of the games future. Overall the game is good.

    Having said that, the overall business model for these AAA titles must change or risk losing their perspective fans. MASSIVE patches and updates just to load in some new shirts and "A" weapon skin "hearts and lips" valentine skin for your m1911 really ... Only to have the next release of,  what i would call worth while content, to of course be behind a pay wall of season 2.  An unnecessary expense when you can pack all of these into an expansion bundle vastly extending game play and RE-play ability. Unfortunately i will no longer be purchasing further season passes or DLC until massive discounts are applied for reasonable amount of content per expansion/ season.

 I hope others reach the same conclusion, and do not support this business model with their purchases.
