How the crap can a business incur charges upon the customer base, without making sure said product is free from problems?  Would you buy brand new Jordan's, if the soles were falling off, or a car that had clear issues with the steering wheel not turning left? If you said yes to either of those examples, you're the problem, not the answer.
I am all for capitalism, but when it crosses over into the spectrum of greed, I have a problem.
I won't buy it and I hope many feel the same. If nobody buys it...maybe they'll get the message?
Just my 2¢.

I've never wished for a 'meh' button on steam until I played this game. I had to play through the campaign a second time just to make up my mind on how I felt about it, and in the end it had to be a thumbs down.

I originally came into the series at SE3 and I liked it. SE4 came out and my mind was blown with all the features that were added, improvements in graphics etc. The two things that really did it for me in SE4 though were the level design and controls. The game was just a joy to play- you could get maybe 5-6 playthroughs of the same level and still find a completely different way to beat it every time. Also, the fact that the E key was a wildcard that could do everything was a really small change but made it damn near impossible to play any other game that didn't have the option to bind the same key to multiple actions, because I just got so much utility out of it. 

Neither of the two things that made SE4 stand out to me are present in this game. The level design is lazy at best but just infuriating most of the time because of one design decision: INVISIBLE WALLS. God, how I hate invisible walls. They. are. everywhere. Additionally, there are a lot of surfaces and (real) walls/ledges/fences that Karl just can't traverse or jump over despite being like 3ft high or very clearly accessible. You can really tell that the devs are forcing you onto a very linear and pre-planned path in every level. SE4 didn't do that, it gave you an environment not a path, and there was just a certain magic to that which doesn't really exist here. Also another thing that SE4 did fantastically was the cover system, the fact that my visibility to the enemy would change depending on a wide variety of environmental factors like lighting, bush/shrub presence, and distance from the enemy gave the game so much depth - it really made you feel like you were a commando officer sneaking around enemy lines. As you can presume this is completely non-existent in SE5. The enemies spot you from a mile away even if you're in a dark, well-hidden area, which takes away the tactical planning you would do everytime you enter a new area. If the enemy will spot you one way or another, why care about stealth... In a stealth game?

Also can we talk about the DLC for a second? Because good lord does it suck so far. I was never a fan of the weapons packs in any of the games, but at least there was always this element of realism before (even realism-adjacency I'd be fine with). But bright-pink colored guns with hearts on them for a "Valentines pack"? Seriously? This isn't Fortnite. Also for some reason the updates that drop with each of these new packs are always 50-100GB downloads, but there is never a changelog indicating that new features have been added...

What really adds insult to injury here is that there are shimmers of a better game beneath all the gunk. Small individual features like the improved environment sensing & minimap, the weapon upgrades, and the lethality system would have stood out so much better if they weren't tainted by the broader fact that SE5 abandoned a lot of things that made this series great.

I'll stay hopeful that the devs take the community's grievances on board and try to at least recapture the essence of the 4th game. But I'm not optimistic...

[b][i]This is a subjective review and may not be reflecting the true value or current state of the game.[/i][/b]

It's a [u][b]Meh[/b][/u] from me. SE5 doesn't give me the vibe like SE3 or SE4 did. Can't say I hate the game, but I don't take a liking to it, either.

The multiplayer modes (campaign co-op, survival and PVP) are almost dead now. The best case scenario I've ever seen was having 3 available lobbies of Survival Mode displayed on the server list. However, I was only able to join one of them. An error code [i]12011[/i] was given upon disconnecting from the other two, but I couldn't find any thread or FAQ explaining what this error code meant on the Internet.

I tried one of the maps of Survival mode, and that map was not fun at all. Too much fight in back alleys and on the streets, and your bolt-actions have little use here. 

"Invisible wall" is really an existing problem. Imagine a top-notch Ally sniper, going on a secret mission of sabotaging Axis's evil plans and assassinating the Führer, was UNABLE to traverse 10 square feet (1 square meter) of thigh-tall bushes which were sparser than the [spoiler]secret-spot hair of your average Russian triple-X stars.[/spoiler] 

Gun customization is somewhat useless and somewhat laughable. Non-lethal rounds on sniper rifles? Against the Axis? Seriously? And changing materials of your gun stocks is even funnier than all that. [spoiler]"Sorry bro, but we don't have that kind of trees around here. If you want to change your rifle stock from white birch to black walnut you will have to wait for the next supply shipment. Oh and BTW, that shipment has long gone due to recent U-boat attacks."[/spoiler] 

Compared with SE3 and SE4, SE5 is not an outstanding installment, nor an unforgettable finale of the series. I haven't beat the game yet, but I still made and carried out the decision of uninstalling it. Maybe I will pick it up one day when I have no other enjoyable games at hand.

What can I say that hasn't already  been said (4 was better). I really don't get how a company can take everything that makes a game enjoyable and just take it out. And even more miraculous is they didn't run into any of the issue while testing.

It seems like management had more of a say in this release than the actual developers.

Some of the issues:

* Invasion mechanic, on what planet do you enable it by default and penalize the player for turning it off (less XP).
* Kill shots look worse than in 4.
* Tagging is horrible.
* Removal of s-mines and trip mines.
* Emphasis on "realism", e.g. tanks are harder to destroy, no more infinite stones, but still implement a non-lethal side. 
* I don't get the non-lethal combat, nobody ever got a medal for not killing the enemy during a war.
* Weird focus system (not really realism, if you ask me).
* Subsonic bullets are a joke.
* Some of the bugs:
  * Enemy bodies disappearing
  * It's not an open world, I've been stuck behind bushes/walls that my 5 year old nephew could vault.
* The list goes on.

All and it's just not fun for me, it feels less like a sniper game and more like a close combat game. I'll be switching back to playing 4.
Just like the last entry, this game allows you to shoot Hitler in the balls in slow motion. What more could you possibly want.

Overall the game is improved over SN4, but I think it has become too easy for hard core Snipers. SN4 was already a bit too easy - Authentic Plus helped, but not enough, so its absence in SN5 is a big minus, with the lure of  frequent saves being too hard to resist, promoting a cavalier attitude that detracts from the game.
Maybe I'll look into the custom difficulty settings, and re-evaluate. Maps are quite good.

Sniper Elite 5 has been released for many months now, and in my own opinion, it's one of the best games of the franchise.  However, it does have its flaws.  Despite being released as a sniping game, it is fairly easy to complete each mission with an assault style playthrough, utilizing unscoped rifles and the various secondary weapons.  If its a more realistic take you desire, a pure stealth sniping route could easily land you 60+ hours of gameplay, and it is worth just about every hour.  Observing patrol routes, calculating the trajectories, pacifying or killing lone sentries, every action demands your utmost attention and ability to plan out the next move.  For example, it takes me about 6 to 7 hours of gameplay just to complete each mission undetected.  The option for just simple run-and-gun DOOM style fighting can also work if that's more your speed.

Moving on from basic gameplay, the visuals are stunning, the levels are large and feature various zones to either blitz or sneak through, and the ability to pick up weapons from fallen enemies and supply crates is a plus, in my mind.  Each level has a hidden cache with at least one MG42 and a belt of 100 rounds to neutralize large groups of soldiers, while Panzerfausts and Panzerbusche anti-tank rifles can deliver stand-off attacks on armored vehicles and troop transports.  Every encounter can be dealt with in a variety of ways, and while that's not a new feature in the series, it's the best implementation of it so far.

The AI can be rather smart at times, but is still rather easy to fool.  Soldiers will take cover when shot at, and if you're using a suppressor on your rifle, this can lead to them actually retreating and falling farther and farther back, but this only works if you are outside of their detection range, which is another very well-implemented gameplay mechanic.  I've played way too many games that feature the Hollywood-esque suppressor where your weapon is silent at all ranges.  The suppressors in this game though work exactly as they should, and while they significantly reduce the range at which your shots can be heard, they don't completely remove them either.

The various types of ammunition you can unlock during the game is another great feature, although the less said about the nonlethal rounds, the better.  Subsonic ammunition though is a game changer, and combine that with a customised Welrod, and you can complete missions with just that sidearm.  And speaking of unlocks, it just feels reminiscent of Call of Duty and Battlefield, where you have to meet the prerequisites to obtain them, from attachments to weapons and gear.  I did enjoy having to find the workbenches to mount the new attachments or utilize the new kit, but it does get a bit ridiculous.  Have you seen a Tarkov-inspired Luger?  Some of the attachments just don't work like that at all.

Moving on to weapons, the selection was pretty decent, but I wish there was more!  The SREM-1 is a nifty little rifle that I actually did not know anything about.  I'd never even heard of it, and thought Rebellion was pulling my leg, until I watched Saint Jonathon at the Royal Armouries actually talk about it and show off the only surviving example.  Speaking of which, Rebellion, would you please complete it's model, it's missing a scope ring, and the point where that can be attached is easily seen on the handguard.  Moving on from that, for a game based in France, there's not a lot of French weapons available.  I was expecting to see a Lebel or a Berthier, maybe even a MAS-36, but maybe that's for a later DLC package, I'm not sure.  I wasn't expecting to see Japanese weapons and equipment, so that was a little weird despite being central to the campaign.

And that leads to a new issue, the campaign is basically the same: the Nazis have a new superweapon, you have to follow all the leads to find said superweapon, then you blow it up and kill the man in charge.  That was V2 with a V2 rocket loaded with Tabun gas, that was 3 with the P.1000 Ratte superheavy tank, that was 4 with an upgraded radio-guided rocket, and now we have stealth-plated submarines with V2 rockets.  The formula is getting tired at this point.  Same for the Hitler assassination missions.  Don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with killing Hitler.  It's just, when are we going to be able to target other senior Nazi officials?  I've shot Hitler's testicle off in four separate games now.  I no longer have that juvenile chuckle.

And now we get to the major issue I've been having.  Sniper Elite 5 is still acting like its out of Alpha and into Beta.  I'm having game-crashing bugs practically every level, more often 2 to 3 times per level.  I don't know if that's because the code is still a little iffy or if it's because my hard drive isn't capable of running it, all I do know is that this issue still needs worked on.  If you've read this far, good for you, make sure your PC is up to the minimum requirements, but I highly recommend going as far beyond that as you financially can.  Maybe it's just me, but I don't have the money to throw at it right now.  I will say that it is very frustrating having to restart my PC multiple times just to finish a single mission.

Well, that's all I've got.  Make sure you get your free DLC downloads when they come out, because hey, they're free even if they don't do much of anything gameplay wise.  I can't say much for the rest of the DLC, I don't have them yet.  Sniper Elite 5 is another solid addition to the franchise, but what's next?  We've gone to Berlin, to North Africa, to Italy, and now France.  There's only so much more Karl Fairburne can do before V2 begins, so will we see him again in the Netherlands as part of Market Garden, or maybe in Belgium for the Battle of the Bulge?  All I know is, his story is almost done, if not done already.  That's up to Rebellion, but I think they might still have one more installment before calling it quits.

This is a good game to play if you've got time to kill, and if you can handle the game-ending bugs and hope they get patched, then this game could be a good entry into your library.  If you want to snipe, look no further.  If you want to run-and-gun, you can do that here.  If you want to be the SOE-equivalent of James Bond, that's here too.  If you have the previous entries, then you know Karl's story so far, but now you have to help him liberate France.  The war is in it's final act, the Western Allies have landed in Normandy, the Soviet Union is moving in from the East, and the Third Reich has less than a year to live.  What insane wonder weapon will they come up next, and who's the next officer to assassinate?  Hopefully, we'll find out next time.  Take care, everybody, and remember: 'Vive la France!'

This game is a 4/5. I really enjoyed the realism of SE 4. 

The Sniper Elite series seems to strive for authenticity. It's hardest mode is called "Authentic", and honestly I'll be damned if it's not the most authentic shooter experience in a game I've had; wind/bullet drop, smart AI etc. But there are basic flaws in the game that make the authentic mode inauthentic and a lot harder, it's terribly frustrating to be killed be inauthenticities when that's the whole point.

1. When searching an enemy for loot, lives enemies can come upon you and shoot and it takes way too long for our character to disengage searching and engage in fighting. 
2. Can't shoot all lights out in SE 5. In SE4 not only could you shoot out basically every light to provide cover of darkness, you could through rocks and do it silently. That was SO COOL.
3. Authentic provides no indication of health, but wouldn't we have some idea how close we were to death if we'd been shot? I guess it's all out the window since we can continuously patch ourselves with bandages and med kits but still. 
4. Melee should be instant kill. We are a super elite bad ass, and yet some of these German foot soldiers can block us again and again and again. One soldier I even shot first, then tried to melee, and he was still able to block me indefinitely. C'mon. 

Still love the game. Recommend.

Kind of - except when you have to download 100gb every update. The levels are full of invisiwalls. The weapons are a real let-down actually. SE4 had a good list, why not offer that, plus more? The non-lethal options for a sniper game is... questionable, at best. Just like many other design choices for #5.

I've put in 250 hours at this point.  100% Achievement was incredibly easy in this game, but in the end, it really didn't mater, because, compared to SE4, this game is a pile of steaming sh*t.  SE5 is missing, and I mean, MISSING the entire 'feel' and 'in game experience' that SE4 provided x 10. In SE4, the weapons, and I mean ALL of the weapons, are FUN to use, are 'visceral', and just plain fun to use.  In SE5, the weapons, and I mean ALL of the weapons [as few as there are], have no 'feel' to them, they ALL feel incredibly  'bland'....especially the machine guns, which 'feel' like I am shooting a gun made out of straw.  ..Sniping in SE5 is MISSING that special 'mixture' of difficulty, and visceral feedback.  All gone.  A 500 meter shot in SE5 can be accomplished by a 4 year old, but, again, it really doesn't matter because the entire 'experience' in-game is just plain empty.  Missions : ALL the missions kind of feel 'bland', and have no soul.  Missions in SE4 are just plain BORING.  And maybe THEE most rotten thing they did to SE5 is that the REMOVED......ALL....of the 'in-game' points tally, ALL of the in-game earning of medals, and ALL of the in-game 'special shot' notifications.  ALL gone.  You no longer get ANY of the 'nice positive feelings' IN-game that took place in SE4, you NO LONGER 'earn' any levels beyond level 40, which you will reach BEFORE you even get close to finishing the game.  I have gone back to  playing SE4 and I have to say, it leaps and bounds more 'fun' to play....and ALL the guns are very satisfying to use, as is going out with your 'gold skins', which, again, are NOW missing from the game.  All in all, SE5 is just a terrible disappointment.  And, No, I don't need to be 'pounded' by ALL female operatives telling me what to do and how to do it.  Female operatives in WW2.....telling American Special Ops Ghosts what to do...???  Really..???  I don't think so.  Utterly absurd.  And last by by no means least : the no-cross multiplayer is 100% waste of gaming design resources, it is a wholesale insult to ALL of us.  ..As is so called 'invasion' mode, which is TOTALLY stupid as-implemented.  If you're going to attempt to do something like an 'invasion' mode, THEN strap it down with utterly stupid limitations that make zero sense, the I say : screw yourself Rebellion.  Save your money and time.  Just buy SE4.  It is superior in ALL respects.  ..and I mean ALL.

I 100% this game with my best friend Jim since we played sniper 4 and had a blast with it. Playing this game threw with a friend was very fun and a great challenge. We even went the extra mile and got all those extra missions in the game that are not achievement based, but require some good shots or skills to get even more items to use and play in the game.

In sniper 4 I couldn't rambo my way threw a level, i needed to learn, adjust, and get better to win. Where in this one it felt like I could go into a gun fight with 10 people, and get out okay, loot there bodies and get enough healing to counter act all the pain they gave me.

Playing this with my friend it was a blast, although we enjoyed the gameplay style, we both agreed that this PvE was way easier on the hardest mode then Sniper 4 was, and like I aid earlier, I don't play this for PvP at all so look to someone else review for PvP.

Another good one in the line of Sniper Elite games. Good graphics, good game play, nice AI's and multiple modes to play (survival, campaign and multiplayer). If you like the Sniper Elite games; I would definitely recommend this one as well.

Well, Sniper 4 was better ) 
Weapons customization - useless and boring. Plot - boring (as usually, but here is like 2 from 5).
Hidden walls - this is unbelievable. Still a lot of bugs like NPC visible through walls or dispersal after dying.

If you've enjoyed the Sniper Elite games this is certainly a step forward. The levels are a little bigger and mostly better, with a couple of exceptions. The system of "how far a shot can be heard" is more complex now and there are new techniques and tactics you can use. Graphics are excellent. 
The price is a little high and the DLC should probably be included in the base game, and there are a couple of levels that are a bit simplistic - but really this is a great game with a lot of variety.

Other than the campaign i really only care for survival, but its annoying because if the host rage quits or get disconnected, everyone else is out of luck. This is especially annoying when it happens in the final waves, which happens the most it seems. so 20+ minutes in, you just get sent back to the lobby and receive nothing.

--- PROS:

+ Great gear customizability. Plenty of different types of muzzles, suppresors, scopes, receivers, etc. You can tailor your guns to your personal playstyle. For each weapon configuration you're given the exact distance at which the shot will be inaudible (suppressors only make it a little quieter, even on lower difficulties). Suppressors can now be used independently of ammo type, allowing for many different levels of gunshot audibility (most quiet of course being suppressor plus subsonic ammo).

+ Increased ammo variety. Vehicles are now immune to regular ammo, even at weak points. Only armor-piercing bullets can hurt them. Subsonic ammo is quieter but has greater bullet drop. Match ammo has reduced bullet drop but is louder. Soft-point ammo deals more damage to human targets but can't penetrate armor or helmets. Additionally there's non-lethal ammo - quieter and doesn't kill (in case you suddenly feel sorry for those poor low-ranking nazis).

+ Music - somewhat better and more noticable than in SE4, at least in my opinion.

+ NPC dialogue. In SE4 nazis sounded like cartoonish villains. Now they sound more like human beings.

--- PROS/CONS (depending on personal preferences):

+/- In addition to the wind indicator in scoped view which allows for horizontal adjustments, there's now also a similar indicator for gravity. This makes sniping less reliant on luck, but also probably a bit easier. Some people will like it, some won't.

+/- When aiming at an enemy with any weapon, there's now an icon above his head if he's within audible range of your gunshot. Same as with sniping, this makes stealth less reliant on luck, but also easier. Again, a matter of taste.

+/- No more "authentic plus" difficulty. "Authentic" is now the highest. Hardcore fans and realism nuts will probably be dissapointed.

--- CONS:

- Map design could be slightly better, with more vantage points and sniping opportunities (except "Spy Academy" - this one is a masterpiece).

- Fairburne is now wearing some lousy sweater, which makes him look significantly less badass.

+VE: gorgeous graphics.  immersive sound.  manual save and load - very few games have this.  
-VE: faulty bots that do silly things, initially tricky to deal with but weaknesses become obvious.
awesome game sniper feels realistic and the combat is good story is awesome  and im loving this game

So I just wrapped up the base game with the goal of killing every soldier in every level. Took about 47 hours and lots of patience. Out of SE3, SE4, and SE5, this was my favorite, and I thoroughly enjoyed the other games. 

I took a firm stealth approach to the entire game, which worked out very well. If you like that sort of playstyle, you will enjoy this. If analyzing troop movements and finding short strike windows is your thing, this game has it in spades. 

What I liked...

- The weapon customization is detailed enough to be fun, although a few of the items are a little silly. I'm looking at you, weirdly-crossed grip tape.

- The visuals are fantastic.

- Soldier bios - This was a nice touch. It allows you to get to know your quarry before you put a bullet through its skull. Not sure why they added this feature, but it was kind of funny.

- The suppressed rifle sounds actually sound fairly realistic. As someone who spends a good deal of time on the range and spent seven years in the Army, it's nice to hear a game get this right.

What I didn't like...

- I'm not a fan of "weapon/item unlock" mechanics in games. I'm not even sure why developers put these in games any more. It would be great if you started with the ability to build your loadout however you wanted. The pros and cons of each weapon/item should be enough on their own to prevent any particular loadout from being overpowered.

- I'm not a fan of the way the player icon displays on the map. I know, it's a small thing, but when you are trying to orient yourself on maps this size, the direction of the character icon should reflect the way the camera is facing instead of the character's body. This is a minor annoyance when you are in cover, which is a lot of the time. 

- Constant kill cams get old. Look, I loved this game. Thought it was great, but if I smoke 150+ dudes on one map, I have to watch 150 kill cams. Each one runs about seven seconds. That's 17+ minutes of kill cams. Bruh, that's a bit much. I know you can turn them off completely, but what about a happy medium or some way to modify the kill cam frequency? This is just one bald dude's opinion.

Overall, this was a great game. Definitely took top spot for me for the SE series of games. I'll be buying the DLC so I can go smoke the dude with the bad haircut and the toothbrush mustache next. Have fun dropping bodies. I certainly did.

If you like SE4.......

I held off buying SE5 because of negative reviews and the many similar complaints among them. I almost let those negative opinions influence me to pass up this game I am enjoying. Here are some of the common gripes that are just not true......

1) "Not open world". "Game-play is funneled by obstacles". 
NOT TRUE.  The map can be traversed by many ways just as in SE4. Even with hedgerows that are common to north France, I feel no constriction.
2) "Few  opportunities for sniper long shots." "Penalized for remaining in one place too long." 
NOT TRUE. I find many vantage points where I remain undetected that afford plenty of opportunity for those satisfying long shots. But if I remain concealed in place too long near the enemy the AI has increasing chance to spot me. 
3) "Feels less like a sniper game and more like a special ops stealth game" and "Stealth is not done well."
NOT TRUE. SE5 offers both and does both very well. And when time comes to run and gun well placed grenades and sub-machine gun spray provide very exciting game play.

Single player.....
Much is said about multi-play and Invasion mode but I play only single-play. Invasion mode can be toggled off. Solo play through the campaign is very enjoyable.

Replay value....
Campaign maps provide many ways to complete and the enemy AI will challenge in diverse ways resulting in unique play every time. 

I could go on. But you the reader have also seen the objections that have you hesitant like I was to try SE5. So I write this positive review with hope my words will help you decide to give SE5 a try. Be aware of the time spent playing as you test the game for yourself. Do not go over the two hour refund mark. If you do not like SE5 then just refund it. But I know some of you are like me and will discover SE5 to be a very enjoyable experience.

After  trying The 4th, which I partly enjoyed, I gave a one more shot for the new Sniper Elite. 
It's been a second game from this series for me, and in my opinion the best of all by far.

[u] Personal thoughts: [/u]

What made me to feel good in this, is that Sniper Elite finally came to France, 1944. That is what I like about it. That is a proof you can make WW2 game still with very modern and solid gameplay, that won't be totally generic.
Surprisingly D-Day doesn't felt like before in this title.  It used to have in call of duty series but, here, SE 5 is one and only a non-multiplayer game like (Post-Scriptum, HLL) that allows you to explore open maps based on Normandy locations. Still having their own and new flavour.
And some maps are enough big to let you enjoy the Normandy from open perspective. What is enjoying too, the number of WW2 guns and their customization is beyond satisfying, and it isnt over-looked nor overdone. If you're a WW2 enthusiasts you can love this series, I'm glad the Normandy came to this series with fresh look. Possibly next game will head towards the Pacific as some hints can be found in the game or into the Ardennes, Belgium, but we will see...

[u] What game offers? [/u]

- large maps and long missions 
- good and fresh looking Normandy and D-Day setting
- replayability e.g. exploring map=unlocking new start locations ,or unlocking new objectives
- use of different paths and fight methods
- good gun customization
- plenty of weapons and attachments to use (smgs, assault rifles, sniper rifles)
- invasion mode in campaign - the enemy player, playing as Wehrmacht's sniper tries to eliminate and stop you, or you can play to stop someone's missions
- multiplayer - with no run'gun cod like, just sniping , no crossing to run, very nice like in Ghost Warrior Games.

[u] What it doesn't offer? [/u]

- not all maps are that super big, half of them is in standard size
- only a couple missions where u play with other squad members or protect squads 
- still lone wolf game, doesn't involve you in that 'large' battle feeling

[u] Issues? [/u]

Game is very well optimized. As the minimum requirements are presented, you can still have 3gb or even less of VRAM, to enjoy the game. Tested on Gtx 750 ti, gtx 760 and finally on 1050ti. Graphics are really nice. Sometimes but much rarely, u can spot dead bodies to glitch in textures and not properly collide with some terrain objects. Not too often.
Sniper Elite 5 is really great game from the series. Though I spent good hours in this game, I feel it should have more missions as there are 8 (basic edition)- however pretty long to complete them 100%.

[u] Any improvements? [/u] 

- new possibilities of enemies AI, they aren't that stupid like before in SE Afrika (what I have heard before) or  you have to respect enemies in open engagement even on easy difficulty and plan your tactic.
- new movement and shot animations, 
- new audio effects: gun shots are extremely good, it's well made that silenced rifles are still loud, which is correct in real life.
- longer missions and more items to use, as well plenty explore and to find in loot.

[u] Conclusion: [/u]

Though I spent good hours in this game, I feel it should have more missions as there are 8- however very long to complete, and each location looks completely different. Apparently SE5 is the best from the series, still it is being updated with new content. The best game to grab from the series. If they make next part in the Pacific Theater it would be total epicness.

If you've never played Sniper Elite but enjoy games like MGS:V or the Splinter Cell series, you will probably like Sniper Elite 5. There is a focus on stealth-action/espionage gameplay, but unfortunately the actual stealth isn't as good as either of those games. 

Instead there are sniping elements like bullet drop, wind speed, and 'sound masking', with a bit of a focus on things like managing your heart rate - e.g if you sprint for a while, your increased heart rate will make your sniper scope unsteady until you catch your breath, and if you are bleeding from a wound then your heart rate will not decrease until you use a bandage or medkit. 

You can also customise elements of difficulty like turning the minimap, and enemy marking on or off. After going through the game once I found going through a second time without a map or markers was an excellent challenge, because you really need to make some of those shots count.

Be aware that the game is a bit janky. There are invisible walls around the edges of missions, and there is no jump button, so sometimes you can't climb over really simple barriers like chest high walls or small rocky slopes (instead you get a button prompt to climb things like walls and fences if it is possible). It makes just a couple of parts of the game seem weird and confusing. But when it is good, it is REALLY good and you can have some seriously fun and very tense moments moving through very detailed European castles and cities. Trying to do a no kill run can be very difficult.

The most fun comes from the co-op and invasion modes, which add extra layers to the experience and allow you to come back and approach missions in entirely new ways. Invasions especially require players to keep moving and always be alert to their surroundings. 

At the time of writing there is one frustrating issue where the player character will narrate information to himself out loud for the benefit of the player (e.g "I see the enemy bunker up ahead, looks like the intel was correct.") and the invading player can hear him speaking to himself. The defending player cannot currently turn these narrations or control their speaking volume when being invaded, which means they might unintentionally give themselves away just by walking into a new area. With enough feedback the developers should be able to patch something like this. EDIT: they fixed this issue.

2nd Edit:  Still crashes at 1440p

I enjoyed it, mostly.
I liked the maps and they did feel open world to me, nonetheless what other people said. Sure, there are some choke points, like doors in a wall you need to get to the other side of, but that's no biggie for me.

But. what is it you expect from a sniper game? Long distance, try to not be noticed? Somehow that game didn't get the memo.
I mean sure, in each chapter you get to do some nice long distance shots, but often you need to get closer, like 50-100 meters. Still distance, sure, but then the other problem comes in, stealth.
You only get proper silencers quite far in and even they are just "noticeable up to 50-80 meters" and often you're forced to get closer. You can use sub-sonic ammo to reduce it quite a bit but somehow the game designers decided that you can only unlock those for the loadout halfway through the game and then get like 15 shots or so and you can nearly never find them in the levels after mission 2. You find loads of non-lethal wooden ammo tho (everyone knows a pointy block of wood hitting you at supersonic speeds just knock you out).
I remember in mission 3, where you assault a castle. Was quite a way away from it, but had no silencers yet, only basic bitch sniper rifle (not that the later ones were all that great) and no subsonic. One shot. And the whole freaking map searched for me. Dudes from a bridge far away searched for me.

So most of the game you either don't bother with stealth at all, go into hiding after every shot until the enemies search no more or actually just go up close with takedowns and the pistol that is properly silenced.
A sniper game where going for melee is the better option. Figure.

There were a list of other annoyances. Like kill someone from a distance that carries a letter. Continue sneakily cleaning up the location, save frequently. Screw up, reload. Finish. Go to the body with the letter to pick it up and whoops, it never loaded in when you reloaded, kiss that letter goodbye.
Or tanks, even smallish ones. Tanks are tanks, sure, but why would you need several bazookas, several blocks of TNT or a satchel charge and one or two packs of TNT? Just make them indestructible if you really don't want the player to kill one.
Also Karl, we're 8 missions in. I think I know by now that I can hide in tall grass without you repeating it every time I touch some.

At the end, this game has it's problems, but all in all, I had fun, I enjoyed it.

Ahh. Sniper. I get dreams about you. Even years after playing the first sniper game, the bullet drop calculation, the wait for the perfect moment and then, the squeeze of the trigger (rather the slow decisive keystroke) and immediately, the slow-mo. 
Dopamine goes Brrrrrr.....

The fifth installment does not disappoint. The same "basic" storyline, the same "generic" baddies and NPCs, "adjusted for inflation" graphics and the "tried and tested" gameplay. Nothing to surprise, nothing to disappoint.

I did however face a slurry of nasty bugs. From the trigger of my sniper stopping to work till I save and reload, or interaction points not "interacting", and enemies moonwalking stuck between a backyard garden and fence. It took me out of the immersion but thankfully, I did not have to restart a mission so all good.

The best part was the non-sniping slealth mechanics. I miss Splinter cell like a cat misses catnip. I came to this game hoping to scratch the itch of my cold bullet drop calculating brain blowing head-shot from 200 mtrs away, but this game scratched my sneak and prowl slowly and get stab them up their helmet itch that old Sam Fisher would scratch. Thank you for that. 

And work on the bugs devs. Fuck you and see you next installment.

There was a lot of people saying "oh invasion is broken, I can't play the game if Jaeger snipers are too strong/weak" or "I don't like it, the level design is terrible and it feels like it's on rails" or "I really preferred 4" etc...
I really enjoy this game, idk what everyone hates it for. Got it on Christmas sale around £25, thought it was a great instalment to follow Italia. The level design is good, I loved how most levels had fun heavy weapons like MG42s and Panzerfausts everywhere if you look close enough.
The weapon customisation system is great, I saw some criticism of it but it's really extensive and there are quite a few ways to build an inventory, rather than token visual effects. All the enemies scale with how far you get into a campaign, the jaegers were genuinely potent in firefights instead of glorified rifle fodder.
Visually stunning, especially the third mission in the castle. Was surprised how detailed the thing was and how little dead space was left.
Would recommend an instant buy for <£30 sales, otherwise depends how beefy your wallet is.

Many are saying this is a step backwards from SE4, but to be honest, there's a lot to enjoy here, especially if you play it on Authentic difficulty (all settings on authentic). 

The best sniping maps are after the 4th map in my opinion, and if you can get through the first 4, the game really starts to shine. The exceptions are the second map, Occupied Residence, and the third map, Spy Academy, which were interesting and had a fun mix of gameplay styles, Spy Academy in particular. 

A tip is to do a bit of scouting before entering areas and immediately starting to stealth kill enemies. A lot of the time you'll kill everyone and miss a good sniping spot where you could have nested yourself and taken them on from there, creating a sound mask by sabotaging a nearby generator. 

Another tip is to put FSR onto Ultra (if you can) and turn off anti-aliasing. The game is quite jaggy and has quite a bit of shimmering, particularly in the foliage, and FSR smooths it out while looking a lot like your native res. Turning anti-aliasing off makes the image sharper while in FSR Ultra mode, so in the end you end up getting a free 10-20fps while making the game look better (I play in 1080p by the way). Play the game on high settings instead of Ultra as well. 

To conclude, the maps are interesting, unique, large, and are lengthy to complete; the gameplay loop is fun; and a bunch of other things they added like weapon customisation and achievements etc. Have fun sniping!

10 hours in this game and I already got tired within the first 20 minutes.

PROS:
1) Nice extension of the storyline from Sniper Elite 4; writers are to be commended.
 
2) Graphics and takedown animations are FANTASTIC providing player satisfaction in taking out enemies and seeing GORGEOUS architecture (makes me want to travel to Europe!).

3) The game mechanics are familiar from previous editions; players pick up right where they left off.

4) Lighting/Shadowing very realistic if you set-up as intended; (snipers not easily localized at first).

5) Storyline very well-developed; kudos to developers for making campaign mode educational with real history references (HINT: Make games super-historically accurate and then schools can promote their use in the classroom --bigger bottom line for the developers while educating the masses!).

CONS:
1) Main character should be able to jump/climb up, over, down anything in the game; give character ability to cur wires fences or barbed wire with bolt/wire cutters - CURRENTLY UNABLE

2) Main character should be able to start with items accrued from last mission- CURRENTLY UNABLE

3) Main character should be able to access weapon mods of previous missions at workbenches in subsequent missions - CURRENTLY UNABLE

4) MORE points given for knocking unconscious or NOT killing enemies (incapacitation) is lame - DEVELOPERS OBVIOUSLY FEEL SORRY FOR NAZIS AND WANT YOU NOT TO KILL THEM, JUST INCAPACITATE.

5) "Mission Boundary" indicators are lame; this is where Snipers Eiite needs to become more open-world. Make it so that there are like things in the way (rubbish, debris, walls, crashed vehicles, etc.) that prevents character from going there rather than basically telling player 'uh sorry, you are at our game limits." 

Suggestions for improvement:
1) Allow players to access their inventory in something other than just the utility wheel to show what has been picked up and what still can sought out. Having menus in different places (wheel/TAB menu/etc.) seems over-burdensome [copyright issues with other titles?]


2) Let player be able to climb over anything you could reasonably climb over or crawl under anything you could reasonably crawl under.  I mean who has not seen old WWII movies where the OSS is hiding under the train car or vehicle and then grabs the feet of the passing sentry to take them down????

3) In terms of freedom of character movement,,...and sorry for this reference, but think Ghost Recon / Division style movement - not necessarily parkour, but at least be able to jump up on a roof to take a long shot across a field at a target.

4) Cinematic animations should reflect correct gender/character used in mission; seems default is to use Karl Fairburne all the time; please fix; not a gameplay issue, more so a polishing issue.

5) Go open world, if you can, in Sniper Elite 6 and beyond.

BOTTOM LINE: Would I buy the game again knowing what I know after 5 missions? Absolutely, YES. 
(I understand this is not a AAA title, but the developers obviously worked their butts off to give us players an enjoyable experience with the budget they had; KUDOS!)

Pros:
-Beautiful maps and environments
-In-depth gun customization


Cons:
-Enemy AI will sometimes be permanently stuck in the "Searching" status, leading to autosaves being disabled for 15+ minutes at a time
-Enemy AI will sometimes see you through solid walls
-Enemy AI will switch between having no reaction to you whatsoever and immediately gunning you down the moment you're in their sight
-Enemy AI will sometimes break entirely, leading them to climbing ladders, falling down immediately after, and repeating the process until they die from fall damage
-Enemy AI will pinpoint your exact location nearly every time you shoot somebody
-The game, despite having "Sniper" in the title, encourages you to and rewards you for using non-lethal options (Leading to the famous Sniper Elite X-ray Cam rarely ever being seen) and also encourages you to use your pistol instead of your sniper due to the aforementioned pinpointing mechanics
-Maps, despite feeling and looking wide-open and large, are incredibly structured and linear once examined while playing
-Kill-List assassinations will hide their optional rewarding objective until you manually open the objectives tab and expand the assassination mission
-The game withholds XP from you for disabling the Axis Invasion setting
-The ending of the story is incredibly anticlimactic and wasn't rewarding in the slightest

Nice game but a bit too forgiving once you have a bit of experience. An Authentic+ mode would be greatly appreciated. The invasion mechanic adds a nice challenge to the game, both for the Jager and the Sniper.

It's a good Sniper Elite game. If you liked the other ones, it's more of the same. You're not going to be playing this game for the story or the characters. You'll be playing it to shoot bad Germans. Level design is good, but I would prefer more options and verticality when it comes to how to approach objectives. The enemy AI is a but dumb, but it doesn't stop the game from being fun. Gameplay has very little variety (shoot the bad guys is as deep as it gets) but it feels good enough that it's engaging the whole time. The weapons feel pretty good and satisfying, but I never really cared for the pistols; they always felt a little 'soft' and weak. Stealth is handled well and there's some finesse to timing shots and properly lining up a good long-range headshot. Get it on sale; I beat it in 14 hours with a reasonable amount of quick-save and quick-load retries.

This is a mostly phenomenal entry to the series. The new features are thoughtful and there are many quality of life improvements.

[b]Invasion Mode[/b] is well suited for a game like this ([i]invade other player's single player missions, with consent ofc, like in Souls games[/i]).

The UI is looking fresh af, even for us Authentic fans. The maps are gorgeously hand crafted. The scenery flows with a noticeable lack of graphical tiling.

The main thing I would like to see added, is the aggressive AI from SE4's Authentic Plus mode. It's hard to tell how much of that was carried over, now that we have one less Authentic level of difficulty. I just really liked how they would never stop searching for you. They would form search parties and fan out all over the map. The upside to that extra challenge, was that you could lure many more soldiers onto the same set of traps.

I also really enjoyed earning the achievements for beating the Authentic modes in SE4 without saving, or manually saving. Those were fun, very challenging, and ultimately forced me to change my play style from stealthy to guerrilla tactics (messing up was much faster that way). I would not have minded seeing those again. I probably won't go for perfect completion this time around, anyways.

I've played the earlier iterations through, and I've played SE5 through. This latest iteration (SE5) introduces some maddening gotchas that make it feel badly-designed and poorly-conceived compared to the earlier iterations. Especially as a AAA game at around $50 USD, it's a rip-off. I got it on a half-price sale and still don't feel like it was worth the cost. If you can pick it up for under $20, you might get your money's worth, but maybe not. It depends upon your willingness to endure the badness. Personally, I find the wonky glitches to be problematical enough that I cannot recommend it.

MANY of the other negative reviews mention my same points, so I would urge you to take the negative reviews seriously! But I'll reiterate just some of the problems for special emphasis.

* Rebellion totally broke body-looting compared to previous iterations! WHY? WHY redesign a system that worked just fine before. In SE5 you have to be perfectly lined-up with a body and looking "down" at it to even get the option to "Search." That's maddening enough, because it's often ridiculously time-consuming to try to get lined up just right to be able to "Search." But....

* MUCH worse is that even when you are lined up just right, you hold "E" to "Search," and instead the dumb interface immediately grabs the nearest weapon (that might even be behind you!) that the body dropped onto the ground! I don't WANT that weapon! I did everything possible to NOT pick it up! But, noooo. This dumb game is just determined that if I hit "E" (even as a "hold" of the key) I MUST want that weapon. It's flat-out ridiculous, and by the time you finish the game, you'll be raging at the number of times you are FORCED to pick up and then drop a weapon you did NOT want to pick up. So, in summary, the looting system is ABSURDLY broken!

* The armored vehicles are stupid-hard to deal with. In previous iterations, you could take them out with Teller mine and/or TNT, which is legit! The 40s-era armor couldn't withstand a Teller/TNT combo, but in SE5 NO amount of explosives can one-shot an armored vehicle. Instead, you must deal explosives damage and then position yourself behind the vehicle and start pumping armor-piercing rounds into the exposed (after the initial explosives) "weak spots" until the thing blows up. It's just time-consuming, inaccurate artificial difficulty. Complete waste of time/effort that does the opposite of adding to the "realism" of the game.

* This is NOT a "sniper" game, like previous iterations were. You are often forced by terrain, buildings, etc. into close-quarters combat. I've actually killed more MOBs with my Welrod than with my sniper rifle.

* A big part of the above (virtually forced) play style is that SE5 utterly nerfed your capacity to CHOOSE to take a silenced shot versus a loud shot. There is NO subsonic ammo for the rifle, as in ALL other iterations of this franchise! You have to choose a silenced WEAPON, but even then the sonic reduction is at most about 30%, which doesn't really affect your strategic decisions. Again, WHY? WHY break/remove one of the key features that made the franchise great? So, Rebellion has decided that if you want to go silenced, you'll use the Welrod, because (did I mention?) the silenced rifles (that I've seen) DON'T HAVE A SCOPE! Whaaatttt?!? Yes, you read that right: If you pick up or chose a silenced rifle, you get no scope! Is this a bug? It can't be a design-decision, because that would be insane! But, yes, you cannot switch between a silenced shot and a loud shot at will in the game. Ridiculous! For me, this was almost a deal-breaker.

I could go on and on and on and on. READ the other negative reviews, and BELIEVE them! But I'll mention one important point that I haven't seen mentioned in the other reviews: This game is WOKE! And it's relentlessly so.

Throughout the game, you are surrounded in enemy dialog, and it's all WOKE. You get tortured language like, "Find the sniper and kill them!" Or, "Sniper, we're gonna find you. Troops, find them. They have to be around here somewhere." And it goes on and on. It's stupid and tortured to refer to a person in the singular and then the plural! Yeah, yeah, I hear in some quarters today that "they" and "them" are now also singular terms. NO THEY ARE NOT! They are not CORRECTLY singular terms, and I REFUSE to destroy language itself to serve a woke agenda! So, now this has to be crammed down my throat in a GAME! Seriously!

Even worse is that this game is set in the mid 1940s, NOT 2022! Moreover, Karl is an obviously manly-man who would NEVER identify as "non-binary" or some such confusion! YOU play AS Karl, and if you don't want to "identify" AS KARL, then go play some other game. In THIS game, there is ZERO doubt that Karl is a MAN, so there is ZERO doubt that HIS preferred pronouns (what a made-up term in its own right) would be HE and HIM! So, the German soldiers of the 40s would be saying, "Find the sniper and kill him!" NOTHING else!!! And if the game is determined to avoid "offensive pronouns," then don't use pronouns! Say things like, "Find the sniper! KILL the sniper!" Simple. But no. Rebellion is making a point here.

Moreover, regardless of how KARL would "identify," there is ZERO chance that German soldiers of the 40s would be using WOKE language! Period! So now we have a game that is literally going to PRETEND that 40s-era German soldiers would be talking like modern snowflakes? Absolutely NOT. QUIT projecting your wokeness back into history. This is a VERY recent dysphoria, and it IS a dysphoria rather than normalcy. That dysphoria was NOT "normalized" back where this game is set.

Worse, this is RELENTLESS throughout the game. Rebellion is making a POINT here, folks! So, when you buy this game (at any price) you ARE paying to support a flagrant and relentless woke agenda. So, vote with your money if this matters to you.

In summary, even without the wokeness, this game is quite bad and a notable decline from its predecessors. It is NOT of the quality of the previous iterations of the franchise, so I wouldn't recommend it anyway. But add in the relentless wokeness, and it's just BAD! IMO, not worth your money. BELIEVE the negative reviews (which are many and which keep noting most of the same points).

Definitely a great game to play by yourself or with a friend. There's enough variables in each shot to make you question "do I really need to take this shot or can I find a better angle" or something similar to that affect that keeps the player honest rather and the game from feeling like a shooting gallery. The story, meh, typical bad guys are bad plot and gritty monologues by the main character, but you're not here for a Quentin Tarantino level story. 

As for the negatives, the weapon selection feels sparse and there's not much variation to make the player ask which weapon is best for certain missions. That said, the weapons are more than adequate in function and feel. I suppose the two biggest negatives are the bullet-xray cinematics are too common and extremely distracting during co-op missions since you both will view each other's kills. You can turn it off, but that feels like throwing the baby out with the bath water. Lastly and most infuriating is the player movement, either your character's spirit animal is a newborn giraffe or the game developers need to take extensive notes from the previous Sniper Elite installment to develop a better solution. 

Summary: Great game, there's enough chance and acceptable amount of "I didn't see that coming" with each shot you take to keep the game from feeling like a fish in a barrel simulator. The maps are vast, as expected and take about 1.5hrs to complete each thoroughly. The main issues are the bullet-xray cam being overused in single player and too distracting in co-op. You can turn it off, but then you miss it entirely. Worst of all, the movement mechanics are C L U N K Y! Be prepared to miss ladders and fight to fit through a doorway. Overall rating: 7/10 - Buy it on sale.

Pros: 
+ One of the few games which supports crossplay PC - Xbox One/Series, for me it was a key point since my partner has only Xbox SX at his disposal
+ Cooperative and invading are fun as hell. It’s not just a tactical stealth action, but can be also highly dynamic: no one forces you to be silent all the time, even on hard difficulty.
+ AI is surprisingly smart and creative.
+ The locations design: these meadows, lakes and castles are very pleasing for eyes.
+ Except a few glitches, this game works quite stable and does not irritate you with crashes/endless bugs/syncing problems.
Cons:
- Visual shimmering and ugly distant aliasing, it hurts my eyes and makes precision aiming/spotting enemies more challenging, especially if the screen resolution is 1080p or below (VRS/DSR doesn't help). DLSS/FFX 2.0 could solve a problem, but this engine doesn't support it - only outdated and terrible Fidelity FX 1.0
- Game design sometimes forces you to wander around the map for some nonsense. Why can't I crack the lock with bazooka or mine, but need a damn satchel which could be very difficult to find? Or in one mission I was looking for a valve for 15 mins.
- Clunky controls. For example, there are no keys to use medicine or grenade, you have to choose the thing and then use F, so in some instances you accidentally explode yourself instead of healing.
- Lackluster story - it is NOT a dealbreaker here. Thanks for the developer all cutscenes can be skipped.
I would give this game a solid 8 out of 10: strongly recommend it for walkthrough with your friends, especially considering the fact that there are not many cool options for crossplay. Imperfect, rough, but you still won't regret the time spent.

I am a fan of the series, I like the pace, the thinking, the trying to be quiet. 
Positive:
- There is more difference between the rifles than in 4, so you can select a rifle that suits you. Be aware that special kills get you more rifles
- As usual, large missions with a lot of freedom. Good maps with a lot of detail and great atmosphere. So a fun a experience. If you pay 30 Euro for it, that is a good price. Took me 34 hrs to finish on medium difficulty
- Complete personal difficulty setting with many details included. Experiment with this
- High replay value
Mediocre/bad  
- The game engine is a bit outdated. The looks are great but the movement is clumsy and erratic., especially fast movement. Reacts poorly to mouse when moving/steering
- The slow motion cam and X-ray cam get boring fast so personally I switch them off. 
- Both you and your enemies are bullet sponges (at medium difficulty) so soldiers will walk away from 20 bullets with a machine gun. That kind of mechanics do fit not this game. But you can adjust this in the difficulty settings
- there is a ,lot of indoor fighting and short range fighting. probably 50% sniping and sneaking, 30% pistol action and 20% just gunning and blowing stuff up. I found myself looking for opportunities to do more sniping!
- the skill points don't seem to do a lot or add a lot. So the ranking does little , as it did in the previous games.
Verdict:
I would rate it a somewhere between a 7-8 out of 10. All in all a good game with replay value

This game is so refined mechanics wise but one of the worst in the series. The gun play, movement, and customization are fantastic(Excluding them messing up the m30 drilling in one of the dlc) and make the game feel like gold. However the maps and enemies are awful. The maps are beautiful but lack the challenge that the older games had, they try to give you more options in ways to do the mission but instead make it so that you can just hide in spots away from enemies and never have to worry about actual combat. The map design makes stealth so easy that you could accidentally stealth missions. The enemy AI is ridiculously stupid if you do end up getting spotted instead of shooting at you sometimes they will just stare at you, or turn around and sprint towards the alarm, but don't worry about the alarm as you can just shoot it and then hide in a corner for 30 seconds and suddenly everyone forgets you even existed. Even on the hardest difficulty the game is not hard enemies die from being breathed on and shoot toothpicks at you opposed to bullets, the AI is what makes the game so easy in combination with the map design. The Sniping in the game is ok, but honestly pretty boring as the bullet drop and wind is barely at all effected by the game difficulties.

This is an average sniper game and a mediocre third/first person FPS.

Just some of the deficiencies:

- you are penalised for camping in invasion mode,  WTF!??! it's a sniper game FFS!!!
- playing as Karl in invasion mode is OP - a rebalance and improvement of this mode is desperately needed
- dead multiplayer (depends on location though)
- game regularly CTDs when loading into an invasion game (no error message or anything)
- game sometimes doesn't close down properly
- headless chicken AI
- bullet-sponge enemies in authentic mode
- enemies hit with a sniper round can recover and be firing their pistol at you quicker than you can chamber the next round
- enemy animations are ridiculously quick
- what you would think would be Karl's internal monologue can be heard by the invading sniper - why Rebellion, why!?!
- you go from a densely populated and impressively complex map like Spy Academy to a dull and sparsely populated map like War Factory
- invisible walls

Overall, I think Rebellion phoned this one in and got invaded by mediocrity.

Rebellion has obviously put a lot of work into updating this game from SE4. There are two innovations here. The first is much improved AI behaviour. I bumped into an SS officer running up the stairwell in the hotel on the first level and tried to melee kill him. He fought back, blocking 4 or 5 of my attempts and we both struggled to grab out sidearms. He was faster than I was and I went down. Very nice and a huge surprise. It is nearly impossible to fire a weapon completely unnoticed. The AI's will systematically hunt you down, working together to surround you and flush you out. They will sneak up behind you all the time. Watch your 6.

The other innovation in SE5 is non-lethal mode. There is non-lethal ammo and a non-lethal melee takedown. You get extra points for this, and it's generally quieter than a kill melee, so you can do this standing right next to another AI without alerting them.

So far I've played the first level through with all the defaults, and then in Authentic Mode which I find far more enjoyable. I use an xbox 360 controller.

Speaking of the controller, I find some of the selection mechanics really difficult and clunky. Rebellion needs to work on this. Picking stuff up, searching bodies, and even choosing things from the inventory wheel is just way too hard. Maybe it's easier with the keyboard/mouse. Dunno. Needs fixing.

This is worth the money. Maybe in SE6 they'll start putting citizens into the maps. It's pretty much the only thing missing now.

A fine addition to the Sniper Elite family. A great variation of missions, which can be solved in many ways. Main campaign is about 30 to 40 hrs on medium 'speed'. For fans, a must have. Best in the series yet!

I was skeptical of buying this game because I saw the reviews with the crashes and various bugs - it appears the devs have fixed the issues because I just played through with no problems so far.

Another reason why I was skeptical - people were saying that "you can't snipe long range" or that "it's not a sniper game" and it's not open world enough. To me, this game has everything you could want in an open world sniper shooter.

Approach any level with your own strategy - customize your guns to fit your style of play. It's all here.

I loved the Sniper Ghost Warrior series and this reminds me of the open play of Sniper Ghost Warrior 3 with the intensity of a close combat shooter with the feeling of sniping in a movie. Dang, it has it all. 

Enemies are smarter and will hunt you down realistically. Stealth is more realistic too. You can't just knock a guy out and expect no one to notice. Enemy officers check in on their squads...if they find that it's too quiet or that no one is communicating (because you killed the whole squad), he is going to check in on them.

All I gotta say is get this game. If you like making your own path you will love it. If you like everything structured, you'll still enjoy it. 

PS - you can shoot SMGS and Pistols with Iron Sights now! And you can pick up enemy weapons and use open sights too - this opens up even more avenues for fun gameplay. I ran out of ammo fighting of 20 guys, picked up a dead soldier's MP40 mid gun fight and began to tear down bad guys. It was surreal!

Pros:
  - Innovative gameplay and the UI is user-friendly
  - Better accessibility features
  - DLCs aren't locked with DRM
Cons:
  - The writing is rather boring and dull (Don't care)
  - No french voice over even though you're in France
  - It's prequel, Sniper Elite 4 is "graphically superior" (more aesthetically pleasant)
  - Time to beat is low for it's price
  - Too many DLCs (and they don't add too much content/play time)
  - Denuvo (+ Easy Anti-Cheat which can be disabled)
  - Bugfest

This is just disappointing to see how Rebellion has been treating the Sniper Elite franchise over the last few years and it is taking the wrong direction. Although I am grateful to this franchise because it has helped me bond with my father since the first one.

If you like war games where you kill Nazis it's pretty fun. It's a bit rough around the edges, and it has fairly limited maps, but those maps are very large and there's a good amount of play time value there, especially if you feel like playing maps again to perfect your approach, try different loadouts and tactics, or find all the collectibles.

By no means a perfect game, but I certainly feel I got my money's worth.

Sniper Elite 5 is no cooler, more innovative, or interesting than any of the other games it succeeds.

It is woefully historically inaccurate, with massive silencers on machine guns, extensive weapon modifications and customization that function exclusively on the rule of cool, and even using Japanese weapons in a French liberation campaign.

There are no new cool features or missions, you get to kill Hitler yet again, and the game is even easier than its predecessors on Authentic mode.

Even so, it's the only game I can play with my old man that we both enjoy. Have fun with the 500th WW2 game with no real substance.

This is a pretty good general improvement over sniper elite 4, SE4 authentic modes are far more challenging though. For those that dont know the series, theres basically a large map you have to roam and do objectives for each mission, eventually uncovering a new nazi weapon and preventing them from using it to win the war. You fight enemies at extreme range sniping and yes enemies snipers are nasty, you fight at mid-close range with SMGs or pistols, or take enemies out through melee but sneaking around and catching them off guard.
Some solid changes are no more throwing rocks, you throw bottles now and they can knock soldiers out when you peg one in the head. I liked the rocks but i abused them thoroughly.
You arent limited to kills, you can now knock enemies out with melee or even special bullets, the advantage is faster exp gain if theyre alive at the end of the mission * you can even use them as bodies if you want multi kill medals/achieves.
Theres new types of special ammo such as AP and bleed bullets incase you wing a hiding enemy.
The authenic modes arent so much an improvement and they felt easier, your scope now has a bullet drop as well as a wind indicator that is accurate and makes authentic sniping alot easier, theres also further ranged shots to do, one as far as 1,870m that i know of that i managed to do in authentic, i enjoyed the authentic and theres no achievement requirement of completing on authentic with no saves.
Theres a focus mode where you can see the outline of enemies making noise nearby, not available in authentic, they dont make it that easy.
Multi player is also active.
I wont spoil it too much but you will definitely enjoy this especially if you like SE4.
The only thing i legitimately dont like is they have removed the crouch running that SE4 has, they should also think about tackle kills where you can run at an enemy and smash/stab them into the ground which would be good if theyre looking into a bush and you want to quickly charge them and get back into hiding.

Ini adalah game ke-5 dari serial Sniper elite yang harusnya kalian sudah main dari 1-4 ketika melihat review ini, jadi yang akan saya bahas adalah beberapa fitur yang menurut saya dihilangkan atau dikurangi dari game ini yang membuat ciri khas game nya itu hilang, [1] Kita udah ngga bisa lagi lari sambil jongkok yang mana gerakan ini adalah gerakan paling fleksible yang dimiliki oleh sniper elite, [2] Kita ngga bisa manjat rintangan-rintangan kecil, seperti tumpukan batu atau karung yang menurut logika itu bisa kita panjat demi mendapatkan pandangan tembak yang lebih layak, [3] Kamera setelah kita bidik sniper via Scope tidak kembali pada titik semula yang membuat kita harus mengembalikan posisi kamera secara manual yang membuat saya terkadang mual(motion sickness), dan satu-satunya tambahan fitur pada game ini adalah kita bisa atur kecepatan peluru X-ray dari 0-100% yang membuatnya lebih dramatis, sisanya 8/10

Update 17/12/2022:
Game runs on linux again. Switch to vulcan and select proton Experimental. 
Update 01/12/2022:
The game used to run on linux (albeit without multiplayer, obviously because of anticheat, which is fine) but then the latest update bricked it. Kind of a deal breaker for me.

Update 01/07/2022:

Snipers are no longer kicked or killed for camping on the players side. I still feel like the game penalizes it a bit too much, but it's a welcome change. I have also quite been enjoying invasion mode, even with the occasional time where the game forces your patience to go unrewarded.

Original review below.

I was really excited for the new invasion mode. Seems like it would be a lot of fun!

"Enemy sniper was eliminated for camping" I'm sorry, what? It's already bad enough that the axis player basically gets led to the enemy, but then you just get deleted for camping? Sniping is a game of campers at it's best! Getting and keeping a key vantage point is super important to any sniper. Snipers, by nature, are campers. That's the whole point. I want my enemy to be able to camp if they want. It's no fun if the game just kills them because I was doing my job too good by cutting off their advance. 

I'm sure it's no fun for the campaign player, either.

If this is changed, I'll change my review. But penalizing campers in a sniper game is such a bad choice.

Ok now this, [i]this[/i] is how you do a stealth sandbox experience. Great googly-moogly! It's kind of amazing to play this after the Plague Tale games, where the narrative is prized above all, and the game is like, "ok after you watch this 5-minute cutscene, you can have a brief stealth section with maybe 10 - 11 guards. But then you have to listen to 7 minutes of whispered dialog and do a puzzle!" Sniper Elite 5 is all like, "Uh...story? Ok! So...the Third Reich is building another superweapon called...*checks crayon scribbles*...O P E R A T I O N   K R A K E N! Now here's a gigantic map crawling with nazis, go ruin their day!" The game absolutely does not care about the story and that is just fine with me. Every map is [i]terrifyingly[/i] gigantic and will give you hours upon hours of sneaking around nazi installations, sabotaging nazi equiment, popping nazi skulls with your all-American bullets (or knife, or grenade, etc). And it's not just that the maps are large, they are incredibly detailed - every problem has multiple solutions, every destination has multiple paths and there are multiple objectives to choose from. You can see Rebellion play around with different ideas too, like one map that takes place on an island and it looks like a normal-sized SE4 map but as you snoop around, you find that there is this sprawling underground facility with more tunnels than an ant farm. It was really cool, like being in some sort of 70s espionage film. Oh and there's also a colossal nazi castle. IMO this is by far the best level in any of the Sniper Elite games. There's so much you can do - from the starting area, you can snipe dozens of enemies, then you can wind through the streets, sneaking and knifing guards as you please, taking out elite soldiers in the sprawling beach in the back. You eventually make your way to the very top and spy on the three krauts planning the operation, assassinating them individually as they make their way to the ground floor. There was also a school for spies that sums up the many ways you can approach a challenging problem. There were about six agents and I didn't really have the twitch skills to go in guns blazing. I could have thrown a grenade, but they were spread out and I would have been spotted by the survivors. I decided to toss some TNT at three of them that were close together; of the remaining three, one of them barged through the front door, which I had prepared with a proximity mine. The others were not going to share his fate, so one made for the side door, which I had also laced with proximity mines. Finally, the remaining spy beat a hasty retreat for a secret downstairs tunnel, which I had also prepped with a proximity mine. All I had to do was hide in a corner and let out a chuckle as their tortured screams filled the afternoon air.

There isn't as much sound-masked sniping as in 3, or even 4, but there are definitely 'shooting gallery' moments where you get your chance to snipe many many guards. The rest plays like a conventional stealth game and I didn't mind that. It's almost like a WW2-era Splinter Cell game - the last level is even similar to the Korea map from Chaos Theory, with you making your way through war-torn streets and enemy propaganda blasting through loudspeakers. There are some improvements over the previous installments. You now no longer have to press a button to tag an enemy, you can just hover over them for a few seconds and they're tagged. It's now possible to alt-tab without crashing the game, which is a bonus! The "radar" is better now (for the difficulties that use it) - it used to portray the enemies as dots on the HUD, which was a bit too easy since you knew exactly where they were at all times. Now, there will be a large translucent white circle that only shows their general area. You can only track them once they've been tagged. The difficulty level is also very atomistic, which I appreciated. You can decide how difficult you want separate components, like the aiming, the enemy AI, the HUD, etc. You can also have "invasions" - a multiplayer aspect where other players can enter your level and hunt you; you can use special phones to get an idea of the invader's location, but this also gives them a hint as to where you are. I didn't try it but you may like it if you're a Dark Souls fan. There's also a skill system that feels a bit tacked-on. You gain XP to gain more skills and they're fairly unremarkable - more health points, more items in your loadout, etc. I guess it's a more tangible xp reward system than previous games, but I could have probably lived without it.

Sound design is excellent, with very vivid foley work - also, I very much appreciated hearing the germanic cursing of your name to the sky, all the while yelling out loud that they're not afraid of the mighty GHOST SNIPER. The music is quite well done but I was very amused that, because the game takes place in France, the composer makes several attempts at shoehorning an accordion into even the sinister and tense string sections. The attempt at making the accordion into a menacing instrument is [i]adorable[/i]. A for effort. The AI is ok, nothing great. If you snipe without sound masking, guards will attempt to get a bead on your location and will frantically search for where the shots are coming from - of course if you make several shots from the same location, then I hope you surrounded your nest with proximity mines! Guards can sometimes get "stuck" which is an example of the buggy behavior that you can sometimes see in the game. However, Rebellion has done a lot of patching and also provided a free DLC - all the bugs that I encountered were mere nuisances and never prevented me from completing any objectives. Although, if multiplayer is your thing, I've heard that the included Easy Anti-Cheat can be a huge headache and you may want to proceed with caution. I didn't test it out myself. Aside from that, I note that bottles are much more useful now...they will almost always distract the AI away, even if they're actively hunting. This can help if you need a strategic way around multiple mobs.

One of the maps had almost two hundred enemies in it. I almost felt like a pest exterminator. So what's the verdict? Well if you prefer a more tight, corralled stealth experience then the incredibly vast maps of SE5 may not be your thing. It is extremely my jam though, and would recommend it wholeheartedly.
