As much as I have enjoyed the previous installments in the series, unfortunately this game did not live up to the expectations that were set. For example I could not get my crosshair to appear (which appears to be a common bug) and after trying every fix I could the problem was yet to be resolved. With a missing crosshair I could not enjoyably play a sniper oriented game and had to give a refund as a result.

While I did somewhat enjoy this game, I simply cannot recommend this game in its current state at all or asking price. This is nowhere close worth 50 dollars nor even the 35 I spent on sale. The game has too many issues and problems that I don't even know where to begin.

I'll start off by saying I loved Sniper Elite 3/4 for many reasons but this doesn't feel good in any regards to them.  Bugs everywhere like enemies disappearing right before your eyes, enemies randomly spawning in areas you cleared previously, no reticle when aiming, enemies floating on objects, the list goes on and on and on. For a game about sniping as well, this is the most linear open level designs I've come across in awhile. I had to replay the entire first mission again that took me 3 hrs all because the mission glitched and never gave an extraction point...which wasn't fixed till two months later by the way. Only 2 out of the 9 maps felt any fun to roam in at all and hardly any of this game actually feels good to snipe in. Enemy AI is also beyond busted with glitches of them seeing you through the map and the fact they can be both braindead as hell but have the eyes of a hawk or react to things that make no sense to react to. This games about sniping yet hardly any of the games design relies on it or uses it at all. Hardly anything to be able to soundmask shots or get into far away engagements. Even when you can soundmask using a generator or vehicle, once again the map is so poorly designed that only about 1 or 2 enemies can even be killed before it becomes useless. Rubble and Ruin was the only map in the campaign that actually managed to do a good job of this and remind me of why I like this series. 

The games optimization is pretty poor, especially for users like myself running on a 1080p monitor specifically do to their god AWFUL anti-aliasing system. Moving the camera in any direction shows off horrendous flickering/shimmering coming off just about any reflective surfaces like water, shadows, bushes and windows. Gates and doors are also heavily affected as well making this game look stunningly terrible in otherwise a really good looking game. Graphically this game looks impressive but the anti-aliasing ruins it entirely and butchers the quality of it all. Performance is a mixed bag as a whole as I currently have a 13700k, rtx 3070, and 32 gbs and see regular dips when on ultra regardless if on vulkan or dx12. Turning down certain settings has alleviated a lot of issues but it amazes me after watching an optimization guide that these settings on ultra vs medium/high show almost no graphical difference but effect fps that heavily showcasing how badly done this game was handled. 

In general too, this games design choices are also baffling. Removing the ability to throw rocks in favor of finding bottles on the map to throw around, the welrod pistol reticle hardly ever hitting where you actually aim (legit the worst pistol in a game I've ever used period), making so many map sections linear as hell or multiple floors that take ages to climb for boring ass collectibles or eliminating an enemy or two making it a time consuming waste. The new decision to make endless vehicles spawn on roads, the mission objectives practically being the same every level, and basically butchering just about everything that made the previous games good were downgraded in every capacity here. Also the new addition of the skill trees was utterly pointless as hell. Skills that add hardly ANYTHING into the game at all for such minimalistic changes. It just is such an inferior game to 3/4 which were handled with such love and care while this feels just thrown at your face. I can't even speak for the Invasion or multiplayer modes but i heard they are disasters too. Forgot to mention when it came to performance this game crashes a lot. It had crashed five times at startup and about another 4-5 times through gameplay. Just pathetic! 

When the game functions and actually plays...it's ok! (Wrote on 12/11/2022, does contain spoilers, TLDR at end)

I've been a big fan of this series since Sniper Elite V2 was released, with Sniper Elite 4 being my favorite by far. So, most of this review will be written as a comparison to Sniper Elite 4. I haven't played any multiplayer yet (including the invasion mode of the single player campaign), so this is going to mainly be about the campaign.

For starters, the graphics are better than SE4...hands down. The maps/map design was maybe on par with SE4--the maps/levels seemed to be a little bigger, but ultimately they were roughly the same as far as size and potential routes/paths go. The ability to traverse the maps--whether through climbing vines or using ziplines--seemed more in-depth and varied (and using ziplines is fun too).

The "Kill List" objectives to unlock weapons was entertaining at least, but they weren't very hard to do. And while the weapon customization is nice (and the task of finding the workbenches adds a nice little side challenge to each mission), I feel as though recoil control, aim stability and suppressor upgrades are the only worthwhile rifle upgrades. Here's why:

The longest shot I was able to make in the campaign was around 475m in the Spy Academy mission if I remember correctly, and that involved a lot of positioning myself to make that long distance possible. Outside of that shot and a couple others in "Rubble and Ruin," the average shot distance in a campaign mission I was able to pull off--just by roughly guesstimating--is somewhere between 100m and 200m. That was a bit of a disappointment to me, as in the *very first* mission of SE4, you are able to make about 12-14 shots (maybe more) that are between 200m and 400m without going very far from the starting position. So, unless there are "hidden" or "secret" long shots (kinda like in SE3)...muzzle velocity, scope zoom level, and match grade ammo is all but useless unless you just hate compensating for wind and gravity.

The "sped up" weapon reloads seem more like a multiplayer gimmick to me, as does the "focus" ability that basically gives you free wall hacks for a certain period of time. I also miss the items/inventory wheel of SE4 where you had nothing but lethal traps/explosives, health items and unlimited rocks/a whistle. You could really make some mayhem in those days. In SE5, your only lethal options are a landmine, grenade, or TNT (and I only really used time-delayed TNT to destroy vehicles when I couldn't get close enough to use a satchel charge or I couldn't find a Panzerfaust), you have a limited supply of bottles--which took the place of rocks, which were unlimited--and the non-lethal Schu Mines...well....I didn't use them once, since the only time you need to knock somebody unconscious is for the Kill List challenge where you have to kill the one officer by burying him in concrete, and you can KO somebody by using your knife/melee takedown. The decoys weren't really useful either, since if you take the right skills, people will get tagged if they shoot at you...which means you don't need to throw out a decoy to get their position.

The skill upgrades were nice, but most of them were either useless, or weren't necessary/very helpful. Like, yeah...it's nice to be able to have enemies get temporarily tagged when they shoot at me, but isn't that what the decoy is for? You can get by without using traps for the entire campaign (ask me how I know) so you really don't need an increased supply of those or be able to throw them down faster, yeah the "focus" skill is nice...but that's basically free wall hacks for a certain period of time. The only ones worth it to me would be the ones that give you slots for special ammo, and the ones that reduce how fast your heart rate rises. And even to that point, the only special ammo that is worth your time would be the AP ammo so you can one-shot enemies through their helmet with your Pistol & SMG, or destroy vehicles in fewer shots.

When it came to the enemies and how hard they were to conquer...I was again disappointed. I found them more annoying than challenging (I was playing on Sniper Elite difficulty, the one where you have to compensate for both distance and wind), and I was able to go through the whole campaign without dying at the hands of the enemy (I can honestly say that the only times I died was because I stood too close to a satchel charge, or because I took hella fall damage from trying to parkour my way through the level). The engineers were cool in that they could undo/fix your sabotaged generator or truck to take away your soundmasking, and the snipers caused you to be extra careful unless you wanted a "bleeding" wound that forced you to use one of your precious med items...but everyone else was just kinda...a nuisance rather than a credible threat. The enemy variety is roughly the same as SE4: radio operators and spotters were replaced by gunners and engineers. Most everyone else you already know and love, with a few variants sprinkled in (like Vampir Jagers or Elite Snipers).

Even the vehicles weren't hard to deal with. If you can't satchel charge them, if there isn't a Panzerfaust nearby, or you can't use a landmine to stop them, just lob some TNT on a timer near them and call it good--it might take two or three TNTs, but it'll work. Run out of TNT before that King Tiger went boom? Just load some AP ammo in your weapon of choice (whether it be the Welrod, MP40 or something else) and just keep shooting the glowing red area.

Satchel charges are either useless or the only key you'll ever need, depending on whether you want to go full stealth or guns blazing. If you take the time and have the patience to take out everyone on the map or hunt down officers...you probably won't need satchel charges unless an objective specifically calls for you to use a satchel charge. Or alternatively, you can just blast your way through doors, safes and walls since you can usually find more than enough to get you through the mission.

The ending was really anti-climactic as well. "That is quite some distance Mr. Fairburne..." *Binoculars say the distance is 230m to the target* "Hurry! Before he gets away!" *Target stops on a balcony, then leisurely strolls to his car before slowly driving away* Sniper Elite V2's final shot was harder than the final shot in this one.

TL;DR While I'm not too disappointed with SE5, I was honestly expecting more. The enemies aren't really a challenge, most traps are useless, and almost half the weapon upgrades seem useless unless you really just want to have a laser beam of a gun that laughs in the face of wind and gravity. There isn't really a lot of opportunity for taking long distance shots (200m or further), unless you really look for them or are willing to do the necessary legwork to set up a long shot. And even if you take your time and go through each mission slowly...the campaign still seems really short. Blasting people with the anti-tank rifle was really fun though, I would recommend using the anti-tank rifle on infantry and nothing else.

All things considered, SE5 isn't a bad game...but I believe that SE4 is better.

I first played Sniper Elite 4 and enjoyed it so much that I ended up getting V2, 3 and now 5 soon after.  These games remind me of what I liked so much about the older Call of Duty and Medal of Honor games back when they were single-player only.  They focus on a vibrant single player story, fun game play and polished level design instead of just large bland arenas designed for endless PvP.  The name says "Sniper Elite" but the game allows you to play however you want.  Want to snipe from hundreds of meters away and play "pop goes the Nazi"?  Great!  Want to set up an explosive booby trap for nosy patrolling enemy?  No problem!  Want to charge into a bunker and clean it out with an SMG?  Go for it!  The missions drop you in a large open-world-ish map (each mission gets it's own specific map) with a couple known objectives along with some extra objectives that can be found while playing.  Apart from that, you are free to chose how you complete them and in what order.  The maps are also beautifully designed (aside from occasional invisible wall) and suit the story and missions well.  The over all result feels like a classic WWII action movie.

I also enjoy that the series knows what it wants to be and keeps polishing the concept and expanding it.  The games are not very realistic (taking out a tank with a few well-placed rifle rounds??  lol!)  but much more importantly they are FUN to play.  The enemy AI is not brilliant but they will take cover, attempt to flank your position and raise alarms to call in their nearby allies.  There are lots of collectibles to find and things to unlock which gives it more replay value than most single player game IMHO.  

My one minor criticism is that it is often easy to chose a defensible location, setup a few booby traps and make a grand racket to piss off half the enemies on the map and then wipe them out as the try to storm your location, leaving you to explore the map unbothered afterwards.  I played on  "Sharpshooter" (medium?) difficulty though, so this might be less true on higher difficulty settings?  Also, the enemy models in kill-cams sometimes seem to lock solid in their death animations which looks a bit awkward?  A more random rag-doll animation might be better.

Sniper Elite 5 is the most polished yet but V2, 3 and 4 are also excellent and worth playing as well.  I got the versions with DLC included and enjoyed the DLC missions as well.  These games usually have great deals on Steams sales too.

Sniper Elite 5 is a third person shooter set during World War 2, where player character Karl Fairburne is sent on another mission to stop a top secret Nazi weapons project being developed in France.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

•	Missions take place in ruined cities, rural towns, and fortified German strongholds. Each location is quite large and contains multiple main and secondary objectives. There are usually a few different paths to move around each map.

•	You can equip a sniper rifle, SMG, and pistol. There are several different types of each weapon to unlock, and most of the ones I tried felt pretty good to use.

•	Each weapon can be customised with mods which are unlocked by finding workbenches hidden around each map. You can adjust stats such as damage, rate of fire, clip size, recoil, noise range, and reload speed. 

•	You can also carry various useful items such as medkits, grenades and mines. In addition to defending narrow chokepoints and doorways, one of my favourite uses for explosives was to booby trap corpses of enemy soldiers so that when someone else came to investigate, I’d eliminate them too.

•	Most enemies are equipped with the same pistols, SMGs and rifles that the player can use. You’ll also encounter a few armoured cars and tanks, so be on the lookout for panzerfaust RPGs.

•	There are a few ways to take advantage of stealth, including silenced weapons and sneaking up behind enemies for melee takedowns. You can whistle and throw bottles to cause nearby enemies to investigate the noise. And if there are loud environmental noises such as planes flying overhead, or cannons firing, this can mask the sound of your rifle fire. However, each map has a large number of enemies, and they can see you over quite a long distance, so I found it hard to stay hidden for long. 

•	When alerted to your presence, the AI will quickly identify your location and aggressively chase you, usually with multiple soldiers from different directions. Objective locations often have alarms which will summon more reinforcements until you disable the alarm. During a couple of missions I had lengthy and very chaotic firefights against massive numbers of enemies.

•	I played on the hard difficulty and while I died a few times on each mission, it was rarely frustrating. Most of my deaths resulted from attempting to be stealthy and messing up in an exposed location. When I started just shooting everyone on sight from a more tactically secure location, it actually became much easier.

[h1]Story[/h1]

•	The writing and voice acting are both average quality. The story only really exists to give you a reason to perform each mission objective.

•	The story doesn’t connect to the previous games in any significant way, so if you haven’t played the other games you wouldn’t feel like you’re missing anything.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

•	It took me 14 hours to complete the campaign and I only missed 2 optional objectives. There’s also a survival mode where you have to fight multiple waves of enemies while defending a control point, which could provide a few more hours of playtime.

•	Controls are fully rebindable and work great with mouse and keyboard.

•	I didn’t have any crashes or framerate problems.

•	I noticed a frequent flicker/shimmer effect on distant objects like trees and narrow railings, which I think might be caused by poor anti-aliasing. You can’t choose which type to use, you can only select low/medium/high/ultra, which didn’t seem to make any difference.

•	There is some inconsistency relating to whether or not you can climb over walls and other waist high objects. Sometimes I approached an object that my eyes told me should be climbable, but the game wouldn’t let me interact with it.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Sniper Elite 5 is a good game that has fun and challenging combat, but is let down slightly by average storytelling and a couple of technical issues. I think most action game fans will probably enjoy the game.

Overall quality is roughly similar to Sniper Elite 4, so if you liked the previous game you should enjoy SE5 too. It might be best to wait for a sale, especially if you also want the season pass (which I haven’t bought yet).

I have played SE3 and SE4 and have immensly enjoyed them. When black friday sale happened for SE5, I was overjoyed and bought the game.
I played the first mission and was very happy with it.
Then the worst thing happened, an update was released with a couple of DLCs and weapon skins. This is where I have a problem.
1. The size of the update was around the same of the original game = 47GB.
2. Once the update completed, the game just does not launch now. I am on Windows 10 and the answer given by devs is update to the latest version of Windows. In what age are we living where to play the new DLC of an already installed game, I need to update the entire OS ? On top of it, there is no way to rollback the update. 
This is the worst form of software development I have seen with zero care given to the users. This mode of break and release is okay if the user is not paying for the software.

For prospective buyers, this is what I see - "Can't find the entry point for procedure NotifyNetworkConnectivityHintChange on dynamic link library". I know very little about game development and windows software development, but this just reeks of breaking backward compatibility. 

I feel that this is a systemic issue and goes into the core philosophy of game development at this company. Look at Age of Empires 4, which has been releasing patches and updates at least every quarter and have not even once broken the game.

Buying this game has been a mistake.

I really love this game. I'm a massive fan of the Sniper Elite series and in my opinion Sniper Elite 5 lives up to the series, though it is not a substantial leap in quality over Sniper Elite 4 in the same way Sniper Elite 4 was over 2 and 3. It's more of a side step, with certain areas improved, others worse, and others changed. 

There's been a ton of negativity surrounding this game, and while certainly it lacks the polish of 4, I think it has enough alterations to the formula over 4 that it can stand alongside 4 as a great Sniper game. While I don't think it is as well realized of a game as 4 (all of the components of that game worked together perfectly to make a game greater than the sum of its parts), I love the increased complexity of the game. I found the levels were larger in scope and more varied than 4, not just in terms of visual design but also in layout, approach, and gameplay. Along with the complete weapon customizability and non-lethal ammo types, there is far more player agency in the levels. While it doesn't have much positive gameplay function, I found the non-lethal options were a fun player-imposed challenge, and its honestly also fun to be a complete bastard and play judge, jury, and executioner based on what it says on the individual enemies bios. I also appreciated the fact that you get updates on the games missions/side missions by exploring the level itself and reading documents/overhearing conversations. I found the game generally easier and the sniping more forgiving than 4, but its still plenty challenging if you want it to be. Being able to unlock different starting locations for missions is a great touch as well. The biggest negative for me is that it is reasonably buggy, particularly with AI and animations, though this has improved quite a bit since launch. I really like the music as well. Different themes for the different levels is an awesome touch, and I really appreciate the more organic way the music changes based on the alert state of the enemies, over 4 which was often far too explicit in its music an audio cues. 

Sniper Elite 5 is not Sniper Elite 4, and I think in accepting that you'll come to find that 5 is a very good game indeed. I was pretty disappointed by this game after launch (probably in large part due to its super buggy state), but have come around to love it. It's refreshing to play a game that's super straightforward and gameplay focused without the fat and nonsense, though I still don't see that a skill tree is necessary in this game. 

There is a TON of content in the base game too, especially in considering the reduced MSRP. The single player levels are more expansive than they have ever been, you have multiplayer (which I am not much of a fan of in general but IMO the multiplayer in 5 is an undeniable improvement over 4), survival (a personal favorite game mode of mine) and invasion, which is an awesome, awesome addition. 

Don't buy the season pass though. It's an absolute rip off, particularly when its price is compared to the price of the base game.

So basically,

This is Sniper Elite 4 but in France. The game side-actions have been " re-balanced " with some items being removed, new items added, weapon customisation, workbenches being divided into 3 different types ( which then gives you even more incentive to check out all the massive/beautiful maps ), and Not every vehicle can be explosion exploited by shooting the gas tank ( fair enough ).

Stealth is now moreso of a factor, so prepare to spend 99% of your time crouching through the map with the other 1% sprinting the fuck away from something. Weapons now emit " noise ", yes, even when silence ( realism huh ), but you can reduce the sound distance with various types of mod's depending on what you want.


Overall, I give it a 3/10 ( still a bit buggy, but its a brand new game ), but players expecting a " new Sniper Elite " game shouldnt have their hopes up, as there isnt much " new " about it, even the graphics ( I am running 3070 RTX )

If you go into this expecting a slightly re-balanced SE4 with roughly 30+ hours of content in campaign alone, you wont be disappointed.

>> Post-Campaign Edit <<

Changed my overall score from 9/10 to 5/10. Reasons:

- Traversal is terrible. Less buildings to climb even though you can see the pipes, map templates such as cutting fences sometimes dont have the trigger or take several attempts to activate the animation, a fair few open farm field maps where your forced down road choke-points with nowhere to hide even though you can see a stone fence that you should be able to jump over, hedge templates in one map will work in one area but wont work in another area even though you can physically walk around the hedge and go to the place you were looking at 30 seconds ago.... to sum this comment up, Map beautiful, traversal garbage.

- Axis Invasion. Not explained well enough, so no one knows how to turn it on/off even though its quite clear. There is an XP " detriment " if you have it turned off, but its such an incomprehensibly small difference that it makes no sense... I turned Axis Invasion off for the entire campaign and was max level by 80-90% of the standard game. Some more explanation from Rebellion about Axis Invasion would make it feel a lot better, as we dont have control over what games we get inserted into as an Axis Sniper, yet some people are clearly uncomftorble with this concept as they resort to camping, restarting the mission, or simply suiciding just to get the Axis Invader to leave lol..... so a little more clarity so that new players dont feel harrassed would be better....

- They added removed a lot of guns but then added customisation to the guns to give you more " choice ". Every upgrade has a positive attribute, but also 1-3 negative attributes. Whilst this is a welcomed addition, some of the upgrades are very copy-pasted and dont directly relate to the firearm. For example the " M24 " rifle that everyone starts with, I can max the damage and stability of the rifle, but the downside is I need to worry about horizontal/vertical recoil? With a bolt action rifle?.... as I said... great addition, not very well planned or thought out.

- SPOILER ALERT -
Missions are very typical of the SE format. Go here, destroy radio comms, blow up this super-gun, find the snipers, kill this guy ( on every map ), find the intel, get out. They added non-lethal ammunition to the game, but didnt provide any mission specific uses or benefits for the ammunition. Basically a complete redundancy. They also have quite easily given away where they want to go next, with the addition of the WW2 Japanese forces to the end of the game, so dont be surprised if the next game finally leaves Europe and heads to the pacific ( which, to be fair, there isn't much left of europe to do, maybe they could do africa? )

>> POST FIRST TWO DLC RELEASES EDIT <<

Its still just SE4 but rebalanced. They have actually listened to me and fixed a lot of the UI issues, thanks.

They however have done nothing about rebalancing what weapon attachments do to weapons, i:e, bolt action rifles can still add attachments that give " more recoil ", effin lol.

As for the DLC, ->> MORE SPOILERS <-.

Cmon Rebellion jesus christ, where is your originality. You make us wait 3-4 months to see the first DLC map, and its another effin BLOW UP THE BIG GUN mission... like FFS... There are literrally hundreds of things you could do, like, for example, finally give us a mission where the NON-LETHAL AMMO ( effin lmao ) Can actually be used to complete a mission objective? Like an aggressive kidnapping mission etc? Please stop with the THEY HAVE ANOTHER BIG GUN!?!?, Its so copy and paste and honestly I cant be the only one tired of doing it. And you not only give us ANOTHER BIG GUN mission, but give us THE EXACT SAME WAYS to destroy it? * sabotage the ammunition *.... HOnestly wtf.

The second DLC is somewhat, half decent. Finally an assassination mission, yet so utterly devoid of long range shots it leaves you really wanting for something more than 200m. That and the target never walks near his window UNTIL you make it inside the castle and his movement gets triggered, but then its not really worth it to run ALL THE WAY out of the castle just to set up a window shot because then you would have to RUN ALL TEH WAY BACK IN to the castle and climb to the top to end the mission... effin lol.

Thanks for the DLC, I havent had the game installed for almost 4 months now. Installed it today, completed both DLC missions with 3 stars and all work benches discovered, over 100 kills each map with a stealth/lethal emphasis, and then promptly un-installed the game again.

Im already playing it on the highest difficulty, yeah, ok, I can go snooping for collectables. But the weapons availability really only points in the direction of 2 rifles, one SMG and one pistol. The rest are almost useless in 90% of any of the situations.

Meh. Rant over.

Sniper Elite 5 is a beautiful and fun stealth sandbox game, and something of a highlight for 2022. As I got it late, I was not plagued with the issues apparently it had on launch. Sniping is the most satisfying thing here, but the maps are dense and allow for both long and close range play, stealth and non stealth. Exploration that provides new sub-missions, weapons, and accessories is rewarding. Cooperative play with my boyfriend has been a great, emergent, and hilarious time. The story is paper thin, but doesn't pretend to be anything other than a reason for the player to be shooting Nazis in the testes on each carefully designed map. The voice acting from the lead is so deep, sincere, and silly without distracting from the important sound bytes and communication it provides. There are a few redundant mechanics (non-lethal options against Nazis? Really?) but nothing distracting or game ruining at all. It runs well, plays well, and will feel familiar to anyone who likes open world stealth sandboxes. It won't blow your mind, but it sure will excite and entertain it.

overall experience: 8/10

Sniping part is the only fun part, no surprise there

Getting into a vantage point, marking everyone with binos, going on a headshot killing spree getting killcams over and over is just an absolute blast as it always was in the past games. The problem is everything else with the game.

This game is no splinter cell, it is not metal gear, it is not hitman, yet they try to pull these stealth games off without actually keeping in mind what made those games fun and fair.

Splinter cell had the visibility meter, actual good cover system, and a multitude of silent gadgets to use.

Metal gear had camo meter, soliton radar that actually worked, and again a plethora of gadgets and things to use to distract and take down guards

Hitman had the giant levels like this game does, except they were actually designed well. Plus it had the most important part, the disguise mechanic and just an overall better focus mechanic. Hitman's is not at all awkward to use, yet this game's is. Idk how that's possible when this game came out after the Hitman trilogy has been out but is what it is.

Overall get it on a sale like I did, for 30 bucks I can take part in the actual fun sniping but man do these levels just grind my gears with how frustrating and tedious in their design. Enemies can spot you from 200 meters away, still no actual ADS for weapons so you're left up to the bloom gods with close range weapons, too many close quarters areas that you need to go into that you can't snipe in, in SNIPER ELITE. 4 was way more open with its levels which allowed much more sniping, which caused me to like that game tremendously more.

The game is different than previous versions (v2,3,4) but not bad. Little things like the flash of a telescope or very visible characters in the multiplayer are annoying - it's impossible to hide somewhere, aim and shoot - such dances behind the cover. In the campaign, the characters are not so visible, there is a more gray monochromatic scenery, where the enemies blend in more with the surroundings - there are places where you have to look closely to spot them (and graphics settings are set to High and over 60 FPS, RX 6600 XT). And somewhere I read a review that the shooting distances are smaller than in the previous parts. My opinion on this subject is that compared to the previous parts, the scale of the maps is different, what in the previous parts was about 300m, now it is 200m - that's my impression. And weapon modifications are exaggerated in my opinion - well, where for a handgun a long stock, or a metal one, and an additional handle, or armor-piercing ammunition. fun with modifications that forcibly turn a pistol into a shotgun.
Updates are the worst. Well, once a week, name, u,. I turn on the computer on Saturday and want to play - NOOO, now a few GB update. Now (July 27, 22) 44GB update again!! Come on, control yourself - the whole game was downloading 55GB during installation, and then another 6GB if I remember correctly. So that you can play without updating and turn it on after the end of the game, that's how I understand it, but steam wants it now and it's over. It's annoying.

In the end, I don't know if I can recommend it or not. Because if some fan of the series (probably I am, but a staunch believer), expects similarity to the previous parts, it's a bit of an old "sniper", but more stealth and melee combat than ranged combat. Opponents, on the other hand, look for the "intruder" more, searching not only those parts of the map where they were on duty, but also other parts. Because the map is divided into parts to do specific tasks. And as in the older "snipers" the opponents moved only in one part of the map, so in the "five" they also search in other parts where they did not have a patrol. And there are units that raise an alarm, which causes the arrival of reinforcements from other "parts" of the map, or, for example, from passing vehicles - when they notice a corpse or hear shots.
As someone new and this will be his first contact with this series of games, he may not fully feel the atmosphere that was in the previous parts. I personally do not regret the purchase. However, I liked the multiplayer maps and the overall graphics (colors, contrast) more in "4" - because "3" is a cheater's paradise.
I recommend five, but conditionally. If someone expects a graphical revolution and similar gameplay as in its predecessors, then no, but if he is open to changes in the way the game is played and more gray graphics (in my opinion) and extensive character building, then yes.

Na koniec nie wiem, czy mogę polecić, czy nie. Bo jeśli jakiś fan serii (chyba takim jestem, ale niezagorzałym wyznawcą), spodziewa się podobieństwa do poprzednich części, to troszkę jest to stary "snajper", ale więcej w nim skradania i walki wręcz niż walki na dystans. Przeciwnicy za to bardziej szukają "intruza", przeszukując nie tylko te fragmenty mapy, gdzie pełnili służbę, ale i inne części. Bo mapa jest podzielona na części do zrobienia konkretnych zadań. I jak w starszych "snajperach" przeciwnicy poruszali się tylko w jednej części mapy, tak w "piątce" szukają też w innych częściach, gdzie nie mieli patrolu. No i jeszcze są jednostki wszczynające alarm, który powoduje nadejście posiłków z innych "części" mapy, lub np z przejeżdżających pojazdów - jak zauważą trupa, lub usłyszą strzały. 
Jak ktoś nowy i to będzie jego pierwszy kontakt z tą serią gier, to może nie do końca poczuć klimat jaki był w poprzednich częściach. Ja osobiście nie żałuję zakupu. Jednak mapy w multi i ogólnie oprawa graficzna (barwy, kontrast) bardziej podobały mi się w "4" - bo "3"  to raj cziterów. 
Piątkę polecam, ale warunkowo. Jak ktoś się po niej spodziewa rewolucji graficznej i podobnej rozgrywki co w poprzedniczkach, to nie, ale jeśli jest otwarty na zmiany sposobu rozgrywki i bardzie szaroburej grafiki (wg mnie) i rozbudowanego budowania charakterystyki postaci, to tak.

Honestly, a really great game overall and maybe my favourite since V2. Each game improves over the last and this is no exception. The new game mechanics and weapon customisation are great additions to the series. The levels themselves and the details within them are also great. I found myself taking the levels slowly, exploring it all, and enjoying every moment of them.

My only gripe (which I got used to as the game progressed) were the silencers on weapons. I understand this is 'WW2 silencer technology' and I was playing on a harder difficulty. But damn, there were multiple instances where I couldn't BELIEVE that my shot and / or silent take-down was heard.

Didn't mess around with Axis Invasion as I personally dislike my single player experiences being messed with. But what I've heard and seen from others is that it's super fun if you're into that stuff.

	So if you have played any of the other 4 games you pretty much know how this works…. You have been tasked to infiltrate your way through a number of locations to weaken the enemies fortification so the fleet can stage their attacks on the Germans. Same plot as all the other games but with different locations and tasks. Ya know what, it aint broke and so no need to fix it! They even have the pretty much mandatory Hitler DLC. 

	What makes this game the best in the series you ask. Well absolutely nothing in my opinion. There are a whole slew of things I enjoyed about this game, but the only thing I feel that was added was a good coop play. If this was in part 4, I never tried it. But I did manage to cross play with a friend on their xbox for this version.

	Lets start with the looks. The game is very polished. There was a lot of attention spent on how everything looks. The smoke, explosions, weapons, and environment all look awesome. This is the best looking version of the 5. Taking that with a grain of salt, graphics have stepped up quite a bit since SE4. So that was expected. What I can say, is that the previous game had better looking locations due to its vibrant colors and focus on detail in cities. Considering this game returns back to a more gritty war environment, you loose some of that. There are some scenes that definitely show off what the game is capable of doing but they are small little sections on each level.

	Next we have the sound. No complaints about that. Voice acting is awesome with little sync issues. The acting was done in a respectable way that presents well to the overall feel of the game. Weapon sounds are done just right. They are not over bearing but definitely let you know what you are shooting. Explosions have that surround effect that just makes you feel like you just dodged something horrible.

	Then we get to the AI. Honestly I think this is where they spent the least amount of time. I consider SE3 the pinnacle of the series. It had a lot of things going for it to include a good set of AI characters. This game seams to use the halfway brain-dead logic from SE4. In one larger map, I managed to make a lot noise near a tower. Half the map ran over to investigate that. This gave me the opportunity to visit two almost three objective locations to set explosives with almost no guards around. I would say this was an isolated incident, however I was able to utilize this tactic throughout the game. I would love for them to take the AI that was in F.E.A.R. 1 and incorporate it into this game. That was the best AI I have ever seen in a shooter.

	Gameplay wise, I would say that nothing much has been changed over from previous games. The controls are intuitive and purposefully placed on a controller. The difficulty level jumps up and down depending on where you are in each map. Honestly, I think the first level was harder than some of the later levels. The game is plenty long. You are definitely getting your moneys worth. This does not even count the pass and DLC. For those looking to leader-boards or all the achievements, you will be playing this for a long while. There are so many little details like shooting a certain number of these small gnomes to keep you entertained. 

	Summing things up, The game is awesome. There is definitely a lot to do and a definite challenge in many locations. The story is on par with all the other Sniper Elite games. Graphics are really well done and complimented with a great audio experience. If you are a fan of the series or just starting out in the Sniper Elite world, you cannot go wrong with this title.

Overall, I enjoyed Sniper Elite 5, it adds some interesting new features, but in a lot of ways it seems like a downgrade.

This is what I didn't like about the game:
- You can no longer run while crouched.
- Tripwire mines were removed, they were my favorite type of trap.
- The ability to throw rocks was removed. You can now throw empty bottles, which you can only carry a limited amount.
- [strike]You can't aim toggle anymore[/strike].
- A lot of objects that look climbable aren't. On the other side, you can actually climb pipes, which isn't highlighted in the tutorial mission.
- Only some kind of grass offers you cover from the enemies.
- When in grass or in iron sights, there is a highlight that you can't turn off around your player which ruins immersion.
- The enemy AI is not great.
- When picking up enemy weapons you can no longer switch to them completely. When they run out of bullets you will automatically drop them.
- There is a limited amount of weapons. They will probably be added back as 100 DLCs (that never really go on a big sale) in Zombie Army 4 fashion.
Love Invasion Mode, Really brings a good rush when playing as the invaded or invader. Love this Mechanic.

[h1]Sniper Elite 4.5[/h1]

Played it on the release date but decided to reviewing it now, and all i can say it's ok.
If you are a fan of this franchise you know what'll expect from the game, but for newcomers who likes tactical shooter plus slightly stealth elements, i highly recommended this game and SE4.

What improvement in this game over to SE4 is actually minimal, infact some people found the level design are actually downgrade over to SE4. SE5 still carries the big open map design but they are smaller compared to SE4. Guns in this game are also highly customizable to your liking and suit your needs. 

For newcomers i really recommended playing this game atleast with Sniper Elite (hard) difficulty. Enemies are very brutal and lethal. Wind, sound firing and gravity are your enemies so you'll need to calculate the ranges between you and your enemies, each decission/shot matters. If you're playing with go all Rambo you'll be punished really hard. Yes this game can be very challenging for some people but that's the charm of this franchise.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Despite with the lack of improvement with the previous release, this game is still a solid title but only getting this game on sale or you can just play/buy Sniper Elite 4.

The core game is the same as previous SE games:
- Cut scenes are still cringe
- AI is still stupid
- Physics are still mediocre
- You get awarded for everything you do
- But somehow still fun as a whole

Somewhere better:
- On authentic you throw away the magazine even if there is leftover ammo in it
- Feels like you can move closer to objects so you can use cover better

- Much better menus

Somewhere worse:
- Carry body option and throw body mechanics feels like it wasn't tested at all
- Sounds are crazy bad; you get no feel of space and distance, frequently repeated music chunks
- Optimization is non existent right now which is surprising because the engine feels like the same old stuff
- The story and characters can't be worse than the ones in the previous installments but just as bad and full of cliches and nonsense so far

I don't know why so many people are trashing this game. People say that the plotline is weak, others say that there are many bugs etc. I just want to share my thoughts about the most frequent complains this game gets:
- SE games were never about plot but gameplay and gameplay in this game is absolutely brilliant. If you look at the SE4 plotline for example you can literally guess the ending as you are introduced to the german informat guy(forgot his name cause plotlines in this series are always just an excuse for gameplay).
- Bugs on the first days of release are expected and I see many people complain about these. Personally I haven't experienced many bugs so I can't really talk about that.
- I've seen many people complain about the fact that helmets are actually acting as helmets and not just leather caps. Most of the time your bullet will still penetrate the helmet especially when you're using AP ammo, but the fact that helmets actually deflecting bullets is a con and something people cry about is just completely ridiculous. Go for organ shots if you see that the enemy soldiers have helmets ffs.
- Many people also complain about the fact that you can now spare the nazi bad guys and render them unconscious rather than dead. I don't even know how to comment on that. People want more "realistic" SE games while complaining about realistic mechanics, it's just... bruh. It's also important to note that irl covert operations during WW2 were not always about killing the nazi bad guys but most importantly about stealing documents and blueprints.

It took quite a long time to get the next installment in the sniper elite series and now that it's finally here unfortunately I have to say I'm a bit disappointed. Not to say it's a bad game by any means, it's just that the previous title, Sniper Elite 4, is far superior in just about every single way imaginable. From the level design, game-play, controls, and attention to detail, 5 seems like a significant downgrade from the previous game. This game honestly feels like a DLC to 4 and not a very good one at that. It doesn't do much to change up the formula, especially coming from a game that took as long as it did to come out after the 4th installment. Invasion is a cool idea, but to warrant an entirely new game to incorporate this idea is too little to late and not enough to keep my interest past a few hours of game-play. Deciding factors for me were the extremely limited weapon variety granted to the player. I'm sorry but when the first sniper rifle you get in the game is better than every rifle you could unlock after that, it not only makes the game-play feel extremely repetitive way too quickly but this doesn't encourage you to experiment and try out the other rifles. In the previous game, it felt like there were tens of rifles to choose from, each one feeling different enough to favor different play styles, but the less than 5 rifles they give you all feel exactly the same. Same goes for the secondary machine guns and the under-powered pistols, both secondary and sidearms only having a hand full of choices to choose from, again the starting weapons being the best out of the lot. But none of these complaints even hold up a candle to the biggest deciding factor in skipping out on this game and just sticking with the 4th. THIS GAME'S ENDING HAS BAR NONE AND UNDOUBTEDLY THE ABSOLUTELY WORST ENDING IN VIDEO GAME HISTORY. Far Cry 5's ending made me instantly regret the tens of ours I poured into that game and made me uninstall it before the credits reached the top of the screen but Sniper Elite 5's ending is straight up insulting. You're quite literally fixed in position and all you have to do, sorry all you can do, is shoot the lead bad guy that you've been trying to get to the entire game and the game just ends!?!?!? I'll be fare and say that the Sniper Elite franchise have never been known for their stories but this ending is the biggest missed opportunity I could possibly muster. Invasion is a small step forward, The horde mode cripples itself by having terrible maps not designed for sniping and I don't think even trying the multiplayer would be enough to overlook this game's many flaws. Long story short just stick with the 4th game. Let the 4th game be how we all remember Karl. A master sniper with the personality of a brick wall and who's good at only three things, killing Nazi's, reloading, and killing more Nazi's.

I spent way too much money on this steaming pile of crap. And it is. For over six freaking months, the devs have been "urgently investigating" (yeah, right) one of the many huge bugs, in this case which makes the scope reticle/crosshair disappear. On ALL scopes. Effectively making the game unplayable. Has there been any progress in those six months that they've been "urgently investigating" the bug? Any solution in sight? Nope. They clearly don't give a shit. And that is far from the only major bug. Many of the gameplay mechanics are also very screwy or annoying, or shallow, or just simply hated nearly universally by players. They've greatly "dumbed down" the game and mechanics as well, apparently to appeal to a wider base, including the younger crowd. So, basically, this game is little more than shameless cash grab.

That being said, it is somewhat enjoyable, there are far more attachments for what few weapons there are (I haven't purchased the dlcs, and I have zero intention of giving these shameless lazy and greedy assholes any more of my money), though the mechanics of unlocking weapons and attachments are also screwy and somewhat obnoxious. The game has some potential, but this potential will never be reached, because Rebellion has gone the same way as most of the other big studios, and refuses to do business the proper, ethical, respectful, and hardworking way. They also clearly have no respect for their players. Or for that matter, even for the game that they've created.

This game is a fantastic successor to Sniper Elite 4 and adds new features that fit right in with the franchise. They’ve improved the formula in almost every way, but didn’t compromise the core identity of the game. Rebellion understands the phrase, “If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” and in the era of modern gaming, this is fantastic. And hey, if you’re just looking for a fun new action stealth game and haven’t touched a Sniper Elite game in your life, I highly recommend this to you too.

The core gameplay is incredibly strong. It feels well put together and satisfying to play. The game’s movement and weapon handling feels more tactile and immersive than ever before, especially with the new active reload system. The weapons feel punchy and the gunshots are very satisfying. The AI is a bit more dynamic this time around but it’s nothing to write home about, it’s stealth game AI. They can’t be perfectly smart even on the hardest difficulties or else the game wouldn’t be fun (This is why Invasion Mode is so fun. More on that later). The game also provides you with tons of different playstyles all equally viable, and with the addition of a graph summarizing your playstyle upon the end of the mission, it ups the replay value and feels fun to try different methods. If you’re a completionist, this game will give you something to chew on for a while with lots of collectibles, badges and achievements.

The actual narrative of the campaign is a bit different than other SE titles in that it actually tries to tell a bit of a story. It’s still mostly just “World War 2 people, doing World War 2 stuff.” But the characters are a little more memorable and there is a narrative that shines through. It’s not why you play the game, but it’s there. Just a way to provide reasons for why you’re playing through the missions that you are. It’s not bad, because it never tries to be good. Rebellion knows exactly what they’re trying to make and I respect that. It’s like John Wick, or Nobody. There doesn’t always need to be an incredible narrative, sometimes you can just have fun.

There are some cool gameplay features new to Sniper Elite that fit the formula pretty naturally. You can now pick up enemy weapons WITHOUT replacing what’s in your loadout, in the form of a “temporary weapon” that is dropped when empty, or unloaded manually for its ammo, meaning there’s a LOT more ammo to go around for your loadout weapons. You can now toggle between soft aim and aim down sights with any weapon, even SMGs and handguns. There’s nonlethal options now! I’m not a huge fan of the fact that sparing the nazis you’ve been sent to kill gives a huge XP bonus, I usually just wished I were able to spare one or two guys that I read about on the binoculars, not play a pacifist SOE commando behind enemy lines. But more optional gameplay styles are no skin off my back, always welcome, glad it doesn’t affect how I want to play. There’s also a more in depth customization system than Sniper Elite has ever had, with so many stats for each weapon it makes your head hurt. You can look more into the stats, or look at a simple visual summary if you don’t care. All the attachments available can start teetering on “cursed gun” territory like CoD Vanguard but nothing that’s unforgivable or COMPLETELY immersion breaking.

The multiplayer aspects of this game are cool, the deathmatch, free for all and objective modes are fun enough, they’re what you’d expect. It’s Sniper Elite but PvP. I haven’t sunk much time into these modes, but the time I have spent was very fun, it’s just not the thing I’m looking for when I boot up SE. When I do, it’s because I want fun stealth and cool killcams, but if you like the idea of sniper deathmatch, go nuts! There’s also Co-Op survival and campaign. Co-Op campaign seems a blast, I love Co-Op stealth experiences, but I don’t have any friends that play, and I haven’t felt the need to delve into Discord or Steam communities to find playmates. Survival seems to have gotten a bit of a downgrade in terms of map count and possibly map size as well, compared to SE4. It also feels much harder. Some command posts feel near impossible to defend from there just being no safe vantage points or high ground and there being way too many flank routes to viably defend against. Aside from a few QoL improvements to the survival formula, I prefer the experience of previous survival iterations more. Give us more maps, guys! Now, all other multiplayer aside, Rebellion has done something fabulous with this one:

There is now, of course, Invasion mode. Invade a player’s campaign mission and hunt them down as an Axis Sniper. That is so damn cool. It’s like the sniper boss fight in Metal Gear Solid, at its best. A tense matchup of two equals, a dangerous game of cat and mouse. At its worst, it’s a game of chicken where the other player finds your approximate location, and bum-rushes you with an SMG. But even then, it’s over quickly and you can get back to finding a good matchup! It’s usually an incredibly fun experience. I can’t figure out which side I like to play more. This may be my favorite mode. I’ve gotten over 100 kills now as the invader and something over two dozen kills as the invaded. Each has their own advantages and disadvantages. I highly recommend the campaign with Invasion on. Getting invaded by a thinking enemy when you’d otherwise breeze through the mission of hapless minions immediately changes the tone to something much more intense. Especially when that enemy can put on the exact same uniform as any other NPC and walk around slowly in a group with them, blending in near perfectly (This is still my favorite way to play as the Jaeger, even with the ghillie suit an option for me now).

Last but certainly not least is killcams. ALL weapons now feature killcams. Handguns, rifles and SMGs. It’s cool, I always wanted the option for other guns to have them. Cool cinematic trickshots shouldn’t be limited to just rifles! And like SE4, melee kills, traps and explosions all feature killcams now as well. There is so much more detail in the X-Ray models it’s almost too much, to the point of taking away from other details. It’s certainly gross and seems anatomically correct, but do I need to see like, the salivary glands in the jaw? It obscures the destruction physics on the bones! I digress. The boring, repetitive organ shots of SE4 have been improved. It used to be that any time there was a fatal shot on an organ, say a liver, that it would BLUR OUT all the other amazingly detailed layers (muscle, bone, etc.) and just focus on a hi-def render of a floating liver getting split in half, the same way, every time. But they’ve done away with this now! The frequency of this has been decreased, and the organs all dynamically respond to the caliber of the bullet that hit, and the direction it hit from. There are also bullet hole effects on enemies now, making X-Ray free killcams very brutal, and still immersive. Used to be that the ai would make a ridiculous face as a floating bullet phased through their nose, with no blood in sight. But no more! It’s a little lazy, just adding a generic blood spat on the exit wound. But when it covers a textured part of the body like the eye socket, it really looks like you blew the dude’s face off. When the blood effect is just pasted onto a flat surface, like the bald head of an enemy, or a torso, it looks pretty boring. And why oh why aren’t there destruction physics on the character models themselves? There’s a beautifully dynamic, fully destructible skeletal system, but if I blow a jaw off in the X-Ray, the guy’s chin is beautifully intact!! Anyway, the killcams have also been improved in every single way, I’m just nitpicking.

In summary this game MIGHT be the best in the franchise but I'd have to replay all to be 100% sure. Like I said, I recommend it to Sniper Elite veterans, shooter fans, and stealth game fans. Definitely a hard cop, maybe even get the DLC too.

So as you can see I have put quite a few hours into this game. And now I feel like I must give my opinion on this game, This game although several months old is still quite buggy with every update, but I feel it getting better. I frequent the Rebellion Discord and have submitted numerous ideas and suggestions, the Community Manager has been very kind to members of the discord giving bug reports often asking for more information or placing a support ticket, and has extended gratitude to those helping and has also passed on a lot of information to the development team.

I grew up watching my parents play Sniper Elite v2 and 3 and now I finally get to experience the launch of the franchise that I have watched for almost a decade now I have loved almost every moment of it in the campaign from learning the enemies patrol patterns and dialogue locations so much that I have practically memorized a vast majority of them. The Multiplayer I feel is rather lackluster however, the poor XP gain and frequent vote kicks from matches have pretty much ruined my prospects in multiplayer along with few maps and rather repetitive game modes. The DLC content missions and weapons are all rather great with the replayability of every single mission with all the different approaches and tactics that are involved especially with loadouts, special ammo, and Authentic mode. Gathering the medals has been a blast also trying to figure it all out.

There are a few negatives to the game I will also like to address

The lack of weaponry.
Now of course I understand that the new attachment system almost makes up for this but I just feel like the current amount of weapons is minuscule compared to Sniper Elite 4 which when I was younger had fun mastering each weapon and each weapon is the same if you think of the trade-offs 

Challenges
The challenges in this game are rather terrible and repetitive what I loved about the mastery challenges for SE4 was the skill and timing it took to get each challenge each weapon required a different set of kill challenges to complete now you just load level 3 up and after an hour or so have every rifle mastered

Axis Invasion
Now I love Dark Souls and this greatly reminds me of the invasion concept from that franchise yet it just becomes boring either being invaded by a player who hasn't bothered with the campaign or invading a level 1 player. I love the few times I get into a game with an experienced player and have to actively work to get the upper hand and try to outsmart the enemy for instance I have an axis invader I got added me on steam due to how much fun we had taking each other down I want more of that not invading a fresh player with little understanding of the mechanics of the game.

I will try to add more to this review in the near future if I remember in the meantime
Happy Sniping

After 33 hours, but months of gameplay, I finally completed the campaign. The sixth mission has some kinks that the developers still need to work out (fps drops and random crashing), but the rest of the game was awesome! I went for a kind of mixed gameplay towards the later half of the game, because I didn't feel like taking my time with too much stealth and reloading saves like I have with the previous games many times. The levels were easier to complete, and I could still take my time here and there, and even circle the map at some points, just to collect what I could do. There's a lot to do, and the season pass looks like it would be definitely worth it (usually wait for a sale though tbh). I think a sixth game would be interesting, and I can guess where it would take place. I will definitely be playing this again soon, especially when more patches release, on a harder difficulty. 9/10 would recommend.

If you liked Sniper Elite 4 you will almost certainly like this one as well. It scratches the same itch... almost. Not sure how much I like the new features in this game, but I still like it overall. Now for what I am not sure I like...

The bigger maps are nice, but frustrating at the same time. There is too much, for my liking, herding you into corridors to force combat. In fact I dislike this enough that I am almost at the point of saying it breaks the stealth dynamic. I will say that stealth does not, "Feel", as satisfying in this release. Perhaps it is the design choices they made to include all the multi player options, (I do not play multiplayer). Also there seems to be issues with enemy infantry swarming you in this game. Maybe it is the bigger maps with more targets and enemy infantry... I find that it is really frustrating at times when you are, "Found", or, "Seen", and then 10, 20 or even more infantry spam your location. Frustrating and not fun. Other times no one is around and you sneak long distances for seemingly no reason. Like I said- stealth needs work in my opinion.

Zip lines, weapon workbenches, skill points and anything else that is not part of the core game play experience are more or less meaningless in this game, (Like they were in the 4th game). They do make SOME difference I suppose; but they are not worth considering part of what makes this game good or not.

I am 64 and am NOT a shooter game player with reflexes like superman so the difficulty settings are welcome, and work well enough.

Overall I am happy with this game... mostly. Hopefully they fix the mission 4 bug so I can continue the campaign. Stuck there because the game will not progress, (Others have had this issue apparently). If they patch it in good time I can excuse these things though.

Bottom line: My message to the Dev's: Stick to the core game play that makes this a good game that people want to play and make more maps, (Longer campaign). And PLEASE- fix the stealth so that it works as well as the 4th game. After all, stealth is the core of this franchise.

My final score is 7 out of 10, (Largely because it screwed the solo players to enable all the multi player stuff- and I do not play multiplayer).

Extremely fun, and it is as difficult as you make it. Having played SE 2-5 I can say that this is possibly my favorite entry in the series. I normally can't stand multiplayer in my single player games, but the invasion mode for the campaign is great fun to be on either side of.

If you've been on the fence about the series, this is the one to get.

When critical sniper shots are required, the game kindly provides you with one of several very powerful sniper rifles.  Once that's done, feel free to return to using SMGs and pistols.

Even in lower modes, the enemy will try and flank you and call for reinforcements. The scopes are more realistic (harder). The graphics are great enough to make you feel sorry for the Germans as you wipe them out. The buildings are gorgeous. The problem is that it is way overpriced for what you get. SE4 was a great single player game and I got months of enjoyment out of it. I polished this off in about a week and feel no real desire to replay. The DLC's are skimpy at best, not nearly as involved as before,

Meaningful items from SE4 were exchanged for meaningless items (keyword: stun mines). The maps are way too big in my opinion. A "times just" play through is not possible. It takes hours. New maps (DLCs) often have around 30GB. Per piece. In addition, the new and completely nonsensical possibility to enter a PvE game of another game and hunt him ...

I would advise everyone to SE4. The maps are varied, the usable items make sense and the controls are intuitive.

German:

Ein "mal eben" durchspielen ist nicht möglich. Es dauert Stunden. Neue Karten (DLCs) haben gerne mal um die 30GB. Pro Stück. It's been pretty obvious that Rebellion has been on a cash grab spree since Sniper Elite 4 was released, but this truly takes the cake as the magnum opus to their greed. I went in with hardly any expectations, and would've been less disappointed if they went with another reskin of a previous game. There are many issues I have with the game, but the worst offenders are as follows:

- Overpriced DLC for very little content that is still locked behind silly requirements
- Lazily tacked on features and game modes that are unbalanced and generally unfun (mainly Invasion) to supplement very little base game content
- Braindead easy to predict AI even on the hardest difficulties
- Unsatifying "loud" gameplay with most secondary weapons feeling very samey
-  "Open World" maps with very bizarre and nonsensical invisible walls

There are many more issues, but much like Rebellion, I would rather not put more effort into this than necessary. The game looks and feels much less complete than it's predecessors and is a testament to how far Rebellion has fallen as a company, as it seems to be much more of a cash grab than a genuine attempt at a game. I can only hope that the game gets much more base game content and has many of it's issues fixed within the coming months, but as Rebellion seems to be a lot more interested in adding more and more overpriced DLC, such as a $15 DLC for a whopping two guns and a weapon skin that's uglier than cat barf, I sincerely doubt it will happen any time soon.

Unlike many of the players offering reviews, I don't have any past SE baggage to drag into the conversation.  

SE5 is highly immersive. The enemies feel real especially when outside of buildings. Shooting feels real. Enemies will "pincer" you if you are not careful, or even come up from behind you.  (Inside of buildings they are less immersive).

One thing I love about this game is how highly detailed the difficulty settings can be, so you can tailor the game to your liking.   You can reach into the difficulty settings and do an amazing amount of customization.  Many games  offer "play it your way". This one delivers. 

Many people have commented that the open world has artificial barriers, such as a stone wall you can't climb over. And they are correct.  I originally thought these we programming limitations. And they sometimes feel like that.  But having played the game now for some hours I see (many) of these limitations as actually the dev's way to shape the level, to make the areas you can go more exciting.  It works for the most part, but running against one of these limitations during a heated battle can be frustrating.  So it's not a perfect system. Still, the battles feel real, and that's a pretty good thing.

There are many things the game shines in. "Sound masking" where you try to shoot when there is noise. You can of course sabotage generators and vehicles to making backfiring noise, but you can also shoot when a loud airplane flys by. It takes a while to learn the ins and outs of noise masking (for example, you have about 4 seconds to shoot after a generator/vehicle backfire) but when you do fully understand how it works your game enjoyment will increase a lot.

I love the weapon upgrades, but do find the "workbench system" somewhat contrived.  I wish physically finding them in the game world was more straight forward. There are 3 workbenches per mission but you don't know where they all are. Further, each workbench specializies in one of three weapon types - rifle, pistol, smg.  But they physically look identical. Everything I've read from veteran SE plays says this is an improvement from past SE games... but I say they still need more work. To me, they should not be so difficult to access. But maybe it's just me...

As for story, it's enough. If you're looking for a Far Cry 6 level story it's not here, but what is here is enough to make you feel like you're in a WWII saga.  It's not bad, and I oppose some of the reviews that really trash it. It's enough, it draws you in, tells you the background and details, and gets you to killing Nazis quickly.

I play single player and coop with a friend.  Both are fun in their own ways.

I wanted to mention the bullet cam system.  You can set it in preferences to show the carnage with almost every shot. New players might do that for the novelty, but at least for me, I turn mine down to very low so it only shows them only once in a while. Otherwise, the flow of combat is disrupted in my opinion.  But seeing it once in a while is like salt to food. Gives it flavor.

I also want to mention the non-lethal takedown and ammo abilities.  It's probably my bias, but I like that. I like to have the option to spare a life yet accomplish my mission.  Other's may not feel this way; I do.

As I write this, Russia and Ukraine are at war; Putin is dropping hints of nukes. The world is baking in heat; and half the people in the US just want to stick their heads in the sand. We have a wannabee US dictator in the news everyday.  But SE 5 allows me to go to a different place and time,  get immersed in being the hero of that world, and forget about the realities of what is happening today. And frankly, I am thankful for that. 

I previously had all the Far Cry games as my go to games. But now there is SE5.  Thank you Rebellion.
It's the same old Sniper Elite... fun but short, which makes it a hard sell at full price.

I'm giving this a reluctant no. For those who like the franchise it's about what you would expect. I was hoping for more. 

1. The world looks expansive and open, but it's not. I often found myself funneled into places I didn't want to go, and trapped by trivial obstacles.

2. The missions seemed to be repeats of what's already been done, many times.

3. There's nothing compelling about the missions, characters, or story line.

In summary this game feels almost like it was designed by a machine. No creativity or originality, just rewarmed content.

Highly recommend, the new game modes are phenomenal. I haven't been able to play with a friend yet, but that would easily add another play through with just as much fun. If you can find it on sale, it is an absolute must have. However, I would still pick it up at full price.

Original Review: SE3 took the series away from being a stealth shooter to be more action based. SE4 expanded and improved upon that experience and provided an excellent blend of sniping and run-n-gun action with multiple ways to play a fairly open map.

SE5 is not that. It is a 3rd person action shooter with some sniper themes. Like an old 3rd person action shooter from the 2000s the levels are lane base and you don't have the freedom of movement of the previous two installments. On the subject of movement, Karl's movements just seem a little off. It's hard to describe but movement is both too fast and too slow while also being overly sensitive in some aspects. My biggest pet peeve is ladders and dropping down a ledge. Karl has a tendency to run past the ladder then dangle off the ledge before deciding to climb back up. He's very sensitive to understanding there is a ledge to hang off of, but not at all sensitive to the ladder he should be using to go up.

Dialogue in the Sniper Elite series has never been something to write home about, but this entry changes it. It really inspires you to get out your best fountain pen and practice your finest calligraphy to send a strongly worded letter over to Rebellion to tell them it sucks. It's like they tried to put effort into the story dialogue, but when you are making a B movie less is more. In this case, less certainly would have been more.

I'm going to skip over Invasion mode because I just turned it off. Not my cup of tea, thank you very much.

There are some things I very much like about SE5 though. Iron sights and kill cams for pistols and smgs. Also, enemies now only carry one long arm (if you remember in SE4 most of them were walking around with a sniper rifle and a smg), so at least the enemy has a reasonable weapons loadout compared to SE4. That's about it really.

As long as you are looking for a 3rd person action shooter where you get to run down your set lanes and kill everyone in your path, then you probably will be happy with SE5. But SE4 is just better and costs less. So why not just get SE4 and be on with your day?

[h1]Even $1 on Game Pass is overpaying for this scheizz...[/h1]
Pros: [b]#1.[/b] Has everything that Sniper Elite 4 had (but with 300% more bugs)
[b]#2.[/b] Loading and saving a save is very fast (under 7seconds).

Cons: [b]#1.[/b] Infected with Denuvo malware, which prevented me from playing the game on multiple occasions
[b]#2.[/b] The game crashed 3 times in 2hours.
[b]#3.[/b] The game has a huge memory leak, which reduces fps to 15 or so. Once you restart the game, then the performance is normal again. It's very likely that Denuvo malware is the cause.
[b]#4.[/b] Has many bugs. Sometimes the enemies INSTANTLY spot you and open fire, even if you're sneaking. Sometimes you get stuck and can't get unstuck.
[b]#5.[/b] Has Day-One DLC. The practice of developers making content and then separating it from the game that you just paid $50 for and then expecting you to pay for that removed content on Day-One is a disgusting one. Rebellion are scum for releasing such a buggy game AND then having the gall to charge for content that they removed from the game, instead of having rather spent that time just fixing bugs.
[b]#6.[/b] The regional pricing of this game is terrible. This game costs 42USD in Argentina, which is one of the poorest countries on earth. Rebellion KNOW that they've priced the game way, way too high in certain countries due to the hundreds of players from those countries that have commented on the situation in the steam forums, and yet after more than a month, Rebellion haven't changed it (and won't).
[b]#7.[/b] The game is highly linear. There are bushes & invisible walls absolutely everywhere, that prevent you from approaching an objective from multiple angles. It's literally the devs' way, or the highway. This means there's no room for inventiveness when taking on an objective. If the devs want you to enter through the front gate of a camp, then you can ONLY do that, there's no side routes or inventiveness to be found.
[b]#8.[/b] You can't jump over a massive amount of stuff, which you'd normally expect you'd be able to. I'm talking about knee-high stuff, that you can even jump over.
[b]#9.[/b] The animations are borked. Multiple times now, I've choked a guy out, except that the animation shows me choking out his mid-section rofl.
[b]#10.[/b] There's basically NO choice when it comes to weapons at the start. ALL weapons are unlocked on different missions, and you only get to choose from 2 weapons until then.
[b]#11.[/b] You aren't given any information about how much experience you gained at the end of the mission, or how much experience various objectives give you.
[b]#12.[/b] You can shoot a guy in the head with a weapon, and he won't die. In a game that claims to be realistic, you shouldn't have to shoot a guy 3 times in the face before they die (I'm not talking about bosses, I'm talking about regular freaking soldiers)

In summation: If you're looking for a good sniping game, then get one of the Sniper Ghost Warrior games, or even just challenge yourself by playing through the entire Borderlands 2/3 game with only sniper rifles... you'll have a lot more fun and you won't be giving Rebellion any more money to make an EVEN WORSE Sniper Elite 6 game, which is a win-win. Oh, and I'm refunding this buggy malware-infested dog water.

I definitely recommend this game. I played all the previous games in the series and I could immediately tell that this was a step up in every way. The graphics have been significantly improved, the mechanics are a bit more user-friendly and for some reason the game is just fun and rewarding in ways that other 1st and 3rd person shooters aren't. I find myself wanting to complete all the side missions and finding all the collectables. Sniping is easier now, which really enhances the experience. You can also choose to 'stealth' through every mission, which is just as fun as sniping. Every game has it's faults, but for me this was one of the best buys I've made in a while. The game also has a very low asking price compared to other games in the genre.
