The co-op campaign with enemy invaders turned on is one of the most fun multiplayer experiences I have ever had.  It's refreshing to play a shooter that isn't oriented around battle royale modes and is instead focused on the ACTUAL EXPERIENCE OF THE AVERAGE PLAYER.  ANYONE can pick up this game and enjoy playing it, which is a stark contrast to all the 'competitive shooters' like Apex Legends, Fortnite, and Warzone where only a tenth of a lobby stands a fair chance at winning, and four percent actually win any given match... these kind of games are 'dopamine traps.'  In order to enjoy your time playing these games you have to be within the top ten percent of all players or else you will just get killed over and over again by players who are sadder and sweatier than you, players who can find and properly get shots off at your head before you can even get your cursor on their avataar..... This game doesn't have any of that 'competitive shooter' bullshit.  You can kick back and play a story driven game if that's what you're into.  If you want a challenge, you can turn on expert mode and actually have to account for wind, bullet drop, and noise concealment against groups of enemies who tactically clear areas and can tell where your shots come from.  Still not hard enough?... turn on invasion, and then there will be a real human sniper trying to take out you and your homie out as you try to complete your objectives.  You will never get a depressed 14 year old rage-a-holic calling you trash just because you're not within the top ten percent of players and made him lose.  You will not get spawn killed over and over again with no clear objective in mind other than getting good at the game to make noobs feel insecure the same way you were made to feel insecure about your useless ability to virtually clear a room.  What you will find is a compelling narrative with clear, obtainable objectives, and gameplay that is diverse and interesting enough that getting to the end of the story doesn't feel like a grind.  This is one of the few shooter campaigns I have actually replayed, and the addition of a pvp campaign helps to add even more replayability and depth.  This is a great game, and they have handled multiplayer in a mature way by providing a challenging experience that is actually fun for the user, instead of the standard ego cesspool that usually occurs in multiplayer shooter games.  Give your nervous system a break, stop playing battle royales that are literally designed to use your own psychology against you to make profit for the devs with NO concern for the quality of the product that they sell, and come play a game that WAS ACTUALLY DESIGNED TO BE FUN, THAT WAS ACTUALLY DESIGNED TO BE A GAME AND NOT A WAY TO PROVE THAT YOU ARE BETTER THAN OTHER PEOPLE.
ENJOYABLE

First of all gripes I have with this is that AI in this one feel a lot more dumb down than SE4, I've only played until mission 4 that's when I lost the interest in the game despite having all these new gun customizations mechanic.

Secondly, the level design. Sure that it feels so vast and with all the area to explore but comparing to SE4 it felt like instead of making it more fun with all the tactical choices I had on hand, it's just makes the game only a bit longer even with the AI road traffic which comes and goes for example in mission 2. Each of SE4 missions setting plays well despite some of the map have a lot more linear paths and even the short (or long depending on how you play it) H assassination mission for SE4 is more fun than 4 missions I played in SE5 so far. 

The Coop was not as fun as SE4 despite playing with the same friend who we had both enjoyed the previous game.

As of now the DLCs, I could say it's even worse than SE4 with all the things they added into the games whether it's the weapons or the recently released ghillies. I understand that they're trying to sell the cosmetic for specific character but in terms of look (which is very subjective) , it's worse than SE4.

Overall, I would recommend you to buy SE4 instead of 5. SE 5 might make a good impression to you who just came to play SE for the first time but the first SE and following sequel up to SE4, SE5 is probably the worst so far in my opinion. If you want to play it I highly recommends for you to wait for the game to be on sales and would be even better if you wait for them to get their act together.

I simply like the game! I have all of the previous versions of Sniper Elite and have played them many times. Many compare 4 and 5 and find 5 lacking in multiple areas. Perhaps I'm just not as discriminating but I think it looks great and plays great. I've had almost no problems with it other than 1 complete lock up that I had give the 3 finger salute (Ctrl, Alt, Del) to get out and shut the game down. There have been a very few times it's frozen but a few seconds later all was well. Of all the missions the 3rd one 'Spy Academy' is my favorite. I've lost count of how many times I played. I think I actually made it through once without dying. 
I would recommend purchasing it especially if you can catch it on sale. I bought it 'pre-release' and am happy with the price I paid vs what I received.
Fun game. Play on Authentic difficulty for maximum Sniperness.

The game is boring but invasion mode is awesome.

     This game's story takes itself too serious and the gameplay is lacking. There are very little good sniping positions, sight lines, and sniper possibilities. It has specific positions which encourage sniping by providing an obvious vantage point and scoped rifles......OVERLOOKING TRASH and like 5 AI. Because of the "realistic map design," the game forces you into their bad stealth.....CLOSE RANGE combat, in a SNIPING GAME, because the maps are near claustrophobic. A few maps are a bit more open and include a few open fields with bushes at every angle blocking your views. To top it all off, DLC suck as of the time of this review...so I either didn't buy them or returned them.

     The new DLC maps they added have the same problem as all the base game maps with much of it being indoors or narrow tunnels. And the gun and skin packs are just a waste of money for dumb looking skins and useless weaker reused guns from the other games which you need to unlock the attachments for through challenges.

     The invasion mode however, is golden. The only reason I would recommend buying this game is if you're interested in hunting down players. The invasion mode is the only thing I play on this game anymore. Using your map knowledge to track down the Allied sniper with the AI's locations, the completed objectives, and the sound cues which the sniper might cause is extremely fun and satisfying. Then once you find them you get to land the classic Sniper Elite cinematic X-Ray kill or get into a sniper battle with you flanking to a new position. It's thrilling.... but has some flaws. Many games end with the Allied sniper getting killed by the AI before you get close and ending the match as a victory (witch doesn't count as a kill for you in order to unlock items) or, they finish the level as soon as you spawn. The Victories and losses aren't tracked at all actually; only your direct kills on the sniper are counted and tracked. But you get nothing past the 100 ghillie suit other than a number going up. Even still, the invasion mode is FUN and by far the best part of this game. If this game mode were to be split off into its own game somehow, I'd only buy that and ignore the rest of this game.

     Unfortunately, even the standard multiplayer modes are kind of lacking. It's exactly what you'd expect from a third person perspective game based around sniping.... people camping in one spot for much of the match and using third person to peep over walls. I know some people like it but I find it boring. 

     That's all I've got to say about this game, hope it helps you....

This game gets extremely repetitive very quickly. You do the same thing over and over on every map and they do not get more difficult. It was better in older sniper elite games where you had a really bad stealth pistol, it made stealthing harder and funnier. 

There's also very little sniping for a game called sniper elite.

Let's just cut to the chase. To say this series is getting stale is an understatement. Is this game bad? No not by a longshot. No bugs or glitches, the famous kill cam and kill Hitler DLC, same weapon DLC whoring, same macho stereotype Karl, and literally the same everything as at least the latest 2 or 3 sniper elite games just pasted in a different part of the 2nd world war. 

This series either needs to end or it needs to get a massive shakeup. Again I'm not saying it's bad, it's not. It's playable and it's fun but each game is literally the same thing over and over again. If this was your first sniper elite game, you'll know what i mean if you go try 3 and 4 after finishing this one. Overall 5 out of 10 just because of how stale and repetitive this series has become.

Its another Sniper Elite game. Not much has changed since 4 in the grand scheme of things. Honestly a good point in my book. Too many games lately trying to compete with another game they feel is their competition(I'm looking at you Battlefield), and lose what made the game great by adding features of another game. The campaign seems to be well varied with both close and long range encounters, and plenty of traversal options. If you go loud the game punishes the player with smarter AI than previous games. They will spread out and flank, fall back and alert others, use suppressing fire when the player is not in direct line of sight, and much more. The Axis invasion idea was brilliant(an option you can turn on or off to allow players to invade your campaign). It is also well implemented well with a good balance for both sides(and a camping detector thank God!). However I have to go back on a little bit of what i said in the beginning. I'm honestly not sure if its trying to compete with Ghost Warrior, or just pandering to the ones who want a watered down experience. Suppressors are EVERYWHERE! One would think you could walk into your local hardware store and buy one. I've been playing since the first game, and there was so much more of an authentic challenge back then. Suppressed pistols are available from mission 2, and suppressed rifles by mission 3. The weapon attachments and their provided "upgrades" are simply comical. We are not to Tarkov levels of customization or anything, but hardly any of it is WWII period. I guess this could be chalked up to an alternate universe as we have killed Hilter in plenty of places and times. Still way over the top for WWII and a bit too much. Simplicity here is best imo. Different guns is fine, but when your putting a 6x scope, suppressor and a shoulder stock on a 1911 a line has been crossed. Now that we have the campaign out of the way lets get into multiplayer. Lets also get the disclaimers out of the way. I am a fan of hardcore(no glint, no aim assist, no empty lung zoom, ect) no cross. My opinions here are going to reflect my game play experiences on this game mode specifically. There has been a lot more work put into the framework of multiplayer compared to 4. This title seems primed to grow into a more successful multiplayer than previous titles. However there's only 2 maps.... 2. there's 4 total i believe, but only 2 for no cross. Might as well be 1 though since omg the beach map is trash. The team on the beach has NO cover. While the other side gets trenches, bunkers and plenty of options to move around the map without being seen. The beach side is just screwed. This is also a pretty small map as well. The other map is built much better. 1 side is a little more open, but you can navigate the map mostly in stealth if you traverse the buildings in the back. A little annoying, but if your not going to be patient in a sniper game why are you here lol?? Now my biggest complaint has to be the Assassins Creed style of movement. You character will literally do that annoying thing from AC where if you run up to a wall you cant climb you just run 2 steps up and jump back down killing all your momentum. Its rare, but stupid annoying when it happens. There is no button to hug the wall so the game decides when you use the wall for cover. Let me tell you this happens at the worst times. You're wanting to go around a corner, and your guy just keeps bouncing from one side of the corner to the other. Just like AC I feel this game has severe movement lag. I constantly find myself correcting my characters movements from doing something dumb and its always 1 step behind what I'm doing, and that's how you end up sticking to both sides of a corner 4 times in a row while your trying to make a break for it. It can also be a problem when your trying to hide on a box in a hall from a player. Its hard to get the character to do what you want it to do to prevent your gun from sticking out and blowing your cover. This would be so easy to fix with a simple button command. If this wasn't bad enough the game will change your characters stance on uneven terrain. Almost the entire game is uneven terrain! If the game decides your character cant "fit" into the area your trying to crawl to your character will go from prone to crouch or stand in rare cases with no warning. In a sniper game and in a multiplayer setting this is simply unacceptable as it stands. I'd rather have my character not move than be a whack a mole. Again we get into the laggy movement. I'll often times find myself panicking and pressing the button again since my character didnt do anything quickly and now he will be standing and crouching a couple times before going prone again. Also prone movement is not great. Objects like a curb will prevent the player from going sideways over it(sure it wont be comfortable, but very doable). This is a SNIPER game. If you cant navigate properly while prone something is very wrong. All my complaints aside this is a good game that has the potential to be a better game than it currently is.

What an incredible sequel!!! 

I love this series and the Zombie Army spin-offs too, the developers have really out-done themselves this time though. Sniper Elite 5 is fantastic and the addition of the Axis Invasion multiplayer mode was another master stroke just like the x-ray kill cams were in Sniper Elite V2. This series just keeps getting better because of innovation and a high level of quality game design.

The weapon customization, level design, collectables the whole damn game is so well made and presented. The sniping gameplay has always been great in this series while the slow-mo x-ray kill-cams never get old. These x-ray kill-cams were and still are a f@cking genius idea, which other developers have tried to copy, in other games but nobody does it like the Sniper Elite team.

How surreal and bad-ass is it to have a super realistic and detailed recreation of the second world war. With these crazy surreal kill-cam moments and evil b@stard Nazis runnin’ amok, it’s just a really enjoyable combination of elements. Karl Fairburne is also a classic American hero character and the assassinate Hitler levels are just the cherry on top of the awesome video game cake. I love this game and it has quickly become one of my all time favorites.

Play like you want, easy or hard.  I suggest playing diferent ways of attacking the map to see if find different things or easier ways.  I love this and have played through at least 8 times and will do again.  Best sniper game ever.

Despite this is a fun game, there's a couple of things that prevents me from giving this game a higher score. First: The inability to play the game in first person view. Second: The way you unlock weapons feels artificial and forced. Third: The fact that you can only use the weapons that you pick from the ground until they run out of ammo, and the fact that all ammo is generic, takes down the immersion.
Fourth: The most worrying for me. The business model. The fact that this studio is selling weapons like the P.1938, maps, skins and missions on micro dlc's is insulting and sad. Yes, they have the season pass, but it's just to justify their aggressive commercial behavior towards their customers.

Great game, better graphics than the last one in my opinion, gameplay is smooth and controls are very easy to learn. Only downside is that you need a good pc to run graphics higher than medium and have higher than 37 fps (I run an i5 and RTX 1660)

Rebellion put out another great game, but I will still keep SE4 installed.  For now.  Grateful for a recent free Survival Map.  Now there are four.  Would like another one that might be similar to Facility in SE4.   The campaign maps are great, Spy Game I think it is, is a sniper's dream.  You can tag and snipe about fifty 300 to 500m rifle head shots without even breaking cover or crossing the beach to the big town that is your objective.  I tagged one on the map high in the right of the screen for a 534M headshot.   You can tag victims after barely moving two steps from your spawn point.   Like 15 or 20 head shots possible over 400M.   50 is enough to unlock the Gilley skin for your favorite rifle.  I farmed Gilleys for all the rifles in this mission and this unlocked the Master of all Rifles Medal.  Any additional rifles obtained through DLC are not required to be mastered for this Medal.
 There is not a great deal new here with SE5.  I haven't looked at the "Invasion" aspect of the game and haven't played as the Axis so I can't evaluate that.  It just looked fairly lame by the description.   I don't want to play as a despicable Nazi anyways. Perhaps the developers misunderstood the sentiment against that regime by Americans and other groups.  I don't want my character in that uniform.   And I don't want anyone "invading" my Single Player campaign.  It's hard enough on the harder levels with enemies sneaking up behind me and machine gunning me in the back.  I like Campaign and especially co-op.  Co-op for me is the strength of the game.  I don't like much of the multi-player.  MP in SE4 seemed dumb or contrived to me.  You were either crawling around getting shot all the time or running around getting shot all the time.  I can get through entire Survival Waves without being even wounded on Authentic Mode and get the most kills on a 3-player Co-op Team.  By skillfully utilizing cover I've gotten the "Untouchable" ribbon many, many times in Co Op.    But I play Multi-Player free for all type modes and I'm getting killed like every 60 seconds.   Playing Urban Map Free For All in SE4?  The rapid carnage was ridiculous.  Somebody went down about every five seconds.   Funny at first, but quickly makes you dizzy.   If you stop moving, you're dead because everybody is moving.  That gets really tiresome after awhile.  Your vision becomes a blur.  But that's the nature of MP.  Everybody gets killed over and over again unless you're hiding in cover.  And if you hide in cover, you can only get trap kills.  Even the best players and the best shots get killed constantly in many games.  Like GTA5 when people kill each other over and over again and it flashes on the screen.  Stupid.   I'm making a $2 million delivery and they're farming PVP kills.  In just about every game I play I couldn't care less about experience points unless it unlocks something.  Then I'll utilize clever ways to farm them and unlock a weapon or something.  But there are easier ways than a circular firing squad.

Either I must be blind or I absolutely cannot find hardly any sniper perches once you enter the mission zones, only places for long distance sniping is at edge of starting zone. Karl use to be able to climb up a drain pipe onto a roof, well not anymore, because there's hardly anywhere to snipe from. And when you do find a spot, you're lucky if you can see down a narrow corridor between buildings or objects. This game is a definite step down from Sniper Elite 4, probably because the same maps are used in multiplayer matches and they removed the advantages so people wouldn't whine. You might as well call this game "Sniper's Call of Duty Elite" now, it's either crouch stealth with a silenced pistol or smg, or run and gun like COD. The long a$$ distant kills is what made this franchise with the satisfaction of the kill cams, well that pleasure seems to be gone and there's hardly any sub sonic "silenced" ammo anywhere also anyway. If it wasn't for the graphics I would quite playing it, because game play wise it's bad. When you come around around a corner and suddenly face an enemy, when you quick aim your weapon immediately points at the deck or in the air like you're trying to hunt ducks. Sniper Elite 4 was the best, because they now apparently neutered Karl's manhood..

Incredible Single Player game, I actually really enjoyed replaying the levels to get all unlockables. They have a huge amount of replayability thanks to the different spawn points and the "authentic" difficulty, which requires you to know level inside and out.


But let me rant a bit about the poorly designed invasion mechanic.
It is horribly unbalanced and the end game is just the host spamming [strike]focus mode[/strike] wall hack with the invader having little to no chance.

The invader has a lot of fun ways of finding out where the host is, like following the bodies, paying attention to the objectives and asking NPCs. Problem is, when you find him, you get rewarded by getting preshot and killed because, again, the host has [strike]focus mode[/strike] wall hack.

As a fix I would suggest that focus mode should not apply to players who are sneaking or standing still. This way, experienced players are on equal footing when they are facing off in close quarters.


Anyway, just play offline. It's an incredible Single Player game.

I highly recommend this game especially when it goes on sale.

1. Singleplayer: 
- Story is cheese and/or meh.
- Gameplay is fairly standard 3rd person cover shooter.
- The "x-ray" stuff is AMAZING!
- The guns and customization is alright. Wish it had more.
- Map and mission layout is ok. Just wish we had WAY MORE, but I understand that it's not easy to craft them.

2. Multiplayer: 
- The co-op mode is co-op so it's as expected and it works. 
- The horde survival mode is like every other horde survival mode. Just wish it was more complex or expansive. Note: this seems to have some bugs.
- The "normal" PVP multiplayer is like every other 3rd person shooter multiplayer game. Very standard and IMO might have been a waste of development time/resources.

3. The Best Part:
- Invasion mode is by far the best multiplayer experience this game has to offer especially when paired with co-op play.
- Basically Dark Souls, but with guns.
- Basically Bloodborne, but more pew pew.
- If you've never shot a Bambi Karl before then have you truly ever lived? This is the real question posed by Invasion mode.
- No seriously Invasion mode is the best thing outside of shooting Nazi ball sacks. Developers take note of this if nothing else please!

Conclusion: Shoot a fucking Bambi Karl then come back here and praise me for my words :D

[h1] This is going to be a weird one. [/h1]

I will try to abstain to it, but I will most likely drop some minor spoilers of this game's story. As B movie as Sniper Elite tends to be, some people might not like it being spoiled. You have been warned.

If you want me to substantiate what I say in this review: I have played all Sniper Elite games except the first, never touched Nazi Zombie Army but watched full playthroughs of most of them.


TL;DR: This plays almost like a side-grade to 4, its actually quite fun once you get used to it, but it feels like a "Megaman Zero 4" effect where things were changed solely for the purpose of making the game feel different to 4.

Sniper Elite 5 is certainly one of the more divisive titles in the series history, and that's even with Nazi Zombie Army and the whole Epic Games fiasco that happened a while ago. I can see why it does have a somewhat mixed reputation from most of the longtime players of the series, regardless there is some merit to be found in many aspects the game offers.

Gameplay at its core is still Sniper Elite, you have 3 weapons, an assortment of traps and distraction tools, and your goal is to move through the expansive maps to complete your missions and any side missions you encounter along the way, while also finding the best spots to pick people off from long range. The real difference lies in the nuances and subtle changes to the formula that make it stand differently from its predecessor. 

There is a level of weapon freedom much more pronounced in 5 than other previous entries. Newly added Weapon customization allows you to kit out all 3 of your weapons to your heart's content, provided you have parts unlocked. You can make the loudest, most powerful rifle imaginable, or you can sacrifice performance for stealth with the addition of a variety of suppressors, some quieter than others. This system makes every single weapon a worthwhile investment, and makes loadouts more interesting as a whole. Want to snipe with a pistol? You can do that. Want to create a stealthy, near absolutely silent SMG? You can do that. Want to go full German and run around with a scopeless Kar98? You can do that. Unfortunately, this same system also dilutes the identity of what makes Sniper Elite . . . well . . . Sniper Elite. It somewhat removes the purpose of the Rifle if you can simply kit out an SMG or a pistol with a silencer and a scope, and often times the Rifle is much, *much* louder than both unless you have suppressors only found in the later portions of the game. Given that there is also a strange closeness to this game that I will elaborate on later, this can make it feel more like you're playing "Commando Elite" instead of "Sniper Elite".

You can also select what kind of bullets to use in your weapon, carrying up to two extra types for each weapon in addition to the standard ammo for general use. Each serves a purpose in-game, AP can destroy locks and damage vehicles quicker, Non-Lethal allows you to knock out soldiers for extra XP, Subsonic makes your gunshots significantly quieter, you get the idea. As novel of a concept this is, it generally doesn't have much of a use outside of making things slightly more convenient to do for the player. It almost, *almost* feels like a tacked on, slightly more expanded concept of suppressed ammo from the last game.

Weapon choice and Enemy Choice feels a little lackluster in my opinion, I like what is there but there could be so much more. Referencing Sniper Elite 4, there were quite a few Italian weapons to better represent that "You're in Italy, go fight the pizzapasta people and their German friends." I don't see that as much in this one, both in terms of Weapons and Enemies. There are a grand total of 2 french weapons you can use: The RSC 1917, and the Model D. Where is the MAS-36? Where is the MAS-38? MAS-44? Berthiers? Lebels? Where the fuck is Vichy even? I was expecting at least a few French turncoats to plink at. Instead its all Germans [spoiler] and some Japanese later on.[/spoiler] Its not the biggest deal, but it just feels bizarre to have so few weapons from the theater you're in. Maybe its future DLC? I dunno.

The Map design in Sniper Elite 5 is both good and bad, if that makes any sense. Maps are still large and impressively detailed, supposedly they referenced real historical photos of Nazi-Occupied France and it really shows. The areas genuinely look like the real deal, and I'm not one to care all that much for scenery, but I can appreciate it when it shows up. Unfortunately, the map design can be really hit or miss from a gameplay standpoint, especially early on when the maps feel really close quarters-y. Again with the whole "Commando Elite" thing, the first half of the game has not many opportunities for long-distance sniping. This gets better later on and the maps do get a fair bit more open and visible after the first half, but it can be very off putting to quite a fair bit of people. I think the highlight of maps is how you discover objectives, some are given, some you have to find. Finding them can range from hearing a conversation between 2 soldiers, or by finding a collectable that indicates the objective (Usually a military document). Its a really novel system and I like the idea that not everything is laid out to you immediately, you actually have to do some scouting (You know, that thing that snipers would sometimes do, especially commandos working with a resistance?).

The story is pretty standard as far as the series goes. Karl Fairburne is dropped into X place to foil the plans of Y Nazi High-Ranking Officer to stop Z from happening, with Z usually being a war-winning superweapon or strategem. Moller is an okay antagonist as far as the series goes, he is not Bohm by any means, but he is not completely boring, Its fun watching him piss himself from Karl undoing his years of work.

Overall, Sniper Elite 5 is still a fun game and still manages to stay in the same vein as its Predecessors. Its not quite a step forward from 4 however. It feels almost as a side-grade, again bringing up the Megaman Zero 4 analogy for those who understand. It feels like it was made different for the sake of making it different from 4, for better and worse. Its a solid 7, maybe an 8 depending on your taste. I would at least recommend waiting for a sale unless you're really sold on the concept of sniping in france.


EDIT: Forgot to talk about bugs. This is probably due to me playing well past day 1, but I have not encountered any game breaking bugs, nor any that couldn't be solved by saving and then just reloading to fix a pathing issue (Looking at you Wolf Mountain). So I cannot comment on what people have experienced beforehand, for me it was relatively bug free aside from maybe a ragdoll inverting out of existence.

The game simply gets better with each sequel and this one is no exception. Levels are huge and you are completely free to play them as you like. 

Weapon mods are now meaningful with each mod affecting some of the weapon's attributes. You can really experiment with different play styles by playing with different mods.

AI's detection mechanics are different than in Sniper Elite 4 and I can already see that people are complaining - they are wrong.. I like the AI in 5. It's not better, it's not worse - it's different and refreshing. 

The only complaint I have is the targeting crosshair - it's simply too big, thick and prominent and obscures too much of a target when attempting really long distance shots.

But yeah... The game is as good as other Sniper Elite games - and still the best sniper franchise on the market.

Edit: After more than 120 hours and all achievements, all I can say - it's well worth the money.

Again the umpteenth World War II Senario but more versatile. Sniper Elite is, after all, a seventeen -year -old series that revolves around the sniper Karl Fairburne, who takes on the Nazis during the Second World War. The first parts revolved around fighting in Berlin, the third part brought Karl to Africa and the fourth part took place in Italy. Sniper Elite 5 uses an even more recognizable setting for many. This time Karl ends up in Normandy, where on the eve of D-Day he has to ensure that the invasion can be a success. Once in France, Karl tracks down a mysterious plan that, if we can believe the Nazis, the war can decide to their advantage. To the one -man army called Karl Fairburne, the clean task to thwart that operation!

Although there is a lot of tactical or if a sniper to go through, there is a lot of recognisability from the previous versions, which makes it less attractive for me, at least from my point of view. Furthermore, the entire gameplay is reasonable to properly adjust to any difficulty per game component, which can be quite useful to achieve and unlock certain achievements. And anyone who knows how to deal with that tactically can easily play the game and unlock all the achievements.

The possibility that other players can penetrate your game or level is a fun and exciting experience and gives an extra dimension. All in all a good game that gives beautiful pictures in the graphic area but at the same time a lot of the same from the previous versions and that makes it a bit monotonous. The yellow and red colors warn you that enemies are on the track or are in fighting. That works intuitively as a steering element; You don't want yellow and certainly no red at all. In addition, the game assesses you at the end of a mission and thereby shows elements as how often you have been seen through enemies and how often the alarm has gone off. So you are clearly sent in the direction of Stealth, which means that Sniper Elite 5 is indeed more a tactical spy game than just a pure snipers game.

As mentioned, it is possible to penetrate games from others, as a sniper on the German side. The player who is busy as Karl Fairburne then receives a report that there is an enemy sniper nearby with an indication of where that sniper is. The telephone system in the game that players can provide extra information about where the enemy is, is also a funny element. This creates a cat and mouse game between Karl and an enemy sniper, which without a doubt yields the most exciting moments in Sniper Elite 5. The dynamic changes when it becomes two-to-one. As soon as you as a loner manage to kill one of the two players, the other player from the team of two only has three minutes to kill you because otherwise you will win the game by definition. That produces a nice tactical issue. So it pays to try to attack one of the two players quickly, because you only have to keep yourself hidden afterwards to let the other take all the risks. And if you don't want all this, you can also turn off the option to have intruders in your game.

In summary, 'Sniper Elite 5' has nice parts, but it is not convinced to me enough and I found the storyline a bit boring. I understand the chosen course of the game developer and you can go through the game as well as a sniper or in stealth mode from start to finish. All in all, it looks like a kind of Hitman game. And for the target group that knows these games a little less well and is not waiting for a very high level of difficulty, then Sniper Elite 5 can be set so that it is still a very nice game. I think the purists among us will miss the focus on real sharp shooting, but at least they can also opt for an authentic level of difficulty.

Regards Q

I have about 80 hours of play time as of today. I played Sniper Elite 4 (SE4) previously and loved it. This game is similarly great however, they have changed the mechanics and scoring. Additional points towards rank may be scored by concentrating on non-lethal take outs. I find this to be tedious and not in line with any kind of war reality. Mechanics have changed in that the smaller booby traps are gone in favor of a non-lethal Shu mine. I really prefer the lethal small mines like the trip wire in SE4. TNT and Teller mines are in Sniper Elite 5 so lethality in mines is not all gone. Also I have tried to harvest mines from minefields which is possible in SE4 and so far have been unsuccessful in SE5. I may try this a few more times just to be sure, but I do not think you can harvest mines from German mine fields anymore. Mechanics of hiding in grass are similar. However, I notice enemies seems to search the grass more thoroughly in SE5. Noise masking from trucks, generators or airplanes works exactly the same as far as I can tell. 

The scenery in SE5 is beautiful. I particularly like Beaumont St Denis. I like the scenarios I have played so far and the weather patterns are interesting and/or challenging. It's a great game. However, I think I prefer Sniper Elite 4 over Sniper Elite 5. Good luck.

I always buy this title, but there no significant improvement from other series. These are the things I totally hate about this game: 
(1) The bullet starvation is ridiculous and forces the player to COD its way into the enemy just to get supplies. Want to limit inventory? Fine, make pistol and SMG ammo scarce, but the rifle should be abundant in quality and quantity. Fix the total amount of bullets the player may carry and let the player distribute them at pleasure. 
(2) Load out: Why do I have to look for a craw bar and cutter all the time? It should be an item the player chooses at start. 
(3) Ammo types: The player has 9 pouches of ammo types (3 per gun). Why in hell has to be fixed? I use 2 types for pistol and SMG while I crave to have most of them for the rifle. Let the player distribute. 
(4) Binoculars take forever. It is so ridiculous and tedious. And lots of times won't tag the pointed targets. 
(5) Frisking corpses is soooo boring just make a sound when the payer passes on top of the to get the items. 
(6) Armory: Common guys is a stupid game! make a room that is worth visiting with unlimited ammo refills, meds, and the enabling full customization (from ammo types to character). 
(7) Selecting an item is a nightmare! many times I threw a grenade when I really wanted to plant a mine. So the developers make me throw myself into he the enemy in a solo fire fight to get ammo (COD baby yea!). Then I get chased by  endless shooting zombie hordes and I can't lay my traps with confidence? Really? I felt like Willy Coyote so many times! I knew I shouldn't brought ACME products to the fight damm it! 
(8) The so called "Decoy". It's really a broomstick with a helmet with no value. It does not work and when it does, the Snipers freak out in yellow or red. And the troops around them freak out as well and some times raise the alarm. Meanwhile you are watching the freak show from afar and wonder why in hell you placed that stupid thing.

The following are my thoughts and impressions after completing version 1.22 of Sniper Elite 5.
Early reviewers have been critical that the 5th instalment hasn’t introduced enough new elements, but I think that Rebellion knows exactly what they want to accomplish with their franchise.  For me there are ample new elements to get excited about.  Much larger maps (with fantastic levels of details), more ways to approach an objective, unlocking optional objectives in mission, ability to customize you weapons through discovered workbenches.  None of these are game changing in their own right but the way it was implemented was done in a way to enhance the core Sniper Elite franchise.  I’ve enjoyed the game so much that that it is the first ever season pass I bought.
Added bonus:  Even though the game has always had a multiplayer option, the invasion mode is what I’m more excited about.  Now that I’ve finished all the missions at least once, I can attempt them again but this time with invasion mode, to play cat and mouse with a real person.

This game differs a lot from the other sniper elite games,  So let's quickly talk about the good and bad changes:

Good changes: 
Weapon customisation. I was sceptical at first, but it is a nice addition, as it does not make a gun a lot stronger or weaker, it instead shifts it's strengths and weaknesses around which is nice.

Infiltration mode: The mode itself is suprisingly fun, and even feels like a good match for sniper elite which i was not expecting. You do get reduced xp without it turned on, but it has little impact on your game.

The Bad changes:
they removed the rocks and replaced it with bottles you find everywhere. Why? just why? It changes the gameplay only a little, but takes away realisme which was appearently something they aimed for on this version. (*lengty laughter*)

The difficulty. It is so darn easy. Unless it's a vehicle, you can just run at the enemy Call of Duty style and win on all but the hardest difficulties. I remember struggling with sniper elite 4 on authentic plus - no saves. It was hardly a challenge to complete this game on authentic. 

The technical/gameplay stuff:

A.I.
Dear god... the A.I. is terrible. They essentially have 2 states. Braindead or cheater. In stealth you can just jog up to them and stab them. not sneak/crouch. JOG!. It's a joke. But god forbid you are looking at them from 30 meters away, because then they are suddenly hawks. Loud is no better. They either run past you like you don't exist, or they start shooting at you like wallhacks are activiated. It's garbage.

Then there is a lot of changes I am just not sure about. The new maps are mostly bigger and feel more authentic, yet at the same time most of them are very void of life. Not just NPC's, but also sounds and animals are very little to be seen. On top of that the game still feels like it guides you trough the map by blocking off a lot of alternative paths with bushes and barbed wire, so what is the point of having big open maps? You just go full walking simulator from location A to B to C.

They removed  many nice things from previous sniper elites. The officers are less important. The soldiers that I think are supposed to be the new valkeries are hardly any different then normal soldiers. Objectives now randomly pop up based on intel you find, making you run around the map a lot. The killcams make you see more, but also less, because the veins and flesh blocks most of your vision of the organs.

Then there is a lot of tiny things like the very annoying climbing and cover mechanisme and poor hit registrations, but I don't even want to get into that.

As a sniper elite game, I miss the hearth and soul of it.
As a sniper game that is more arcade, I kinda like it.
There is a lot of tiny things that frustrate me, but still enjoy it.
This game pisses excellence. Never gets old.

[b]Sniper Elite[/b] is back with more Nazi super-weapons, more Karl Fairburne and more gruesome bullet cams; if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it. This successful series is serving an old recipe with some newly added buzzwordy ingredients, including weapon customization, non-lethal takedowns and more.

[h1]Setting[/h1]
This time, the year is 1944, the German stranglehold on Europe is loosening as desperation begins to set in for the Third Reich. The Allies are about to launch the largest amphibious assault ever to be seen in history. You play as Karl Fairburne, an elite sniper who has yet to find his match. Your objective, along with some U.S. Army Rangers, is to weaken the Atlantic wall in preparation for the Normandy landings. However, Fairburne soon assigns himself his own mission, destroying the new wunderwaffe, Operation Kraken.

[h1]Weapon Customization[/h1]
The most notable change to the series is the ability to select new attachments for your many armaments. Suppressors, muzzle brakes, night-vision scopes and more are among the various pieces one can use to modify their weapons. No longer must you be content with a single silenced sidearm or DLC weapon; you can now live out your dream of infiltrating enemy lines with suppressed SMGs.

However, one curious addition to all of this are less-than-lethal rounds, the long-range solution for a pacifist run, working in conjunction with non-lethal stealth takedowns. As far as I know, you don’t receive any bonuses — or achievements for that matter — for being a pacifist, other than being able to live out some grand fantasy of being an elite operative who saves their blade for the hearts of the most malicious of enemies, if they even have a heart. Do be careful, however, that your unconscious victims don’t land in centimeter-deep puddles, they will hilariously drown themselves and you will have a conscience to clear.

[h1]Level layout[/h1]
The missions in [b]Sniper Elite 5[/b] feel like they were an attempt at making realistic levels that felt like they were organically evolving and to some extent they achieved this. The previous entry in the series had almost every, if not all, optional objectives revealed to you through character interactions before even starting the mission, sort of like a debriefing, whereas [b]Sniper Elite 5[/b] will often have optional objectives revealed to you either by listening in on conversations between soldiers, or simply stumbling upon them as you go from point A to B. Many missions also have roads with traffic going through checkpoints, which stop those vehicles for inspection making the map feel alive, though the illusion may only last through your first campaign.

None of that is to say that this game’s level layout is a masterpiece. As much as I jumped for joy at the ability to mount stationary machine guns, I didn’t find an opportunity to use it, that being said, I didn’t perform any sort of extensive search to find said opportunity.

[h1]The Resistance[/h1]
One feature I was hoping to see the return of were resistance forces. The previous installment saw the Italian partisans fighting the fascists in skirmishes for at least two missions. Disappointingly, however, you never see the French resistance forces fight anywhere. Fairburne even participates in an airborne assault on German positions along with Army Rangers, but you never see them in action either; it’s like having your significant other send a lewd text, only to find them sleeping in bed when you get home.

[h1]Axis Invasion[/h1]
On a more positive note, there’s another new addition to the formula; the Axis Invasion game mode allows you to drop into another player’s campaign as Jäger, Fairburne’s Nazi counterpart whose description declares him as infamous, but he may be better described as being opportunistic.

The best time for Jäger to strike is when his rival is in a firefight, when he will be ensnared and unaware of the glare coming from Jäger’s scope. Therefore, those going up against Jäger must not get tied down in an unwinnable fight. It is best for Fairburne to run and hide, rather than become a sitting duck for Jäger’s crosshair. But one particularly useful skill Fairburne does boast is his innate ability to sense from which direction Jäger might be coming from until he gets too close, then Fairburne’s senses will tell you that he’s right on top of you. Jäger, however, may get even more detailed information on his rival’s location as he can have fellow soldiers report it directly to him. Notably, however, Jäger can invade a co-op campaign and in that instance, should he be successful in eliminating one sniper, the other will have just three minutes to avenge his friend’s death.

This game mode has the potential to make a high-stakes game of stealth, however good luck in finding a good match if you don’t have a friend to play with. Rarely did I find a skillful sniper in strangers’ campaigns. Most of the time they abandoned the idea of stealth at the first sign of trouble leading to an easy win for Jäger.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Much of the [b]Sniper Elite[/b] series could be accurately described as a casual stealth experience, the same is true here — especially so in many co-op campaigns — with the potential exception of Axis Invasion, which makes stealth a borderline-necessity. [b]Sniper Elite 5[/b] took around 20 hours to complete the campaign, mostly stealthing with a few instances of careless running-and-gunning plus a half hour of incidentally recreating the JFK assassination with a Nazi officer. The non-existence of friendly soldiers clashing with Germans is only disappointing because of the potential that such an improvement could’ve brought, the Italian partisans were present in the last game, but they felt like a test run rather than an integral part of the game. Thus with all that being said, most of what was present in [b]Sniper Elite 4[/b] is still present here, with a few great additions and all with the latest game being cheaper in price, thus I think veterans of the series will like this iteration. Overall, it was quite enjoyable and I can see myself playing through it again.

I am a full series veteran of the Sniper Elite series, especially Sniper Elite 4. I recommend the game to anyone who has enjoyed previous installments. It pretty much picks up right where the series leaves off. 
-Story is familiar and all but I was not super impressed by the progression that I would expect from a solid title.
-  The controls might be the worst of the series, taking into account that it is 2022. This is the main reason for my lower rating. Doing simple things liked climbing a ladder or trying to search multiple dead bodies near one another is awful. It is worse than SE4 was IMO
- I really love the landscape and architectural graphics but again, the terrible masses of "tiny objects" that halt you in your tracks or seem like you should be able to climb/vault but cannot, its pretty bad too.
- Combat is satisfying and not too terribly different than the previous games. I like shootin' Nazis, they've got me. 
- Sniper Elite is a niche serious IMO abut they should try to evolve their series a little bit. I am not sure I would buy a SE4 expansion if it is literally just another map or 2. Lets see how it ages!

I really really want to like it having loved SE4, and this is similar. The big way it is different is that this is a buggy mess. Game-breaking bugs like falling through the floor/out of the map still have not been ironed out and enemies can spot you through opaque surfaces. The fact you can lose everything to bugs so often encourages the player to save-spam and means a lot of game time is spent in the loading screen. 

Separately, it doesn't appear to be a bug but the fact that if one enemy spots you, all enemies on the minimap spot you is not enjoyable at all when playing through on a lower difficulty just to have some fun.
Some minor imperfections do not detract from how much fun this game is if you like sniper games. I just wish it took longer than 29 hours to complete so I'm playing it again on a higher difficulty.

Sniper Elite 5 is both some of the most fun I've had in years and a frustrating mess at the same time. The highlight of the game and what makes it worth it is the invasion system which creates these really unique and tense encounters. I never know what is going to happen when I invade someone. One game I invade a new console player who after he finds my location stands up in the open on a hill and gets a bullet through his skull fired from my rifle. Another I get into a twenty minute long game of cat and mouse across a wide open area in a sniper duel. The maps are big but you can use evidence in order to find the other sniper once you are used to the game and the maps.
Now for the negative, I experienced plenty of bugs and a few hackers but the most frustrating thing is the mantling system. Some fences can be scaled but some can't without much difference between them. There are invisible walls in areas that you should be able to enter and the climbing system often takes you in the opposite direction of where you want to go. Sometimes the AI bugs out and does bizarre things or the alarm gets stuck on and never turns off.
It is a bit frustrating but the invasion mechanic makes it worth it and adds a ton of replayability to the game. Currently there is less content than SE4 but I imagine that will change over time as they add more DLC. Definitely worth it if you like slower paced games with lots of tension!

Sniper Elite - but the sniping is just another weapon, and you'll end up using your other weapons more.

You get placed on maps where you think - at last, I can be a sniper - except there is no proper vantage point, and no clear shots, and then you notice a few enemies nearby that you will hear you so you have to clear them first by going up close, and then move back out of earshot before sniping the original targets. On one map you get to excitedly climb a church tower only to find there's a massive tree blocking your view of the enemy camp. Truly astonishing how frustrating the game is and how limited the real sniping opportunities.

More like an old medal of honour game really - and if that's what you like, then its a good game. But you're a Commando who happens to have a scope on his rifle - rather than a Sniper.

Oh, and I'm on mission 6 of 8, wondering when I might finally be rewarded with a silencer for my sniper rifle, so that I can take out nearby targets by sniping rather than stealth - only then do I read the small print. You have to find the rifle workbench in mission 2 - a workbench I just happened to overlook as I just wasn't that interested in completing everything.

So the XP rewards are nice but not that great - and the one piece of equipment I am desperate for is out of reach unless I go back and re-play mission 2. What a joke. It should be available from any rifle workbench after mission 2 - not SOLELY from the mission 2 workbench. (Sadly, despite finding a few workbenches across the different missions - I also missed the rifle workbench in mission 5 - so the upgraded silencer is also out of reach - given that you can modify any weapon from any workbench, it was a bit surprising to find that the game distinguishes between workbenches at all)

Great addition to the Sniper Elite franchise. It offers well though out levels, lots of guns to choose from and multiple modes to play. This review is purely focused on the singleplayer aspect of the game, I never touched any part of the online part.

I don't understand all the people in here complaining about how they do more sniping in <enter non-sniping game here> than in SE5. If you chose to go in guns blazing, mow down everything with the MG42 and chuck some nades you can hardly moan about the lack of sniping opportunities.
If you don't make use of the custom difficulty options and then go on about how there's too much UI clutter and how the aim assist is literal cheating you can't expect people to take your opinion seriously.

SE5 surely does a lot of things worse than SE4, especially when it comes to terrain interaction (vaulting, invisible walls, crap like that), but level design isn't one of them. The maps are huge, allow for a range or even mix of approaches, open things up for replayability, can be punishing, but never unfair and are generally not as CQC excessive as is often claimed. Also, they look amazing. Seriously, Beaumont-Saint-Denis and Saint Nezaire are probably among the most atmospheric levels I have ever seen.
You can and will snipe a whole bunch - IF you care to find and secure suitable locations to set up in. If you don't, well..

The AI is still pretty braindead, no point in sugar-coating it, but if you're looking for a challenge you can still Sam Fisher this on Authentic (or Custom) and have a hell of a time regardless.
SE5 is a respectable successor to SE4 with a lot of improvements and a few downgrades here and there. I very much enjoyed my 45ish hours so far and will continue to do so, hopping into the DLC mission.

Addendum: gun modeling and textures are superb (with a few tiny exceptions), same for accessories (minus suppressors). Gun behavior as well as animations such as reloading, bolt manipulation and handling are top notch. If you care for gun play and the details surrounding it then this game will deliver on that front.

Good game

Well, I don't know quite what some negative reviewers have been playing, but this is by far the best of the Sniper Elite games to date by a country mile.  Don't be put off at the start - the first ten, fifteen minutes of the first mission seem rather restrictive in where you can actually go to achieve the set goals, but after that, freedom to move around a vast world gets somewhat better.  
This world in Sniper Elite 5 is simply beautiful.  Campaign Italy in Sniper Elite 4 was good, but this is even better.  The detail is simply incredible - a huge variety of scenic battlegrounds combined with close quarter town elements provide a breathtaking experience.  It is simply beautiful.
Game play is far more challenging.  It takes a few missions to develop a style of play that you find works.  There are multi objectives in each of the main missions bar the very last one whcih is a bit of an add-on compared to the other missions.  There are far more enemies around - you simply cannot go in guns blazing with a hope of blasting everyone in sight and surviving.  Strategy is needed - a space to bail out to if things get tough - and boy are things easier if alarms are not triggered.  Added to that - weapon tactics are much more realistic in this game.  In SE4, you could pick up a weapon, keep it, and add copious amounts of ammo to it as you progressed each mission.  Here, you pick up a weapon, and can only use the ammo left in it before either going back to your own weapon, or finding another similar weapon to use.  Far more challenging and realistic.
The sniping element has changed the least in my view.  Depending on what level of difficulty you play, the sniping mechanics are pure Snipe Elite as it always has been.  Unlike Ghost Warrior Contracts, sniping distances are not that extreme.  However, the cut scenes are pretty brutal and weapon sounds are a huge step forward.
Afraid the voice acting is just as bad as it ever was, but there we go....you won't be buying this game for the cut scenes which are still somewhat predicable and hackneyed.  
I like to play each level to the full - if you want to, you can take a good two hours game play for each of the major levels in this game.  And each mission has such wonderfully created environments.  Most compelling and enjoyable.
Tanks and vehicles are more difficult to destroy - this is one part of the game play thatis nothing like previous SE episodes.  You will need Panzershreks or armour piercing weaponry and ammunition to destroy tanks and such like in SE5.  Much more of a challenge than sniping gunners and drivers as experienced in SE4.
There aren't many games that I'd justify not waiting for a sale price - this is one of them.  Buy it.  It is a load better than SE4 and that is saying something.
At the time of writing, there are two major issues that need sorting - one is the lack of zoom functionality on the middle mouse when in sniping mode.  It's designed to work, but doesn't for me.  Secondly, the zip wire bizz has a bad habit of freezing up which stalls the game play badly.  Save before zip wiring, and it's ok.
Great game, continues with its previous ones.

TL;DR Sniper Elite 4 was a MUCH better installment. Sniper Elite 5 isn't AWFUL, but super weak compared to earlier games in the series. 

Pros:
- New first person aiming mechanic
- Improved weapon sound mechanics (such as decreasing stealth effectiveness of suppressors at point-blank range)

Cons:
- Clunky movement (was using a PS4 controller at first)
- Weapons customization odd and imbalanced
- Many series familiar weapons not included, possibly blocked behind a DLC paywall
- The campaign maps are meh at best, not many long distance shots.
- THE MULTIPLAYER MAPS are WAY too close range. 
- Campaign AI are WAY too easy. Some players even saying Authentic difficulty is hardly a challenge, compared to Authentic and Authentic Plus from Sniper Elite 4, which were insanely challenging and engaging.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h2]Sniper Elite 5 Review[/h2]
	
[h2]Storyline[/h2]
I am pretty sure you would have realized that the Sniper Elite series are gameplay-heavy games. In Layman’s terms, the Sniper Elite series is known for the Genre-specific gameplay rather than the storylines. People play this game just to attain satisfaction from the kill cams or for the fun co-op experience they offer. 

There is a lot of redundancy in the storyline across the series. It usually involves infiltrating bases, taking out the higher-ups, and finally killing Adolf Hitler. The games’ plots are always something along these lines. So, if you’re looking for a proper unique storyline in this game, this isn’t meant for you. Let me sum up the entire plot in one line:

[code]Play again as Karl Fairburne in 1944 France as he fights to uncover a secret Nazi project called Project Kraken.[/code]

Yeah yeah, it’s the same ol’ plot. Karl is immortal or some shit & Hitler can apparently respawn. Alright, I’ll stop questioning the logic in this game’s story.

[h2]Gameplay Mechanics[/h2]
The gameplay part of the game is what made this series so popular. The kill cams and the gory after-effects of your shots are what the players find most appealing. Well, here are the multiple segments again:

[b][u]Core Gameplay[/u][/b]
The core gameplay remains the same. As I mentioned in the introduction, Sniper Elite has established a solid gameplay. It’s already challenging and fun. It is because of this that the developers are not trying to introduce any major differences whenever they release a new part. And the good thing is, people are barely complaining. 

So, each mission takes place in an open-worldish environment where you are given multiple objectives. Yeah, the objectives are very similar to the ones from the previous games; killing targets, destroying stuff, etc. The very generic shooter game objectives. What’s good is that you are given completely free reign on how you approach these tasks. There’s no laid path for you to follow to complete the missions. Since it’s an open-world setting, you get to choose your own approach; stealth or guns blazing. I prefer stealth since that’s how a sniper should actually take down their targets. At the same time, I take up the guns-blazing approach when I run thin on patience. 

You must be wondering how one would take a guns-blazing approach in a Sniper-focused game. Well, you have secondary weapons. These secondary weapons obviously have less ammo to discourage relying on them all the time. It’s best to use them when you’re in a pinch or want to take out someone in close range!

[b][u]So, What’s New?[/u][/b]
Apart from the usual upgrades to the already existing features, Rebellion apparently added a handful of new features to Sniper Elite 5. So, here is the list of the so-called new features:
[olist]
[*] [b]Improvements to the game’s campaign:[/b] They’ve taken references from real places and included them in the game now. Some assets used are the result of photogrammetry which gives them more detail since they are basically scans of real objects. You can now share ammunition and healing items with your co-op partner. 
[*] [b]Weapon customization and Map Traversal:[/b] Weapon customization has become a bit more detailed by allowing you to customize almost every part of the weapon. Traveling across the map has been enhanced a bit through the addition of slopes and ziplines which can come in handy in various situations.
[*] [b]Invasion Mode:[/b] This is an entirely new campaign-based PvP mode they introduced in this part. This allows randoms to invade your playthrough. Their main target is taking you out. This adds a bit more spice to your playthrough while making it a bit more challenging. 
[*] [b]An Enhanced Killcam:[/b] The Killcam in the Sniper Elite series has been one of the most vital features the game offers. They keep on making it better and better with every new release. So, it’s pretty obvious that they have made a lot of improvements to the kill cam in this game. It’s more graphic than ever!
[/olist]
[i]Source: [url=https://gamerant.com/sniper-elite-5-improvements-campaign-weapons-traversal/#:~:text=Sniper%20Elite%205%20will%20additionally,companion%20within%20co%2Doperative%20gameplay.]Gamerant Website on the Same Topic.[/url][/i]

So yeah, this is all the new stuff the game offers. Not a lot but the core gameplay is what would keep you hooked. And yes, I had to look up the stuff that was new in this game since they were not very obvious when I played the game. I hope the next part will have actual noticeable introductions.

[b][u]Difficulty Modes[/u][/b]
So, there’s a new difficulty mode in Sniper Elite V named “Civilian”. It’s now the easiest mode. The other difficulty modes are the same as they were in the previous parts:
[olist]
[*] [b]Civilian:[/b] As the name suggests, pretend that a civilian is given a Sniper Elite and is thrown into the battlefield. The civilian would now know how to fend for themselves. Hence, everything should be easy as fuck in order for the civilian to have higher odds of surviving. That’s basically this mode, easy as fuck.
[*] [b]Cadet:[/b] This is the somewhat easy mode where weapon ballistic is omitted and the AI would have the IQ of a rock. 
[*] [b]Sharpshooter:[/b] Basically, a slightly harder difficulty mode where bullet drop is a thing. Enemies can now aim a bit better and can deal a bit more damage to you.
[*] [b]Sniper Elite:[/b] Oh my god! This difficulty mode is the name of the game! But it isn’t the hardest difficulty mode. This is where the actual sniper ballistics come into play. You have no assistance whatsoever. Everything becomes manual.
[*] [b]Authentic:[/b] The hardest mode the game has to offer. As the name states, this mode is as hard as real-life….apparently. It requires a lot of skill since enemies are as sharp as a knife and can deal a shit tonne of damage to you. Pretty sure they can one-shot you.
[/olist]

Apart from these, there’s obviously a custom difficulty mode where you can alter the difficulty of the different aspects of the game. These options not only make the game tailor-made for you but also add a lot to the replayability rate. 

[h2]Visuals & Audio[/h2]

The visuals have greatly improved when compared to its predecessor. Everything is way more detailed and polished right now. I love the new gorey and overly-detailed kill cam kills. It’s way more satisfying! The visuals are an easy 10/10! As for the audio part of the game, I am not really sure what to say since I didn’t pay that much attention to it. I was a bit too focused on the gameplay…

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] The killcam still reigns supreme.
[*] You have complete freedom on how you want to approach a mission.
[*] The AI is challenging depending on your chosen difficulty mode.
[*] There’s quite a handful of difficulty modes to choose from which adds a bit to the game’s variety and replayability rate.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] The story is very dull and kinda repetitive since the previous games have a similar plot.
[*] The missions also feel repetitive.
[*] There are minor bugs but I am sure the developers will rectify them in the upcoming updates!
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Sniper Elite games always manage to fascinate me. I am a sucker for the kill cams and the authentic sniper mechanics. Yeah, the game is a bit too pricey. It is worth that price but I do recommend waiting for a sale. It’s very expensive since it might be considered a AAA Release. If you wait long enough, I am sure the game would go for a dirt-cheap price!

Have been playing SE for years and years, and was really looking forward to SE5.

I'm a fair way into it at this point, and I'm... disappointed.  An understatement.

This isn't a SE game.  It's a first-person shooter with an occasional long shot. Well, it only has 10 rounds in it and you can't keep it - or even switch weapons without dropping it)

Graphics: amazing.   Other parts: ...? 
The frequency with which the game crashes with "GPU Device Lost. Closing Program" is quite a pain. 
Compared to Sniper Elite 3 & 4, in this game... it's like they regressed backwards in everything but graphics.
 
Level design seems to be the main weakness. With a new edition, one would have thought they'd give you more freedom of movement, more things to climb, more places to hide, more sense of immersion in interacting with a realistic environment, but instead it feels like a game from 15 years ago: The number of places you can't go, can't do, the insanely high number of hedgerows all over the place, and tiny walls that our supposedly-badass dude can't climb over... it feels so limiting its bizarre.
And the enemies see you a mile away and swarm.  Such has been complaints from others in the past for previous SE games but I really feel it this time around. 
Even with customizing the difficulty types, the actual sniping stays pretty easy and trivial, and the "holy **** these guys keep coming out of the woodwork and locating me too easily" just seems ....off, compared to previous editions of the game. 
So far I'd say: Sniper Elite 4 was way more fun.

This review will highlight some of the German kit, which was a huge plus to me as a reenactor. Generally speaking, most games are horrible about getting the small details of kit right. while this game does still have stuff wrong, its *technically* correct even if unlikely (for 1944) for so much early war kit to be plentiful.


The german kit, overall, is quite good albeit basic. The regular infantry is clearly based on a reenactor, as the gas mask can is identical to the modern reproduction cans, which have shallower ribs in the can compared to an authentic gas mask can. The tunic is an early war M36, with early war Litzen on the collar. The shirt is the mid-late war soft cotton it seems, which is a common reenactor-ism. That is, being worn for an impression covering any time period of the war. The boots are well done, especially gamaschen with the low boots. 

You do have one mistake early in the video regarding low boots. They were not issued as a cost-saving measure, they were issued alongside the marching boots. Their frequency within units all depended on the unit itself. Some units were only issued lowboots and others just marching boots. 

The officer seems to be wearing the iron cross first class, second class ribbon and a knights cross on his neck... which is ambitious for a generic field officer.

The Jaeger class is just a Fallschirmjaeger, which is also well done. The zeltbahn tents are also well done, along with the weaponry and German vehicles. The helmets are late war M42 helmets, which would have been an odd combination with an early war tunic. They have good k98 ammo pouches, but I was disappointed to not see any K43 pouches in the game. 

All the small details, kit laying around, field items like the trinkwasser, and propaganda posters are a great touch. 

For vehicles and equipment markings, they just picked unit logos out of a bucket it seems. The anti-tank guns all seem to be the smaller 37mm, which was gone by 1944, and they have the logo of the 12th SS on them. 

US uniforms are quite rough. but alright.

The story leaves much to be desired, but there are some comical oversights. Such as you liberate the town in Liberate, advancing North, only to have Sherman tanks move through the town to advance south... where you just killed like 100 people. Overall, the game's story is easily forgotten, it is generic as hell. But if you like shooting Germans in ww2, popping skulls and nutsacks, this is the game for you.  8/10 imo

What I write for this review is the experience I had with the game, everybody will experience things differently. This is my honest review if you don't like it well tough. Also no game is safe from a review whether its early access or full release now onto the review.

Sniper Elite 5 is a great sniping video game. You playing as the famous Karl Fairburne in finding out a secret German nazi weapon in 1944. This game is absolutely amazing-ish. 

The campaign is pretty slandered from the other Sniper Elite games. Find a main nazi bad guy, snipe them & done. You can pick different difficulties from I link lowest is civilian to authentic but they now added more customization options to suit a players comfort when playing. 

Graphics looks amazing even on the lowest setting possible it just amazing. There wasn't a lot wrong with the graphics except for when you join in on other players missions you sometimes will have bad graphic quality for a few seconds. 

Weapon sounds were okay but if I am being 100% honest they all sounded the same to me except the anti-tank rife. I am not sure its just my bad hearing or I wasn't paying enough attention to the weapon sounds but they just sounded the same to me. The rifles sounded the same to each other, the SMGs founded the same to each other & the pistols as well.

Game-play was okay, movement wasn't bad except for the auto cover messing a few things up. Aim movement was actually okay for my default, normally I have to adjust it higher but this was okay. Another thing I had an issue was the buttons being the same for so many different things. Throwing stuff sometimes bugged out to where Karl would just be stuck in the throw animation for a long time. There was the re-load loop issue where you select an ammo type & Karl would just infinitely reload the weapon until you re-select another ammo type. 

Weapons were okay but I didn't like how they were locked through challenges or finding workbenches. Skill leveling would have been nice to do for the weapons & attachments should have been challenges (& some are). 

Attachments are good I guess, I didn't see any issue with them except for the pistol scopes & the pistol suppressors not showing on the gun sometimes. 

Axsi Invasions is where a player is an enemy sniper trying to kill you or your partners if your in a joined match. I turned this feature off in my game but some players I joined has this on & I don't think its a bad idea since it gives a slight more exp reward. The only issue I had was helping a player in his mission & we defeated an invader (damn sounds like Elden Ring & Dark Souls over here) 5/6 times. I would like to see a system where you defeat an invader you can't get invaded again until the next mission. 

Survival is how it sounds, you survive waves of nazi's. I can't remember is this was in Sniper Elite 3 but I know it was in Sniper Elite 4. 

Multiplayer is blank for me meaning I don't know how it is due to never trying it. I my first SE multiplayer was in SE4 & first game there was a hacker which put off multiplayer for SE forever.

Accessories were okay, there were some changes from SE4 to SE5 like no trip wires anymore. The only issue I had with the accessories was the satchel charges unlock requirements were never explained better. It only said complete the campaign to unlock which I did on the easiest difficulty & never unlocked them come to find out it has to be hardest (authentic) difficulty to unlock them since I did easiest to hard & still didn't unlock the satchel charges.  

With all said & done I felt SE5 is nothing new really. Its just the same the previous games. Only thing new (from what I can tell) is the Axi Invasions & thats it. The DLC is the ame & the campaign is just repeat. I would love see Rebellion take a bold move & try something else like a different time era. Don't get me wrong Rebellion does amazing work I think better then Underdog Studio. 

So Sniper Elite 5 gets 5/10 score from me making just average but I still recommend buying this game also the other Sniper Elite games as well.

That's the Pony review for Sniper Elite 5

Still a great game. I just finished the campaign. I played on the 2nd highest difficulty level - Sniper Elite Hard. I've played the previous games on all levels including authentic with no saves, so I got a reasonable amount of experience. The thing I didn't like and got me killed a couple times were the restricted jumping over fences and hanging off ledges. In SE 4 I don't recall ever having to worry about hopping a two foot high fence or wall to avoid detection. But in SE5 I learned the hard way that sneaking past a sentry and hopping over the fence before he turns around is a gamble because - nope- that part of the fence in unhoppable. Or that part of the ledge is unhangable.  You have to creep along to find that one spot. But you can't risk that when trying to quickly get past or avoid a busy spot.  I don't know why they changed this from SE4 but it's highly annoying.  I also found myself spinning and twisting more in order to grab an item or open a safe - you have to be in such a precise spot that it became very frustrating. The game kept popping up the planet charge on safe option when I had the key and every little move would flash the key option only to disappear when you stopped. Spinning, twisting, around and around. 
Minor criticisms I suppose. Overall it's a great game and I really enjoyed it.

Sniper Elite 5 is fun. You shoot nazis, you shoot hitler in the dick, it's a great time. It feels like 10 extra missions for Sniper Elite 4, which would be fine (I loved SE4) on its own... but the new features for SE5 are all riddled with different issues.

Navigating the map is awkward, with inconsistent, unpredictable object interaction. Every map is covered in knee-high obstacles that Karl refuses to vault or climb. Karl constantly gets stuck on things, and decides to "climb" on objects when you are trying to vault, which results in awkwardly flipping back and forth over an object. You get used to it eventually.

The Invasion mode is a cool idea. The other reviews saying they are upset enabling Invasions is a requirement for XP are hyperbolic; the bonus XP is very small and will not be the reason why you do (or don't) level up and unlock perks. But there are a lot of half baked issues with the implementation: For example, the number of players who fucking ALT F4 the second they get hit. If I down an Invader and he quits like a little bitch before I can finish him off (or quits DURING THE KILL CAM), I should get a "kill" not a "Invader Fled."

Invasions also don't tie into any other part of the game. Completing 100 invasion kills unlocks cosmetics as an invader... it does not grant any cosmetics for singleplayer or multiplayer. There really should be a camo, a rifle wrap, even a stupid hat, I don't care.

Also, Karl will not shut the fuck up about how much he fucking loves tall grass. Every time you so much as look at a strand of wheat in this game, Karl will let you know about the fat load in his pants ready to blast all over you the second he touches some tall grass.

Invasions are HEAVILY in the player's favor. I don't mind the player being at a slight advantage but as it is, you can see the invader coming in from miles away. You can also clear out a map, cover it in as many landmines as you want, and then bait easy invader kills. The Invader, meanwhile, doesn't know which difficulty settings are turned on - are you unkillable? Can you see through walls? etc

let me some up a few points, as a fan of the series:

I wanted to love it, but when it was over (after a day and a half) I found that I don't want to revisit any of the missions. Not only is it super short, it's not a sniping game! It became a stealth game with mediocre equipment. Think Wolfenstein without the campy storyline or any of the interesting gear. The story is as bland as can be and you basically find yourself using the same blah-rifle you start with since the game doesn't let you keep any of the better equipment you find along the way. It doesn't even let you keep the ammo you collected. It would have had some redeeming quality if it was open world, but it isn’t. The maps are very linear and there are basically 4 enemies. You are fighting a clone army, but not in any cool sense.
Finally, most fighting is in streets and building, meaning there is not real opportunity to try and snipe most of the time. I think there were two maps in which I could really make a nice long shot and feel like I was in one of the old versions of the game.
Great game, the only thing is campaign needs to be longer or even better if it was open world with set missions would be awesome.
