Yeah ... so it's not Sniper Elite 4 v2, or an upgraded SE4 with more missions - but that's not what I expected anyway. If that's what one expect SE5 isn't quite up to par, can't really put my finger on why though. I'm a 98% pve player though, so that might be why.

On its own though, it's a game where you can roam around on big maps - not open world as you will find paths iinexplicably blocked, although you can get to the area behind that block by taking another route ... somewhat irritating. 

I'm a somewhat exploring type of gamer, and in that capacity this game tend to reward me when I start roaming around and not just follow the main mission points. Extra missions pops up, special killing missions and so on, and that's always fun.

So ... I do like the game, just need to take time to explore a little, and its rewarding - the ai isn't all that stupid, allthough it could be better ... and possibly a few more npcs.


Edit : What would've made it immensly better was if the developers/map designers had made the maps more vertical - in mission 3 the map could've been so much better if they'd actually made more of the buildings open/more floors.

Very much like SE4 but a little harder. Which is a good thing.

Spotting enemies or other things with binoculars are harder (it was too easy in SE4) so it's all good in my opinion. But it's harder to snipe at distance since enemies will not spawn until you have traversed a certain distance or threshold/spot in the game (which make it interesting when choosing a path different than the developers thought you would take - that some enemies do not spawn in their spots the first time, only when you circle around and pass a certain threshold/spot is passed. But again, that was a trait with SE4 too.

I agree to an extent with other reviews that the game play is tilted to a more wargame, or stealth, type. Its sometimes impossible tow snipe, at a distance, since enemies are now spawned until a certain threshold/pot is triggered. That's a little bit sad -- that is, you shouldn't need to run around an trigger thresholds/spots and then run away to get good sniping distance (if you can).

But again, it'a a beautiful game and a worthy sequel of SE4.

Right now, there's been a 40Gb content patch that chonks up this games data to 120Gb total. Ouch. You'd better delete some of your files before you get this game because it is AWESOME. Really makes me feel like an elite agent sent in before the army comes, while being hunted by enemy agents through the invasion system. Invasion system now allows you to set it to Invite Only, letting friends be the Elite Nazi scalps that you collect throughout the whole campaign. And if you play smart as the main character, you will scalp enemy players who must rely on the info passed on from their threatening yet misleading Axis AI allies. Freshest part of the game.

Though I did buy this game on a discount, I would say it is worth the full price. But if you can get it on sale then great. The DLC on the other hand I would not say it is worth its $15 price tag. The visuals and Game-play are stunning and as normal with this series the story is fantastic.

started out as a ~6/10, seeing this as a Metal Gear Solid: Phantom Pain... but less complex in every way, from no base admin (which was welcome because it did get a lil long in MGS:PP), to incoherent decisions about which walls you can or cannot jump over (which is just lazy & stupid, hence the 6/10, but still I could live with it 6/10) .... but now after 10hrs.... am a 3/10. it gets boring quick, and your play style/approach per level becomes the same. it's the most closed/no-real-options of a self declared 'sandbox' i've ever seen

Speaking of other Modes, Invasion! Pretty cool to be able to invade other players' campaign. It becomes a game of cat and mouse, having to play as a German Sniper Jäger to hunt down the Protagonist.

Originally posted 2022-06-03.
Update on 2022-07-29:
After having played the game for the over two months its been out now and getting over 200 hours, here's an update.

It's still fun. The Campaign looses a bit of replayability, especially because your Level is capped at 40. You just don't progress any further than that. Would have loved to have infinite levels, or at least several hundreds. As it is now, someone with Lv 40 could have just reached it, or been there for months. There is no way to gauge how long someone played the game from this.

Loads of bugs have been squashed by the devs. What I mentioned with Exfiltrating on Mission 4 (War Factory) has been fixed, and more recently you could actually get the No Stone Unturned achievement for completing all optional objectives (16 total across 8 missions).

The Axis Invasion is an absolute blast. As the invader you can infiltrate another players Campaign as a German Soldier and your goal is to sabotage Karl by killing him. Rebellion have nerfed the Invader quite a lot with the two recent updates (early July and a few days ago). First reduced the Invaders health pool from 125 to 100 HP and adjusted Grenades and Teller Mines from 2 to 1 each. More recently they've silently removed additional Ammo types (sub-sonic, armor-piercing, soft-point). The Karls that were complaining about it got what they wanted (I guess?), even though that Karl has all the advantages that you could wish for. 150 HP, replenishable ammo, different types thereof, literal wallhacks ("Focus"), more Traps. Despite this I already got over 300 kills as the Invader 🙃
Aaaannyway...

I am old so I enjoy these type of games. Not a ton of keys  to map and remember and a decent story line. It wasn't a Max Payne quality story line by any means but it will do in this era of Zombie and multiplayer survival games. I never mind paying the prices for PC games that have a great single player story  and a lot of action. 
I haven't really seen many bugs or glitches like a lot of players are complaining about, at least nothing that is a deal breaker for me, then again I'm just happy to see a game in this style come out so maybe I'm just not noticing them.
Graphics are decent, but kind of bland for this era of 1,000 Horse Power graphic cards.

Bought the game only for the experience of jumping into other people's Campaign Runs and hunting them down. 
Super fun! Definitely worth the money.

The graphics aren't the prettiest; Some of the swaying flowers look 2D and stretched, etc. 

The map does at times feel very limited in how much it allows you to move through it.  I wish there was a bit more freedom to climb map rubble, jump over/move through more of the bushes, etc.

Basically, the game is a stealth game with a little bit of sniper action. If you like sneaking around and taking out German soldiers, then get this game. Interestingly you get a massive point bonus at the end of each mission for just knocking everyone out. Kind of strange in a war, leaving all these knocked-out soldiers all around. But the maps are big and you are pretty free to go around where you want. You can do some shots, but there is not much sound cover in a lot of missions and you will be heard pretty easily. I like games sneaking around, so for me, it's worth it. Other versions 1-4 were better, but it's not as bad as some people complain.
Just like all the other Sniper Elite games, this one is a lot of fun.
the skeletons are scary

Starting a "new" should wipe out previous earned weapons, etc. This does not happen in this game.
Also played game three times and now can't zoom in with rifle. I changed key bindings and no effect.
Poor tech, have been hung up on several occasions

I tried my best to give this game a good shot, but from weapons fallign through the ground, to enemies not loading in and forcing me to restart the entire mission, to objectives outright being failed and the game not telling me when something like that occurred needing for me to restart the whole mission AGAIN just to try and complete the objective, to the fact that you can't use weapons you pick up for more than the ammo it currently has and nothing more and can't even switch off the weapon without dropping it and ENTIRELY ruining the point of scavenging around for weapons to take from your surroundings...

I tried to refund this game because of all of its glitchy, buggy, half-baked and little thought-out mechanics coming together as a whole to make something unsatisfying...and because I wanted to give this game a shot, I REALLY wanted to after how much I loved SE4, I wholeheartedly do not recommend you get this game. Don't fall into the same trap that I did. This game only reared its ugly head after a few hours of play, and it WILL make you regret how it plays and feels in comparison to how good 4 was. I was excited to actually keep up with this series after how well things came up altogether prior, but I am thoroughly disappointed. Please, please, save yourself the money, as the glitches and bugs I have found have not even been attempted to be patched out. After all, why scavenge around at all in a level to try other things out when instead your guns can fall through the floor when you try to make a stockpile? In MULTIPLE areas? Please, save yourself the trouble...as of course, since I 'passed the 2 hour mark when attempting to refund the game, I am ineligible for a refund.' It's clear these guys want to focus on multiplayer...in a series that never focused on multiplayer ever before, and left things dissatisfying in single player.
Awwesomenesssss
If you like any of the Sniper Elite games, you will like this one.

I honestly do not know why anyone would say that this is not a fun game to play. It is what i was waiting for, met all the expectations, and just delivered on what it set it out to do. It is another of the series and it is excellent. The artwork, the mechanics and the play are what most games get wrong, but Rebellion got right.  It can be a lot of fun, for those that do not get it, well - move along.  If you don't like it, don't play it. This one does not disappoint and is everything I expected it to be.  Seeing the progression from Rebellion makes me think they've got a winning formula here for a good game. Seeing the people saying it isn't fun is just like, why bother? There are games that have serious flaws and warnings are warranted. This is not one of those - this one is fun, challenging and enjoyable for a stealthy challenge. If you take your time, each level can take hours to play. If you have no patience, likely not a game for you.
If you enjoy the legacy, go for it... This one is the best of all!

Very fun, like if Ghost Recon and Splinter Cell had a baby and it was born in WW2. The controls are admittedly annoying at times (Oh you're carrying a body and quickly need to dump it? Why don't you pick up this MP40 instead????), but overall the game is very fun, along with the invasion element. A lot of reviews are bashing 'not sniping as much' -- that's really on them for not being patient and choosing their shots, weapons, etc. and want to just go ham. That's not how this game was designed.

My storage doesn't appreciate the additional 45.7 GB update that their 1 map, 2 weapon DLC added. 

Game can be fun with a friend, however they go forwards in some areas, and backwards in others. For a sniping game, there sure are a lot of invisible walls. The term open world loosely applies to the game when you put invisible barriers up that severely limit your avenues of approach which mainly hurts you in Axis Invasion. The focus ability that the Allied sniper has should not be implemented the way it is currently in Axis Invasion. I understand trying to level the playing field but if you use focus, it feels overpowered, practically wall hacks (when close) or a compass (when far away) that tells you where the enemy Jäger is.

Minor complaints: 
-The cover art shows this massive D-Day landing with all these allied troops behind you. In game, you never fight alongside Allied infantry, or see so much as 2 allied infantrymen together. 

-AI is incompetent, German Snipers will stay "in combat" and shoot at a wall if it is in the last known direction of the Allied Sniper.

-How do you manage to mislabel a German Panther tank a Tiger in a game with this much funding. This is one mistake of many that big developers making a World War 2 game should not be making.

Immersive.  Fun stuff. A little change on the limited/restricted approaches/direction in  some early levels. And the mapping gets a little confusing at time especially with objectives. Aside from that, love the game, but so wish the loading out was the same as Sniper Elite 4.  Workbenches seem like a waste of time. And a few glitches need to get fixed.  What would be great is some new campaign levels for Sniper Elite 4, best game ever made. Cheers!

I was hiding in some tall grass near an open gate between hedges to a road.  On the other side was a guard I wanted to get near me so I could incap them.  I tossed a bottle behind the hedge getting the guard's attention.  As he walked over, crossing the road, an oncoming transport's headlights shown on him and honked their horn.  He started, apparently surprised and jumped back onto the original side of the road and went about his business!

Nice little moment of "realism" I wouldn't have missed if it wasn't there, but certainly added to the realism!

It's that solid 7/10 action game; nothing is quite as interactive as an immersive sim, or as freewheeling as an open world. Sometimes it can feel confining or arbitrary - why do I have to walk 200m down a shin-high stone wall to enter a field, or only climb perfectly things with perfectly flat edges? The flip side of that is that it gives Rebellion a chance to control the experience, to funnel you this way or that, and give you the limited-yet-fun options they've dictated for a given encounter.

There's solid, satisfying action here, and once it starts to click, the limitations are liberating, unlike what I find can happen in open worlds or even immersive sims where I'm always wondering if I "played it wrong." Though there's lots of weapon variety, relatively lean set of overall options - loud, quiet, distant, close, traps - make what's there gratifying. 

A little more disappointing is some general jankiness - world objects that are extremely particular about where you are in space to interact with them, enemies that get stuck in alert-investigating-cancelled-alert loops. This last is especially bothersome because despite a huge, rich set of accesibility and difficulty controls, the HUD options are terribly limited. You get quest markers and enemy tagging and status updates (alert, investigating, etc) and tool tips and etc etc or you get nothing - no option just to have, say, a few essentials on the screen and leave the rest of it up to the thrill of the hunt. I might remember wrongly but I'm pretty sure that this is a regression from SE4. 

The menus are also a terrible modern design paradigm where everything is tiles, and there's no simple way to just resume your campaign. It's not a touch interface; I don't need 5cm x 5cm block of screen to resume my campaign. 

I wish it leaned more into the eponymous sniping - it's so rewarding, especially as you dial down assists. This game seems less confident than SE4, though, and does have habit of clearly blocking lines of sight, or tucking enemies into places that you can't engage except at close range. Speaking of things to lean *out* of, Carl talks too much and this game doesn't need (or at least do well with) the cutscenes, in writing or execution. If you want soulful Nazi-hunting, go play the new Wolfensteins. SE5 I think has aspirations but can't meet them.

It's all still worth it though, and so refreshing that, even if a bit less confident than the one before, is still proudly what it is; a schlocky, shooty power fantasy that is fun to play. Turning off all the assists, sitting 800m out from a target and nailing that shot is something that no other game does or has replicated.

Edit 26 July to add: Rebellion has implemented the Shooting Range feature, which is so so helpful to learn to place your shots. Glad to have it back for SE5, thanks Rebellion!

It’s Sniper Elite. There’s some new additions here as with every new addition to the series. But it’s more or less the same visceral, satisfying action game you remember.

The biggest change is the idea of invasions -- other players busting down your door mid-game, usually as you’re carefully infiltrating a nazi mansion, or gunning down a blockade. Always a little inopportunely. Always a little too frequently. And always a serious monkey wrench in your machinery.

I love it. It fits the rest of the ethos perfectly. These games have always been about embracing a bit of chaos. Sure, it disturbs the otherwise meticulous and predictable gameplay. But it’s all about being allowed to play and improvise. It’s not really a puzzle, even if you can treat it as one. But you can throw caution to the wind too. 

You’re allowed to bring out the big guns one moment, and recede into the darkness the next. No one makes you feel bad, or lectures you about how to play. In fact, the game implores you to explore both its world and all the mechanisms and systems.

Invasions embrace that, turning games into heart-throbbing cat-and-mouse rounds. Both parties with itchy trigger fingers; knowing full-well that every missed shot, unnatural movement, or revealing glare from your scope gives you away. It’s tense. It’s fun. But it’s also a serious distraction and padding to your overall play time -- for better or for worse.

Recommended, if you enjoy Sniper Elite.

Sniper Elite 5... Where to begin... I suppose in a comparison to 4 and the previous titles. The current game I can't really recommend, loads of the killcams (especially headshots) are very buggy. If you land a head shot, more likely than not the camera will zoom into the brain and have it jiggle around a tiny but without being able to see the rest of the damage inflicted to the head. There is also this odd bug where in the kill cams, the jaws of characters are shoved upwards into the upper jaw looking really strange. Missions say that they are "open" and they kind of are, for the most part theres only 2 or 3 routes to go forwards in each lvl. The main issue I have is the "weapon customization" and the fact that the rest of the starting points aren't unlocked til after you finish the map. On top of this, these new infiltration positions aren't even implemented that well, with one of them being next to a road where the ai can immediately spot you on harder difficulties (mission 6 liberation). I'd say that around a quarter of the lvls aren't really good Sniper lvls, this is more of a ww2 Sam Fisher experience. The handful of missions I enjoyed left me distracted with the new weapon attachments system. There are only a small selection of ww2 guns that actually have suppressors, the list goes as follows and are extremely rare. 1. Walther PPK and PP, Erma EMP, G43, K98K, STG-44, Beretta 1934 Pistol, Nagant 1885 revolver, Nagant 91/30 Rifle, Tokarev TT-33, Welrod, .22 caliber Winchester M74 rifle, De Lisle Carbine, Sten MK2, Webly & Scott .25 Pistol, Silenced Standard H-D Pistols, Thompson M1, M3 sub-machine gun, Winchester M74. Seeing other weapons with extended magazines, wire stocks, compensators, ect is very immersion breaking. I am very glad that they fixed the Bullet Drop and Wind Adjustment aim reticle from 4, and made it actually work properly. I get it, the weapon attachments are supposed to add customization and other "fun gameplay elements" but you can make it so they are historically accurate, like being able to Modify a PPSH 41 into the PPSH 43, ect. Other than that I don't have any complaints, the new invasion mode is a good time, and I don't play MP so idk. 6.5/10

I gotta say, what a disappointment! Five years on since Sniper Elite 4 was released and you bring out an almost duplicate game now in Sniper Elite 5, but with more flowers and some freakish AI spawning mechanism that teleports endless AI's into your battle zone. Why? What the hell have you been doing for the last half decade??

If I had anything nice to say, it would be on the improved graphics, the lush scenery, the attention to detail of the buildings and their decor, the dev team's creativity on the cool looking wall posters (thumbs up to Ricardo and co), but that's about it. As for the actual gameplay and gamer/user experience, it's like the Face Off movie but for video games.... same body, different look. The maps control where you can and can't go which is just stupid! What ever happened to the open world style that you gave us in SE4? Also, I can climb a wall like a superhero, but I can't step over a 2-foot fence? The AI is almost laughable too. On easier modes, you secretly kill one guard and the rest follow one by one to the exact same spot which takes out any sort of challenge at all. On some of the harder modes, if you happen to get spotted, well, you realise that you cannot hide anywhere because it is almost as if the game tells the AI where you are located.... all the time (even if you run away and hide)..... and the experience turns into an all out shoot-em-up just to avoid being chased (so much for trying to be stealthy and hiding and stuff). 

The game is a bit clunky/buggy too as I often find myself trying to almost step over a table in order for the game to recognise that I am trying to pick up a gun/bottle/important papers etc. And what happened to the Playstation button config? I am using a PS5 controller on PC through Steam and all I see is Xbox button configs during game play. My same gaming set up works fine with Sniper Elite 4 showing PS buttons, but now with Sniper Elite 5, they only show Xbox buttons (why would you do this to your PS on PC gaming fans??). 

The levels are longer and that's great! But the game mechanism and gamer experience to take out AI is extremely repetitive and becomes almost a dragging bore by the 2nd mission, it is just more of the same. Unless you are a professional historian who will appreciate the different array of available old guns (which all sound exactly the same, I might add), the game is simply a longer barrage of SE4 but without the sniping ability (because like, AI sort of know where you are now and so you pretty much have to turn into Rambo of some sort and shoot your way out). 

So, for players who are looking for that kind of experience, they'll probably be ok with paying the AU$70 for this. But, for the avid SE fan who has enjoyed your series since the beginning and looking for something new and exciting, will most likely be disappointed (like myself) in the overall game play and user experience, wondering what the hell Rebellion was thinking when they put this into production.

Paid the full $50 price because I've become a big fan of the franchise in the past 2 years and wanted to show support since I bought SE 1-4 heavily discounted. SE5 didn't surpass SE4 and seemed like a downgrade with less weapon selection. I've done 1 play through on Medium difficulty using a PS4 controller. No online play yet. The Bad: I missed the tripwires. The entire weapon selection seems to have been downgraded from SE4. Temp weapons option was a good idea for small arms and rifles, but doesn't work well for anti-armored vehicle weapons. A lot of jank when trying to pick up items or navigate ladders. The overall story was underwhelming, especially considering the setting. SE isn't a story heavy game but SE4 engaged me a lot more with the various factions involved. SE5 was underwhelming and was a bit off. The Good: The burnt out urban hellscape of Level 8 was wonderful. Level design in general had some nice variation and challenges. 
Hoping the game will grow on me and updates/Season Pass will add more weapons.

One of the best games I've played! Here is what I like about it:
  - lots of content: 10 huge maps - really huge
  - the game seems to have been designed for stealth and the gameplay is good. Not hitman good, but still really good
   - the graphics and athmoshere are superb. Maps are great
   - you can save and load games any times you want, trying anything new and have maximum fun

What I don't like:
   - guns are almost never a good idea. All gunshots are heared from some distance, even if you use a silencer and subsonic rounds. Pretty much all the time I tried a gun, I found myself swarmed by enemies. The only time I did succesfully were isolated enemies which I could have easily takes out silently anyway. For a game called sniper elite, sniper guns sure are useless.
    - in the first 15 hours of gameplay I already encountered 2 game breaking bugs that completly ruined what would have otherwise been a perfect stealth run: one weapon got stuck infinitly reloading the subsonic rounds, rendering it useless (even after loading the game again)  and another one where bodies despawed after loading the game, yet somehow enemies kept seeing and going to them and then raised alarms. There was nothing I could do because I couldn't see the dead bodies
    - when it comes to stealth gameplay you only have some bottles you can throw as a distraction, and some accident kills by shooting objects that can drop down, and that's it. Kinda thin. You can't setup more elaborated accidents or take disguises. Not even a dropped weapon will distract the AI.
    - the game seems to encourage to tag enemies and not kill them, which is very unnatural considering that unlike in the Hitman series, you are not dealing with innocent bystanders here

I have had fun with this game.  The graphics are beautiful.  The AI is decent and the kill animations are really cool. As far as the missions go in single player, you can play them as you wish, guns a blazing or in stealth mode.  I preferred a mixture of both because sometimes it seemed that stealth just was not the answer.  Overall, I would purchase it.

If steam would've added option to add mixed review i would post it as a mixed review because game is overall good,optimisation is pretty good,gameplay is still the same and good like in older Sniper Elite games but it's slightly changed in some places for better,in my opinion it's better than Sniper Elite 4 BUT at the time i'm writing this review it's missing some features like No sprint crounching that was present in Sniper Elite 4,No DLSS support or AMD FidelityFX Super Resolution 2.0 they instead used AMD FidelityFX Super Resolution 1.0 that is pretty bad compared to DLSS or AMD FidelityFX Super Resolution 2.0.

Update:
I removed things from missing features section that they didn't added like Fov Slider and toggle to aim because they added those in update still they didn't implemented DLSS or AMD FidelityFX Super Resolution 2.0 and sprint crounching from Sniper Elite 4 and main menu music is still the same generic one it's a improvement for sure but i will not change my review from bad to good until they add/fix features listed above.

I like the game. It is beautiful and the sniping is fun, but there are a lot of "buts"

* The game feels very arcadey, meaning it have tons of invisible walls, small rocks and hedges that you just cannot pass. It feels far less open world than SE4. You are very much stuck to one or two paths.

* The fluffing ladders from SE4 is still in. You just automatically grab a ladder when you don't want it and you can never climb one when you want to.

* Very often you have to stand up to pick something up and you frequently pick up things you don't want to pick up (at least you don't drop your stuff at random like in SE4).

* Even if you kill all the winesses in your vicinity the marker for "last seen location" is still on you and 15 new ai is coming your way. This makes it more of a combat-oriented shooter than a sneaky sniper game.

* Very often the notification that you are about to be discovered is never there. From nowhere you are just suddenly shot. It is also a lot harder to discover ai than SE4 (not necessarily bad) and the minimap is very imprecise  - sometimes it looks like ai is extremely close and then you realize they are far away.

* Some of the objectives are very unclear and the markers does not help.

* SE4 was a better game overall than SE5, but SE5 have very much content (you spend hours on each mission).

Played all sniper elite games on  different platforms. Was worried for SE5 at start because graphics looked sub par when  compared to SE4. It is not. It's gorgeous. 

Gameplay is very good. Only thing that really sticks like a sore thumb is to many closed off sections and routes on maps. Speaking of maps, some are better than others. Spy Academy (the one with the huge castle in all the promos) is by far the best (in the whole series). I like this kind of maps, open, in beautiful sunny day, lots of great positions for sniper nests and long shots. Not really fond of dark night maps in crowded towns or scrapyards. 

Infiltration mode is hell of a fun, except for the first 4 minutes until the phones become available, during which you are just wasting time sneaking around because maps are huge and finding enemy player before that is just pure luck. 

What really surprised me is multiplayer. It's crazy good fun. Again some maps are better than others. "Landing site" is the best while the one in the german alps is the worst (too crowded with houses). Finally unlocked Gewehr (best rifle in the game if you ask me) for MP and I'm having a blast, that is, when console players don't one shot me behind cover with their modded controllers. 

Yes you can turn off cross play, but then you get absolutely no servers. Rebellion really needs to fix that. Because it is loosing it's PC base really fast. 

*There needs to be an update to PC version, that sets cross play OFF by default*

Starting the review with Rebellion have absolutely knocked it out of the park for me with Sniper Elite 5 for me and if you want a short review, this game is a blast to play and a great addition to the SE franchise.

in-depth review for any of you interested, if you're new to the Sniper Elite games or a returning fan this game is a must buy for you and I want to start out with what I think are Sniper Elite 5's strongest features.

Top feature for me is the campaign maps as they are phenomenal to me with such a high standard for detail as it's not like they are just large, expansive maps that are full of just empty fields or void buildings as all of the maps have amazing structure to them and every map is very unique even down to the architecture of them as you go from very various settings that all are a breathe of fresh air and I didn't once think a maps designs were repetitive at all. They are very in-depth maps as each map can take you anywhere from 45 minutes or 2 hours to fully explore depending on your play style and how you approach them.

Second best feature for me is Axis Invasion, an optional feature that takes inspiration from the Dark Souls series where a German player can invade your campaign game and put even more pressure on you, or you can be the Axis Sniper and hunt down players in the campaign. It's an extremely refreshing idea and is very addictive on both sides and this is boosted by my previous comments on how good the maps are. If you are the Allied sniper and get invaded it pumps the adrenaline to 10 as you start staring at all the NPC axis guards to spot out the invading player. I really hope they expand on this feature more.

Third feature for me is the gun play in general, the customisation in guns and their variety while not a vast expansive list is still big enough to make you switch out and try different weapons. It gives you a reason to also explore the maps and try to find all the places to unlock said customisation. 

Some of the cons I will mention is while they maps are very good and expansive it can seem like you've become less of an Elite sniper and more of a stealthy infiltrator as it can feel like you're playing a Hitman game sneaking around tight areas and stealth executing or knocking them out but it does give a bit of variety rather than being able to sit from a high-point and take every enemy out. 

The story is also on the rocky side as the main protagonist "Karl" seems to be voice acted like he's a 80's action hero and the cutscenes can be a bit questionable at times but you bought this game to see rifle bullets go through skulls and crotches in X-ray vision so the Story can be a background feature.

Here's the thing about Sniper Elite 5. 

As it is - it's full of bugs: Player characters getting stuck in endless animation loops. Enemies falling through the world and still showing up on the map. Shooting dudes and watching a detailed X-ray camera of their head exploding - only to then watch them finish climbing over a wall and walk off. Options in the menu for a melee X-ray camera, that just plain hasn't been put into the game at all.

As it is - It's pretty fun. Like a less polished Sniper Elite 4, only with less weapons, a worse Survival mode, and a MUCH better campaign. 

As it is -  Every update makes it a lot better than it was on release.

As it is -  It's not worth getting over Sniper Elite 4, which is  the same game, only with a lot more content for a lot less money.

So unfortunately, as an early adopter, to get my moneys worth, I've got to play a shit version of a game that will eventually be good...

So do I recommend Sniper Elite 5? Yes, but not as it is. 

Buy Sniper Elite 4 if you want to play this game, and when you've played the living hell out of that, SE5 will not only be cheaper, it will be better.

Everything works and feels like it was simultaneously designed for gameplay and as a lived in real place. There are bathrooms in logical places. The bunk areas sometimes have playing cards and beer bottles that can be used as distractions. I have never wanted to explore every nook and cranny of a game the way I do with this one. Also, you can play this how you want. I tend to play this as a "Kill Everyone" challenge, turning my character into a bit of an Allied Jason Voorhees, but you can do largely pacifist runs as well

This piece of shit game is so imbalanced. Literally unplayable. I want to have axis invasions, they seem like a nice addition to the game. The ability to merge PvE and PvP content is amazing. The point is to camp!! If this game is for realism.....Real scout snipers can be sitting in the same spot for DAYS at a time. This is a major disappointment after SE4. This game is really clunky and movements are horrible. Lost a lot of details in the vehicles so you can no longer shoot out tires or drivers (in the tanks and armored vehicles). There are only 8 missions with the base game and then a 2 second mission at the end. Of those 8 missions only 3 of them are actually fun and have good map design.
The online part (which is what i was looking forward to the most) is the absolute worst part of this whole game. The quick match options are set up on the easier modes so you are playing with no wind, hit indicators, death cam and aim assist. The one thing that sets this game apart is the realism in the ballistics department and there are never any options to play pvp in authentic mode so you can actually experience that part of the game. plus the majority of the pvp maps are terrible.
This game is a total waste of money and extremely disappointing considering how amazing SE4 was.

🖼️ The new graphics is amazing. I wish you could turn off all on screen indicators for better immersion, even in authentic there are some. The photo mode 📸 is nice but I could figure out how to take a snapshot.

🔊 The sound is better than 4. I like the random things the characters say, some even sound excited they found you 😆 There are times the sound is delayed ⏳ or plays when it shouldn't which can be distracting (less immersive), thinking there is something there that isn't or miss someone that was. I played authentic first and this made it even harder.

🗡️The single player was fun. I like that you can start from different locations. 🏕️ ⛺ It is also fun that there are so many ways to achieved the same thing. The DLC mountain in the Alps 🏔️ is extra fun 😎 too.
I like the long shot challenges 🔭 yet some seem impossible. One I looked up on YouTube 🎬 and it ended up being you had to shoot through some bushes, so you couldn't see what you were shooting at (and in authentic almost impossible). There may be another way that doesn't require this, but I couldn't find one.

⚔️Multiplayer can be fun but you have to find a good group of player to play with. The maps were far better designed than the single player as far a glitches, yet they are smaller and designed for multiplayer so they should be. I have still yet to find glitches, yet some have. The players who play better or play more are rewarded with perks 📦 that make it easier for them to play. This makes it a bit off balanced and the other players can't figure out how one player can be so superior that they get yelled at, called a cheat 🤨, and/or kicked. I would suggest only cosmetic perks or allow single player perks to carry over to multiplayer to fix the unbalance. ⚖️ Also if they had dedicated servers instead of player hosting individually those players who constantly leave and come back un-muted 🤐 just to troll 👹 could be banned 🚫 or at least kicked for a whole game.

🐞There are still many bugs, even though they have fixed many and seem to continue where things have been reported. When in prone walking up stairs or hills you end of having to stand, thus revealing yourself. There a few places where you hang then can't drop or climb back up, so you have to load a save. One place I dropped of a hill and was falling forever, it wasn't until an enemy shot me that I could do anything. There are times the AI doesn't know what to do so they run in place or sit there just waiting to be shot. I believe there is a glitch with snipers randomly shooting after the are aware of you instead of targeting you. There was one level a vehicle was moving on it's side instead of it's wheels. In Co-Op twice weapons have been stuck in a reloading loop 🔄 so you can't use that weapon type. So far only the machine gun and pistol, never happened to my sniper.

🩸I think it's also a bit too much the detail on the kills. I don't mind it sometimes, but wish I could reduce some of it sometimes 🔪, especially when trying to use melee kills sneaking around.

💲 Overall I believe it was worth it, because of the campaign. The axis invasion add a new type of fun/challenge. The levels are much bigger and more detail than 4.

Played on release with my little brother, and honestly had some of the best fun I've ever had gaming. The levels are really well designed, interesting to explore, and the plot is engaging. The graphics are absolutely beautiful and the French countryside setting adds greatly with luscious flower fields, pristine castles, hanging gardens, war torn streets, and mysterious German bunkers to name a few. The customization and weapon variety is just enough to add an extra layer of depth to delve into, making you want to find all the parts and collectibles that you missed on earlier missions. The new axis invasion mechanic is also very stressful but rewarding forcing you into outsmarting other players. It adds a whole other element that completely changes how Sniper Elite is played, and invading other player's worlds is 10 times more satisfying with cosmetic unlocks as your progress. 

The survival system they added is also tons of fun having to face down hoards of enemies wielding MP40's to King Tiger Tanks. Each map is wildly different from the last and adds different challenges to defend a command post. The only drawback is that there are only 3 maps currently. The Multiplayer seems well thought out, but was not enough to draw me in, but provided some fun every now and then. 

All these things together this game is an absolute blast and honestly would get a 10/10 from me if it weren't for the bugs. There are several game breaking bugs in the Voice System, the party matching, and the axis invasion. Some have been patched, but many still persist. It's a shame that these tarnish an otherwise amazing game, however they are not nearly enough to push me completely away, because I'll always be back to shoot Nazi's in the balls. 

9/10

Multiplayer is currently a waste of time. In the past 9 matches, the host has left 8 times before the game ended, which means nobody gets any XP for the game or any progression towards unlocks. That's HOURS lost.

Also, considering that the game requires you to install Anti-Cheat before you can play the game, there is a surprisingly high number of cheaters, and I don't mean good players that could be mistaken for aimbots, but players that can teleport to the other side in no-cross matches and kill everyone. At least this is easily detectable, I don't even want to think about aimbots and radar/x-ray hacks that are virtually undetectable.

But first things first, get DEDICATED SERVERS or severely punish(ban from multiplayer) hosts that leave the game.

[UPDATE]: ESP and Aimbot are currently ubiquitous. Instead of less issues, the game has much, much more cheaters than before; multiplayer is completely unplayable. What a shame, since multiplayer in these games usually last a very short time until you don't find games anymore. Servers of course are still as bad as they used to, lower player count means worse hosts though and you are now going to get high pings more frequently and see people rubberband more often. Just awful altogether.

So day 1 i gave this game a drunken negative review, then i removed it thinking i was being drunk and having unfair expectations of a game ive literally waited years for. Ive put about 30 hours into game so far, on Sniper elite 4 between two systems i have over 1500 hours, and sniper elite 3 i have probably 1000. This game feels like a downgrade to sniper elite 3.5, and not an upgrade to 5. There are some new mechanics, and obviously alot of work went into the map design and such. But there are many elements of this game that frustrate me as a fan of the series. 

1, it has always been a complaint that the AI is either retarded or terminators, and this installment is no exception.

2, bugs, still after weeks of being out has bugs, like hardcore immersion ruining bugs. Infinite reload animation preventing you from shooting, landmines blowing up after successfully disarming them, being seen and shot through walls, nazi steps on your landmine and suddenly the entire map knows exactly which bush youve been hiding in for 5 minutes. Like I dont get it, wasnt those sort of things iron'd out in testing and could you patch it in some kind of quick manner? And the graphics, man, already seem like a downgrade from 4 but textures flicker and strobe out at the worst of times.

3, shots to the face not killing. Like, nazis face is the only thing visable above a brick wall, no helmet, 30 meters, full powered ammo, rifle shot directly to the face, nazi doubles back, just looks surprised, and returns fire. SE#4 was bad for this as well. 

4, no 500m zero? like was that oversite or did somebody go, naw theyll never shoot around 500 meters, lets go from a 400m zero to 600m, so nazi shows up at 527 meters and I gotta kentucky wind the hell out of it because a proper adjustment isnt there. I dont play with the diamond that tells you where to shoot, defeats the point of having to make adjustments in the first place.

5, this game dropped without content that was Pre-ordered and I understood to be released with the game. its not a big thing but a disappointment none the less to see all the hype and buildup and realize its just not there.

6, Clunky movement. The main thing that this game reminds me of SE#3 with is the movement. Its, blocky, fake, exaggerated, and its a game mind you, so forgive some of that, until the movement is what causes you to be spotted constantly, like try to climb over a wall when you have like 5 seconds of time to sneak past a patrol, and hold the space bar just a millisecond too long, well now you are flipping yourself over and over on the wall side to side like a madman, and suddenly you start getting shot.  In SE#4 you had the tenancy to accidentally jump to your death alot, I think the devs Knee jerked the other way and now its almost a mini game to let go of something without hopping back over to the side you just came from 2 or 3 times. 

I love this franchise, but I would give this game a 3 or a 4/10. Based on the previous games, all of which I own, I had higher expectations. Theres some really cool elements for sure, and theres clear work and passion involved in the creation of it. But maybe instead of pursuing the side project of designing and making a board game, we should have focused the next video game instead.


Edit-update 7/11/22-
The gameplay is still horrid. And the fact that this game is 50$ while SE4 is still 60$ should say something. Ive blown way past the 2 hour return mark obviously, and Im committed now to finish the campaign. But after that I dont know if I'll touch it again. I want to love it, I just dont. 

Heres the thing, the maps are beautiful. Gorgeous. Especially the first and third mission. Bravo on that. But my love ends there, the gameplay is lackluster at best, the bugs ruin immersion so bad, and its been out for two months, they've had time to fix some of the major issues. And I am 100% serious when I say, I feel its more broken now than weeks ago when I put it down to give them time to fix it. 

I could care less about the bad animations in cut scenes, bad voice acting, bad animations not lining up with the  bad voice acting, or the random decision to use a black female Irish character being a special ops agent in france in the 40s. Because that checks out. Truth be told, I dont even need the story, never did. Its like porn, yeah theres usually a story there, but thats not why we are here is it? nope. we came to shoot, stab, bludgeon, blow up, crush, and otherwise maim and dismember Nazi scumbags. But its just not fun to do that when you have to constantly reload checkpoints because the game doesn't follow its own rules consistently.

I wish I could upload a screenshot I captured to this review, because it represents the state of the game well IMO. In the screenshot, I was falling thru the map, randomly just fell thru the earth, and guess when the game auto checkpoints? Yep, right there. so reload checkpoint and boom, falling into the abyss and dying again. Now you can load earlier points I know, but its just hilariously bad.

The AI are so dumb and deaf they cant hear a Springfield 1903 rifle shot like 60 yards away, or the bunker next to theirs blow up. But somehow these deaf nazi scumbags can hear a welrod shot at like 50 yards away with subsonic ammo, And pretty much just using a forward charge hand signal to the guy standing next to him, telepathically lets every nazi in the area know down to the blade of grass your boot is touching where you are. Little things break missions in this game, dont skip cutscenes, dont complete certain objectives in certain orders, or the scripting on the AI might bug out and they just stand there like the dumb nazis they are and never move even though you snuck into the room theyre in to watch the meeting they never start no matter how many times you reload save points. I think after I beat the campaign, Ill set it down. Maybe in 6 months Ill come back and it will be great and ill change to thumbs up. But for now I wish I could just tell my younger self not to spend the money on it. Because it wasnt worth the hype.

Out of every entry from 2 to present, I think this is my absolute favourite. Depending on what you enjoy about the franchise, this may or may not apply for you as well. 

I preferred playing this as a stealth game rather than a sniper game. In that sense, this entry is no doubt the best one yet. Nonlethal approaches are plentiful in ways that previous games lacked - nonlethal takedowns and bullet types are at your disposal and work great. There seems to be a lot of scrutiny towards the new bottle system which replaces the traditional throwing rock. But they are much more versatile - they can distract or even take out enemies, which is really handy. Yes, you have a limit on how many you can carry, but restocks are plenty and I never found I was lacking even as a stealth-heavy player. In past games you would be soft-punished as a nonlethal player. Even if you committed to it and snuck around enemies to progress, the lack of nonlethal takedowns meant you couldn't acquire letters or other collectables enemies keep on them. This problem isn't present in 5. 

This game sometimes gets described as a WW2-themed Metal Gear Solid V. I think it's fairly accurate. Again, nonlethal is encouraged. Maps are open-ended and have lots of enemy patrols you need to watch out for. Like MGSV, non-stealth combat is very enjoyable, so it doesn't feel like you're punished for going loud. Previous Sniper Elite games made combat with SMGs and pistols fairly unsatisfying: enemies felt unresponsive to fire and took way too many shots to kill from anything other than sniper rifles. The animations and time to kill in SE5 make using them a lot more fun, and viable as a playstyle. Each mission ends with a chart showing your performance according to Stealth/Assault, and then Lethal/Nonlethal. It's a small detail, but I felt like it did a great job at presenting other playstyles as legitimate. 

Weapon customisation was something I was sceptical about, but I think it was implemented perfectly. There are lots of options that don't compromise the WW2 look and feel, which is great for me since I personally don't like the more extravagant customisation you see in games like COD: Vanguard (though there are definitely options for that, if that's your thing). What really won me over is the ability to remove the scope on rifles, since I've always preferred the look of a plain rifle with irons. Also great is the option to mount a functional bayonet, making assault/melee playstyles even more fun. Having to acquire these attachments through finding workbenches also gives a fantastic incentive to explore each level more thoroughly than I might have otherwise.

UPDATE: I finished the game so to update my review:

Combat: It's stellar. Not much more to say.

Stealth: It's horrible. Very limited hiding options and not all foliage is created equal. Tall grass will hide you but bushes and tall flowers do not. There's not really any hiding options if the enemy is searching for you, just hope they dont check the room you're in. They also always seem to know the general area you're hiding in even if you relocate. Also because enemies are so spaced out it's difficult to get away from combat because if you fight back it'll alert more enemies. If you run you're guaranteed to run into more enemies.

Ballistics: Awesome as always.

The main reason I'm not recommending this game however is the wokeism. This nonsense has got to stop. I don't mind people of color in video games or women but don't insert them into circumstances where they just don't belong. It's just cringe and offensive.

if you are a fan of the series, you will no doubt enjoy this.

there should be a "ehhh" or "informational" rating. there are things i like and things i don't like and i can't give it a clear verdict.

the stealth genre has decayed over the years. despite (or more likely because of) all of the interesting, complex and emergent scenarios you can get with bigger maps, better AI, better vision mechanics, etc. the genre has compressed towards very circumscribed "situations" that don't or can't interact with each other. two to five dudes follow a scripted pattern, you kill or sneak past, move to next situation. it may as well load a new map because nothing you did matters once you leave the area.  everybody's talking about this shit already.

sniping has also decayed, but honestly what's a sniping video game supposed to look like? it's pretty much a typical stealth game where you have a sniper rifle and sometimes it's your best tool.  often it's not, maybe even usually.  everyone's said this already.

maps are huge and seem open at first but are very on-rails once you get into them. lots of invisible walls, everybody's talked about that already.  let's get to what actually matters.

there are black people in the game, and women, and even black women. i really hate this because there's a softball-sized dent in my brain

the actual thing that matters is the invasion gameplay. it's pretty cool. you spawn as a german guy in another player's game, or a german guy spawns in your game, fight to the death. you can use focus mode to see the enemy's general direction or hear his footsteps when he's close, use "invasion phones" on the map to get his exact location (if you're german this pinpoints you too), and so on. german can tag NPCs to see their status for situational awareness.  when it works it's very tense and exciting, when it doesn't it's a lot of running around aimlessly.  just like single-player i find myself rarely actually using the rifle. scope glint is ludicrous, it's like you have a flashlight on the end of your gun. unless you really get the drop on somebody or awp quickscope him once the fight actually starts it inevitably creeps into SMG range. you could use ironsights or the 2x no-glint scope though.

also for clarity, i've seen a few reviews imply there's an assassin's creed element to the invasions where you can pretend to be an NPC. i guess technically if you have the right uniform and just stand there but the animations and mannerisms are different enough anybody paying attention will notice immediately.

the regular team-based multiplayer is a clusterfuck.  

like the other games you get a little lore tidbit for enemies when you mark them. some are evil, some do nice things, it won't stop me from kneecapping them to draw their friends out of cover.  that would be my lore tidbit if i was in the game.

is it bad?  yeah kinda.  is it good?  yeah kinda.  should you get it?  yeah kinda.
Feels more like an expansion for Sniper Elite 4 than a new game, but it's still fun.

There is a a glitch in this game that prevents weapons from reloading.  This glitch has caused me to lose progress on a number of occasions because my primary weapon was rendered useless.  The sales of this game need to be halted until this bug is fixed.   The developer is aware of this bug and has done NOTHING to address it.   

The game is fun and would otherwise be enjoyable but with due to the number of bugs in it, especially the bug preventing weapons from reloading, the game is not fit for sale.

If you can refund your purchase, I suggest you do so.

I don't know, what everybody is complaining about. Are there graphic bugs even after the update? - Yes, a few. Is the AI super intelligent? - No. Is the Invasion Mode unballanced even after the update? - Yes, a little bit.
But at the end only one question is relevant: Is the game a ton of fun? - Yes, it is.
I started late with the series and only played SE4 before this. But I preordered SE5 and never regretted it. It is a ton of fun. Yes, all maps could have more NPCs (which for me is the most annoying thing, tbh, because the maps sometimes feel empty; it's just not realistic, that the Nazis would've guarded their most valuable assets with only a few hundred soldiers, which are scattered around the map; this also is the reason, why the game never gets really hectic), and there are still some bugs here and there. But at the end, the game is a ton of fun. Especially the non-lethal ammo makes the game more stealthy and kind of like Hitman, because you now can, if you want, only eliminate the one target, every map has.
My goal right  now is again 100%ing the whole game. Getting all the medals is fun, because it forces you to play differently and for some you really have to know the maps, for other you have to search a lot, etc. I would definitely recommend the game to everyone, who likes slower, stealthier games.

I feel this franchise has confused the idea of what made Sniper elite games so fun. 
The killcams feel dull, and unsatisfying compared to previous installations. 
AI switch from a dumb, unaware state to a blood-doping skill-level once alerted.
The cutscene dialogue is TopGun-grade cringe. 
The weapons have to be unlocked via Kill challenges - and they are nothing special, with the last weapon being a WW1 era weapon. 
As for the unlockable cosmetics, you are the most unconvincing sniper, with a wardrobe of berets, and strange hats. The unlockable characters also look equally boring. 
The addition of  Silencers, whilst making the game feel a little less stale, they break the immersion of a WW2 shooter. 
I haven't tried the non-lethal weapons yet, but it asks the question "why would you want to do a non-lethal playthrough in a game featuring na@is?"
The game doesn't feel polished, there are bugs and glitches throughout, from faces of constipation in killcams, to guards experiencing delirium and waving at walls. 
My last negative would be it feels like I can play the game with just a knife, the executions are hand-to-hand takedowns are satisfying. 

The multiplayer itself is quite addictive, although you may find one in a few games disconnect as the host leaves. Additionally, the upgrade system is a grind.
The youtube vids of the new invasion mode seem to be quite fun as well for those who want a more adrenaline-filled experience to the single-player campaign (I haven't tried it for myself yet).

The takeaway, please save your money until the game goes on sale. It has it's fun moments, but it's not $/£50-60 worth in it's current state. I just wish that the game would move on from WW2, and into the Korean war or Vietnam war, or maybe something more modern.

I'll go ahead and write a review for this game since I've played it for a couple of hours all ready. The gunplay in this game is miles better compared to SE4. Submachine guns are actually useful in SE5, when in the previous games there were very few moments when it was useful. Invasion mode is thrilling and adds a suspenseful note to an otherwise easy mission. I would often find myself checking every corner and marking every enemy in sight whenever I had invasion mode enabled.
The maps are larger than any previous games, and it shows (especially with the audible ranges that each weapon has, which delineates each type into specific encounters and engagement ranges). 

The story is enjoyable but if you have played previous titles it will seem familiar (bad nazi with big nazi death machine now go kill him and destroy this), but the stealth factor has increased and there are multiple ways to approach targets and zones. AI is the best in the series with groups honing in on your position if you don't move and they will spread out in a search pattern before finally going back into a regular patrol. 

PS. If you are an achievement hunter this game is relatively easy to complete, however multiplayer modes in SE games never last long so if you are planning to 100% this game I would recommend getting it early in its life cycle, or get a couple of friends together to complete those.

Despite bearing the name of previous Sniper Elite games, this is not a game about sniping, but about tactical warfare. The levels seem open, but force you via certain routes, and the enemy AI will rush your position as soon as they hear a single shot. This game was best played by choosing a position behind a choke point, and luring the enemy in via the above mentioned mechanics, and taking them down using an SMG.

The choice of weapons is disappointing, as are the (unrealistic) modifications. Almost all shooting happens at close range (<50m~150m). The storyine, which is for most part a bad ripoff from sniper elite 4, is extremely boring, with predictable and bland punchlines, and it lacks the suspense which was found in the previous installments. The acting within the game is cringy, but apart from that, not really noteworthy, since there is little to none to be found.

But above all, this game departs from the traditional sniping base, in a way I hope Rebellion will recover from.

I haven't truly played Sniper Elite since the original release of V2. I tried a few missions in SE4, but couldn't get into it. Maybe that's a mistake on my part, because this game has been great!
This is probably the closest I'll ever feel to playing Splinter Cell again, because we know whatever Ubisoft decides to do with the series is going to be lackluster. Sniper Elite gives me the opportunity to be sneaky and I love it. Crouch walking through rubble with my pistol in hand? Heck yeah.

Sniping itself is as glorious and satisfying as I remember. I turned off the assistance and use the scope markers to gauge my shots (The game lets you completely customize the difficulty). This game knows what you want to do and delivers that fantasy. Watching the slow motion bullet cam afterwords is 100% satisfying. Truly a 10/10 experience. 

I LOVE that the game doesn't give you a giant list of objectives when you first load missions. Many are discovered by exploring the map or picking up intel. That's a wonderful way to handle it. Kudos to the devs.

Levels are long and intricate. Most were 90 minute stealth sessions for me. Lots of opportunity to play how I wanted, and that was great.

That said, it's not perfect.

I do wish level designs were a little more varied. There were too many "remote village with grassy plains and farm houses" for my liking. This is most likely because they're staying true to the setting, but variety is nice too (Sniper Elite 6 in the Russian Winter, please?). Later levels were a lot of fun, as was infiltrating the castle in mission 3. Also, I would have liked more inclement weather. There were a lot of nice weather days, and I was honestly hoping for more variety to mess with how I would have to line up my shots.

The AI is just "okay". It responds to sounds and bodies most of the time. I do miss the days of game enemies putting on armor or more helmets in response to you being seen/bodies discovered. These enemies to try and call in reinforcements, but that's all.


All in all, a solid B+/A- game for me. I had a lot of fun, and if there's more DLC I'll probably come back for it.

Pros

Combat system well implemented and realistic but not too OTT
Weapons choices diverse and made the game able to be tackled in a myriad of ways from out and out ghosting a whole level to killing virtually every Nazi on the map
Excellent XP system which really boosted your chances on missions instead of feeling in some games as if the skills are useless mostly, almost all the skills are extremely useful
Plot and story line good with believable protagonists and antagonists
enjoyable game mechanics which worked well and enabled missions to be done in so many ways from stealthing the whole level and never being seen to out and out running gun battles with almost everyone on the map, and the vehicle combat also was nicely implemented.


Cons

Dialogue a little corny in parts

75 hours in the game. And I enjoy it. Completed in Medium difficultly and now halfway a campaign in Hard mode.

I like the graphics and the [b]design of the world[/b]. The buildings are nice. Sniping is nice, but not as nice as in Sniper Ghost Warrior Contracts 1 and 2.
And not a single crash (eat your heart out FarCry 6!)
And a lot of multi player options, so if you are into that, enjoy! I am not a co-op or multi player kind of a player, so I tried it, but really too little to have an opinion on the quality.

[b]BUT[/b] (in decreasing order of frustration):
* [b]Really silly restrictions on moving[/b]. Can't jump a little fence, but it is OK to walk around it. Unpredictable if walls or fence can be crossed. I get it that the game world has to have limits, but I don't get the pointless restrictions.
* [b]Game mechanics are clumsy[/b]. Frequently needing 5 tries to pick stuff up. Getting stuck when trying to move through a space which should not be a problem, until it is. 
* There is a lot of (sometimes close quarter) [b]required combat[/b] and (stealth) melee needed to complete most levels. I am into sniping, not into combat. 
* [b]No humor[/b] whatsoever
* Characters are [b]boring[/b]. And who talks like that? Not anybody [b]I[/b] know...
* [b]AI sucks[/b]. 1 shot and all soldiers are all over you and know exactly where you are. But when searching they run around like headless chickens.
* It is [b]too easy to trap a large number of enemies[/b] by hiding in a room and melee kill every enemy coming past or shooting the one or two who are too quick. The harder the game mod, the easier it is to just kill off a bunch of enemies because they get really aggressive in the harder modes.
* [b]Story is poor[/b]
* [b]I turned off invasion mode[/b]. And after a few tries I also quit playing invasion myself.

For me the limitations have become part of the game, but I can imagine it could ruin the game for some players.

The Sniper Elite games have always been an amalgamation of whatever design trends are popular in recent games, bland, predictable, but with its core mechanics concentrated enough to be thoroughly enjoyable. In that regard SE5 is very similar to SE4, with improved gunplay borrowed from MGSV, and music and contrived deaths taken from Hitman. The maps are all mostly similar to SE4, some better, some worse. The real star of the show and makes paying $50 for the same game feel worth its price is the invasion mode, which is wonderful to play from either side of the encounter. While its matchmaking times vary wildly, the tense cat and mouse rounds that can ensue for upwards of 20 minutes at a time give a fantastic focused adaptation of Hunt: Showdown's best moments. It turns the usual nazi-hunting into a brilliant mini-boss combing detective-investigation, situational awareness, and proper sneaking against non-AI players; all fit neatly into the WW2 genres themes of espionage and counter-espionage.

After many doubts I'm giving Sniper Elite 5 a firm thumbs up. Sniper Elite 4 is, in it's own way, a perfect mix of tactics & strategy (I clocked up 2500+ hours). SE5 derives a lot from SE4 but is a very different beast & it took me a long while to tune into it. SE5 is infinitely more realistic especially the landscape & the weaponry. I have finally earned a terrific trio of silenced rifle, MG & pistol (each with scope) which opens up the game no end. In SE4 I used to cheat to get sufficient silenced ammo. In SE5 the weapons can all be silenced & regular ammo used - so it works out very satisfactorily. Ultimately it's much tougher than 4 but it rewards skill & application.

A little me: This is my first Sniper Elite Title that I have ever played, I have played over 100 hours played, I have completed campaign on Authentic with all associated medals completed, all survival medals completed, achieved level 50 (highest level) on multiplayer and completed most of the multiplayer medals, I have also completed over 100 invasion kills, all to say I have pretty much done everything there is to do in the game, which as I stated has taken just over 100 hours.

I really enjoy this game, the combat is fun and the kill cams are rewarding, even though you will probably turn them off after awhile. Multiplayer was a fun grind even though it was very annoying at first, but once I stopped trying to play it as a sit back and snipe type of game, I ended up becoming a monster on the battlefield. Invasion is a super cool game mode and helps add a lot of variety to the campaign mode. The progression systems in Campaign and Multiplayer are very simple, but do impact the game play in relatively minor ways, so even as a new player you are not at a super significant disadvantage, but weapon attachments have to be found in each mission, and those can have a major impact.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Third Person Shooters, Sniper/Stealth game play, the Campaign was very fun, especially on Authentic, which is where the game shines brightest. Multiplayer is hit or miss based on your own level of expertise/proficiency with Third Person Shooters, and survival is pretty boring for the most part. I look forward to seeing how the game develops with future DLCs.

Sniper Elite 5 feels a little less like Sniper Elite, and more like Commando Elite. Not complaining, but i would prefer the game function like what it says on the tin. That aside, the decision to visually obstruct the players view of the whole map may feel like a downside, but i found myself thinking more tactically to avoid or eliminate enemies. I haven't really utilized axis invasion all that much, but I appreciate the feature. I enjoy the return of the weapon customization, it really allows me to tailor my loadout. The invisible walls bug me a bit, but i can get around them. the changes to armored units really makes you more cautious around them. Overall, I like Sniper Elite 5. would definitely recommend.

Let me first off say that I really enjoy playing this game with my buddy. We've played through almost all the SE games together, it's been fun and the set-piece being France is great, love the views and the works. 

However, the first couple of missions we did, we already mentioned out loud that the game feels like it needed some more polishing before they launched it, but that can happen and it's only been out for a couple of days. The odd climbing mechanics I can forgive, although it's sometimes confusing that I *can* run off of a random wall and just land, but if I want to run off of a beam in a stable, I have to meticulously hang off of the edge and drop down. Little honorable mention where we both managed to get ourselves stuck in the ground while trying to walk over a ramp (it made us hang off the edge of said ramp into the french dirt). 

These things are managable and probably patchable... BUT, I have some issues with the game as well. 

It feels like the game has been developed to have become more "Nazi shooting galary number 1944" (yes, I both mean that it's been done many times before AND that it's the year the game is set in. Thank you, observent reader). The customization is very interesting and I have taken much pleasure into creating (and finding) the most cursed guns on the face of this barren rock floating through space that we call Earth. Just for the reason of showing it off to my gun-nutting friends. 

That being said I feel like I don't need my rifle (as much) anymore since I can slap a scope on a welrod and proceed through the game with not too much of a fuss. And that's a slight issue. Not the customization but the fact that, dispite feeling like massive masochists and playing on the authentic difficulty, after a few missions we were casually walking up to our enemies, taking my sweet 3 seconds to aim at their nutsacks and preventing the birth of more of the nazi youth. I can casually walk through the streets of Mont Saint-Michel where the only annoyance was that sometimes we were invaded. That was the ONLY source of our challenges. And BOY do I have something to say about the invasions. 

I like the concept. You can be interupted mid-mission by an actually scarily good sniper and have an awesome face-off. Where-as the AI is... daft, you might find yourself being outplayed or simply jumped on by someone half a mile away who, wholeheartedly will give you a craniotomy. 

What you're apparently NOT allowed to do is, be a sniper. Maybe you dissagree but hear me out: You play a marksman, you are currently being hunted by a few dozen men and what do you do? I'd set up a few traps, find a nicely defensive possition with high ground and a bunch of windows to poke my barrel out of until I can make short work of my "hunters". What happened when I did this during a mission? 
I died, not because I was shot, not because I was stupid (which does happen sometimes, granted), not because of some sort of glitch or mishap... but because the game killed me for "camping". Let that sink in for 3 seconds. I am not allowed to stay in the same *building*. The game pinging me after a few minutes is annoying but I can accept it, it's not supposed to become a game of hide-and-seek, but it killed me because I refused to leave my carefully trapped church. Later in the game, when I didn't care anymore, I ran out towards the invader and I was still getting tagged, dispite active searching for the little shit. And guess what? THEY found a defensive position with many an AI soldier to distract me with, hung out in-and-around a tower until I walked up to him. And did they get pinged? Nope. Did they get killed for not leaving their nicely defensive position? Nope. This is a load of bovine manure and I hope they change it. 

There's a last little mention I'd like to do about the special kill-list missions, which are hard to pull of sometimes because the AI just walks around and doesn't really go back to the area we're "supposed" to kill them, but that might just be us getting caught too many times. 

All-in-all, I like the game, I'm glad it's out but I'd only really recommend this if you have a friend to hang out with while doing so. Have a good day.

Edit: I'm reading in the update that they actually removed the part where you get kicked/killed for camping. Did not expect that.

If you liked the previous versions of Sniper Elite you will like this one even more. It's bigger, more emersive, and better to look at. Most chapters offer alternative paths to the objectives, so it can be replayed for even more fun.

Awesome sequel to the great Sniper Elite franchise, just as expected. The maps are downright huge, reminded me of some Commandos maps back from the old days. For the people that love the franchise or Dishonored, Hitman, Commandos -- this choice should be perfect.

Now for some critique: the animations sometimes are weird, the side characters boring and the story overall is fairly meh. Loved the invasions, reminded me of the recent Deathloop but the issue here is that they have been happening WAY too often and usually disturbed the gameflow -- so even if I enjoyed the duels a lot, had to turn them of as to enjoy the campaign as intended. Will probably play as a Jager soon.

The bottom line is that the game is definitely worth your time and money.

I play almost all WWII games I can get my hands on from aircraft to ships. So yes I have 2, 3, 4, and now 5. I read a lot of reviews on-line from other sites and steam, I have come to the conclusion that most people that complain about the mechanics of the game are new to it. People not knowing how to sprint or crouch have not played it for more than 5 minuets or they have used a cheat of some sort to bypass the built in tutorial on the first mission. The graphics are marginally better than 4 but I was not expecting ground breaking graphics in the first place. The new level and point system I do like, it's an all or none at top level which is 40. The weapon unlock system gives me something to work for and that is something I like from all games or why would I play them in the first place. Some missions are not as open world as 4 but I have found that only in 2 maps as best as I can recall. Getting invaded adds an aspect to the game that is refreshing and brings an aspect of Elden Ring to Sniper Elite. It's the same if you decide to invade someone. I have not tried the survival mode yet and I'm not sure when I'll get around to it.
The campaign is ok multiplayer is boring the first major bugfix patch forced me to download the whole game again 5/10 is mediocre.

Movement feels awful, mantling and climbing is a joke, and the AI are so basic they'll aimbot you through walls and pre-aim corners.

I'd still suggest the game if you like sniper games but I hope dev studios stop phoning it in and stop releasing games that feel like they are still in early access.

The Sniper Elite series continues to improve over time. Not all the maps offer the same level of detail as the best ones, but Sniper Elite 5 is a great example of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" while at the same time having more stuff to do than its predecessor.
I don't care much for the non-lethal options (we are killing Nazis after all, so why bother knocking them out?) but I appreciate that the option is there for anyone who wishes to use it. Otherwise, we can still happily dispose of Hitler with a well placed nutshot, and that alone is well worth the price of entry for me.

I'm very disappointed with Sniper Elite 5. Compared to the SE3 and especially SE4, this feels like a huge downgrade in so many ways. Just to name a few of my grievances, the game's maps all feel worse than those from SE3 and SE4, all are both far to large yet also too linear. The former might seem like a weird complaint, but the maps in this game feel disjointed, having a few areas surrounded by lots of open space with nothing happening. The first, second and sixth missions are especially bad, having vast flat field with little verticality, and a few very tall positions that turn the mission into a cake-walk. Several improvement from SE4 were also removed, like the ability to sprint while crouched or the small hub areas at the start of each mission, and whats new in SE5, like the ability to look down the sights of any weapon or the useless sniper vision I never used, aren't good. Sniper Elite 5 just feels like a massive downgrade from Sniper Elite 4, having worse maps, less tactical depth and poorly implemented mechanics. If your looking to get into the Sniper Elite series, go play Sniper elite 4 instead. As a fan of the series since Sniper Elite 3, I'm not impressed with rebellion's latest showing. 5/10

The Good, The Bad and the Ugly. 

The Good:Game play wise this game is top notch and there are modes for everyone! The game has gotten larger and is beautiful and stunning! I love that the multi-player isn't forced! I love that co-op is making a come back! Bring us more of that!

The Bad: Character models & bad acting! Granted Sniper Elite isn't meant to be a movie drama and it isn't to bad. But it could be better. BUGS! Biggest and most annoying is a grenade bug. I will hold the shoulder button and sometimes the game tosses a grenade at my feet ( or three! ). I've also heard of multiplayer cheating, but I've not played multiplayer yet but do know how prolific it is. 

The Ugly: The forced diversity. In WW2 there was a black french unit of Senegalese soldiers and they wore military uniforms. However there were no blacks in the french resistance as they are in this game. I am NOT saying this as a racist or from a place of racism. It is just a FACT. I think this game would have been served better having the co-op players be any race would offer a more realistic approach to a WW2 game. 

Conclusion: Bugs and forced diversity aside the game play is what it is all about and I give Sniper Elite 5 two thumbs up and a 9 out of 10 and 4 gold stars.
