Game was long-awaited. It's good...and bad. 

Some maps are large, some are small; you have an adequate tutorial map for basic mechanics for the rest of the game. You get a lot of gameplay if you like the challenge of stealth and are a 100 percent-er that explores everywhere. If you simply want to speed run the game, there is a bit of reward for doing so, e.g. you get something for 1 star, else, you're shorting yourself for the cost of the game.

Lots of bugs with it, though. You'll have cases where it didn't register your hit with a particular weapon, but will with another (same distance and stance). You'll have cases where you set a distraction, but they fix it like 3 feet away, ruining your ability to stealth kill. Auto-saves don't save properly in mission 8 prior to U-boat, bringing you back to before you left, surprisingly. You will crouch, get the "Pick up" prompt, but can't crouched, so you have to stand up to pick up eye-level papers.

All can be fixed in time, though. If you like the Sniper Elite franchise, then play it, just make sure your saves are there for when you need to redo something when you hit an aforementioned bug or inadvertently go out of stealth to pick up a paper (or after saving). It's a solid 3/5.

Just finished my first full game play-through of the single player campaign with a few comments.  I used Normal (medium) to see what the game was like.  I did not do any co-op or multiplayer.

Pros:
1)  Missions and maps are diverse.
2)  Stealth makes you really think and plan out you approach.
3)  Lots of other weapons can be found in the field (though you can't keep them).
4)  Option to heal before you die helps you stay in the game.
5)  Frequent system autosaves.
6)  Graphics were good if your graphics card will allow you to jack it up some.

Cons:
1)  Some bugs, primarily on movement and picking up items.  I realize the game just came out, and I received my first patch today.
2)  The 5th installment is more of a stealth game than a sniper game.  Use of your sniper rifle in most instances is too loud and will attract multiple enemies.  The maps don't allow opportunities for long-range sniping like previous versions.
3)  The terrain in the maps is hilly and rocky with good sniping spots, but you are blocked from leaving the paths to get a better sniping position.  This can also make you more easily located by enemies.
4)  On some maps you are swarmed by enemies if discovered (15 on 1), but other maps have very few enemies.
5)  Not a fan of the weapon options.  Only 3 of each to choose from (sniper, secondary and pistol).  The upgrade format means you have to complete several missions to improve the guns (ammunition clip size, suppressors, etc.).

Overall, it is a Sniper Elite game and it was enjoyable.  Karl is still a stud.  Going to try it again on Hard.  But I don't feel it is the best in the series, and Rebellion had plenty of time between versions to make it better than Sniper Elite 4.

Update:

Went to Hard difficulty.  No change in shooting mechanics or number of enemies, just in damage taken.  Expected more.

If you don't have a satchel charge, TNT won't replace it to open a door, safe or tank/222,  Very limiting.

I was killed several times when the map would stop me from entering trees or getting behind cover, leaving me out in the open.  Very frustrating.

So just recently finished the campaign for Sniper Elite 5, and tried out the multiplayer and invasion mode as well. Here is my updated review.

Pros: 
1. Graphics are good, pretty much carbon copy of Sniper Elite 4.
2. Loved the idea of the various weapon customizations, similar to that of Sniper Elite 3 which was a good game for its time back in 2014. 
3. I appreciate the larger wide open maps in this game.
4. Was quite interesting bringing in first person shooting sights for secondaries and pistols which is quite nice and welcoming.
5. Multiplayer is a bit of fun especially Team Deathmatch.
6. Interesting to bring Squad Match in multiplayer. 

Cons:
1. Well this game has quite a bit of bugs at launch and early stages of the game's release, so no surprise there. Examples like killing an enemy in campaign the body is like weirdly seizuring up on the floor before it disappears, or when I was at the time grinding mastery for the Webley revolver there was a bug where after i fired like half my rounds decided to go for an early reload, once I was fully reloaded again the gun wouldn't fire. 
2. Invasion Mode although it sounds interesting, it's just not my thing tbh, I'd rather just want to play campaign solo without having someone join mid-game on German team and just using that phone and go to my location just to pick me off.
3. Focus mode just freaking sucks, like I'd rather prefer the see through the wall binocular movement of the enemy from Sniper Elite 3 and 4. 
4. Certain maps in the campaign like Spy Academy when you enter the urban area, War Factory, Liberation, and Urban Ruins that 8th mission, since the areas aren't as wide open and really tight and compact, plus factor the audible from the shot of rifle even with suppressors, the AI can still hear and like triangulate where you are thus forcing you to relocate around the map. It doesn't feel like a sniping game as in those situations I would rather prefer using the secondary or pistols to just get the job done and advance forward. 
5. There is this one multiplayer map for the No Cross mode called Urban Ruins, the game mode simply doesn't work on that map and for good reason. It's such a small map, that you could barely get a long distance shot out of it. 
6. Can't even crouch sprint no more like Sniper Elite 4, which made it way easier to sneakily move around the wide open map.
7. No more infinite rocks, rather just 4 bottles that the player is limited to and that they have to go around the map to find for.

Overall not a bad game for the few weeks I enjoyed, just not a fan of some of the newer features in Sniper Elite 5, not happy with one of the maps in multiplayer, and the bugs in the game is all.

My only "major" complaint is 0 day DLC which is not a good look. It's like going to a restaurant and ordering dinner and then getting charged $8 for silverware to eat with. 


Also- this game is free on game pass. Save yourself 50 bucks and play it over a few days with your trial there (15-20 hours to beat the game normally without going all hardcore for achievements).

Will change this thumbs down to a thumbs up when they fix the buggyness of this game.  I am constantly laughing my ass off at the amount of glitches I can find in one sitting that I will be making a video compilation once I beat the game. Like have you tried CLIMBING at all? Because you hold the W key, you get back up the ledge you were trying to hop off of.  Oh yeah, and dead/unconcious bodies load at the same time or before the map does, so every time you load a save, all of those bodies can fall through to the floor below where 30 guys will see it.  That objective you perfectly stealthed over to kill?  If you knock them unconcious, or kill them and not loot what you need before dying, upon reload their BODIES WILL NOT BE THERE, making objectives UNABLE TO BE COMPLETED.

Voice acting is atrocious.  The Nazis blow up your ship and he's just like "damn nazis." With no horror.  I got into the armory, and he's just like, "Sweet, an armory."  Like it was just, "next line reading, please."

You have to make it so that the sniper jager can't hear the host, because your character doesn't seem to shut up.  I knew the exact location of a guy like 3 times because of that, once because he was DOING AN OBJECTIVE.  At least let us have the option to turn it off for ourselves so we can hear footsteps and not him talking about how quick a pistol is or how SMGs are short controlled bursts for the 500th fn time.  Also blaring woke elements, so it's best to just skip cutscenes if seeing a heap of "strong" women and black french resistance fighters really ruins the WWII vibe and instead makes it feel like a parody, which the glitches help create.  Honestly, between the woke sh*t, the voice acting, and the bugs, I was keeled over laughing my ass off by the second level.  Upon having a kill target disappear, my laughter had subsided.

Everything feels janky, like you have to wait for player character animations to complete instead of canceling it with another input/animation.  Like with climbing.  Instead, it likes to remember what you pressed during the first animation, then will perform whatever input had been pressed, regardless if you had stopped pressing it or switched to a different input.

Gameplay wise, the game is fun as hell regardless, albeit with some bugs as regards to when prompts should work, like melee kill prompts, especially for the PvP.

For real, all these other reviews that say the same are just telling me that I need to pick up Sniper Elite 4.

Game Slaps. It is WWII Hitman with Dark Souls invasion mechanics.


Lining up a long ranged silenced snipe on the intended target in authentic difficulty, adjusting for the wind and drop without guide squares? Pretty darn good.

Doing the exact same thing on an actual human player who has invaded your game and is actively hunting you? INCREDIBLE.

I liked Sniper Elite 4, played CO-OP with a friend for 100+ hours! But Sniper Elite 5 sucks in comparison! Prettier graphics and a more detailed kill cam. but that's it! WAY MORE TO DISLIKE THAN TO LIKE! Lousy control, stupid AI, linear levels, you can only hide in tall grass, not in bushes! If you're on a road with bushes on both sides, you're screwed! You may as well be in a hallway! Minimal stats, you can climb a six foot wall, but a one foot high bush stops you cold! I went into an area that LOOKED like it had a ton of places to go or hide, but nope! Invisible walls kept me from doing anything but look around! And many times, a melee kill results in both of you standing there blocking and punching, in a loop, FOREVER, until you draw a gun and shoot him! Sometimes it takes up to 3 BURSTS to the head with a machine gun to put a man down! And I don't know how many times (lots) I've blown my cover because I couldn't hop over a two foot wall because my guy wasn't perfectly lined up with that wall! And the Kill Hitler DLC is just stupid! In the middle of a firefight, I ran around a corner and ran right into Hitler, like he was just another soldier, boom, mission accomplished!
This game feels unfinished, like they rushed it!
All I really wanted, basically  was Sniper Elite 4 with more missions and maybe updated graphics, but instead, they decided to "improve" it! The CO-OP servers are wonky as Hell, and kicks my friend several times before we're able to finally play! All of these issues can be fixed through patches/updates, and hopefully they will! But as it stands right now, I cannot recommend a game that frustrates me as bad as this one does! 
A HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT!

This game is just plain fun. 

Pros:
The stealth aspect is fun.  
The locations and scenery feel authentic and immersive
Sounds are great and easy to locate the source especially when near
Sniping is fun and the overall open world planning is great
The environment feel real and alive as Ai is constantly moving and traveling around
Invasions is a unique (to me) option and adds another layer of value to the gameplay

Cons:
AI are a bit dumb in medium or less difficulty.  You can shoot someone right next to them and they react slow and with no real panic
There are a few bugs namely the Kill Steffen Beckendorf task in the first map that can be gliche
The controls on PC are not that intuitive with secondary actions. 

Summary
Fun with lots of replay value and rewards for playing in kill or no kill possibilities.  I feel far more rewarded then punished.  Never feeling rushed.  Very open world with a real world feel.

Played this one fresh after playing through 4 again. This game overall was an improvement on the series and I hope they can find additional stories to tell in the future. As for the unique differences compared to the previous, here's what I've noticed:
- Virtually no more grenade kills? Idk if they removed them or the chance of hitting one but I still haven't been able to snipe a grenade on somebody, which I did frequently (maybe too so) in 4
- Vehicle combat is very different now. This actually is one of my few real complaints with the game; they went from a system of being able to snipe out gunners and snipers to "blow up the back and then shoot the engine a bunch." At first I was actually wasting resources because I didn't realize once the engine is exposed you just have to shoot it repeatedly until *kaboom*. 
- Much more linear maps overall, compared to Italy you're generally more restricted in this game. More walls you van't vault, more gray areas on your minimap. This coupled with sometimes vague mission instructions left me running back an forth across the several lanes of map to find my objective. (Don't call destroying a radio "neutralizing defenses", it's misleading at best. 
- Much better "quiet" options in the loadouts. While we don't have really more options than previous games, they've made suppressors more accessible and subsonic ammo a great option on all guns. I really have a wide range of configurations to decide on how loud I want to be. For 4 I actually purchased a DLC just to get the suppressed pistol in it (only quiet option base game is the Welrod) while in this game basically all pistols can. 
- Slow-motion controls are kinda neat if you really wanna get cinematic with your shots. I only wish the slow motion focused more on bullet entry/cavitation and less on after the bullet has passed through, but that's nitpicking. 
- I'm too much of a pussy to do Axis invasion, because I hate pvp in most games, but I'll happily join an easy coop. This is something made easy to use and though connections are tenuous at times it can be a fresh change to play a map through with someone. 

Overall recommending to anyone who's enjoyed the previous games, any sniper games, or some Nazi-smashing therapy.

Ultimately, I will have to leave a positive review for SE5 because while it has a LOT of glaring issues at launch, I'm sure most will be fixed over time through things like patches or content packs. There's definitely a lot more polish to be brought to the game. Now with that out of the way:

Bugs:
There seems to be a good chunk full of bugs in my playthrough so far. Karl getting stuck on slight geometry on paths that are clearly meant to be walked through. Being caught on an infinite slide animation because of one stray rock. Enemy bodies completely disappearing when I take them down in tall grass. Animation locks when hugged up on cover. Enemies just not registering the fact that you're right in front of them sometimes. It's a good handful but that being said, I do expect these to be addressed later on and as of right now, none of them feel super game-breaking.

Gameplay:
SE5's big new appeal is having this new hitman-inspired approach to the missions, basically taking SE4's maps and then making them a bit bigger and a lot more open-ended for player agency. It actually works out a lot and makes it feel a lot more fun planning approaches or having a completely different approach to go with the next playthrough. It really does encourage replays of missions and that'll help SE5 in the long run. The new weapon customization is also extremely rewarding and fun to tweak BUT it's completely stunted by two things, a complete lack of weapons to experiment with (there's 15 weapons total, 5 per category) and no shooting range to test out your new build like you could in SE4. Hell, I realized there weren't even any shotguns in the game and that sucked because I LOVED the M30 drilling. Also, they got rid of S-mines and Trip mines and only brought back the Teller mine, we got the Schu mine but that's just a non-lethal mine. Rocks were replaced with bottles (now a limited amount) and added the decoy which is eh. I hope a lot of this is addressed over time but I'm skeptical, though the gameplay is still fun.

Setting:
I think this is SE5's saving grace, the authenticity of WWII is so prevalent here and I absolutely love it. I liked Italy in SE4 but it felt weird for a WWII setting. You are experiencing everything from a German war factory, to the Atlantic Beachhead of Normandy, the Occupied Austrian Alps, to the French Countryside akin to Operation Market Garden, all militarized by the German occupation of the area and it was just so completely atmospheric. The German's have proper loadouts for their time and I found that extremely impressive because it's the entire standard issue equipment for your basic Wehrmacht soldier on the western fronts. Your Jaegars and Vampr Soldiers actually look authentic this time around vs SE4's style of just a basic get uniform. I personally found that to be an extreme nod to historic authenticity. 

Conclusion:
The game is pretty good as is but there's definitely a lot more polish and a lot more content that needs to be added to further reinforces the game's gameplay systems.

[h1][u][b] Campaign only: [/b][/u][/h1]

[b] Summary : [/b]
Great game for all type of gameplays. Sniper fans and close range gamers going to have fun. 

[b]Graphics: [/b]
The game itself looks gorgeous. I have decent hardware so I turned up the settings. No bugs that I noticed during my play.

The leveldesign is great and maps aare designed for all kind of playhstyles. Sniper player are going to have fun but if you dont want to snipe that is also great when you indoors.

The French Setting is nice but on later levels there are areas/maps similiar to Sniper Elite 2/SE4 which was nice as homage.

[b]Mechanics: [/b]
Now the mechanics ! I have read a lot of review before writing this one criticizing the mechanics and that it doens't feel like a sniper game. Which I can understand but all depends HOW you want to approach the map/enemys. 
I personally found it easier to get the feeling to snipe when I took the stealthy approach to the level/map. Meaning once I understood the general way where to go and  where to took the angles from then I had a lot of fun. Roughly in the middle of the campaign there are few sections which are small indoor areas where it is more difficult to go for snipes. 

In my opinion they find a good balance to keep the core of the sniping/stealth in the center of the franchise while adding some new mechanics(zip-line etc.) to the game. A franchise or developer in that sense obviously just doesn't want to to the same game all the time so I can say they really honour the legacy of the previous games while trying to appeal to new player 

[b] Sound: [/b]
Good Sound and Music. 

[b] Story : [/b]

The story itself is great but nothing special.

This is the first game I've left a review on in a  long time. This is the best Sniper Elite they've made by a long shot (in my opinion). The replay-ability is through the roof. The entire campaign is coop and you can jump in and leave as you please while maintaining your progression and unlocks. It has an almost Hitman like mechanic to the missions where there's several start points and ways you can complete your missions in whatever order you please.

The new 'invasion' mechanic is a god send and give the game the edge it needed. At any point an enemy player can invade your campaign (including coop) and has to hunt you down and kill you or you them. It's a blast. Highly recommend this game.
Great, but buggy

So im gonna explain something incase anyone sees this review..

This is not your normal sniper elite and heres why

Maps : Bigger than any of the series.
Weapons: Very limited even with the road map for season pass users
Attachments: they're cool and okay. Nothing specifically special
Bullet-cams: You end up staring at the exit wound than anything. in SE2-4 you could be satisfied by the bone shattering bullet cams but in sniper elite 5, you trade all of that to see the muscles and more detailed looking character models getting shot. Its not satisfying in this game. Infact bullet cams is why i enjoyed the series but this game is probably the most failed of the series..
Objectives: Really prolonged and poorly explained. Some missions give you a broad objective "Neutralize enemy defenses".
Now to the mind of a SE user, you think AAA guns or cannons right? Nope.. You gotta find a crowbar and disable a radio in one of the buildings of a town.

And for the finale of my review....

BUGS: Yes this game has more bugs than Cyberpunk. The amount of times i was shooting at an enemy and a vehicle is also shooting at me just to get a bullet cam or cut scene like an objective for the vehicle to go invisible. Same thing with enemy foot soldiers, they will become invisible, granted they can't harm you though.
Bugs for weapons: You will come across infinite reloading.. Yes it happens.
Bugs for weapons part 2: Me and my buddy were doing challenges to unlock the Karabiner98(Kar98). We did the kill challenge several times just to find out the mission is bugged alone and cannot get the weapon.
Bugged AI movement: Yes more bugs.. so you will come across AI that will break and loop. What i mean by this is some priority targets will get triggered by something like gun shots and will not go back to their coded position for an objective.
Bugged AI triggered status: This one isn't very common but it's more annoying as again me and my friend were doing COOP and we selected a different starting location but upon spawning, the enemies about 100 yards away were already investigating as soon as we spawned. Another time we were doing one of the final missions(8 i think) and had several bugs in combination. We had a triggered AI in investigation mode for about 45 minutes, got combat triggered AI through walls, several invisible enemies and the worst of it all, our objective on the map was in the middle of the room with 2 submarines. when the ACTUAL objective was in a back room which we felt stupid about not checking but they shouldn't say its in a giant room and not actually be there.


So if you are looking for a bug-free game, buy something else im sorry..especially for Sniper-Elite veterans but if you  wanna run and gun and enjoy shooting balls off Nazis then buy the game.

Sidenote bugs:
DLCs: i do not own the Hitler DLC or seasons pass but i have access to the dlc pistol and mission however the mission spawns me in but i fall to my death instantly. For other players who bought the dlc/seasons pass, some don't have access to the dlc pistol.

Within the first few hours, I noticed that the AI is weak/flawed along with sub-par graphics. 

The main issue with AI is that 90% of the time when a grenade is thrown near one or more NPCs, they'll cower where they are and die. They could be standing, walking, running or in a truck. The search pattern the AI uses is questionable as the NPCs will only go so far while when here a noise. Half of the time when I whistle and I'm close, they don't hear me..sometimes they do but they go in a different direction than towards me.

The graphics are fine but I've seen better. My PC has run many AAA games at max settings with no problem with Ray-tracing/DLSS but this game mimics them to a far lesser extend.  The serious weakness with the map is that they don't allow true freedom to roam. There are artificial walls and scrubs that force you down predetermined paths which I hate! 

The story feels good and the UI is easy to understand.

**8/10**

The game is pretty good, I have played through most of the SP, played the invasions, Coop, and MP. All the game modes are good. I particularly like the invasions of the "Axis Sniper", it gives the campaign a whole nother feeling, and this fun nervous pressure to find them while not to be killed by AI or the player sniper(s). The Coop levels are hard, lots of people are not good at it lol. The MP is fun, it can be slow, precise shots which are satisfying, or some faster paced gunfights. The game leaves a satisfying fun with you and I get hooked playing for a couple hours. End game content is somewhat slim, but there is a good grind to it all. Not a grind that is overly much either.

Overall, good game to pickup, either now or on sale!

After completing all objectives in sniper elite 5 (what I consider to be 100% of the game as the collectibles are for the most part completely meaningless) the game seems like it would have been released in 2015, the graphics are mediocre and a lot of it looks unpolished and just downright old, the gameplay is okay enough for sniper elite fans to enjoy, but it looses its charm very quickly, and as a person that likes to do everything, I found that as the game progressed I was doing less and less as I just was not interested anymore.

Usually I make my reviews a lot longer because I have a lot to talk about, but this one there just isn’t much. If you like sniper elite games, you’ll probably enjoy this one at least a bit, the missions are pretty cool, up until the final mission which is too quick and downright stupid. The characters are incredibly boring, they aren’t voiced well, and their facial expressions look like something out of the Mass Affect Andromeda release. The visuals are sub par, explosions particularly look awful. Some environments look great like the first mission, and the spectacle of loading into them is always good, but there is always something wrong in them like textures that feel like their taken from a PS2 game (I should note I’m playing on all ultra with RTX on).

Overall the game just isn’t very good, I wouldn’t pay more than 20 dollars for it, therefore I cannot recommend it at this time, its not that I hate the game, it’s just that it feels unfinished and for $50 is simply was not worth it in my opinion.

I read the reviews before getting this game and I was a little skeptical but I risked it and let me tell you : BEST DECISION EVER! Personally, I bought every Sniper Elite game since the SE V2. I played all of them for like 3-4 hours so I thought this is just one more for the collection and it will sit in my inventory never to be played. This one hits different though. This is going to be a longer review but I wanted to clear things for people who are skeptical like I first was.

How I play the game:
-I play at sharpshooter (medium) difficulty for everything except the sniping which I play at the hardest difficulty Authentic.
-I NEVER engage in combat and play every mission undetected. It takes me approximately 150-200 minutes per mission (usually 90-100% completion for collectibles).
-Sometimes I take 10 minutes just to do recon and learn NPC's paths from a distance before deciding my next move. Also, I ALWAYS hide the bodies or throw them out of sight when possible as to avoid suspicion.
-Sometimes I stay in a corner encircled by NPC's for several minutes just waiting for an opening. I also make use of ALL of the available equipment (70% is bottles/whistle/sticky grenades). 
-If they find a body or I create an explosion and they start investigating I simply plan ahead where to hide and wait it out.
-I really try to stick to the games script and play it as if it was real. Sometimes I even reload a situation if I don't like the outcome or it comes off too unrealistic. 

With that being said, nothing is stopping me to try and snipe everyone or run and gun in with my smg... But I just find it so much more satisfying when your have to work for every kill. Also that way, the x-ray cam when you finally have the opportunity for a long shot never gets old!

LOADOUT:
-Springfield M.1903 with attachments that maximize long range shooting (reduce bullet drop and add power). I also use the silencer that doesn't affect bullet drop (gun is audible from 87m).
-The rest doesn't really matter lol. But I usually use a silenced pistol and silenced smg.

1st negative point I saw in the reviews: You have to play online to unlock certain things:
-The only things that you unlock through multiplayer are a couple of COSMETIC skins for the guns and some character skins that you can play in the main story instead of Karl.
-Every other gun/attachment that actually changes the gameplay is unlocked while playing the story.

2nd negative point I saw in the reviews: You get less xp when you turn off Invasion mechanic for you campaign. This is true, however:
-The skill tree is like 70% useless in my opinion so xp is really not that important as it is only used to unlock perks.
-When you thoroughly complete each mission, you get more than enough xp to max out the  different skill trees without needing to enable Invasions.
-I am currently on mission 6 and need 2-3 more skill points to max out my skill tree.
-To give you an example, I've only lost like 3 health bars total in all of my 6 missions so far.
-Once I complete the campaign I will try out the Invasion mode to have a change of pace and work towards 100% completion but is really not required to fully enjoy the story and all of the weapons, attachments, etc the game has to offer.

3rd negative point I saw in the reviews: There is not enough sniping from huge distances going on. Instead, game is focused on stealth and sneaking around with pistol.
-Personally I get somewhere between 10-15 long shots (100m-450m), 15-20 short range pistol kills (10m-40m) and like 20-30 takedowns. Tip: when you perform takedowns try to pacify them as it gives you considerably more xp at the end of the mission. 
-Here is the difficult thing : You REALLY have to plan your approach. Sometimes I don't take the cool long shot x-ray cam even though it kills me inside because I know it will screw my whole stealth set up.
-The 3rd mission offers a ton of great opportunities for like 300m-500m shots in the beginning before you start approaching the castle. Just use your binoculars to scout around.

4th negative point I saw in the reviews: There are bugs and you often get stuck on like small ledges.
-Yes you do get stuck on some stupid small rubble sometimes but you just go around it or find another path because the game doesn't want you to go through there. Didn't really affect my gameplay at all.
-There are some bugs that I saw like enemies getting stuck in object or walls. Nothing that prevents you to complete the game properly tho.
-WARNING: In mission 4 (war factory) it took me an hour to complete the kill list target with the special objective (using the rat bomb to kill him). This was the only really annoying bug so far.

I really hope this helps you have a better idea of what to expect from this game! I hope you get to enjoy it as much as I do! :)

Sniper Elite is a game franchise that manages to refine itself on every iteration.

2 was linear, but had some nice setpieces, gore, and a focus on sniping, which let it stand out from other WW2 shooters.
3 added bigger maps with different routes between points of interest.
4 had open map design, lots of interesting architecture, and was fun co-op.
5 seems to be a culmination of the previous game's improvements.

Maps are open ended and dense with enemies and terrain. The freedom to move around also means that close combat and melee takedowns are viable and useful. The gore is pleasant as always. There is meaningful gun customization that changes rifles, smgs, and pistols functionally and aesthetically. Coop is back, though I can't speak on its systems without having played it. The new invasions are extremely fun.

Allowing invasions in the campaign game gives extra XP. I played the base campaign solo, and by the last level I had plenty of XP to upgrade all the skills. The game seems balanced around solo XP gain. XP gained by allowing invasions is extra. Unfortunately, many people seem to allow invasions to allow the additional XP gain, but disconnect the moment someone invades. When attempting to invade, maybe 1/2 or 2/3 of players d/c immediately or soon after. Of those who remained, there was a lot of fun to be had. The mechanics support an enjoyable invasion system. Tracking enemy players by gunshots, tagging ally AI to better predict player movement, seeing what objectives are already destroyed on spawn, planting bombs and traps, makes for an exciting and tense game of cat and mouse.

Overall, pretty fun game to wander around and murder in.
Had a blast playing this and it has a good coop experience too. Thoroughly enjoyed it, definitely worth it!

*This is not a review of game play, but solely based on un-optimized software that the developers should've taken care of pre-launch.  Their first patch 2 weeks later still hasn't addressed any of these issues and it's unacceptable
*
The game is unplayable for me.  Even after attempting the *many* fixes posted all over the internet, this is more poorly optimized than an Alpha state game.  I've seen others have things go off without a hitch on youtube, but my specs exceed the recommended and I still couldn't get it to work.  75% of the time the game would fail to launch directly from the launcher.  The remaining times, my single player matches wouldn't start, they'd get stuck at 98% load with no way to escape the game than closing it, resulting in another 'failed to start (2)' loop of madness. 

Graphics issues were also prevalent, but were fixed by switching to Vulcan in the launcher settings. 

I am disappointed, I've been playing this Franchise since SE3 - and am annoyed this is the way they released this game.  I have a feeling the people not having issues are all very privileged to have next-gen PCs, while those of us who can't afford and/or couldn't get access to are left un-optimized and ignored by the developers.

I didn't like it. I have played almost 1200 hours on SE4 and still love the game. SE3 was just about as good and just as fun to play. This game didn't feel like Sniper Elite, other than the one map in the castle. I waited anxiously for the release of this game. I bought it immediately when they opened it for pre-sale and waited the months for it's release since it is definitely my favorite series. I am disappointed. 

Let's first start with the characters: This is WWII in the 1940's. There was a French Resistance and by all means had men and women actively participating in the effort. After all, their country was overrun. Main character of the resistance here was a black woman with a Scottish accent who is obviously not from France. Ah, nothing against that but it is certainly out of place here in the 1940's in WWII. It wasn't believable.  In SE4, it was an Italian woman who's father was leading the resistance in Italy and took over his duties when he went missing - believable and accepted. What were they thinking here? Where are the French men? Hiding in bunkers while the women did the work? Through the entire game did I even hear a French man speak with a French accent? I really have to think back on that. I would like authentic, please. Also, they called him the "Shadow" yeah, I heard them call him the "Desert Ghost" in one cut scene but the Shadow diminishes the character to be someone else.

Gameplay: It didn't feel like Sniper Elite. It's not a bad game but it doesn't want me to go back and play another 1200 hours. Where are the designers and writers of SE3 and SE4? It is a little bit of an "open map" but it is more tunneling type of gameplay than I like for this series. In SE4 you can start the map and go in any direction and complete the maps in so many different ways, stealth, loud, or both. SE5 used too many of the same old tricks in SE4, such as "turn the valve, create pressure and blow it all up". A little more originality would have been nice. It felt like rinse and repeat. 

Weapons: Yeah, so many have already commented on how they could have done it better that I don't need to reiterate. 

Skills: I didn't see much benefit from the skills I obtained. More health good - throwing a grenade back that was thrown at me? I never once had the opportunity. A lot of them were useless. 

Rank: 40 is the limit? I reached that before the end of the game. 

Menus: They were a lot more difficult to maneuver through and things lit up for upgrade when no upgrade was available. I'm still confused on some of the selections. Is there a gun based achievement in this game other than attachments? 

Overall: I'm disappointed. I had warned Rebellion on their Discord to not ruin Sniper Elite like they ruined Wolfenstein. If you're going to have a WWII game, in which I love, keep it authentic and if you're your going to turn it into  a wreck like most of the WWII games did, I'm done with Sniper Elite. I'll go back and play SE3 and SE4 for another 2400 hours.

I have honestly been waiting for years for this game. I played through (and re-played through) SE3 and SE4 so much, they were my go-to games when nothing else held my interest. They will STILL be my go-to games over this one. 

What SE5 got right: 
- Moddable/swappable parts for guns
- updated held-breath mechanic
- Removing the "always know where an enemy is" bits. I feel the new wide-circle system makes the engagements far more entertaining and challenging
- Crowbar, Bolt-Cutters, Satchel Charges needing to be found in order to be used. This opens the player up to a multitude of different playthrough options per engagement

What SE5 got wrong:
- Simple mechanics. There are SO many ledges under 3ft in this game that cannot be vaulted/mantled where in SE3 or SE4 you could pretty much climb almost everything, OR the game map was built in a way where the only ledges you encounter WERE climbable. 
- Sniper Posts, or lack-there-of. Finding a good spot to snipe from, with or without noise blocking, was an awesome thing in all SE games until now. It feels more like they focused on the objectives rather than the actual gameplay when the gameplay is what made these games fun
- Map Size/Intricacy? Maybe its just me but I truly feel that these maps are smaller than ones in previous games and don't allow for much fun in setting up a sniping position, grouping enemies together, etc. I felt like I was just constantly moving from one objective to the next which really makes this feel more like a combat game than a sniper game. I ended up using my pistol more than any other weapon, nearly twice as much as my actual sniper rifle.... in a sniper game... because of the constant movement. 
- Time. In SE4 I had the option to race through everything, guns out going loud and insane and finishing in under 20 min. OR I could take my time, scope everything out, snipe everything that crossed my path and move on quietly, utilizing the entire environment, taking an hour or so to get through each level. In SE5 it feels like I'm rushed to get through everything. 
- Silly challenges for weapon parts or weapons. need I say more? Just make them available once you reach a certain gun table or find them within the level.

Possible solutions for SE6 (if it happens):
- Start with simple game mechanics. Copy a game like Assassin's Creed where you can climb all walls, you can jump off things onto soft areas, you can hide, you can sneak around. Take those game mechanics and slap the better features of this game on top of it
- More selection in gun modding. I loved what you brought to SE5, however if I look at other games with similar capability, ones like Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Wildlands takes the cake when it comes to modding your guns. The differences in available scopes or magazines made a huge difference to how you would play any given situation. Also add to that the fact that you needed to find them. I did enjoy a good portion of that with the gun tables in SE5 but it still felt lacking.
- DLC Weapon options. I won't deny, once I've played the game through with the base available options, I like to splurge and buy the super silent weapons or the super loud weapons and see what trouble I can get into with those. That makes the game fun. There simply aren't any of those with this game.


Final words: Will I play this again? maybe. At this point its not likely but who knows. Its a possibility. Would I recommend it to others? if it comes out discounted or free, go for it. Its an ok game, but not one I would spend full price on again.

If you have either not played a Sniper Elite game before, or have done and enjoy it, buy this. If you have and don't, don't buy this. Simple really. It is very much just another Sniper Elite game, but it is one that does what the series does better than any of the previous games. Better graphics, better progression/customisation systems, better game modes, better maps, better XRay, better everything really... but it's the same game at the end of the day, just better in every way. Rebellion haven't tried to reinvent the wheel here, but why try? The series does what it does extremely well, especially considering the relatively small size of the dev team, and they have continued to do that with this game in a day and age where so many games are trying to be everything at once and failing instead of doing one thing to the highest standard they can. Sniper Elite continues to be the best sniping game available by a large margin, and considering it's name, you can't ask for much more.

Sniper Elite 5 is a polished, well-done game. The only bugs I notice are getting caught on objects while prone under large objects, and a few bugs that makes corpses caught in the floor. Pretty good considering it hasn't even been two weeks since SE5's release. I enjoy the difference in graphics, and the detail in kill cam in comparison to Sniper Elite 4. It's still incredibly satisfying to put a bullet through the skull of a Nazi across a large gap. It's safe to say, I'm satisfied with Sniper Elite 5.

Pros
- Good game play and story.
- Graphics looked much better than SE4.
- AI is better and enemy is very aggressive. 
Cons
- The campaign was a bit short.
- I was hoping for a more "Open World" approach.
- Player movement around objects on the maps is limited.

Overall, a very fun game to play!  :)
FINALLY. A game that shows Swastikas on every corner and lets you play as a Nazi. Nuff said.

As the fifth big installment of the Sniper Elite Series, this game does not contain many surprises. As every Sniper Elite has a bit of an identity crisis, this one is no different. The gameplay of Sniper Elite 5 is probably the most hybrid third person shooter gameplay of the whole series. The sniper rifle is still a trusted tool (also the only weapon with optional aim assist) but submachine gun and pistol work almost equally well - and I like that. I like variety in my shooter gameplay and this game gives me enough choices to fill that want. 

The levels of the campaign are beautifully crafted and offer very different combat arenas/sandboxes/sneaking challenges. I've read the critique that many maps don't offer that long shooting distances as in previous installments and while that is certainly true, I don't think it takes away much. You're still able to fight at ranges of 100-200 meters very often and it isnt like you would hit much beyond that without the aim assist. The story is nothing to write home about but that is also not the point of the game. It is written well enough to justify the mission sandboxes you're getting dropped into and for me that is very much sufficient. 

Also, the invasion mode: Before buying the game, I apparently dodged all the announcements about this gamemode and was pleasantly surprised upon discovering it. In this gamemode, you can join the campaign games of other players. You play as an enemy sniper and have to stop the other player. A simple concept that makes each mission way more thrilling for me. I absolutely love getting invaded in a mission and suddenly having to adapt to the new circumstances, because NOW I am facing not only the AI but also a human player that can do almost everything I can do - and can also kill me in one shot. It is really something else and even if you get killed by an invader, you don't really lose progress. You can still save. 

And you can turn it off. You can turn the invasion mode completely off and be done with it. I don't get the negative reviews where the major critique is this gamemode. Just turn it off. You can also kick an invading player from your game session since you are the host (yes, really. I also don't get why you can do this).

Sniper Elite 5 plays really well on my PC.  The scenery is beautiful and the game feels more fluid.  I prefer single-player campaign and have no opinion on the invasion or the multiplayer mode.  Having played this for 4+ hours at the first review time and 24+ hours for the second review, I have overall enjoyed the game's smoothness, graphics, and I like the improvements over the previous installments.  The game feels even more modern, but still retains the original Sniper Elite characteristics, such as x-ray cameras, bullet ballistics, difficulty levels, and traditional stealth or loud options with multiple ways to progress through each mission, which makes this an all too familiar game and genre.  I have not encountered any crashes, frame rate issues, or errors.

Pros:
- Beautiful scenery and graphics
- Massive levels with multiple approach and tactics
- Different ammo types
- Rifle iron sights and first person view for all weapons
- X-ray camera for all weapons

Cons:
- No crouch-and-run mode (this was a great ability in SE 4)
- No Shooting Range to practice with weapons and earn medals
- Too many invisible walls and inaccessible terrain
- No customization for Karl (no different outfits, jackets, etc., which was great in SE 4)
- No AP or tripwire mines
- Limited distraction objects (SE 4 had unlimited rocks, while SE 5 has limited bottles)

Neutral:
- Silenced weapons are not truly silent, but this keeps the game interesting.
- There is not enough weapons to choose from, and weapon modifications do not make up for this.  SE 4 had more rifles, pistols, and SMG's to select from.

Thank you, Rebellion, for delivering such a great game, but some improvements are definitely worth including in SE 5, especially the crouch-and-run option for stealthy approach.  Perhaps, these will arrive in the future updates or DLCs.

Current PC Specs:
Intel Core i5-9600K, 5.2 GHz
EVGA RTX 2060 Super XC Ultra, 8 GB
Corsair Vengeance 32 GB RAM, 3200 MHz
Samsung 970 EVO NVMe M.2 SSD, 1 TB
If you liked SE 1 thru 4 you will love 5.

- Limited weapons so far and the customization is very underwhelming

It is ok if it was called Pistol Elite 5! And I mean just ok and not worth the $$
Where were the nests? The setups for long shots? They set the maps up to push you into close quarters combat. You didn't need a rifle just your pistol!
 
1st, Mission 10 should not be a DLC that you have to pay $7 for! It should be included!

2nd, The game forces you to stay on set path. Way too many invisible walls in the middle of the map. Example, there are bushes next to a walkway but you can't get to them to hide if you have to because you will run into an invisible wall at the edge of the path. I also found rock ledges I could not get to that were close to a path because of invisible walls. There were fields, and wooded areas I could not walk through because of invisible walls. There were also times when I would try to run for cover then get trap in a area of no cover by invisible walls in the middle of the map. I the age of open world games there should be NO invisible walls in the middle of the map. I understand that the map has boundaries but not in the middle of a field or wooded area. Don't funnel the player into combat in a Sniper game!

3rd, Hand to hand combat sucks. You get stuck in a loop of pushing "E"  to stagger the NPC with no real means of fighting other then shooting them. Specking of NPC the AI sucks! Not only are they aimbotts (i.e. shooting through trees and hills) but their dumb.

4th, Mission 9,,,, WTF What happen did they run out of money and stopped paying the devs?? There is so much that could have been done with that mission but what did we get??? "That's a long shot",,,,, "Watch this"!!! Please what a terrible way to end the game!. Sniper Elite 3&4 was much better then this. 

There were other problems I ran into but these 4 were the ones that really got to me. I started mission 10 but had to quit. The invisible walls on that map are just over the top. They completely kill the immersion. I mean I'm at a stone wall and I want to vault over the wall at point "A" but I can't. The game won't let me! I have to vault over a few meters away where I will be seen pushing me into combat on the games terms not my terms! As a sniper you engage on your terms not the other way around.  I really want to like this game but I will have to say it will be uninstalled and I'll go back to 3&4 when I need a SE fix!

All in All this game provides a sublime sniping experience that is as good if not better than the prequel games but I do have a few notes that would help in deciding whether or not to purchase this game.

Pros
- Lots of customization
- Decent amount of replay-ability 
- Graphics & Effects are top-notch
Cons
- *Massive lag spikes / Freezes
- Maps feel a bit restrictive
- P2P Connection on multiplayer

* Game tends to fully freeze for up to 2 minutes when you discover a new objective, a cutscene starts or someone joins your game but i'm not entirely sure if that's all just me because I haven't found a fix for it yet

I have not tried this series since Sniper Elite V2, and man I was really impressed with the development and innovation the developers at Rebellion brought fourth in this Fifth installment of Sniper Elite. Set in France, this game has alot to look forward to if you are into co operative gameplay and sneaking around or just going batshit rambo against the evil nazi empire.  There are alot of customization, easter eggs, and fun collectibles that make replay value higher then most of these types of titles. The price on the other hand is high as expected, its not going anywhere so I'd wait for a sale and get it with a few buddies to enjoy the invasions and co-op atmospheric elements. 8/10.

Overall I like this game and I love all SE franchise. However, I seem to be quite a little disappointed because Rebellion removed quite a lot in SE 5 such as crouch-running, dynamics and varieties in bullet cams, the game has less weapons. So I hope that Rebellion will put into considerations to put restore all those they've removed in SE 5 from SE 4 and SE 3. I'm also quite a bit disappointed as there's almost no x-ray on engine cars and almost no environmental kill bullet. However the multiplayer is dope and cool. Very fun to play.

Yes - with caveats - read on.
First off let me provide context. I'm most certain an 'older' gamer, and a casual gamer. I have played and completed all the Snipe Elite series, as well as played many other sniper style games.
Did I enjoy this? Yes, Was it worth the money; not sure.
I know many are waxing lyrical about how good this is, but I'll be honest ... I was 'meh'.
On my older rig I'm probably not running at full detail, so can't comment on exactly how good the graphics can be; for me I'm not seeing a massive improvement over SE4.
In terms of game play, there are a few new elements, but overall it is very much more of the same with some tweaks. I didn't feel the game play was markedly different to SE4, to be honest.
I still felt frustrated that my supposedly 'elite' sniper who has years of experience, is still unable to clamber over rocks, move through bushes or step over small walls. In fact, in one map I 'swapped cover' from one side of an open gateway to the other side and promptly got stuck behind a knee-high hedge garden and had to re-load a save. A well known issue for snipers the world over, I'm sure :-|
The enemy AI also doesn't appear to be that much better than before either. I can shoot a guy in the head, right beside his mate, and there might be a bit of 'searching' but not the panic and calling all troops into a search that, I'm sure might happen in real life. Be 'concerned' for a couple of minutes and then "ah well, no bother, back to guard duty, nothing to see here after all". Really?
I'd also like to see more missions of having to sneak in and make a kill and extract without any other conflict. One shot, one kill.
Would I buy this game if I knew all the above in advance? Well, probably, because I like tactical stealth sniper style of games. But I'm not altogether convinced it is worth the asking price. If you don't have it already and are curious and not a hard-out fan, then I'd probably wait for a sale. If you are a hrd-out fan, well, then you likely have it already! :)

Fitting in the Sniper Elite (SE) line, SE5 differs very little from SE4 with many of the game mechanics remaining the same, with some minor GUI updates. The campaign is classic SE, the level and environment design being top-notch, especially the St. Nazaire level. The AI was extremely good, more than once finding myself backtracking to get out of trouble but with no trip-wire explosives available to lay (the Schü-mine, though period, wasn't as effective). Weapon customization was excellent, as was the skill progression tree. I don't feel the story line was as engaging as those in SE3 and SE4, at least for myself, but overall, a well executed game and worthy of the time to play.

This is based on my experiences playing sniper elite 5 (not gonna compare with previous) game because I don't remember em, anyway this is my Pros and Cons of this game. also it lag sometimes (I'm using GTX 1650, 16GB RAM, SSD).

Cons:

3. Sudden lag, usually I get 80 fps, but for no reason it goes down to 30

I played Sniper Elite 5 through mostly in co-op with my brother on authentic difficulty.

In addition, I did replay individual missions by myself on authentic to collect any missing medals (we collected collectables during co-op play) while waiting for next co-op session to advance.

I have not played axis invasion, multiplayer or survival... only campaign.

All in all, for what I played, I'd recommend the game and I think it's worth 50 euros.

I did pay the price for the deluxe edition (~80 euros) for it, and even then I'm not disappointed... just dreading to see what kind of dlc I'll be getting for that extra support as dlc nowadays can easily be pretty lackluster.

But that was a risk I was willing to take.

Anyway, here's some pros/cons:
+ good launch experience
+ overall decent technical quality
+ very much like previous installments, which is good
++ map design is impressive
+ fun/enjoyable
+ co-op went overall well
+ sniper rifles are varied and I found some I liked (I prefer long distance)
+ weapon tuning is kinda nice
+ weapon tuning is ok to do only once to suit your playstyle, and not necessary to vary all the time
+ the wolf mountain extra mission was nice
+ overall mood and feel is generally nice

- bugs with co-op that sometimes required loading autosave from earlier parts
- bugs with reloading that required me to get other ammo type to get the weapon usable
- smaller random bugs
- some collectables practically required using online guides to find (may be easier to find on easier difficulties?)
- my fave sniper rifle Mosin Nagant isn't in the game
- the plot and cutscenes are as cringy as one might expect (plot is secondary to me though)
- cannot do axis invasion with selected steam friends, just via random matchmaking

~ sniping of vehicles isn't as fun/cool as it was in Sniper Elite 4 (sniping tank drivers through small windows); on the other hand, vehicles aren't too easily bypassed anymore so it's kinda ok that way too
~ i haven't noticed significant impact from Denuvo, though right after launch my virus protection quarantined the executable
~ i don't know how multiplayer with randoms goes
~ i don't care about comparing real life stuff with this game; one should never mix up fact and fiction... doing that is to me a warning sign of mental health issues

Still, despite its short-comings, I'd say this game is good enough for its 50 euro price tag.

I had fun and played it for over 60 hours, which is pretty good for a recent game release.

It's not perfect for sure, but I believe it's worth the price if you're in the mood for a sniping game.

As such, I'd say this game can be recommended to other players.

After 20+ hours:

With the exception of some lagging grenade throwing, melee, and killcam jankiness, the game feels really slick. The gunplay is incredibly tight. It rewards practice and makes you feel like John Wick vs. the nazis. There is a lack of equipment at the moment, but missions and weapons will clearly be added.

Overall, the game is good and will only get better. I will now list my gripes, which define the game for me at the current time.

Removal of trip mines, crouch-running, stuff like that: You suck, Rebellion.

When it comes to difficulty: Authentic mode is kind of a joke. Missions in SE4 are very tough on authentic+ mode. It takes real planning and nerves of steel to beat them. For a combination of many reasons which are tough to fully articulate, anything below authentic in SE5 is a cakewalk. I would say that overall this is a negative.

Level design: My biggest gripe with this iteration. Invisible walls are my least favorite thing about this game. The stupid 3-foot-tall objects and fences that should be easily vaulted and invisible walls are extremely immersion-breaking. Being constantly funneled through chokepoints is awful. The levels appear open but feel much more linear than SE4. It is a shame, because they are absolutely gorgeous. 

The Target: Fuhrer mission feels like a jumbled mess with only a few approaches compared to the gargantuan sub base of SE4. Gives us missions like Deathstorm: Infiltration or the SE4 Target: Fuhrer, please. Whoever console-ized the level design needs to be fired and blacklisted from working in game design ever again. You are part of the problem with modern games.

Multiplayer: No hardcore mode. I don't want to play with magic scope glint and hud markers and stuff like that. I know we can do custom lobbies, but it would be real nice if there was a decent preset for more serious players. And, you released with only 4 maps? - come on now! 

Weapon customization: wow, you can install a little leather decoration to your rifle that will make your aim worse for some weird reason! The customization system needs work, but there is greatness here somewhere.

Otherwise, I pretty much love the game. Fix, please.

I'll recommend this, although it has some wonkiness.  Many times I accidentally picked up the alternate temp weapons when I didn't want them - I was just trying to loot the dead soldiers.  Sometimes getting in the right position to pick up items is also annoying.

Otherwise, the game is perfectly serviceable.  I'll recommend it, but frankly I think Sniper Elite 4 felt tighter and more composed.  The maps in Sniper Elite 5 are larger, and the missions feel a bit slower and longer.  So it all depends on how you like your missions.  I found myself wanting to replay several missions in Sniper Elite 4.  I don't have any strong desire to replay missions in Sniper Elite 5.  I also noticed that Sniper Elite 4 has a number of threatening vehicle and emplacement challenges, and Sniper Elite 5 has almost none.

Beware of bugs in Mission 4 that prevent its completion.  You can always restart it and try different approaches.  Hopefully it gets patched soon.

This is just a direct downgrade from SE4. I've clocked a lot of hours in 4 cause the game felt AMAZING, every movement had consequence and weight to it but here everything just feels inconsequential especially getting spotted. There is NO feedback for being spotted, just a white line going red with no audio cue or anything.

Credit where credit is due the game looks good, weapon customization is neat, and the maps are "Expansive" more on that in a second.

The maps, they are supposedly larger... they don't feel like it. You're given a objective and you have to discover side objectives only it feels bland and just uninteresting, a good comparison is the first mission from SE4. In SE5 you're set loose on a beach with no good vantage points or interesting opportunities for kills, in SE4 on the first mission you get TONS of interesting kills and opportunities including dropping a ammo crate on someones head, you get vantage points all over the place and generators are abundant with those positions. In this game however... yea on mission 1 you're just sorta thrown in without consiquence, there is just nothing interesting about the first mission and its side objectives.

Side objectives, in SE4 they felt like meaningful alternative objectives cause they were openly presented to you with a location. If you got lost in either a main objective or a side one you'd either only have a small area to search or it would be pointed out for you, in SE5 not even damn close. The objectives on mission 1 felt directionless like the radio bunker, to sabotage a generator you need a crowbar which I spent 10 damn minutes looking for. I eventually found it and had to hit a fuse box, there was a objective marker over where I was and one adjacent which just made me PROFOUNDLY confused.

Enemy AI and stealth, SE4 had some of the best stealth mechanics I think any game has ever had. It was unforgiving but fun and concise, AI was not the best by any stretch but it was serviceable especially with how the stealth felt. Shooting felt weighty and purposeful, stealth was slow but tense, and enemies felt aware of their surroundings with good placement in their enviroment. In SE5 you just have random ass patrols wandering around seemingly not knowing what they're doing, stealth is just too fast and just has no weight to it. In SE4 you had audio and music cues for when you were being spotted, searched for, and in combat with each being distinct and telling you exactly what was going on. In SE5 you get generic sniper music constantly that just feels out of place, while also getting no audio cues for stealth.

Weapon customization, this is just a straight upgrade from SE4. Each upgrade is at least slightly grounded in reality and in history itself, it feels rewarding and each upgrade has a tangible effect that feels distinct. Shooting feels the best it ever has, it feels weighty and guttural every time you use a gun without a suppressor, the addition of iron sights as well is just a godsend.

The Invasion mechanic. Okay look I get that its a cool feature but here's my problem, when you have it during the first mission of the game while someone is still trying to learn the game? Yea that's frustrating.

The controls. It just feels scuffed and just awkward, it feels like a call of duty game rather than SE4. Stealth should be slow, methodical, you are a sniper after all and your main tools are... ya know a SNIPER AND STEALTH. In SE5 it just feels limp, it feels like its trying to be a intense multiplayer shooter with stealth mechanics and it just DOES NOT WORK.

In summary, go play SE4 its a far better game despite its flaws.

This is a review after having played the first five missions.

To start with, Sniper Elite 5 is a superior game that continues it´s legacy it gained after the first title. The story is catching and the cutscenes are well made. To be honest, even better than Sniper Elite 4´s. The armory is detailed and highly customizable and you can now add suppressors for example, which was not a thing in SE4. This applies to all guns (except revolvers, WELROD, Shotguns)!

So much for the good, but every leaf has it´s brown side.

Moving on, there are plenty of bugs. In the fifth mission when having to kill the target, there is a ramp where you fall out of the map into the blue-void. If that happens twice, you simply die without ragdolling. There are also plenty of little things like a small delay when entering an activity i.e. the phone in Invasion-Mode.

Nevertheless the fact that this game has just been published polishes these small mistakes and I hope that the above named bugs are fixed in the near future. 

To end my review I would give this game a 7/10, because of it´s superior story and gameplay, but still having some annoying bugs.

Disclaimer: I might change my review in the future as I only have 9 hours of playtime and completed the fifth mission.

Let's talk about the problems with Sniper Elite 5. Each new version of Sniper Elite has fine tuned the mechanics of the game for the better... until now. I don't know how other people play SE but I play stealthy sniper mode. I take my time. I infiltrate, clear an area with the silenced pistol, set up a sniper nest with something to cover the sound of the shots and terrorize the enemy by picking them off one by one. If I'm detected I either exfiltrate and come at them from another direction or go to ground and wait until the heat dies down, you know, sniper style. This game feels as if it's designed to be more One Man Army CoD like.

Game Play:
I don't know why they felt they had to redesign the AI, but now the enemies are dumber yet more aggressive. They stand around talking to themselves for no reason. They charge and swarm. It becomes a human wave FPS instead of a sniper game. The enemies in SE4 seemed to function pretty logically tactically. Groups had areas they defended, if shooting occured in another area they didn't charge across the map, they stayed in their areas. If they recieved fire they hunkered down tried to identify the direction of the threat then tried to flank it returning fire, moving from cover to cover. These enemies are suicidally brave and mindless. In the second to the last mission in the ruins I was shooting from the end of a street. I miss timed a shoot so it was heard and practically every guy on the map aggro-ed on me. They began pouring down this street. I was shooting so fast I didn't even bother aiming any more. There were 36 guys laying in heaps in front of me at the end of it, THIRTY SIX. I know, I counted them as best I could. There were no tactics involved in that. They just kept running straight at me, ignoring cover, like they were programmed to run straight up to me and shoot me at point blank range with their rifles. 
They don't talk much either. Although like I said they do have conversations with themselves for some reason. In SE4 if they find a dead man they would make comments 'A man's dead!' 'Who is it?' 'Oh my god!' You know, human-like reactions. Yeah, that's gone. 

Let's talk about stuff that's gone.

- Did you like how the aiming reticule would shrink down the longer you held your breath making your aim more precise? That's gone.
- Did you like how you could shoot a grenade on a guys belt and blow him up? That's gone.
- Did you like crouch running from cover to cover to avoid detection? That's gone.
- Did you like throwing rocks to lure guys? That's gone.
- Did you like trying to make that really long shot? Don't expect many opportunities. These maps are mostly cluttered and confined.
- Did you like how you could detect unseen enemies by them clearing their throat, or coughing, or humming to themselves? Well that seems to be gone too.

Story:
The story is pretty dull and feels completely tacked on to try to create a narrative. Some maps have no beginning cut scene just a basic text opening. Some maps feel added on, like they had a map that didn't fit the story but had them and wanted to use them anyway. The D-Day map for one. Black SOE operatives in WWII France? Riiigghhttt. If you want to throw black folks a bone to get them involved why didn't you just have the option to make the sniper black? It's still unlikely but much less unlikely than black spys in 1940s France going unnoticed by the heavily racist Nazis. JS

Graphics:
The textures look much improved, I think they used some filters in SE4 that seem to be missing here. There, done.

Music:
Why does there seem to be generic RPG music in my Sniper Elite game? I finally turned it down to 25% to make it bearable.

Multiplayer:
Not interested, didn't p[ay.


Overall:
This is a somewhat disappointing game that honestly feels like it was designed to appeal to the console market. I'm going to go out on a limb and say that this is probably the last Sniper Elite game that's going to get made, and it feels like it. It feels like a game only made to take advantage of the player base and name recognition. 

Is Sniper Elite 4 worth $59.99? Yes, I'd say it still is, Still.
Is Sniper Elite 5 worth $49,99?  No, I don't think it is. It's not the game I wanted or hoped for. Wait for a sale and prepare yourself to be disappointed.

Still some bugs to be fixed but nothing game breaking. Little weird that this is the only SE game with no M91/30 base game maybe in future DLC? Note schu mine + TNT or environmental explosive  = improvised mine

Game is "ok" but just that: after 3-4 maps into the game the mechanics of the game are easy to understand - how and when enemies spot you, how you can hide in (literally) plain sight and how to "invisibly" kill them either at long range or close up. After that the game becomes just a repeat of itself - I can even see people doing speedruns of it for fun because of how extremely constricted the  mechanics are. Some examples: "tall grass" can make you insible to the eye of God himself, any other vegetation unless the very simplistic enemy "field of view" is blocked - not at all. Darkness and or/light (except spotlights) make no difference at all. Or if you blow someone's head off outside of audible weapons range, and another NPC has his back turned and is a few steps away - your kill is "invisible" even though his buddy's head just exploded like literally 2 steps away. Or conversely if someone has definitely spotted you and "combat" mode appears - lierally anyone can see you anywhere. You can engage in a rambo-style spree, then just hoof it a couple of hundred meters and wait for some time - and all NPCs will reset and just stroll back to initial positions like nothing ever happened. Once all that is understood the game can be played to any absurd extent - like cleaning out an entire huge map of any and all enemy NPCs and getting out without being hit even once,
Besides the extremely simple game mechanics there are the obvious flaws: tanks, and not just some tanks but King Tigers literally roll around wherever they want - on patrols. Like take big circles and or patrol routes - like some basic NPC persons. Literally 70 tons of steel burning fuel away like crazy doing the most basic patrol, stuff that would level half the area IRL... anyway. Oh yes, and the "sound mask" basicly means anything loud magically hides your shots... any shots. Except that of course a big german V12 of a tank with no mufflers what so ever makes no such masking sound, while a cement mixer will. 
What else... the maps are gigantic and are clearly made for multiplayer gameplay. Very beautifully done though, but obviously while the artists went all-out to make very detailed gigantic maps people who coded the game just got done with making Doom 1-style AI and game play. If in some previous SE games anemy snipers had xray vision here they have a cane and a guide dog, snipers are probably 1/100th the problem to kill compared to say a group of soldiers in a tight space. Same goes for the most god-awful facial animations and ragdoll lip movements. Weapons are completely over the top with the usual customizaton nonsense like zoom scopes, bullet drop and wind is extremely overdone for the fun of it.

Sniper Elite 5 has very good amount of content. Singleplayer campaign has 9 missions. +1 one DLC if you pre-ordered the game or bought the DLC separately. Story line is good, but nothing out of the ordinary. Replaying the missions in different ways was always a strong point for this franchise. Sniper Elite 5 is no different. 

Same as Sniper Elite 4, killing Hitler with a testicle shot is worth it alone. Survival mode is fun and challenging, while Invasion mode is a nice and fresh game mode that is as fun as you can make it yourself. Anyone can hop into invasion mode and rush down the opposing player with an SMG. Try out snipe the other player or better yet, sneak up melee your opponent? That's fun. 

Multiplayer modes like TDM and Free for all are Okay-ish... nothing special. Fun for a while, only scope in your rifle after you have spotted the glare from another players rifle across the map is the only way to stay alive. Your binoculars are gonna become your best friend.  The modes become very repetitive and not for me personally very enjoyable. 

Overall great product, will be interesting to see how they expand on the invasion mode and hopefully add on a few more missions for single player.

Being German myself, I'd like to comment on the design of the Germans in the game.

The first thing is the language and voice acting. It's great that German soldiers speak native German, but the actual acting is horrible. Everyone sounds vaguely comical, as if not taking the situation he's in seriously. I have not heard any voice that I could reasonably believe to belong to a real soldier in a serious scenario. There are also literal translations from English expressions in their lines, that aren't proper German, as well as smaller details, like grammar errors in Propaganda Posters.
I know the game had expert advisors on weapons and such, why couldn't they have also had just one or two German people to check for this kind of thing? They would have spotted all of it immediately.

The level design goes for oversimplified Pseudo-German set pieces, like a large sign that just says "Achtung!" in the middle of a camp. I get that this is useful for being recognizable by Non-Germans, but that sign makes no sense. "Achtung!" for what? There needs to be some explanation on what that sign is a warning against. Especially since German is famous for being very detailed and specific.

I don't want to make this too long, so I'll say this in conclusion. In order for me to enjoy fighting enemies in a game, I have to be able to take them seriously and have respect for them. That is what is lacking here. Even though my complaints may be less problematic for Non-Germans, I'm certain that a more authentic depiction of them would make for a much better game for everyone.

So please, pay more attention ("Achtung!") to detail when designing villains, antagonists and enemies.

I am english and studdied german as a hobby, grew up in the golden age of ww2 shooters. Quite a delightful game to set me back and possibly the last of the games I will be buying for my collection with that in mind. Family history of WW2 duty and cold war service started me off in gaming as a tool of understanding the times as they might have seen them.

Reading reviews I was on the fence if i was even worth dropping a few coins on it at release, but I can safely say this one will be re-visited when I have time, even after the story is finished.

I don't like certain progression milestones that have interrupted how I would have liked to play the story, but they are a tool of modern conventions and not a problem with the game, unlocks, linearity and AI limitations are certainly factors that time has set in stone. Theres still a lot to offer.

I intended to play the whole game on realistic settings but submitted to easy mode sprint and objective grab after the third mission. A decision I made myself but without a good set of tools to fit my play style one can only decide when there are no better options.

Still, thats just how games work these days, and when im showing future generations what grandad games looked like this will be one of the first i go to, even though there are better games out there in every regard.

Anyway, for a game about sniping there are far few testicles assasinated for my liking in my playthrough. The voice of your protaganist is the loudest noise in the game and can drown out gunfire, sad because it's the most generic example of american retro bravado, good you can turn it down but it's both the charecter that fits the most and the flattest impression in the game at the same time. Fitting really, that it doesn't fit me.

So in terms of playability and replayability the game stands out for being unremarkable in every what it HAS TO, and that make it stand out for every reason that it doesn't need to stand out already, as a game about stealth and options it has the right amount of hand holding and blunt force to succede.

Should you buy? Yes, I only reccomend it to anyone with some patience and a lot of standards to live by, only to be willing to let them slip. 

It's pretty remarkable in it's generics and I find that especially poetic if you couldn't tell already. There's character in it's lack of character for anyone with an eye for detail.

I might even consider going back for SE4, I tried 3 when it came out but hated the way it handled as a PC game, im not a console shooter type, this version NAILED the PC controls for those it matters to, but I can't say im in a rush to find out if 4 had things covered even if reviews came in positive about the general experience.

TL;DR, 5/5 review, perfectly imperfect. 

To address bad reviews, that's your fault for not knowing what you really want to play, you won't be happy with any more or less, me neither, the difference is I accept that.

The Axis Invasion is a neat concept that I hope they eventually put in a way to join your friends and not just a random game.

Overall I'd rank this game RIGHT NOW second, better than 2 but not as good as 4 YET.  Game's been out for 2 weeks and they just patched it the other day.  Rebellion is paying attention and I trust that by the end it'll be as good or better than SE4.
